description:
Came here for the fancy toasts. It was a great decision. The servers are sassy which is pretty funny - we came in a group of ~8 people, and we all ordered toasts. A lot of us ordered the peanut butter, honey, and banana toast, and after we ordered, the server said "uhh, you guys ordered the most time consuming toast to make, so y'all are going to have to wait for a while." It was pretty amusing. The toast was AMAZING though...I'll have to come back to try some of their other ones.

The interior is really tiny with a small counter (around 4 seats), but there's a large outdoor parklet area to sit and enjoy your coffee and toast. This is also right next to Outerlands so I'd imagine a bunch of people come here to order some coffee or a small bite while waiting in that ridiculous queue for brunch.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Really rude snarky staff. I've been here loads, living right around the corner. 

I love the coffee and the cinnamon toast however I feel compelled to write a negative review based on the experience of the horrible baristas. 
It never changes, every time I have been here, I get the same nasty vibes. Why!? Is it really that hard to share a smile and a hello, or general chit chat. I generally believe in greeting everyone with a smile and warm hello and usually I'm greeted with mutual warmth. Sadly not here. I'll still continue to come here for my coffee and cinnamon toast though, it's just a shame about the guys that work here. 

Update: A latte is not the same as a flat white. Still shitty staff who don't know their ass from their elbow.
author: Aoibheann M.

description:
I'm not sure I'm hip enough for this coffee spot, or should I call it an anti-coffee spot? I feel like I don't have enough mascara and pancake makeup to come up with my age-appropriate goth look. That's at least the vibe I got from this outpost toward the end of Judah in the Outer Sunset. It appeared to attract a cast of regulars as they looked pretty settled in their stools. I tried a $5 Cafe au Lait to take with me on my Ocean Beach stroll (photo: http://bit.ly/2SCpnZ7). It was pretty good though nothing all that memorable once I left the premises. More memorable were the life lessons scratched on their black boards (photo: http://bit.ly/2QhZ7Sc). Live fast. Die old. Yeah, I'll try to remember that.

COFFEE - 3 stars...it provided the warm fuel I needed
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...black is the new black
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...I don't remember, I'll split the difference here
TOTAL - 3 stars...why do I want to sing that song from "The Music Man"?..."Oh, ya got trouble, right here in River City!"

RELATED - Are you out in the Sunset? Here's a collection of places I've visited and reviewed: http://bit.ly/2JypfGg
author: Ed U.

description:
A coffee experience like no other, and not in a good way. 

I'm sure most of the people that come here are those who are waiting for a table at Outerlands to open up because I can not think of any other reason why anyone would be drawn here. Coffee is overpriced and meh and customer service is just downright horrible. 

The storefront itself is so small. They have a small counter with 4-ish stools for you to wait. Creamer and sugar is located outside of the store. There is 1 person working as a cashier, another as a barista and one other person making toast. 

The menu is literally a 8x11 in sheet of paper on a clipboard hung to the right (basically out of sight). There's also not much to chose from. Beware that the machiato and cortado are only available for dine in only. Be prepared for a wait though. The barista and toast maker work at a very slow pace. 

Customer service is by far the worst I have ever experienced. The cashier gave so much attitude and could not keep up with my order, I had to repeat it a couple times. He low-key scolded my friends and I for being on our phones in their "no phone zone", even though everyone else was on their phones too. I heard a customer ask what type of teas are available (reasonable question since there is no clear menu posted) to which the cashier replied: "we have a sh*t ton of teas here".

Another disappointment: I paid $4.75 for a basic, unflavored latte and it had the saddest latte art I've ever seen. The barista did not put any effort in it and did not look like some of the better work I've seen on other Yelp reviews. The toast is just okay, basically thick sliced bread covered in sugar, I could make it at home. 

But I guess bad customer service goes with their whole "thrash or die" theme. Safe to say, I will not be back.
author: Yennhu N.

description: This place is not for the faint of heart the coffee selection is great baked sweets are limited they also have pb&j's & sugar toast. The music is loud and seating inside is very limited most people hang out outside.
author: Samuel H.

description:
So you know: they have terrible chai. 

^ I would not get their chai here or at starbucks. I'll say it had some foam to it though, but it was just watered down, and it wasn't the artisanal I was expecting. 

-

But their peanut butter honey toast is good.

^ some lady took our order though.. so we ended up waiting..
author: Lilian L.

description: 99% of their customers come from people who are waiting to get seated at Outerlands. Coffee is mediocre and the toast tasted like it was made from someone who was high- OH WAIT IT WAS!! WELCOME TO SAN FRANCISCO. The aesthetic was confusing. I felt like I was inside a 200 square foot size Hot Topic with a coffee machine. As stated in previous reviews, the customer service is shit. But I'm pretty sure that was the theme they were going for- delinquent/low self esteem dick heads who probably suffered from childhood trauma and want to take out their anger to the world. Great job with branding. I'll be back next time I come to Outerlands but definitely wouldn't go out of my way to come here :)
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Welll the servers need to LEARN CUSTOMER service .
If I don't like the music and I shut my ears ...it's my choice ...but asking me why I come there if I don't like the music his NOT YOUR RIGHT BEHAVIOR.
It was my first and my last time there, how much ever I love Coffee ...This place will be my last option !!!!!
Happy Sunday
author: Abhilasha S.

description:
I was the only person in line, yet I waited for more than 20 minutes to get something I didn't order.
Coffee: I had better, much better! 
Costumer service: the worst. It's pathetic how sad and bitter the workers are there.

Do yourself a favor, save the trouble and walk two blocks down to beachside coffee or java beach cafe. Both have better coffee, price and service.
author: Alice S.

description:
I had built up the cinnamon toast in my head and the cinnamon toast was on a pedestal. I decided to go by Trouble Coffee for the first time today to get the toast($4). I realized it was not rocket science or a big deal after all. I asked for 2 toasts. I watched the guy at the register pop some white bread into a toaster right next to him. I watched him slather butter on the toast and sprinkle a bunch of cinnamon sugar on top. No brainer. I'll do it myself!

Also, this is an alternative/subculture coffee joint.
author: Denise C.

description: Coffee is good. Toast is good. Cool interior. Service may not always be the fastest, but staff have always been friendly, and gotten my order right. Yes, cell phone and computer use is frowned on, so if that sounds untenable to you, then maybe it's not your kind of place.
author: Garrett K.

description:
Coffee is unparalleled. But the staff is pretentious.
Coming here made me question my life decisions that led me to ordering coffee here, which I am sure would please the staff.
author: CM P.

description:
As with most trending hipster-y places with a cult following, I'm eh on this place. We came here needing to refuel after a long morning and a fun walk with baby and doggies. 

Location: Nice neighborhood with near other groceries and small shops (i.e. bookstore next door was very cute and a great place to wait for my order to come out). 

Order: 
Latte 
Double Espresso (came in a little clay tasse)
That legendary cinnamon toast (thick cut white bread with a generous layer of cinnamon sugar, a touch of vanilla, and drenched in butter. 

Pros: 
Latte was good but small.
The cinnamon toast was quite good but verrrrrrrry rich, even just for being 1 slice of bread. 
Outdoor area has some informal seating, great for being there with the doggos and stroller. 

Cons: 
Overpriced for average coffee and for literally a slice of bread with sugar on top ($5ish). I'm all for small businesses and unique places but this was a little over the top. Someone in charge here is a business genius. 
Cramped store especially near the entry / register, but fortunately they have some bench areas on the sidewalk.
author: Anita T.

description:
So I have been wanting to come here after reading how this business started and of course, the yelp reviews.  We ordered the peanut butter and jelly toast and cinnamon toast to go with our cafe lattes.  Like most coffee shops, it is rather small so we walked outside by the large tree and seating area to enjoy our snack.  Also I like that there is a book store next door.  

The coffee and toasts were a delight!  I like that the bread was thick and toasted to perfection.  While we were sipping on the lattes, I overheard the group next to us talking about the history of this coffee shop and the next thing I see is the owner getting off her bike next to us!

Immediately the owner picked up trash underneath bench.  You can tell the owner takes pride in her coffee shop.  Then I purchased a book next door and sat down on the bench next to the coffee shop.  The owner said "hi" to me while walking into her coffee shop.  When in San Francisco, I plan to make another visit !
author: Annie L.

description: 30 minutes for a latte??? I don't care how good your coffee is, 30 minutes for a latte is ridiculous!! They have a bunch of kids running the place. They don't use gloves or tongs to stock or remove pastries from the display platters. The long haired kid making the toast was coughing all in the toast, never covered his mouth. This place is absolutely disgusting!!! I wouldn't recommend this place at all!
author: Imran A.

description: Very nice staff but seemed a disaster otherwise. Drip coffee was burnt. Cinnamon toast wasn't anything to write home about. Checked it off the classic SF list but won't be back for seconds.
author: Morgan W.

description:
Hm. I entered & said hello but the cashier ignored me & kept speaking to her friends. I had a hard time looking for the menu. It's to the right & incredibly small. Stood right in front of the cashier & she just kept talking to her friends as she looked at me.  She acted the same way with the customers after me.

I ordered a mocha & the texture was so gritty. Didn't have a chocolate taste either.  It's a cute place if you care about Instagram though. Just don't expect fantastic service.
author: Jenni D.

description:
Cinnamon Toast & a Coconut- #42 on the 2015 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

I stopped by Trouble to check out their coffee and cinnamon toast, and wasn't disappointed! There was a short line early on a Saturday morning, but it moved quickly, and everything was ready in less than 10 minutes. I tried:

-Soy Latte (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=EhTRJapb5IyVDS_gYYYdqg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Solid soy latte, and the coffee was great quality. 
-Cinnamon Toast (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=uf45HtO-ON2Uid1d8-u3Yw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- super crispy and buttery. It tastes a lot like a life sized version of the cinnamon toast crunch cereal. 

Now I need to come back for the coconut at some point, but I'll be back for more coffee and cinnamon toast as well! Parking in this area is extremely difficult, and there isn't much street parking to be found.
author: Amy D.

description: This is my favorite of their coffee shops, it might be due to: the good music playing here, it's really cozy and I need to warm up from my bike rude, and the mocha was delicious.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
Bookmarked Trouble as soon as I saw the name, the location was an added bonus.  A few friends and I decided to have a beach morning so we stopped by Trouble Coffee. Here is what we tried:
-vanilla latte w/almond milk: good strong flavor
-iced coffee: smooth strong flavor
-cinnamon toast: one big piece of toast topped with copious amounts of sugar and cinnamon, absolute perfection
-banana and PB toast: yummy, again generous slices
Everything tasted great, service was super happy and friendly as well. There is a tiny bar area and about 4 stools inside, but out outside there is this fun wooden seating area with plenty of room and fun little succulents to look at too. A great place to get solid coffee and hang out with friends enjoying the many types of SF weather.
author: Angela D.

description:
SIGH. I love this place. Like out of all of the coffee places in city, this one wins my heart because it's got this grungy punky vibe to it doused in caffeine and that's me in a nutshell. 

Trouble has garnered quite a bit of following recently so it's usually VERY busy. Like ridiculously. But the main reason why I'd say this is one of my favorites, if not THE FAVORITE, is because it's not overly pretentious like some of the other hipster coffee shops. It's a tiny little coffee shop and the coffee is straightforward. It's not the best, it's not the worst. But it's quick and no frills kinda coffee. It's cool and i dunno, I just like the whole punk vibe of it. Parking is decent in the area, because Sunset ya know. It's VERY small. I repeat VERY SMALL. Do not expect to come here and sit at a table to work for 5 hours. Not gonna happen bud. Come here, grab a cup of coffee, try that famed cinnamon toast (or the peanut butter honey toast, which I prefer more), pay an arm & a leg for coffee (bc this is SF and this is what we do now), and take a walk down the street to the beach. It's walking distance to Ocean Beach and what better way to enjoy your cup of joe than with some salty ocean air and a view like no other?!?!? Seriously, what are you doing? Just get some coffee here, eat the toast, and take a walk. ENJOY LIFE. ENJOY COFFEE. EVERYTHING IS GREAT W/ CAFFEINE. 

I love trouble.
author: Amy T.

description:
It really is A-ok. I mean, yes, they have above average coffee.  And the Toast is good - definitely better than toast at a diner, but it only gets 3-stars because it just doesn't live up to the hype.  

For somewhere that pretty much created "Toast" it really isn't very innovative. It's good bread, with simple toppings.

The coffee is strong, but they don't do any decaf....

And it's always busy...

So really there is nothing wrong with it, but it just doesn't live up to the reputation - and that's important.
author: Sarah C.

description:
So refreshing to have a spot that is no bs.  Blasting hardcore punk/punk rock of gut wrenching screams laid to the catchiest back beats you can't help but stomp your foot too, sipping some incredible java, and taking in the ocean breeze and beach views. No gimmicks real people expressing their true selves with java to boot!

Here's a thought to a review I recently saw, know what you are getting into. If you are coming to a place that is likely anti-establishment chilling in the entry on your iphone the whole time taking IG's wearing your Patagonia fleece not enjoying the environment or taking a moment to enjoy what environment this establishment is setting or what is stands for might get you a few looks and "rude" comments.. Think about the other side, ignore what stage they are setting and coming into their home.  

Trouble keep on keepin' on we need a hole lot more anti-establishment in this day in age!
author: Morgan S.

description: Very poor customer service. Went in there between work meeting with the intent to enjoy my latte while I respond to a few emails. Worker comes up to me and says, "Sorry to tell you this but you have to put away your computer. Our owner doesn't want people to be on their computers." And follows up with, "She's on her way in so I'm saving you the trouble of hearing it from her." I told him, "I'd like to meet this owner who doesn't believe the costumer is always right." Then I ordered a bag of coffee beans for my co-worker (he suggested the place). And the whole time I'm getting attitude from the barista, hands me the bag and in a snotty voice, "You enjoy that." I packed up my stuff and didn't even finish my latte. What a shame.
author: James L.

description: Cozy little coffee joint with a cool history. There's a cool public parklet outside the shop that's a great alternative to the limited seating inside. No gluten-free toast (part of the hype here) but they often have GF bakery items as an option. And you can drink out of a coconut. That's pretty cool! They get really slammed on the weekends but they have really cool specialty drinks (both coffee and tea). It's a little overwhelming if you're not a local or a regular but definitely a cool place to check out if you're in the outer sunset!
author: Sarah N.

description:
Meh. What can I say, that it's better than Starbucks? Maybe. Baristas appeared stoned.

Who puts a spazz sticker on a la Marzocco machine, spazz = la spaziale, another Italian espresso machine manufacturer

My latte was bitter and astringent. Not good.
author: B. M.

description: Best coffee to date on my recent 3 week stay in the US. I always struggle to find a good coffee. Thank you for the caffeine hit I'd be longing for.We ordered a take out coffee & enjoyed drinking it out front of the premises on some upcycled wooden seating. Must say I liked the packaging as well. Seemed like a very busy pocket of shops. Great book shop next door as well.
author: Lyndal G.

description:
I am one of the many who discovered Trouble Coffee while waiting for a seat at Outerlands. I am one of many who walked in and groaned at the price of the toast here, but bought some anyways. What I wasn't, was someone who at the time, understood what this little coffee shop represents, and the story of the woman behind it. 

Give this article a read for a little... perspective to go with your coffee:
https://psmag.com/social-justice/toast-story-latest-artisanal-food-craze-72676
author: Patricia K.

description: Very chill place to have coffee and the best warm cinnamon toast. Super friendly staff. I'd highly recommend a Cafe Mocha. Also, the backstory behind the creation of this coffee house is a very interesting human experience.
author: Seth S.

description: Giulietta's amazing, her story is incredible, and the product is superb!  Do you go for the coffee? the coconut? or the delicious toasts?  Try them all... why not.  This spot just also fits the vibe of the Outer Sunset in San Francisco, and can easily walk to Ocean Beach.
author: Jon R.

description:
This place has terrible customer service. I walked in on a Sunday morning looking for something to order but not a menu to be found anywhere in sight. I approached one of the associates and had to repeat myself to him multiple times because of the very loud music playing. The workers here were very rude when I tried to order Matcha tea latte which they didn't serve but I would've have never known that because there wasn't a menu for reference. 

Anyhow, I'd would walk a couple more blocks down the street and head to Java Beach House Cafe for better service.
author: philip s.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon with le bf after walking around the neighborhood. Le bf wanted to come because he had heard about the cinnamon sugar toast. 

We decided to share:
1. A latte ($4) 
2. Cinnamon sugar toast ($4)

PSA: They don't decaf coffee here.

The latte was kind of small for the price, but it did taste good. It was strong, but it tasted smooth. None of that super acidic taste. I normally put sugar in my latte, but I didn't feel like I needed to for this one. After taking a bite of the cinnamon sugar toast, I knew I would come back for more. You get a single thick slice of bread covered in butter, sugar and cinnamon. What is not to like about that? 

Though pricey for the portion you get, the coffee and toast all tasted good. The music was a tad loud if you sat inside. There is a nice area to sit outside if the weather allows. I think we will be back if we are in the area.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: Welcome to the kingdom of hipsterism. This place will condescend your drink orders while making you wait thirty minutes (at least) for their confectionery. It's all a sham propagated by the corny faux punk rock owner gaining her only credibility by how "punk she is". Seriously this spot is a joke. Don't let the line out front fool you.
author: Barney S.

description:
I've been here twice now and while the place is cute, the logo is the coolest, and the baristas are nice, waiting 27 minutes (7 in line and 20 once we'd ordered) for 2 cappuccinos is pretty nuts. 

We'd originally come here to get a coffee while waiting for the 9 tables on the Outerlands waitlist to be sat, but the coffee at Trouble took so long (and there's no room to wait inside) that I actually got sat at Outerlands a good 5 minutes before the coffees were ready and I think it took less time to get our order placed and food at our table there, than it did to get those drink from Trouble. 

I want to love the place but have a hard time reconciling a caffeine fix that takes almost 30-minutes. Not exactly worth the trouble.
author: Candice G.

description: Truly embarrassed that such a small little place in the neighborhood I grew up and lived in all my life could be housed with so many holier-than-thou, impudent "employees". It's no wonder yall are driving all the real locals far away from here... I've passed through small towns in the Dirty South and yet still have never been treated as rude and condescendingly as I have at Trouble. Please do us all a favor and leave the Sunset.
author: Jen C.

description:
What you need to know: 
- this tiny coffee shop is my favorite place to get serious coffee in SF
- there is a parklet right outside to sit or the beach is steps away 
** INSIDER TIP - buy their 1 pound of coffee $14 and get a free cup of coffee! 
- accepts credit cards 

What I always get:
- Elbow Grease coffee - as I always like to say: I like my coffee the way I like my women - strong, yet smooth!!! There is no acidity, just smooth and intense coffee. A pure joy to drink!
author: Karen L.

description:
Another coffee shop run by rude and pretentious people who think they are more important that they really are. 
You're selling coffee.. for goodness sakes. Get over yourself!
author: Sani Y.

description:
Stopped by here several times, a couple times to kill time waiting for the brunch place nearby.

Hole in the wall. Hipster ambiance. Limited seating.

*THEY DO NOT HAVE A MENU UP* The customer is suppose to know what to order already. First time I came here I asked "Where's the menu?" and the cashier answered "what do you want?" With a rude smug voice trying to imply I was dumb for asking for their menu. TIP do not ask for a menu or they will belittle you. The whole transaction the guy was treating me like I was dumb or a noob. Customer service lacks alot. Very rude! Horrible

Drink was good however. Ordered a latte and it was delicious. However I would not return here because the customer service stinks and they have a "i'm better than you" attitude, which is not a place I would like to visit when I just want a drink.
author: Michele G.

description: We happened upon this cafe while taking a tour of the Sunset District with some friends. They said we had to come for the toast. We approached and the line was out the door. Said my husband, "Well at least we know the hipsters like it" haha! He was right. It is a very hip spot with very few places to sit or stand inside and a few benches outside. While the coffee was just okay, the toast was legitimately amazing. We tried the cinnamon toast and the avocado toast to make sure we tried both sweet and salty. Mine was better and I think it might have been the best avocado toast I've ever had. The slice of bread was thick and eggy, buttered, slathered in ripe avocado, and sprinkled with salt and everything bagel topping. I didn't even want to let him take a bite. The bookstore next door is charming too and has an outdoor place to sit if you check out the back patio. Our only detractor was the customer service, but we stepped outside for a glimpse of the ocean so it didn't much matter.
author: Kara T.

description:
Beautiful coffee and toast. Bionic man barista and friend, we love what you make, but not how you treat your customers. 
Kind words do not cost much. Yet they accomplish much.
author: M M.

description:
As others have mentioned on here, it does have a hipster ambiance and the place is also rather small. The barista seemed very nice to me and my friend (I didn't really get that negative experience some others have commented... maybe we just came at an unbusy time?) 

While here, my friend got the 'dealer's choice'; he said it was very good overall. Strong but not burnt tasting. I don't recall what the actual order was, it was more of something the barista chose since it was our first time here.

I ended up getting hot green tea and I thought that was good. We had a good experience overall and would come back, next time we're in the Sunset.
author: Joseph Y.

description:
This is the best coffee nook in San Francisco, bar none.

Their drip coffee is as rich and good as most decent places lattes, and their lattes are stellar.
author: Ben R.

description:
I was a regular for 6 months, but finally decided to take my business elsewhere. The coffee is good, the toast is tasty, but the service is pretentious and even rude. From my wife getting scolded for looking at her phone, to the eye roll when asking for more butter, to a yell from across place when I got too close to the old map on the wall. 

I get that you're trying to retain some locals-only hipster vibe, but for a lot of us, waiting 30 mins for a cup of joe and a piece of toast is a big ask, especially when you act like you're annoyed to have us as customers.
author: Parkin K.

description:
Came here specifically to try the artisan toasts to see what the hype is all about. The toasts are AMAZING! I had the peanut butter and jelly and the cinnamon toasts. The toasts were big,  fluffy and so soft. The peanut butter was creamy and cinnamon was just perfect, not too sweet.

The place is tiny.  Literally there's only room to order and that's it. There are 3 bar seats,but it's so crammed there, sitting inside is uncomfortable.

Outside has a cute, hipster tree log decor that could be used for seating.

I had a regular hot coffee which was goood. Also tried the girlfriend drink with almond milk. Didn't like it too much because they substituted it with almond by request so can't blame them for that. 

Overall, place is very hipster....good toasts, good coffee...I'd definitely be back!
author: Caitlin P.

description:
Synopsis: Don't even bother. Terrible customer service. Astoundingly pretentious attitude to the point of it being a comedy sketch. Mission hipster attitude transported to the Outer Sunset. Seriously, Fred Armisen could do a Portlandia sketch about this place and not even have to exaggerate.

Read other reviews. I am not alone. This place is a joke.
author: Daniel G.

description: Good coffee really bad attitude, bad experience- not worth it... will go next time to other coffee place..  I'm also a punk/heavy rock liver, but it doesn't mean I have to be pretentious and rude:)
author: Anat S.

description: Cool place. Need to speak with owner. Just heard good things about her. Mostly interested in people that run businesses like they care about sf & the homeless. I got that vibe from her. Also, the mocha was good. I'll be back. You should too.
author: Asif H.

description: A great small coffee shop, home of the original SF $4 toast this place is a favorite stop when I'm heading to ocean beach or nearby. The coffee selection and quality are excellent and the service is always spot on. If you want a nice treat with your coffee/chai/yea I definitely recommend the toast. Why is the toast good? Well first off they use thick slices of bread and have generous toppings on them. I personally love the original cinnamon and sugar but the peanut butter and honey also is pretty damn good.
author: Peter P.

description:
I really loved the coffee from this shop, it was smooth and didn't taste burnt. They are a classic coffee shop so don't expect anything larger than 12 oz, and for a latte probably 6 oz. 

I did get the pb & honey toast which was good but in my opinion much to much PB. I had to wipe a bit off, it was overwhelming and stuck to my mouth. It also somehow had butter in one area?

My friend had the cinnamon sugar toast and thought it was amazing! 

Very small spot, so try and make it a stop and go. Or sit out by the "tree bench" if it's nice out.
author: Samantha R.

description: This coffee shop is...amazing. Their coffee is delicious and rich and they have many things on their menu. I've also tried their cinnamon toast and it is seriously out of this world. Their bread is so thick yet so soft and buttery. I watched how they made it and it appears that they poke holes in the bread once it's done being toasted so when they apply the butter and cinnamon, it seeps into every crevice so you get a very rich and flavorful experience. It is slightly pricey but totally worth it. Love the atmosphere and the vibes I get from here and it is one of the best coffee shops i've been to.
author: Izzy M.

description:
I was looking forward to trying Trouble after a glowing review from my aunt. My sister used to live right off Irving so we were able to locate it pretty quickly. There was a line out the door when we drove by and we parked Just down the street. The line was still out the door when we arrived, but we learned it was more so because the place is so tiny there is not much room from the counter to the door. The wait to order was only about 5 minutes. We ordered a chai latte with almond milk, a coconut, cinnamon toast, and peanut butter honey toast. The coconut was served almost immediately. The wait time was almost 10 minutes for our toast. I had my kids with me and the baristas were impatient with me as I tried to collect my toast, which I thought was rude and completely unnecessary given that there were no customers waiting to order at that point. We were also told that they needed to close the shop because it was shift change and they needed to mop the floors. While I was not expecting to hang out inside, I was still waiting for my chai latte! They told me they would bring it out to me and quickly shooed us outside. I felt like the toast was kind of a letdown. My aunt told me that when she had the toast, the toppings were swirled into the bread, like the knife cut into the bread so that the toppings melted down into the toast. We were served a thick slice of bread, which tasted like Safeway French bread, and not "artisanal" bread as other Yelpers have described. The bread was not very toasted at all and was white on the bottom, which made it too flimsy to pick up and take bites, so we just tore pieces off to eat. Since the bread was not very well toasted, the butter didn't really melt into the bread and it was pretty dry with all the cinnamon sugar piled on top. I really liked the peanut butter and honey toast. The peanut butter was all natural and very creamy, and the honey was delicious! 

It ended up taking 26 minutes for my chai latte to be ready! The chai tea is freshly brewed, which accounts for some of delay, but it's unreasonable to have to wait that long, especially since I was eating toast slathered with peanut butter! I also thought it was odd that they left the huge tea bag in the cup given that it had already been steeping for so long. The flavor was delicious, the chai was nice and spicy and not too sweet.

Would I return? No.
author: Melanie E.

description: Workers especially the guy with the dislocated shoulder were incredibly rude and mean. The drip coffee and earl grey was nothing special except the skater bro entitled hipster culture from upper middle class, rich parents makes this place more suited for trust fund babies and pretentious insecure faux hipsters to gather here.
author: Barry A.

description: I once got a coconut here / they cracked it open, gave me a straw, and I left feeling like the coolest dang hippie headed to the beach with my "casual" coconut water. Gotta check this place out if you are in the hood.
author: Megan C.

description: I never thought that after high school I would encounter another place where they banned cell phones besides something like a planetarium. Yeah they can have whatever policy they want but I can also buy whatever subpar coffee I want without being treated with disrespect. I was only checking the time and I was told to leave immediately.
author: Ellie R.

description: I can't tell if the bad taste in my mouth is from the overly roasted/brewed "French roast" or the poor treatment from the owner. Don't let the fake self-aggrandizement fool you. She is a monster!
author: Bai B.

description: the coffee was decent, but not phenomenal. not bad pastry. i got kind of rude service, which at first i attributed to the time of day (early), but when i talked to a friend about it, she had had the same experience.
author: Mari N.

description:
Stuff is good, service is SH*T
They definitely don't care about you as a customer, but they love your money. Enjoy yourself some tasty treats and rude service.
author: Hassan K.

description: Apparently you have to ask for permission to take a photograph here because the hipster nose ring wearing female barista who I don't even care to remember her name gave me a full out lecture for taking a photograph in this coffee shop without asking her first. Funny, considering yelp is full of photographs from this place. I will never buy anything from this coffee shop or go here again, there are too many other good places in the city (reveille, sightglass, the mill, blue bottle, saint frank etc) that have friendlier staff. Totally put off. DO NOT GIVE THEM BUSINESS, thanks.
author: Danny T.

description:
Serious hipster vibe aside, there's not a whole lot to rave about this place.

The coffee is reasonably good, and the toast isn't bad, although a bit spendy, so overall it's a pretty decent choice for both. There's only a counter inside and some benches outside, so get your stuff to go. On that note, it is conveniently located at the end of the N-Judah line for your commute coffee fix, and the coffee and/or the toast are some nice warm treats to have in hand if you're heading to Ocean Beach.

Not mindblowing, but not bad either.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Because of it's clear popularity, this probably isn't the spot to grab a cup of coffee if you're in a hurry.  That said, the vibe is spot-on for a coffee shop: hip and cool without the pretentiousness you'd get from similar places in the Valencia corridor on the other side of town.  My latte was unexpectedly one of the best I've had in the city, made the ~25 minute wait on a very busy Saturday morning more than excusable.

Pro-tip: their vanilla flavoring is alcohol-based rather than a syrup, which makes their vanilla latte taste much more refined.
author: Derrick D.

description:
Recently went here before sunrise surf session and waited all of 3 minutes before they opened and there was already a line and full of people! Wow, Trouble has come a long way since I first tried their amazine toast and coffee back when they opened and I lived on that street...I remember back then being happy and loving the yummy toast and strong coffee...I also love grapefruit juice so thanks for the simple menu. 

Being a person who doesnt' drink alcohol anymore, coffee is my new drug of choice and coffee shops are like bars to me in a way...if you look at it this way, this place rules and fucking yes, tip your baristas people. Theres a cool and unique aesthetic that works here and I'm happy to see the old sort of unique vibe of San Francisco is still somewhat alive here, I love hearing that people get scolded for taking photos...it's a teeny coffee shop and just be in the moment assholes, 

Trouble Coffee please don't change! I love youuuuu
author: Kimberly H.

description:
What a gem of a place. My friend recommended coming here while we waited to be seated at Outerlands and wow did we thank her later. The coffee was awesome and the cinnamon toast  was the most perfect/amazing appetizer for a few hungry gals before brunch. Seriously delicious.

It was very busy and a very small coffee shop so we waited a little for our coffee/toast but it was definitely worth the wait!
author: Ilana B.

description:
I have told stories around the fire about this legendary toast from Trouble cafe. A single piece of bread, perfectly toasted, freshly warm, and smothered in butter, cinnamon, and sugar is essentially a slice of heaven. I literally drive all the way out here just to get a slice of toast. It sounds ridiculous but you have to try it for yourself to know just how good it is.

Their cafe has a warm, intimate, and stylish vibe and their staff are super friendly and welcoming. They're also only a few blocks from the ocean!

Pair the toast with a hot chocolate and a oceanside stroll and it is pure bliss. You can also enjoy it in the cute outdoor seating area right outside the cafe.
author: Jacqui C.

description:
This is a horrible location and a pretty terrible place to go to. I thought the cafe at Oakland had bad service but this place here is even worse. The staff gets all the orders wrong and the small venue is cramped and not a good environment. The music is noisy and they don't allow computers here. What kind of places forces you to leave if you want to study and get some work done on your laptop? I'd be more ok with it if the staff weren't so rude about it. I'm very disappointed.

I did enjoy the peanut butter and honey toast they serve at Trouble Coffee locations but this experience ruined it for me. Moreover, $4.50 is quite overpriced for a piece of toast with peanut butter and it's even less worth it with bad service and bad ambience.
author: Catherine S.

description: Paid $5 for a lavender/honey latte. It was just okay. A bit too sweet.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
"Big Tim, the human piece of toast." -- Jurassic Park (1993)

This may seem like an odd review, but their coffee is only so-so. I'm sure you are thinking "then why the heck is she giving them 5 stars?!"  Let me tell you something... They know what the heck they are doing when it comes to toast. Yes, I said toast.

Ben G told me I had to come here and get a slice of cinnamon toast. I don't question Ben when it comes to all things bread (if you know him, you understand). So I made the drive and walked in to this little pocket of a coffee shop and ordered a slice of toast and a medium coffee. 

As I watched, they sliced off 1/6 of the prettiest Pullman loaf of bread. I watched as butter was slathered and sugar and cinnamon were coated on world's largest slice of bread. As it baked, the perfume of snickerdoodles filled this tiny shop and my stomach started to roar with hunger.

They handed me the golden bread shaped idol and my cuppa Joe and off I went. A small station of cream and sugar was set up at the edge of the shop and I doctored my coffee and was on my way. I was sold at first crunch into the most succulent piece of bread and I was returned to my childhood and I have been aching to go back there ever since.

Toast + waves crashing = bliss

I'd eat there every day if I lived nearby. Damn, now I need a slice.
author: Lindy F.

description: I really don't get the cinnamon toast. Hipsters who think $4 piece of toast with butter and cinnamon on it is so amazing, please tell me why?
author: Karen T.

description:
I had trouble coffee on my list of places to check out in SF for a good 3 months.  Saturday morning rolls around, goin' for it...

Enter the place with my roommate- first thing the cashier says "no pictures.  Don't take pictures of me. Delete it. No pictures."

Thinking he was kidding, I laughed.   To then realize he was serious. #getoveryourselfdude 

The food was awesome. Drinks were great. The people that work here look like they all want to kill themselves.  I didn't even know there were still places in SF that could be run so horribly. 

Get new employees.  Keep the toast.
author: Rachel U.

description: I was in the middle of pouring creamer into the two coffees that I purchased from Trouble when the lid flopped off and fell into my cup. I went in to talk to the cashier and was standing next to him and was waiting (two feet away) for 4 minutes until he turned around and asked what I needed. When I asked him if I could get a new cup of coffee since the creamer lid fell in, he said nothing and angrily poured out the coffee into the drain and threw the cup into the trash can, and gave me another one without saying a single word. +1 for decent coffee.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Great place to absorb the neighborhood vibe of the Outer Sunset, walking distance to Ocean Beach with cinnamon toast in hand and maybe a new read from next-door Blackbird Bookstore (very well curated selection and great kids' section). I visit from Sausalito to soak in the progressive and laid-back atmosphere as well as the caffeine. 

Was pleased to meet owner Giulietta who chatted up my 4.5 year old while her kids waited patiently to hit the beach.

Expect a line on weekend mornings and to put down your electronic device when ordering. Baristos may also be students who also work at the tattoo shop 2 doors up the block, or not.

Fantastic place to recharge and connect with your neighbors, if you live in the 'hood. Otherwise, fantastic place to people watch and feel the community.
author: Monica M.

description:
Places like these have no place in San Francisco.  Ordered 2 drink and a toast and the cashier said
 "you gonna tip or what?"
I've never had a place ever ask for tip let alone give me shit for it.  I'm never coming back.  Coffee is just sub par and $4 for a piece of bread is absurd.  I'm glad they are closing at Bay View.  Now just get the hell out of SF.
author: Bart W.

description: Trouble , u r trouble. Very rude people behind the counter. If it weren't for that , i'd praise the coffee and toast.
author: Wendy V.

description:
I didn't come here for the toast, but I did have a pastry and cold brew. I loved the coffee because it wasn't acidic at all and super smooth. I didn't get to try the toast, but it seemed like everyone in line was there for it. They're huge slabs of bread - definitely filling, even though I don't know if it's worth $4-5. 

It's in a cool and hip area in the Outer Sunset. I came here after a bike ride along the Great Highway, and it was a great pick-me-up. The baristas are also nice and patient even though the line is always out the door since it's so popular!
author: Steph V.

description: Don't even bother with this place their soul is as dark as their coffee. STAY FAR AWAY!!!
author: Merray A.

description: Family in town and went to Lands End and headed to the Sunset for lunch and ran into Trouble by chance a few doors down. Cappuccino was great but the best bit was buying the Elbow Grease coffee beans... probably the best c0ffee I've tasted for a while....go get some coffee and take beans away with you
author: Bob B.

description:
I don't quite understand why some people seem outraged over the fact that their toast is just toast. I mean there's only a couple ways to dress up toast. It's toast, what do you expect?

There are also a couple arguments that this place is too hipster for average people. Well, I mean I'm pretty much an average dude, and I didn't feel like some sort of an awkward outcast. It's a coffee shop for Christ's sake. How ostracized could anybody make anybody feel?

Really, the last argument I want to address is people's remarks about food & beverages being overpriced. I actually don't think it's that bad. Let's keep in mind that we are talking about a business that is located in San Francisco, literally a stone's throw from the beach. Prices are bound to reflect that geographical location. 

I mean, I don't know, people seem to be REALLY upset that the coffee is just coffee, the toast is just toast. In reality, this is just a fun coffee shop that serves extremely thick pieces of fresh baked toasted bread. The cinnamon and sugar with butter tastes like cinnamon sugar with butter, and the toast with peanut butter and honey taste like toast with peanut butter and honey. There's no way around it.

 The excitement  of this coffee bar is driven by novelty. I mean it's delicious and everything, but you get almost exactly what you expect. The same applies with the coconut. It's fun, it's delicious, and it's really silly, but it's just a coconut.

Their prices are average, perhaps the toast is a little on the pricey side, but again, it's not like they're forcing anybody to buy anything. 

I think this place is great, it's just kind of fun.
author: Dave K.

description:
I had the BEST hot cocoa I have ever had here. 

I had a hot cocoa with almond milk and fresh whipped cream (I know that seems like an total contradiction to mix dairy milk and almond milk but oh well )

it was so freakin good. totally creamy and the fresh (I assume house made) whipped cream was like BUTTER - it was so dense yet light like a cloud of heaven on my perfectly dark chocolatey perfectly less insanely sweet cocoa.  

I WILL BE BACK. 
thank you for hot cocoa heaven.
author: Win H.

description: I visited San Francisco a year ago and discovered this amazing spot. Before coming back, this was the first place I wanted to go to have the best butter and cinnamon toast ever. The service is very good, they are very friendly and welcoming. Highly recommended!
author: Juanita J.

description:
Been coming here for a number of years now. Maybe once a month or so since I live near nopa and it's kind of a trek.

The reviews about the service recently are pretty accurate. I feel like the place got super popular with the "toast boom" and their feature story, then for some reason the staff thought they could act like a-holes. Recently I feel like I am treated differently when I come in, especially if I'm on my way to work and dressed business casual. Seems to not be the blue collar vibe they are friendly with.

To be fair, I think that problem is due to a few bad employees. The lady who manages (owns?) the shop has always been super cool and really nice.  Also to those who complain about not being able to work on their laptop in there - are you f'n kidding me? look at the place this isn't starbucks/peet's. Grab your drink, chill in the parklet, walk to the beach. Tune in to what the vibe is here - don't make it match your expectations of middle america coffee that you are used to.

Also, The Mill is not better than this place. The waits are even longer there, and they are way more expensive.

Lastly. I like their Chai, it's spicy and unsweetened like it should be. (See my comment earlier about how this is not a middle-america freeway exit coffee shop).

Oh, and who the fuck else serves you a whole coconut? No one.
author: Ross H.

description: Great coffee and great hipster toast, but this place has shit service. They call out the food orders on a first come first serve basis that usually leads to having to argue with some white techie named Becky or some shit.
author: Carver F.

description:
When I first listened to the This American Life episode on the origins of the toast trend in San Francisco 4 years ago, I knew I had to visit this cafe. But then Outer Sunset always felt too far to travel for coffee and toast. After today's Ocean beach bike ride, this cafe popped up as nearby on Yelp, so this was my chance to finally try it out

I had the peanut butter and honey toast. It was amazing and definitely lived up to my expectations!! Thick, warm bread with melting peanut butter and dripping honey are the perfect mid-day snack. Be sure to check out the decorations too!
author: Jenny K.

description:
Just a few nights ago at a friend of mine's bday in Cole Valley, a few people complained about being invisible. You know, when you hit a certain milestone age, you just don't seem to matter, or be noticed anymore anywhere. But that's the beauty of it. I like being invisible, so that no one pays attention to you, so that YOU can observe. This is a good place to observe hipsters sporting facial hair here. Grab a seat outside, and count how many men are wearing a beard of some sort, 10 out of 10. It's infested with hipsters with facial hair, and robust looking young female companions, with one or two occasional joggers in their stretching positions while sipping a coffee.

My companion ordered us two lattes. They were served like European sized cappuccinos, smaller but as they ought to be. They make them with patterns that you now see in most boutique coffee shops. He gave me the heart shaped one and he kept the flower one. I swapped it hastily. "Keep your heart. I like my flowers." I took a sip to mark my territory with my rouge lipsticks on the rim of the paper cup. Their espresso drinks is very very good. Their outdoor waiting area, reminds me so much of Omotesando Koffee in Omotesando district near the fashion district of Tokyo. Please, someone must know what I'm talking about, and that was pretty much what I had thought the moment I stepped into that small coffee shop. It is quirky and pretty, if they didn't have the heavy metal music, I'd think I was in Japan.

Really great espresso drinks. People watching is fantastic. Like you are in an episode of Portlandia. Chat with your friends about your coffee drinking experience in Japan and how that drift wood reminds you of the decor in Omotesando Koffee. Stay invisible. Near the end of N Judah line. Take a bite of that cookie so dense that you know one bite will do you in.

But don't stop here, keep on walking. You have an entire ocean in front of you.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Living in Cole Valley I like to make my way out to Trouble from time to time and it's always worth it. They only have a few things on the menu, but they do them really well - coffee, specialty toast, and fresh coconuts. My absolute favorite is the cinnamon sugar toast. They use deliciously soft, fluffy bread (I think it's Acme's Pan de Mie) dripping with butter with a generous helping of cinnamon sugar covering it all. But, I've also had the peanut butter honey which is delicious as well.

I never expect to get a seat inside because it's very small, so I try to go on nice days. They have a large outdoor seating area that's especially pleasant when the sun is shining. I reccomend hitting Ocean Beach for a walk before or after your stop.

TIP: This isn't a coffee shop where you could sit and work on your laptop.
author: Allie E.

description:
Texts to the bf while waiting in line...

"Hey baby! It's good - Just waiting. Smells delicious!"

"Wait. They're burning ALL the toast!"

"The place smells like...burned toast. Literally. Ha! *Trying to stay positive here*" 

"No...I wasn't ready. This guy is scrapping the burned top off! Not sure how good they actually are..."

"They seem slow and lost LOL"

"OK...This is taking forever."

"Yeah they're surfer bros...More like...Bro surf my coffee up tho. Why you cracking so many jokes and not delivering coffee?"

So...burnt toast. Good coffee. Terrible service. Non existent parking.

Thumbs down.
author: Charo F.

description:
Oh Trouble. I knew you were trouble when I walked in...

After visiting The Mill, I have unfortunately acquired a taste for expensive toast, which prompted me to check out Trouble. According to the NPR story, Trouble is purportedly the OG of SF's artisanal toast trend. (Though I can't help thinking, didn't thick toast originate in Asia?!)

Trouble is a tiny space that gets crowded even on weekday mornings. They have one paper copy of the menu, no website, and little seating besides logs outside and minimal counter space inside, because anything more would be too mainstream. In fact, they apparently shun technology with a grumpy no-pictures rule; I took care to take my food pics in secret so as not to get chastised. I managed to get multiple pictures in multiple settings with multiple angles including cross-sections :)

I got the PEANUT BUTTER HONEY LAVENDER TOAST ($4) because the cinnamon one sounded too sugary. The design of the honey drizzle compared to latte art, and the toast itself was scrumptious: the peanut butter went unexpectedly well with the honey, and the subtle hint of floral lavender added a nice overtone. However the quality definitely fell short in comparison to the in-house craft bread at The Mill, where you could really taste the freshness, the baking expertise, and the thought put into the creation of each bread. I also noticed that the bottom side of the toast was quite burnt. 

The ICED COFFEE ($4) was not bad, and there was even soy milk at the bar. It came in a neat stamped cup branded with Trouble, but the portion size was very Troubling, approximately a Starbucks short. 

There were a number of kinks: the cashier who handles (cash-only) payment also prepares the toast; instead of real napkins they only have paper towels (the coarse ones that you usually find in the bathroom for wiping hands); the milk and sugar shelf is so tiny that you run into Trouble trying to juggle toast while adding milk to your coffee.

After reading some reviews about their hipster attitude, I braced myself for abrasive criticisms when I asked for a straw for my iced coffee. It turned out thoroughly amused when the barista made a clever pun and announced the request as "the last straw". 

I feel bad giving 2 stars despite their punniness, the originality of the store as a whole (including the notable Trouble etch-a-sketch decor), and the owner's NPR story which is indeed quite amazing. But at the end of the day everything still overpriced, especially with respect to The Mill where there's better (and non-burnt) toast, better coffee, a far more spacious and nicer interior, and I actually end up paying less. I guess irony is, after all, part of hipster culture :3
author: Edna C.

description:
After reading all of the mixed reviews, I feel compelled to hand off five stars because it's damn good and it's my aunt's favorite place on the planet (probably because she won't clean her own damn house). 

Yes. The toast is overpriced. But they created the toast, so I give them props. And for goodness sake, they clearly aren't having an issue finding people to pay for it, so why whine about it? 

I had a great experience with the dudes behind the counter. Sort of. Since my aunt knew them and all. The latte I had, I will bitch, was incredibly small. Not a Starbucks tall... Like the short kid size small. Damn. It was really really good though. And sounds like the espresso drinks are the way to go... Apparently the coffee is hit or miss. 

And for goodness sake, I'm sure the owner had to work really damn hard to get that parklet... So maybe whining about the tree seating isn't necessary. It's cool! Kids love it! They get to feel like they're climbing trees... Okay, I loved it. It's true. 

Cinnamon toast? Boom. Warm bread underneath, crispy cinnamon sugar butter on top... That's the way to go. I might shy away from the hipsters on my own, but I thought trouble was top notch.
author: Tina S.

description:
The absolute WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE I've ever experienced. The woman at the counter yelled at me for no reason. I will never return and promise to retell my experience to every single person I know and encounter. This place should not be in business.

And oh by the way...it's BREAD, CINNAMON AND BUTTER people. How can it possibly be so complicated that they charge $5. Anyone paying that price for 50 cents worth of food is an idiot. Unbelievable that this place has duped so many people. Save your money and go somewhere else. Supporting this place is supporting a hateful staff.
author: scott f.

description: My favorite spot for coffee in SF! The workers there are super nice and chill, great vibe and great coffee! Also, love the outside sitting with view to the Ocean!
author: Jul R.

description: The Owner was yelling at her employees while there were customers there saying "im the boss". So unprofessional. No whipped cream for hot cocoa?!?! What!
author: Torres F.

description: Came in as they were about to close, lured in by the wonderful coconuts on display!  Unfortunately, he was just closing up, but I asked if I could buy a bag of beans anyway (not have him make me a drink).  The fella said sure, as long as I had cash, since he shut down the register.  I appreciated his flexibility and bought a half pound of Elbow Grease.  It smelled great and I love dark roast.  Some googling tells me various things about the oily beans in Elbow Grease, but one thing's for sure:  This brewed up (burr grinder + Chemex drip) into a rich, dark, and smooth roast the next morning.  YUM!  I hope to return to try their cinnamon toast and/or coconuts.
author: Kati P.

description: Believe the hype! Believe This American Life! I've been coming to Trouble for years and it's my favorite. I will go out of my way to make sure that I can get my cinnamon toast fix. The bread is so thick and chewy, the cinnamon sugar crispy, and the butter gooey and delicious. I'm obsessed. The coffee is nothing special but that's not why people come here.
author: Jack M.

description: The cashier was nice and took my order quickly, however the place is very tiny and there is no room to wait and the rest of the staff is very rude. The coffee mixing station is outside of the establishment, that gives you an idea of the size. My drink took about 20 -25 minutes. This wouldn't be a big deal if they let you know this ahead of time and didn't have to wait in the cramped waiting area. The decor is very hipster and unique, that is definitely something to check out.
author: Mandy B.

description:
The "menu" is inside on the right side, on a small clipboard. The best part about this place is the toast. Got the PEANUT BUTTER HONEY BANANA toast, and I'm fully aware that I can make this at home for less than $1, but the bread they use has such a nice consistency to it. It's almost flaky or has some layered textured feel to it? (I sound crazy)

CHAI was not bad, it's very chai-y and loaded with spices, not too sweet. You can add your own sugar outside near the door. There's also options to substitute for soy or almond milk for $0.50. It's a cute and hipster coffee shop with overpriced but tasty and simple items. There's only a few seats available inside but everyone is mostly hanging out outside eating their toast.
author: Jessica L.

description:
It's interesting how hit-or-miss the customer service seems here. There are never complaints from Yelpers about the toast or coffee, only about the staff members. What a shame. I didn't want to get in Trouble with the person who told me not to come here (because she said the baristas were snobby) but I was curious! This cafe is very close to where I live, so it wasn't too out of my way to check it out.

On my first time here, I just wanted a cup of black coffee. There was no menu posted, with the exception of six words on a slab of wood -- COFFEE, TOAST, YOKO, TEA, LATTE, COCONUT -- I can't remember the exact words. I wanted to know what a Yoko was, so I asked after ordering my coffee. The barista explained that it's a shot of freshly squeezed grapefruit juice. She made it sound super rejuvenating, so I swore I would try that next time.

I came here again on a Saturday morning. Their simple menu had transformed into a one-sheet page listing all the beverage and food options. How peculiar! This time, I did get the Yoko and felt somewhat more energetic, but it was probably a placebo effect. Either way, I've had a decent experience at Trouble Coffee both times. There's a few barstool seats to chill in while you're enjoying your drink or toast. Otherwise, you can hang out in the seating area outside, where everyone congregates to await their delicious toast. This cafe is cool in my book!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Came here after reading reviews on yelp. The cinnamon toast is delish, but this place was way too pretentious for me. Also, there is no where to sit or hang out except for some wood outside. There are much better coffee places in the city!
author: Michelle J.

description: Trouble is a gem. Only had a steamed milk with lavender and honey with some baked goods this time around, but I will be back. What we had was lovely, and the service was amazing. I love the story and the branding too. All in all, as a native San Franciscan, this place is the kind of neighborhood coffee spot I want to see flourish. See you again soon for some caffeine, Trouble.
author: Cat B.

description: Too much butter (regular butter) on their toasts. The peanut butter toast doesn't even taste like peanut butter because of the huge amount of regular butter they put on it. It looks like they've changed the way they did their toasts. Too expensive for what it is.
author: Leticia R.

description:
-These are the text messages I receive from my girlfriend as I wait illegally parked in the car. 

Hey baby! It's good - Just waiting. They're burning ALL the toast! Toasting too fast! and this guy is scraping the top. Not sure how good they actually are, LOL

They seem slow and lost LOL

Yeah they're surfer bros. like bro surf my coffee up tho. Why you cracking so many jokes and not delivering coffee?

-The parking is obviously non existent, so I dropped her off. 

-The cinnamon toast was as advertised. but lets be super real about this... Texas toast, toaster, butter and cinnamon sugar. the problem with these trouble makers is that true cinnamon toast needs to be made by blending the cinnamon and sugar WITH the butter before its spread. Anything else is plain backwards thinking and has no place in a progressive area like SF.

-Let's just say that it's more likely we get coffee from the 7-11 across the street before we step foot back in this place.
author: Jamal F.

description: Coffee's good, toast is over rated, service is the worst. Do yourself a favor and go down the street to Beachside Cafe.
author: Karen F.

description: Enforced no cell phone policy. Idiotic. End of story.
author: Erika K.

description:
Okay, I admit it: I'm a nerd. So the only reason I found out about Trouble was through listening to NPR, specifically on an episode of This American Life (http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/520/no-place-like-home). Hearing the story of Giulietta really struck a chord with Jiwon M. (whom I practically forced the story on) and I, so we were determined to make the long, surprisingly sunny journey out to Outer Sunset. 

To our surprise, there was no line that Friday morning, and to our disappointment Giulietta wasn't there, just two pretty apathetic dudes who seemed like they were equally disappointed with our sudden appearance. "Coffee?" the cashier prompted as we tried to take in the cramped, eclectic (and eccentric) surroundings. A creepy baby doll, a copy of Yoko Ono's Grapefruit... 

We scrounged together the last of our cash (exactly $14) to purchase two Lattes and two Cinnamon Toasts. Because, Trouble doesn't need to go to the trouble of purchasing a card-reader when they're so popular. There were some interesting sounding pastries also on display, but unfortunately we felt we were on the last ropes of their hospitality as we waited at the narrow counter for our food. Jiwon attempted to take a picture to document this moment and how much it meant to us, but the cashier shot our dreams down with a curt "No pictures." 

I'll admit, it's pretty amazing to see how simple the toast is to make but how delicious, crispy, and buttery it is when it gets into your mouth. It's also pretty amazing how tiny the coffees are in comparison. Their espresso is definitely on the citrusy, bitter side, but it's a good counter-balance to the sweetness of the toast. We enjoyed our coffee and carbs using the twisted tree trunk outside as a bench, and another more level tree limb as a table. On a good day like the one we were blessed with, this serene setting is perfect for a long talk while you people-watch surfers walking back from a morning dip at Ocean Beach. Fortunately grouchy barista didn't reprimand us for taking pictures outside, but we've gotten into enough Trouble for now to last us awhile. ;)
author: Helen S.

description:
Disclaimer: This is a first-impressions review

SERVICE: So-so. I had to wait in line because of all the people that wanted coffee from this place. In my experience, long lines tend to make SOMEONE anxious/impatient. However, that "someone" should never been the person taking your order. This was my first time here so I felt puzzled to see that there were no menus to order from. When I asked the gentleman at the register, he appeared upset that I did not know how things worked around here. Good thing I already had an idea of what I wanted. 

FOOD: I ordered a coffee and toast, the two most commonly posted things on yelp. The coffee was earthy and bitter. Nothing exceptional about it. Although I will say that having the sugar and cream outside is a little off-putting,especially since this place is located on a slope. The toast was tasty but nothing to rave about. I really wanted to try the peanut butter and lavender honey toast but I guess they only serve a single type each time. Today was "Cinnamon Toast" which tasted exactly as described. One notable difference is the layer of butter on the toast. It makes the toast extra moist which is nice. Total was roughly $6, not a bad bargain.

AMBIANCE: I cannot comment much here considering that my old dorm room was larger than this place. There are a few stools inside but this place is really not a sit-down sort of deal. They do, however,have lots of open seating right outside this cafe. 

OVERALL: This place gets 3 stars because all in all, I was not dissatisfied and definitely will try to revisit this place another time.
author: Greg Y.

description:
Got a vanilla latte, wasn't the best but the girl working was nice. Coffee kinda tasted like alcohol. 

Cinnamon toast on the other hand was soooo good.
author: Heather M.

description: Good coffee, but I had a very poor experience. The staff was not friendly whatsoever. They probably don't want to be there, which I get. However, their attitude has an impact on everyone who walks through the door and that's not fair to the customer.
author: Devon M.

description: Coffee has lots of flavor and it is on the bitter end which I like. Never tried the toast but the cookie is awesome ! My wife interact with the male staff so i do not know how rude he is but the female staff treated me friendly. I believe they just want to pay attention to their jobs imagine unlike Starbucks this place literally have people waiting in line all day.
author: Wai C.

description: It's a decent place for a cup of coffee when it's not busy. The cinnamon toast is pretty good. Small inside (4 seats at the bar and 3 at the window) and some places to sit outside. Experience is dependent on the staff working. Some are chill, some are rude.  Some know how to make drinks, some don't.  Came in on one particular day, not too busy.  20 minutes, no drink.  Went to the cashier and had to get my order called out again.  Heard the guy making it say "yeah, no way."  Because he didn't know how.  Didn't get my coffee.  Sadness.  If you're in the area, yeah sure, but there's so many more options for good coffee in the city.
author: Christopher M.

description:
1 star for their absolutely rude cashier. Their menu had very limited options and I've never been here before. I was with my mom so I wanted her to have a good idea of her choices before we ordered. I was on Yelp looking at their clearly extended menu. First encounter:
Me- Hi!
Cashier- Can you get off your phone, while you are ordering
Me-I've never been here before, I'm checking out your menu. *shows phone*
Cashier- Well can you not do THAT, while we do THIS? I can help you *does not tell me drink specials*
Me-What is a Gibralter? *as seen from Yelp photos from phone, not seen anywhere else in store*
Cashier-one ounce milk, one ounce coffee(?) our menu changed *still does not provide help*
Me- ...can I just get a latte? 

Left with a latte and an unpleasant experience.
Latte is average. 

I understand how constantly being on your phone may be perceived as rude but being spoken to like that from a cashier was way out of line. I wasn't texting someone else or on my phone having another conversation. I am entitled to being informed about your establishment...little did I know about your costumer service...

TLDR- rude costumer service


I
author: Nicole N.

description:
Following an amazing meal at Outerlands next door, I decided to give the much hyped Trouble Coffee a try for dessert. As their toast has made the 7x7 list two years in a row now, I ordered that plus the fresh coconut which it was paired with on this year's list as well. 

I just don't get it. The toast was just not impressive. There are many other gourmet toast places in the city which do this item much better (The Mill comes to mind). The coconut was just that, a coconut with a straw and spoon. Maybe I'm spoiled coming from Hawaii but it wasn't even that great of a coconut. I've definitely had better.

To top if all off, the cashier was noticeably unfriendly to a number of customers, myself included, and then overly friendly with others who I'm guessing are regulars or perhaps more likely, just the cute girls.

Overall, this place simply does not belong on the top 100 list. Find your gourmet toast elsewhere because this just doesn't get the job done. "I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description:
Everyone's rude and the space is small. The toast is good, but it's so expensive. I get that all of this is their shtick, but I'm just not down with it. The server lambasted us for not ordering coffee and then pressured one of us into buying a coconut. I don't like living in a world where I can see someone get pressured into buying a coconut.

Also, there are no visible menus. I don't think this place actually wants you to buy their food.
author: AJ P.

description: Cute little coffee spot not far from Ocean beach. They're quick to crank out those thick and buttery cinnamon toast--yum!
author: Yad L.

description:
Trouble coffee is a cool little shop in Outer Sunset. 

They have a very simple menu (coffee, tea, toast), but the barista (or person serving) can make a wide range of items. 

It is a tight little place with a few bar style seats and that is about it. Add your extra coffee things on the small table outside and enjoy your toast and coffee.
author: Rawlins R.

description: Perfect spot to walk to from the beach for an ice cold coconut and a quick snack (cinnamon toast PLEASE). Expect a line, maybe just on the weekends, but the experience is so worth it!!
author: J R.

description: I could have gotten into this place despite the slightly evil vibe from the staff and the death metal blaring. I could have really enjoyed it. But the toast is really just ok. It does not compare at all to The Mill. It's too light and airy and insubstantial. And the espresso drinks are pure sludge. Undrinkable. Why is the latte so small and so overly concentrated and burnt tasting? The proportions are way off. This is not a serious coffee place. I love that there are dogs everywhere and I did get a little smile from the guy who actually makes the toast. That was nice!
author: Ari R.

description:
Although it seems like it can barely fit anyone, Trouble Coffee Company is definitely one of those famed little hole in the wall establishments that meets the hype as I came here on recommendations from more than a few friends before starting my day of exploring this "sleepier" part of San Francisco (still terrible parking though). 

Located just blocks away from the beach, Trouble Coffee looks like a tiny surfer hangout for social rebels and people living on the edge - I'm not used to having toast and coffee with loud rock music blaring in the background. 

I had the LEGENDARY cinnamon toast and boy it didn't disappoint - just thinking about it while I'm typing this review means I'm trying to keep my drool from falling onto my laptop. We are talking about a perfectly thick piece of bread that is toasted with the most remarkable slathering and balance of butter and cinnamon you can think of. Would it be too much to suggest that this humble piece of bread be a MUST  HAVE food item alongside Hog Island Oysters and Blue Bottle New Orleans coffee? 

Methinks not.

I also had a smooth macchiato that complemented my toast perfectly and got me in the right mood to start off the day and made me warmer in what was chilly weather. All together, I'm pretty sure I spent 10+ bucks on my little breakfast but it was definitely worth it.
author: Albert L.

description: Wow, the people who work there are assholes. Don't even bother going there unless you like to be barked at by tattooed ego maniacs who think they are too important to deal with customers. Screw them and go two blocks to Andytown Coffee Roasters!
author: Christie P. C.

description:
I don't like leaving bad reviews, but I love my hot chocolate. And when you charge 4.75 for hot chocolate, it better be good. The hot chocolate was neither hot nor chocolately, and tasted like lukewarm water that someone accidentally poured milk in. It didn't help that staff was rude. 

The place itself is cute and pleasant, but the quality of the products and service need some serious improvement.
author: Desiree C.

description: Grabbed a cappuccino to go, the place is teeny tiny. They have a cool seating area outside made from tree limbs, comfy. The coffee was good, I'd like to try some of their toast it looked really good. I found the service to be friendly, a little surprised by the low ratings on this, could it be because it is small and busy????? Hmmm just saying...
author: Karen R.

description:
This place is amazing. Cinnamon toast + gibraltar = puuurrrfection. 

Bonus: They have a bucket of fun stickers to the right of the cash register.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Coffee is good and their toast is awesome! Staff...horrible! I won't go into detail because I dislike when people give excruciating details on their experiences. I will say that I have been going there on and off for years and I always knew most of their staff were assholes. It wasn't until recently that I decided to stop going there because I had enough. I would rather spend the extra dollar at Beachside, where I know their slow drip is the best (seriously it's delicious) with wonderful customer service to complement it. 

Maybe for some the side of attitude is worth it...

Side note: You can replicate their wonderful toast by buying bread from Sheng Kee bakery.
author: Ericka L.

description:
To start, these guys probably serve the best cup of coffee in all San Francisco.

Having said that, I can't believe the amount of negativity towards this place. You guys want a menu? For a coffee shop? What?

Look at all the baked goods on the counter and now order whatever kind of coffee you want.

There's your menu.

I swear, some of you people are acting like this is the first time you've stepped foot into a coffee shop.
author: Nicholas L.

description: The most pretentious coffee shop I've ever been to. It was such a hassle to just get an espresso to go. They demanded they had to give me an americano to which I said "fine but could you just hold the water" and after 3 minutes of bickering they finally made my espressos sans added water saying "this is the only time we'll do this." Why? I don't know. What kind of place refuses to sell espresso? Why must it be an americano? Looks like they really live up to their name because it was nothing but trouble dealing with these pretentious hipsters.
author: Joseph W.

description: Grab some strong coffee with some surfers. This little spot offers divine peanut-butter toast and a little bar that you can chat with locals or the barista. If it's a nice day they have seating outside or you can head a couple blocks to the beach.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
I've been around the neighborhood, but never in this particular area - the location at Trouble Coffee is rather unique. 

I heard about Trouble Coffee through NPR, and the story was so compelling. Since I was in the area, I decided to come check the place out and to support her business. When I walked in, I was taken back from how small and quaint the coffee shop was. I looked around for a menu, but the guy at the cashier greeted us and jokingly said he is the walking-talking menu. We sparked up a nice conversation, along with some recommendations on what to get at Trouble. I decided to get an iced coffee and their Cinnamon Toast. 

The coffee itself was delicious, and I didn't need to add cream or sugar, which in my book means greatness when it comes to coffee. The Cinnamon Toast was delicious as well, and I was impressed at how great it taste! There was also some wood-bench-things outside where you can sit around and enjoy your coffee and toast. 

Although this place may not be a place to sit down, sip your coffee, and surf the internet type of place, I enjoy the quaint little setting and fun workers at the shop. It's apparent that this is a local coffee shop where the workers hang out with the customers while they wait for their drinks. Aside from that, this place only takes cash - so make sure to leave your credit cards at home!
author: Victoria K.

description: FIVE dollars for an iced coffee. Which is a lot, but i could stomach that if it tasted like high quality cold brew. But it tasted like hot coffee that was prepared as usual, put in the fridge overnight and then iced.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Solid latte stop! Liked this place a lot. Good music, good food- buttery cinnamon Texas toast- what's not to like??

Not a lot of seating but My kids liked the huge piece of driftwood outside to climb around on. 

Quiet area a couple blocks up from the beach. We were passing thru SF and I found it a pleasant stop for local color.
author: Julienne K.

description: Best coffee in town! Also the cinnamon toast was amazing! It was really packed but staff worked very well together and was friendly. Definitely recommend stopping by!
author: Shanice S.

description: we always make sure to visit this coffee shop when my aunt and cousin come to town. my aunt complimented the barista on the cafes unpretentious and authentic feel (and then the barista joked back that they have been called the opposite, thanking my aunt for seeing the place how it really is). the coffee is of course great too :)
author: Jun S.

description:
They don't really have a menu here so I was a little confused when I stepped inside. The interior is really nice and there is a park let outside for people to sit and enjoy their coffee.
