I ordered a latte and an almond toast. The coffee was good and the almost toast was really good! 

Would have been nice to have a menu though. Definitely a spot I would return to!
author: Lydia H.

description:
There was a bit of a wait for brunch next door at Outerlands so we came to Trouble for some coffee and a "light snack". The cappuccinos are more than perfect. AND I've been dreaming of their lavender honey peanut butter toast since the day I had it. Mmm.

 CA$H ONLY
author: Elysse P.

description:
I was in desperate need to see GOD/DESS...so I hopped the N-Judah and visited the most holiest of holy places on this earth, aka GOD/DESS, there, right before me was the most amazing, massive, slate grey shimmering evanescent bubbly waves, welcoming the early morning sun. I was at peace. 

But, than I got the thinking about that other thing, that is pretty darn holy for me, it starts my day and helps me tone my "bitch down." 

Now, after years of living happily, sometimes, shitty-wise, in the Bay area, Ocean beach has seen better days and those days did not include coffee shops teeming with fellow coffee drinkers ready to start the day or end. It's like a peaceful little village at the end of the line...

I just had to get in TROUBLE, and had some mid-morning coffee and I was happy, with the coffee and with seeing the Sea! plus, the dude who greeted me, was kind nice...because, I've learned you greet people with zero "tude" you might actually be treated with a good attitude. 

Plus, I had the coffee and it was darn good! not that fruity stuff or day old brown crap in a paper cup, so watered down, you'd think it was dirty water. It was just the right amount of coffee too water ratio...I was told by someone, who said the ratio of water and coffee make all the difference.

Anyways, I will return, because of the sea and the of course the coffee.

P.S. this place is small, so if you are expecting to seat at a table for 4...not going to happen, this is "get your shit and go sit outside and enjoy the view, type of place." Or you can squeeze in at the long gallery bar. but that is a tight squeeze.
author: Valerie D.

description: My go-to spot before work! Excellent coffee, delicious pastries (the ham and cheese croissant is  ) and the cinnamon toast is so buttery it's sinful. Cute little parklet right outside for enjoying your food.
author: Ashley M.

description: This 1 star review is for the dark brown haired lady at the register taking the orders. I just got scolded because I asked her to hold off on adding any more butter on my hubby's cinnamon toast. She not only took offense to it, she also started to lecture me on how it is not normal to be told how to make this toast as she knows how much butter is required for the cinnamon blah blah blah in front of other patrons in line. I thought it was just me but others in line rolled their eyes at her. Sorry if you hate your job or are a miserable person but please don't take it out on me. As far as I remembered I was the customer. She needs to find another job that makes her happy. Life is too short! PS at least I got her to make me a new toast with less butter!
author: Helen Y.

description:
I think if you view a visit to Trouble Coffee like it was a short story, by say... Flannery O'Connor, you will be in the right frame of mind to enjoy the visit. 

You will encounter entertaining and unusual characters (today the were surfers, former hipster mothers with toddlers, confused seeming tourists and a semi hippy girl sitting at the counter going on at length about the various preparations of tinctures.) No one will want to take your order and when they do, they will be sure to not rush in its preparation, what with there being iphones to check, giant canisters of cinnamon to relocate repeatedly and other customers more interesting than you to chat earnestly with. 

Once your order has been fulfilled (patience), you will be able to enjoy it (may I recommend a coffee and coconut combo with perhaps a slice of thick toast?) in the parklet out front. There are 3 bar seats inside but sit there only if you do not suffer from claustrophobia. The outside benches are roomier and have been assembled from scrap lumber, drift wood and succulents that seem to be held together by sheer force of will. They are reasonably clean and not that uncomfortable. They offer a view of parked cars and a store with fancy pencils.

Enjoy the quirks and conversations of the denizens of the outer sunset who surround you. Be happy they will stay here and not go back to your house with you. Wish them well in their journeys and quests, as you go about yours....refreshed and perhaps a bit relieved to depart.
author: Nicole M.

description: I passed by this coffee shop last night and decided to get coffee here today. Trouble Coffee creates such a relaxing atmosphere by playing John Coltrane's locomotion in the background. The almond latte was strong, smooth, and slightly bitter. I will definitely get coffee there often.
author: Angela L.

description:
Sometimes people just have bad days so I try not to judge a place because of a couple bad customer service experiences but when it becomes constant, maybe that is just the way it is??? 
The staff here is RUDE and uninviting, End of story! I just don't get it for a place so small.
author: Sierra L.

description:
Coffee here is delicious and the toast is a must try. 

I have tried all their toasts and my favorite one is the cinnamon toast. That with a side of hot coffee or latte is the best combination.

I agree with other reviews, customer service really is a hit or miss. Luckily, the day I accidentally spilled my coffee, one of the (nicer) workers were outside and offered to get me another cup! I'm usually in and out of this place in 5 minutes so the substandard service does not really bother me. 

This will continue to be my go to place for coffee.
author: Shirley S.

description:
Yes, the toast is boss - but the coffee is only OK and the space isn't very inviting.

We showed up on a Saturday afternoon for coffee and toast - nowhere near closing time.  As we walked up, they began locking up the shop.  We asked - what gives?  They told us that they decided to close the store for a while to clean.  No particular reason whatsoever.  Totally bizarre and not exactly customer-friendly.  But whatever - the boyfriend HAD to have the toast.  So, we came back about 20 minutes later and ordered a black coffee, a latte, the cinnamon toast, and the peanut butter honey toast.  

I was immediately annoyed by their sign to stay off of your phone.  Like, I'll text or browse the web if I want to - LOL!  Angry hipsters...  I was also very turned off by the super loud, aggressive music and the attitudes of the workers, who seemed to think they were at a punk rock concert and not serving customers.  It's just not a place where you can really sit and enjoy your snack and coffee because it's so loud and you're basically sitting in on the employees gossiping and such the whole time.

The coffees were totally average and they keep ALL of their coffee "gear" (i.e. lids, napkins, etc.) outside, which is so weird.  

However, yes, the toast is amazing.  The peanut butter honey was definitely my favorite.  I guess if I was around here and I HAD to have the toast, I'd come back.  But there are better places out there...
author: Tay H.

description: The coffee was ok. Not worth the rude and pretentious staff. Not worth the loooong wait. I don't get why anyone would want to come here when there are some amazing local coffee shops that actually appreciate their customers and have better coffee.
author: Danielle T.

description:
It feels weird to get very excited about cinnamon toast, but damn is this awesome cinnamon toast! I'm fairly certain I saw a face in my toast, which was probably a divine sign that I promptly ate. Also, the drip coffee, Elbow Grease, is fantastic. I highly recommend both.

The toast and large coffee were $7.50, which seems fair, if not a little on the high side.

Also, definitely give the This American Life episode about the owner a quick listen!
author: Ryan H.

description: I've been coming here for years 5+ years. Has always been good coffee but average to poor service, but they have a nice parklet. Went in on a busy Sunday. Ordered 2 coffees. Waited 15 minutes. Coffees were a long way from ready. No problems, it's busy but I got to go. Asked to cancel. The guy said he would just throw the cups away. I asked for a refund (I'd paid cash plus tipped) and he just said "sorry, no. I wish it was a better situation". You know what? Screw that. There's tons of other coffee shops in the area with great coffee. Andy town, beachside, and more. No reason to come back here again. Terrible service.
author: Sebastian J.

description:
Summary: be careful not to say/ask the wrong things around the Toast Nazis. 

The first time we went, my friend legitimately got yelled at and told to leave because he took a picture of the toast with his phone. We laughed it off at the time. Some people have strong feelings about food pictures. Whatever. 

The second time I went there I watched the non-native English speaker in front of me get yelled at for asking for a clarification on his order. F words were dropped with no hesitation, and I winced when I saw the mans young son (5 years old maybe?) cower a little bit.

We didn't get yelled at this time, but eventually the palpable hostility in the air made us too uncomfortable to stay in there. We took our toast and ate outside. Frankly, from all my experiences here it was only a matter of time before we did, or said, or took a picture of something that they felt deserved retribution.

I texted a few of my friends to compare notes with their experiences at Trouble. Par for the course turns out.

For what it's worth, we enjoyed our toast. It's good toast.
author: Joe B.

description: Great latte and great location! Just a nice walk up from the beach is this cute little coffee shop you won't miss bc of the crowds of people. A nice strong latte without too much milk is perfect with a little sprinkle of sugar!
author: Audrey F.

description: The coffee is good... but I have never waited that long for a latte ... maybe once at the airport for Peets' coffee... but I didn't have anything better to do at the airport... and this time I feel like I wasted a perfectly fine half an hour the first day of the year... a bad sign... I don't understand why it took so long... several people who showed up 10-15 min after me got their espresso drinks before me... not sure what their system is but I don't think it is working that great... By the time I got my coffee, I was so pissed, I couldn't even enjoy it any more... Not really worth the trouble it took to get it...
author: ania w.

description: Perhaps we came on a particularly good day, but the service was great (even offered to let us use their sink to wash our hands after having been at the beach), and the coffee/cinnamon toast were excellent. While the toast was a bit of a no-brainer (fresh bread, butter, cinnamon sugar--what could go wrong?), the gibralters were the standouts. Honestly some of the best I've had in the city, and their space is very cute/quirky. Be warned that the space is small and does not have a bathroom.
author: Amber H.

description:
Their snobby, elitist attitude started showing through. 

Toast is still amazing but,... I guess I will work to perfect my own toast at home in a more inviting environment. 

I won't be back.
author: Angela C.

description:
CONSISTENTLY RUDE :( 

All Trouble's bad yelp reviews have one thing in common - rudeness. It's accurate. I am a local and have been here several times and always feel like such a bother to the workers. They seem to hate customers. No special requests and hostility towards customers who dare to think about asking (I'm looking at you today, young lady with the short black hair). Even when I'm straight with my order, they take it with a sneer. I like coffee, but not with a side of bad energy. I just can't anymore.
author: jessica h.

description:
It's particularly odd that I'm giving this a one star review when I actually enjoyed what I had at Trouble. But, if it's one thing that I won't stand for, it's being disrespected, no matter how good or delicious anything might be.  And to be clear, I'm writing this review days after my experience, so there's no knee jerk reactions going into this either.

In reading up on the delicious cinnamon toast that Trouble offers, I decided that on my day off that I'd head out across town (literally in my case, since I live in South Beach) to Trouble and stop in for some of their highly publicized toast. In walking into the shop, it's clearly a surfer/hipster place, which is all well and good; nothing I hadn't already seen in other places before.  In ordering my toast, the guy behind the counter seemed friendly enough.

As everyone's mentioned, this is a cash only and no coffee & menu board kind of place, so coming ready is essential.  Somehow in my excitement for my toast, I missed the teeny tiny sign on the door that says 'No Electronics' so when my toast arrived and started taking photos of it, I was immediately the butt of the barista/toastmaker's jokes to his buddy who was sitting at the counter.  Small jabs and ribs about how I was taking photos of my food seemed to cause a lot of amusement between the guy and his friend, and proceeded to make fun of me for some time.  Never mind a separate person that's sitting at the the counter reading his emails and watching Netflix on his phone; that obviously doesn't qualify for jokes, but taking food photos is.  I've been to a lot of places, had experiences of subpar service, but never have I been laughed at and disrespected by anyone at any of the places I've been to.  So, along with paying for cinnamon toast (which in all seriousness is something that I truly did enjoy), I apparently also paid to be someone's entertainment that morning. Call me a sourpuss, call me a rulebreaker for not paying attention to their small (and frankly, sort of silly) sign, but I don't pay places to make fun of me and my general enthusiasm for SF fare. There are far too many places in this city to go to for delicious breakfast items on your day off.

Sorry Trouble, but you aren't worth the trouble of returning to, no matter how great your toasts and coffee might be.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Hipster hangout to the MAX.

It's like Portland left a little part of itself here.  

The guys who work here can be douche bags, but hey, just keep making that fat cinnamon toast and you're golden.  I dig the young coconuts and lattes.  

Cash only.  Simple.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
I find the reviews for Trouble Coffee Company hilarious to read through because what everyone's saying is 100% true. My first time here with the bf, we were looking to get a quick pre-breakfast snack while waiting to get seated at Outerlands. 

Like others have said, you better use yelp to figure out what you want, because they don't have a menu, and if you try asking them what they have, pretty much all you'll get is an absurd amount of snark from the cashier. We got called out that first time for "coming to Trouble Coffee Company and Coconut Club" and not getting coffee or coconuts. It was pretty ridiculous and annoying, but the cinnamon toast was pretty good and left me sane enough to continue waiting to be called into Outerlands for actual brunch. 

The second time we came here was for the exact same scenario- needed to eat SOMETHING because I was starving and waiting for Outerlands. This time we didnt bother asking about a menu or anything, just told the cashier exactly what we wanted. No snark this time. Yay? 

SO yeah. Bottom line - I'd still never go out of my way to come here, but it's a good way to temporarily satiate you if you're in the area and need a quick fix.
author: Stephany L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday morning and it wasn't too crowded! Coming from living in Santa Cruz for about 4 years, this coffee shop reminds me of those hipster-like, small joints that I would find in the downtown of Santa Cruz. Here, they have coconuts, coffee, and their famous cinnamon toast that a lot of people snack on with their beverage. My friends got a iced coffee and latte both with toast, and I just got the mocha. The drinks range from around $3-$4 and their cinnamon toast is $3. I tried a bit of the toast and it was really good! The way they make it is PERFECT; just enough toast with enough seasoning and BAM hits your mouth.

What i don't like about this place is that there is NO MENU! How can you expect us to know what you offer and look at me like I'm clueless or something when this is my first time! They offer the usual cappuccino, mocha, latte like every other coffee shop does, but I'm all into specials and what drink they are known for so I was a little disappointed at that. Also there is barely any seating; everyone usually sits outside in their patio with a huge tree branch and all that.

They also put all iced drinks in a hot cup container. What's the downside of that? The cup gets super soggy.. not really a fan of that. And I love my iced drinks! I get how they are probably trying to reduce the use of plastic but.. in those times it is very convenient.

3 stars for the food because it IS good.. maybe they can work on their service to be just a little more friendlier.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
The cupcake fad is behind us and macaroons are no longer the "it" food. Because now, now we have some good ole' toast. 

When I first heard of the new toast craze that had hit SF I I thought "really?" I mean I like toast, but how could people really be paying 3-5 bucks for something so normal? Enter Trouble Coffee and Coconut Club. I came across an article claiming this is one of the places (what I can best describe as charmingly odd) where the toast phenomena began. And honestly I was so intrigued the menu items and the owner's story behind the business that I had to check it out.

There's no menu on the wall but the owner strategically created an eccentric but simple menu based off the things that were important to her. Toast means comfort, coffee means speed and communication, and coconuts represent survival. Oh and shots of fresh squeezed grapefruit juice called "yoko" is another random menu item because the owner's theory is that a person can live off coconuts and vitamin C alone (hence the grapefruit).  "Build Your Own Damn House" is menu combination item consisting of a coffee, a coconut, and cinnamon toast. I skipped out on the coconut but my cappuccino was on point and honest to God I don't think I've ever had a better piece of toast in my life. Yea sure I could probably have made something similar at home but paired with my coffee and leisurely stroll to the nearby ocean on a foggy Saturday morning...it doesn't get much better.

Oh a few other things I noticed:they only have whole milk or soy, no decaf, and no espresso to go. And don't let the creepy plastic baby on the wall deter you. The whole place is decorated with random things yet it somehow just works. There's about 7-8 barstools inside but they also have some cool tree branch/trunk type of seating located just outside.

Ok so this isn't your typical review, but I just thought this place is so, just so unique. Which is saying a ton in a place where everyone is screaming to be just that. Read the article here: http://www.psmag.com/navigation/health-and-behavior/toast-story-latest-artisanal-food-craze-72676/
author: Miriam M.

description:
The coffee and toast is good, but I have only have three words for the customer service:

RUDE. WHITE. HIPSTERS.
author: Katrina P.

description:
Coffee is mediocre.

The thick, crunchy/soft toast slathered with butter and cinnamon sugar is crazy good and deserves a star. 

I am troubled by the nonexistent service and pretentious vibes.
author: Maya S.

description:
There is no menu which gives me super anxiety at first, but at the same time makes me feel super cool & hip because (due to lots of yelp research/reviews/photos) when you walk in, you kind of just order as if you know what you want like you've been going there forever. However most people aren't crazy like me and won't go through the extensive research and may just find this inconvenient...totally understandable! So here are do's and don'ts so that way this coffee place won't be seen as trouble when you walk in (okay no more jokes).

DO'S
-Do the toast! A lot of people will say that they can make toast at home, but I mean, are you really going to go through the effort of finding the perfect balance of peanut butter & honey or cinnamon to throw on a perfectly toasted thick piece of bread that's crisp on the outside and warm and soft on the inside???? Okay, that actually does not sound hard, but being able to buy it here, freshly made for you is always easier. 
-Cookies! they have these wonderful cookies that have a chocolate peanut butter candy in the middle (reeses??) and they looked like they would be hard and unpleasant but nope, they were wonderful and soft and not overwhelmingly sweet.
-Do the girlfriend! Aka earl grey tea with milk, honey, and lavender. It's actually been a hit or miss. Sometimes it's really good and other days mediocre (is that why it's called the girlfriend? omg no okay I will stop). 
-Coconuts! They sell coconuts to drink right out of, which is really cool and refreshing, but a little overpriced compared to how much you can get it at an asian grocery store. Still worth it because how many coffee places do you know of that sell coconuts????

DON'T
don't come in here not knowing what you want since there isn't a menu inside!
don't come in here without cash.
author: Maleah M.

description:
you better yelp what you want to order because there is no menu but yet they have names for every drink. how are we suppose to know this? I don't know but they will call out the name of the drink when it is ready. once again, if it is not busy then it it okay because you can identify your drink by sight.   I got the fresh grapefruit juice since I didn't want caffeine. the grapefruit juice is called Yoko. it is tiny and I don't even know the price since no menu and we ordered 4 items together. 

also ordered the toast. I expected more since it is the birthplace of the toast phenomenon. it wasn't warm enough for me and I cut the roof of my mouth from the toast. I have eaten a lot of toast and this is the first time it has happened to me. I was in pain for days. so the toast was too hard. 

it is near the beach so watch out for the beach bums. one lady bum went into the coffee shop and took a bunch of stickers and went outside where they keep the sugar and straws and took a straw and sat down next door and was chewing on the straw....luckily she didn't touch the sugar. the sugar jar lid was wide open and exposed to the elements. 

we had to sit on the log outside since they don't permit electronic devices inside. and with the cars driving by, you're inhaling exhaust.
author: Jules L.

description:
I should start the first Cinnamon Toast Addiction Club, and crown myself President. 

Came here for, what else, the coffee, and left with a toast addiction.

The strange thing is that I don't like cinnamon. Other than in small amounts in a smoothie, I think cinnamon tastes like fried copper. I even hate the cereal Cinnamon Toast Crunch.

Why then do I find myself munching on the cinnamon toast and mumbling like a mad man over and over to the barista how "good this toast is?"

They must add ecstasy in it or something. Maybe they mix the ecstasy in with the butter; it's that good.

But, back to the coffee. I've read how they don't allow pictures inside the store, and how the barista's can be kind of rude.

Not so, in my case. My buddy Dan and I were shown how to open a coconut, and were told how they named their peanut toast after some regular client who requested it.
I even took pics inside, and no one said a word about it.

If the toast wasn't as expensive as a gallon of milk, and if this place was actually close to where I lived, I would be here more often.

But, for now, I think I need to stay away from the toast.

Just back away slowly...
author: Jack R.

description:
Eh okay. I also hate places that don't take credit card and this place doesn't.

Trouble is notoriously famous as the place that started the toast hype (really, there's a NPR episode about this, it's quite interesting). The place has a lot of character, and no menu, making ordering pretty hard if you don't know what you're going to get. Yes, you can use your common sense and just assume they serve your typical coffee sets, but I don't like when places don't have menus.

That being said, it's totally got the hipster vibe going on and Trouble's story is quite inspiring. I came in the afternoon with a friend to try the famous toast for $4. It was good... but ... it's just toast. Yes, it's delicious cinnamon toast but again, how mindblowing was it? Not so mindblowing. I'm actually not sure if it's even better than The Mill's toast so yeah there's that.

Didn't get the chance to try the coffee, but will update if I ever make it out here again.

tldr; overrated toast, but it is the place that birthed toast, so maybe worth trying. Trouble has a really inspiring story even though I was uninspired by the food here
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Came here after listening to a podcast and reading a couple articles about the owner and the shop.  I was so inspired by her story and the meaning behind the name of the shop I had to come! (If you don't know what I'm talking about you should google it! Supa interesting).

Since I don't live in the Sunset anymore it's hard for me to come out this far, but I happened to be in the neighborhood and definitely had to stop by.  Holy shit Judah is getting more and more gentrified it's hard to recognize it now adays.  But that's a different story.

I knew I had to get my hands on some cinnamon toast and an iced coffee.  I was so excited!  Although $4 is a ridiculous amount of money to spend on ONE PIECE OF BREAD WITH SOME CINNAMON AND BUTTER I politely handed the barista the amount without a speck of regret, because I was just so happy to be here after learning about the history of this place and getting to experience it first hand.   

My boyfriend was literally horrified at the cost of the toast and after tasting it said he'd had much better bread at other places, but to me it was much more than eating cinnamon toast on a log.  It was about appreciating the moment, and since there is no wifi and no tables, you are kind of forced to interact with the people you are with and who are around you, and just appreciate the moment a bit more than you would at SBux or some shiz. And because there are tons of hipsters literally eating coconuts with metal spoons outside of this place, strangers are always striking up conversation because of it.  Which (if you read the article) is the reason why she has coconuts on the menu in the first place. 

As I enjoyed my ice coffee and toast on the log outside of Trouble Coffee, I realized I couldn't wait for the next time I would get to do just that.  I think even though items are slightly overpriced, you get so much more out of the experience than just good snacky food, but a moment to appreciate the environment Trouble provides, even if it means no wifi to post your coconut IG pic.
author: Christina L.

description:
I've been to Trouble a couple times over the years when I'm down in the deep Sunset and I truly love it, especially the owner's backstory (listen to This American Life on NPR, episode #520, about 45 minutes in, but the entire episode is awesome), very inspirational and made me get a lil' choked up.

For toast being such a simple concept, this sh*t really knocks your socks off and makes you feel all warm and fuzzy inside. I used to eat toast as my #1 dish growing up, usually SF or Santa Cruz Sourdough, slathered with salted butter and cinnamon sugar, so now that I'm an adult and *try* to eat healthy most of the time, it feels so darn good to indulge once in a while and just go nuts on some chewy, crunchy, sweet, adult-style toast.

The shop is unique and funky, not your typical Starf*cks/Peet's, but in a good way. Hope to be back real soon!
author: Crystal C.

description:
Bestest coffee and music.....
The owner is pretty chill...
author: Jen T.

description: Here's the thing about trouble coffee, it's not for everyone but it's the best coffee shop in town. Yeah it might get busy but not only can you see the ocean from the line, there's usually a friendly pup or two sniffing around for some friendship. Now the coffee is amazing, near perfect but the last thing we want is this shop to get an ego as it is already a small place.
author: T R.

description: Not worth the wait. Staff was rude. Coffee is ok. 30 minute wait for a coconut. They're always busy and always taking it out on their customers. Wouldn't recommend to a friend and certainly better local cafe's in the area if visiting. Not what OB is about.
author: Michael S.

description:
The thing about hipsters is that they're like the cool outsiders. So what happens when an innocent non-hipster civilian gets in on the cool outsider side? 

The answer is HA, or as the hipster goes, with a nod and a low "hey"

I just wanted some coffee whilst waiting for my table at Outerlands. Went to Trouble and asked if they do iced coffee. "Yes." Do you have flavor shots like vanilla or hazelnut?" No, we only serve puritan coffee." 

Well,  I walked out with nothing. I guess this civilian's taste buds are not pretentious enough to handle puritan coffee.
author: Naomi Y.

description: Best cup of Joe you can get. Delicious beans and for $2.50 it is a great treat to my morning (straight coffee high!) I go for straight cup of Joe- i don't get the fancy latte's or the grapefruit shots- but it is about small and simple- not grandeur and large. The cinnamon toast is delicious- but expensive. So i don't go for this all the time. The Texas toast is delivered fresh every morning though and they don't skimp on the cinnamon sugar. Small location, really has it's own personality, and don't go in there asking a bunch of questions. There is hardly a menu posted! This is a locals only spot so if you aren't going in with someone who has already been there, i don't recommend trying it. This is a referral based spot- with a lot of pride to the outskirts of ocean beach. stay away haoles
author: Julie H.

description:
Shelling out money for warmed up bread. Waiting to get into a cramped up space to order. Eating it while sitting on tree logs on the sideways. Oh yes, this is San Francisco. 

Met a friend here, and we got the cinnamon toast. Gotta admit, the combo of cinnamon, sugar, and butter was nice.

Other side notes-
- Waiting Time: It's a small place, so things can take a while. There was a line when we got there, but waiting times can fluctuate. We waited about 10 minutes for toast. Grant it, this may be because the person ahead of us ordered about 8 pieces of toast, so it took a while to get ours. Get your carbs in, bro.
- Cash only. 
- Seating: The best part of this area is the creative outdoor seating on tree branches and stumps.
author: Joanna L.

description: Coffee tasted burnt, toast was whatever, and the staff was rude. Not cool.
author: Bridge S.

description:
I'm all about their toast, bout their toast...yes, Trouble..coffee. Haha. 

Came in on a Wednesday morning and luckily there was not line I'm used to seeing on a Sunday morning trailing out the store front. 

Like everyone has mentioned, the Cinnamon Toast is pretty stellar. Cinnamon sugar sprinkled on top of a buttered, thick toast. A slightly crunchy bite but soft on the inside. It compliments well with a cup of their standard dark roast drip called "Elbow Grease".

Solid pairing and much needed pick me up for the week's hump day!

Note: Cash Only
author: Vincent L.

description:
Four bucks for a miniature latte that really wasn't all that good. But the Cinnamon Toast was a sugar sensation from heaven.

Hipster baristas who act all snobby and rude when they take your order. But that Cinnamon Toast is essentially a Godzilla version of cinnamon toast crunch, the taste you can see!

A stupid rule that prohibits aspiring food lovers from taking a picture inside. But there's this huge slab of fatty butter in the middle of the Cinnamon Toast that's mind numbing good.

The trouble with Trouble Brew is that everything sucks there but I'm still dying to go back for the Cinnamon Toast.
author: Ringo M.

description:
Coffee is delicious and reasonably priced, but service is so bad that I will probably not come back again. Good thing I took maybe 10 of their stickers (avail in a small tin bucket above the menu).

Cafe is super small, so definitely a grab and go sorta deal. I tried the Au Lait w/ soy. They only have whole milk and soy milk. Lame. I wanted my nonfat or almond milk. 

Their website also sucks and tells me absolutely nothing about the company and the menu.
author: Samantha C.

description: Just went for the first time. The iced coffee was good (it has the wonderful handmade taste to it), the staff was very friendly and helpful, but let me tell you, the cinnamon toast was life-changing. I'm not kidding when I say it almost made me cry, it was so good. The one piece of advice I have for you is to explore the menu a bit. I saw one or two things on there as I was leaving that made me realize that what I got was pretty basic. It's almost worth taking the BART across the bay just to visit,  though, so I'm sure I'll be back soon enough!
author: John E.

description: I meant to take a picture of the toast I just ate, but it was gone before I could get the camera app to start.
author: Anna H.

description: Cinnamon toast and the young coconut are a must! The cafe is tiny and you usually have to take your food/drinks to go. You can grab a seat on the large tree branch outside. Cute place to check out!
author: Noor S.

description:
My first time trying their cinnamon toast was so incredible so I went back again. However my toast got burned pretty badly on both sides since the guy was talking to another customer. Instead of starting over with a fresh toast the guy roughly scraped some of the burnt black char off and proceeded to prepare my toast. He even made a comment to the other barista how easy it is to burn these toasts. I couldn't believe that he wouldn't just start a fresh new toast. And he didn't even scraping off the char diligently as I could still see the black char underneath the cinnamon sugar.

Still I gave it shot though I knew it wasn't right. When I bit into it, it tasted so awful that I had to spit it out immediately. I went back in and ask them to make me a fresh one. Instead of apologizing for burning the toast to begin with the guy said 'oh you want one that's less toasted?' REALLY? He then quickly whipped up a new toast which tasted dramatically different than the burnt one. 

Goes without saying that it's probably best if they offered a fresh one whenever they burn a toast to begin with!
author: Ai Z.

description: Fantastic cinnamon toast. Also had toast with seasonal pluot jam which was excellent. The iced coffee is just right and my wife liked the chai tea. Good music and friendly people behind the counter. Definitely will return here often. Next time I'm not splitting the cinnamon toast. I might even get a double order.
author: David L.

description:
Unfriendly - I'm embarrassed by how rude they are. I hope people visiting don't think everyone in SF is like that. They went out of their way to insult a woman in line for literally no reason.

Coffee - fine. Nothing special. 

Bread - good but SF has a million places with better bread and friendlier people. 

They do have a menu now. 

Not going back.
author: Nicolette L.

description:
Folks, there are lots of other coffees and toasts in SF. So please don't trouble yourself with this particular shit shack. 

Can this place please go out of business so all those RUDE hipsters find someplace else to mope and be bitchy? This way, a more deserving business can set up shop in this space. By the way, I'm not just talking about Trouble's bad attitude. Their  products were fine, but very average. The coffee tastes like coffee you could get almost anywhere, and their toasts are burnt. You want toast, go to the Mill.

But I'm here to talk about the overall experience you'll have here: Seriously, service is non-existent, and the general attitude and vibe of the place is, generally speaking..........garbage.
author: Tanya S.

description: Wow. This place is not worth the time. If you need someone else to make you cinnamon toast then they are decent  at that, but if you watch close they burn the toast a lot(esp. If they are busy)then they just scrape the burnt off and serve it up. A $4 masterpiece!! Usually however it is served with a heaping helping of: attitude, brashness, condescension, judgement, abstract/trying too hard to be cool musician or just downright rudeness. Some times all of the above! Let's just say you can't believe everything you hear on NPR. The owner uses her supposed mental illness as a license to be a jerk to anyone she deems unworthy. I have seen it firsthand on more than one occasion. Customers, staff, neighbors even her own children(God help them)The coffee? Over roasted, over extracted, one dimensional and that's just the espresso. The drip is comparable to licking the spot your old, leaky car left on the driveway mixed with charcoal from yesterday's barbecue. It should be a crime to pay what they charge for a young coconut here! High notes- good tea selection, great repurposed driftwood and a cool seating area outside. Trouble is the perfect name for this place. Good luck
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I came here with my friend and neither of us had been here before.. We had a few questions about the menu (since it was nowhere to be seen), and the cashier was very rude in answering them. 
Our coffees were decent but not necessarily worth the price, and certainly not worth the bad attitude. 
My suggestion is that there should be a clear menu up somewhere, and the staff should be more helpful and willing to answer customer questions. Probably won't be going back here, which is a shame because it's conveniently close to the beach
author: Natalie C.

description:
Came back for a coconut! Good but I realized later supermarkets on Mission sell the same thing for $1.49...

I do like that they give you a spoon and you can scrape off the coconut meats. Great slightly sweet + savory flavor.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/trouble-coffee-company-san-francisco?select=baCEuXzFe83aeRFG6MeKKQ#baCEuXzFe83aeRFG6MeKKQ

There was a long line coming out the store but they move efficiently. Probably a lot of people waiting to get into Outerlands (aka like us). Even though there were lots of people hanging out inside and on the sidewalk, it was easy to find a seat on the tree-trunk bench outside.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Cool local coffee joint. Barristas make a great cup of what you need. Came here for the toast. Local made Texas cut toast with cinnamon, PB, banana, honey, you decide. All good.
Heard about it on a podcast and near some surfshops I wanted to check out. Makes for a good morning walk. On a dry day the seating out front is chill.
author: Tommy B.

description:
First of, this is not an everyday place for me not will it be. This is mostly because I don't live in the area and slightly because I found their coffee average. I came around 9:00AM on a Saturday to try out their thick toast and latte. 

Toast and coffee: My latte had a nice balance of cream and espresso flavor. My only gripe is that the roast is not strong enough (in flavor) for me and was diluted by the milk. Now that toast on the other hand, WOW. It was like a bite of heaven! I'm more of a coffee person than a toast person but this place really makes an A+ toast.

Experience: I really appreciate places that can handle a crowd. There was already a line at 9:00AM but they were able to crank through it like its nobody's business! There isn't much seating inside but they have a nice seating area in front to enjoy your coffee. Parking can be an issue since it's right in the middle of a residential neighborhood. 

This place is a 3 star coffee shop with a 4 star toast. I absolutely recommend both and to let your pallet be the judge.
author: Chris W.

description: True, Trouble always seems busy, but if you come some weekday night, or somehow manage otherwise to find a slow moment here, I swear you'll never want to leave. Trouble's is one of the best dark roasts in the city, and undoubtedly the best Texas toast. The baristas are every bit as lovely as the coffee they make and the place itself seems the love child of a wax museum and a Nirvana concert. Quite possibly the coolest cafe in a hundred miles.
author: Izana N.

description: Although I find it extremely ridiculous that there is no menu, I would recommend Trouble Coffee to friends. The classic toast is super tasty and there is some seating available outside the small shop.
author: Tara N.

description: Great place! The coffee is good, the punk rock vibes were sick and the cinnamon sugar toast was perfect (crunch on the outside, buttery softness on the inside).
author: Leon S.

description: Just out of our cozy Airbnb near this coffee shop, we came here as an alternative to the brunch place next door which had a long wait. As it turned out, their coffee was very refreshing and the PB&J along with peach pie/muffin thingy was great as well. Prices bit on the higher side, and not much room inside. Street parking.
author: Sid W.

description: We made a big detour to trouble coffee to try the "famous" cinnamon toast, which was a pretty big disappointment. There was really nothing super special about it, and the barista even put so much on that a lot of it wasn't "wet" in the butter. The coffee was also pretty average; I got an almond milk latte, and it needed some help. The space is also very small, so plan on taking your food/drinks to go. There are better places nearby Golden Gate Park, and I certainly wouldn't make a special trip out here based on the reputation that the cinnamon toast has built up.
author: Brian S.
Dan B.

description:
This is a great place to grab a coffee while you're waiting to get a seat for brunch at Outerlands. Their chai latte was meh -- but coffee is great. It's a tiny little gem in the Sunset. I've still never had the toast there, but am meaning to try it one day if I'm not heading to Outerlands.

It's also a short walk over to Ocean Beach! Grab a coffee and just watch the sunset. 

Note: Right at 5 PM, they clean their place before it closes. So it closes for about 15 minutes or so - do don't go at 5 PM.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Guys, this place is over-the-top hipster... I mean, they don't even have a drink menu. The guy at the cashier was rude. I asked for the lavender honey toast and a small almond milk latte and the cashier goes on a rant about why he doesn't understand why people think they have lavender honey, because they don't and that its funny that people think they taste it and post reviews about it. Maybe if they had a damn menu, this problem could be resolved. All of the customers sit outside on the logs, drinking their lattes with their raw denim and down Patagonia jackets, and looking at you like you don't belong. 

It cost me $20 for two toasts, 1 drip coffee, and an almond milk latte the size of a double espresso. Meh, I am a huge fan of good coffee and am willing to pay for it, but this place offered a mediocre product for an outrageous price. No thanks, I'll take my business to the coffee shops where the staff is welcoming, there are places to sit, and the product is higher quality.
author: Melissa A.

description: Went on a monday evening around 6, no line so that was a plus! I read many reviews saying that the service here is really bad but thankfully I got assisted by a guy who had just started working here (he told us it was his first day) & he was super chill & friendly! Sucks they don't have a menu but i knew what i came here for- the cinamon & pb honey toast! I had a bite of my friend's cinamon toast & it was pretty flavorful but honestly not worth all the hype. The pb jonry toast wss really sticky and gooey when you bite into it but it was decent. If it were on the way, i would probably go again but its not something to go out of your way for.
author: Celine C.

description:
After missing out on devils teeth bakery today (they close on Tuesdays), I stop off here for breakfast and coffee.  I ask the Barista whether my friend pastor Joey had stopped by for his coffee yet.  The bearded friendly dude said' "not yet." I smiled and replied that Joey is my homie. 
Bearded barista quipped back, with personal ownership and said that "he is all of our homies."

Oh coffee is really good here as well !
author: Jeff W.

description: Over priced and rude hipsters. The clientele of this place is rich white kids who use their parents money, too dumb to notice shitty service. I rather go to devils teeth
author: Diego G.

description:
I finally made it out for the famed hipster toast!

LOCATION.
Probably the best part of the place - it's not too far from the Ocean (okay, several blocks, but you get a nice breeze). They've built some sort of mini-urban-park thing in front of it (outdoors seating, basically), and it's a nice way to enjoy your drink.

THE DRINKS.
There is no menu. Which I get is kind of cute and kitschy but is also a little annoying when you'd rather just see a list of what they make, rather than play a guessing game with the cashier guy as to what they have and if it's good or not. 

THE GIRLFRIEND.
This was my drink of choice (thanks to searching yelp photos before coming) - earl grey tea with milk, honey, and lavender. It was pretty average, no better than what you'd make at home, unfortunately. 

THE TOAST.
I've heard raves about this toast for ages, and was sad to see it was a bit hyped. It's literally just a piece of Texas toast, that the cashier rubs butter over (guessing no utensils for food prep? it is a VERY small space), and then pours a cinnamon-sugar mix over. It wasn't bad, I was just expecting something a bit more special.

Overall, if you want some coffee or tea and you're in the area, it's not a bad place to drop by, but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit again.
author: Claire S.

description:
The staff is super friendly and the pastries are yum, but I hate that there is no menu and that it's cash only (yet prices remain expensive). 

Since the barista was so gregarious, we had to wait for him to finish his bajillion convos with other locals (and they weren't patrons, just folks who clearly like hanging out in this area) before he was ready to serve us. Again, he was super nice, but the overall structure (or lack thereof) could be off-putting to newbies. I guess Trouble is unapologetically a local SF spot and wishes to stay that way. If you walk around this area of Outer Sunset, it does feel like it has experienced the least amount of change since the tech boom. The buildings, streets, and parked cars all look like how I'd imagine it would have looked like 10 years ago. I suppose that's my impression of Trouble--like it's trying very hard to cradle a piece of decade-old nostalgia in a coconut. Too bad the irony of $4 toast (a trend that is apparently spreading like wildfire among the SF elite) is not lost on me.

Disclaimer: I have yet to try the toast. I have a feeling it could very well add or subtract another star from my review.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Americano and toast did not disappoint. Busy on a Saturday morning great people watching and delicious treats, can't wait to go back.
author: Emily W.

description: This place is as hipster as it gets, haha. I never really even saw a menu with all their drinks. The toast with cinnamon and sugar was delicious!! For sure getting that again. I also got a cappuccino which was pretty good but next time I want to try a latte or something not as strong. The service here was great, very nice staff :)
author: Hayley D.

description:
Tiny rustic coffee shop right next to Outerlands -- one of SF's hottest veteran brunch spots. Trouble Coffee holds their own though I have got to say.

Hands down, Trouble Coffee serves the BEST cinnamon toast! It is the BREAD I swear! The bread they use is like no other; it's almost 2 inches thick and soaks up all the delicious toppings perfectly. Just go get one and see for yourself. It's crack, seriously! 

Lots of free street parking nearby. There's outdoor seating and an indoor counter top behind the arrow front window. Perfect spot to chill and people watch.
author: Ellen W.

description: Had a cup of coffee while we were waiting for brunch at the neighboring restaurant. The coffee was good. Toast looked very good, next time I want to try.
author: Kaori M.

description:
The outer sunset is my hood, I've been here since 1991 and really the outer sunset didn't  change till trouble coffee came. I'm not hatin, just statin. I've been coming here since it first opened some time ago since I live a block away, and really I love their coffee. The only thing is that, its kind of pricey. But I guess it's expected since their coffee is really good. I get their black coffee and lattes a lot. The coffee is fragrant, aromatic and earthy from the roasting. It's not heavily acidic or watered down like some of the other coffee shops I've been to. Also I think their lattes are made with two shots of espresso instead of one. This makes their latte  taste more like coffee than milk/ cream. It's a good thing because a lot of coffee shops have it the other way around. 

One more thing! (lol jackie chan adventures reference for yall 90's kids) I can't submit my review until I talk about their famous cinnamon toast of course! All you need to know is that it's heavenly, but you might need to see your cardiologist if you eat too much of it since it's packed with butter. They melt so much butter in the middle but it's so delicious. I try to limit myself to having one once a month but sometimes it's so good I definitely have more than the recommended amount.
author: Janet K.

description:
Just gonna be real. I remembered that this place existed from This American Life and I needed to have a taste of the story.

This place is super simple. Toast, coconut, coffee. Looks like they now do some baked goods sourced from other places, but you're likely here for one or more of the three choices. 

Latte + cinnamon toast = $8.

Latte is gentle and enjoyable, and the cinnamon toast is thick cut, with generous helping of butter, sugar, and cinnamon. Probably not something I will consume regularly, but  this was my first time having cinnamon toast and it wasn't a bad experience.
author: Hayne P.

description:
I'll let everyone else here rave about The Toast (it tastes good and gives your taste buds quite the ride because it's simultaneously sweet and salty, but I would not call myself a fan, nor will I insist that you are not living until you try it) and the espresso. But let me tell you about The Girlfriend. 

Since I already had my self-allotted cup of coffee for the day, I ordered an earl grey tea. The guy making the drinks turned around and asked, "Who ordered the earl grey tea?" I said it was me and he promptly told me to try having a girlfriend. A what??? I've had one of those before, and let's just say that I haven't been the same ever since. As it turns out...at this coffee shop about a block away from the beach on the surf-y end of Judah, The Girlfriend is an earl grey tea with lavender, milk and honey, and it's supposed to be the owner of Trouble's go-to drink whenever she doesn't want coffee. That sounds great, I said, I'll take it. The woman who was waiting to order heard our exchange, and she quickly said that she wanted a Girlfriend too. 

After taking the first sip, I was in heaven. It literally tastes like a Bi-Rite flavor. If you don't like lavender, ignore my review. If you like lavender, this is a must try. If you're on the fence about it, try it anyway. You might just be swept off your feet like I was.

Things to be aware of:
-Cash only. There's a 7-11 across the street, so buy a pack of gum and get cash back, or something.
-Street parking only. Fortunately, it's a residential neighborhood. Unfortunately, parking can be difficult. Beware of the street cleaning signs for the first and third Friday of the month.
author: Olivia V.

description:
Stopped by here for a cup of joe because Andytown insists on staying closed when I'm in the area ROAR!!

Super hipster kind of thing. Why is there no menu? -.- I just ordered a latte and thought it was OK. It was a tad toooo milky. It didn't have the perfect balance of espresso and milk.It's pretty pricey. 

Overall, I wouldn't list this as one of my faves, but it is definitely not bad. Maybe I'll try the toast next time..........................

=]
author: Judy W.

description: The bread was super good! Being a cinnamon fan I made this place a must and I loved the bread! My friend and I shared the Holy Shit and yes... one bite and HOLY SHIT! We also got coffee and it was also delicious. The great thing is that it's near the General Store which sells really cute items and has a nice little garden. Another  fantastic thing is that it's by Outerlands! I still have yet to try their dutch pancake, but Trouble Coffee definitely hit the spot! Will totally return and bring more friends!
author: Michelle H.

description: Trouble Coffee is really unique. Their toast is amazing and their drinks are great as well! A lot of the reviews say that the service is really rude, but from my many experiences here, I've always been welcomed and I haven't had any issues with the workers. I removed one star simply because their iced drinks are also served in their paper cups. This causes the cups to become softer and soggy overtime.
author: Alan D.

description:
An Ode To Toast: 

Should you find yourself wandering and wanting in Outer Sunset, there is one thing you need fill your bags and belly with: Toast. 

The staple of morning meals. The linchpin in all prospective corners of a complete breakfast. The square that can served as a side or an entree item: Toast.

Where else is there a perfect vehicle that transcends all time, space, age, and overtly conscious and sophisticated palates: Toast.

Trouble Coffee is where I want to be. Take a step into this tiny shop, order a cup of black coffee, a piece of toast, and walk down to the shore of the Pacific to ponder your life. I feel like this initial visit was a right of passage. A true joy. 

Note: The famed cinnamon toast is wonderful as is the peanut butter and honey variety. Both are well-worth the trek to Outer Sunset.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Three things immediately stand out at Trouble: the fresh coconuts, the cinnamon toast, and the coffee. Space is limited, but the outdoor patio is a wood lover's dream. The gibraltar is pure caffeine bliss. The lattes and mochas are done well and served in a hug-mug (the handle is replaced with a spot for your thumb). 

Many people complain about the rude service here, but what do you expect from a hipster coffee shop? Don't you notice the damn mason jars on the wall? They're serious about their coffee and are loyal to their regulars so if you come in wanting a decaf, just show yourself the door.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
I was confused when I entered bc I saw no menu so I ordered a cold brew for my boyfriend and a latte bc hey, they should have that at the least. People were more interested for their toast which looked divine might I add. Looked super tasty that I wish I ordered one. The cold brew was interesting bc it had an alcohol tasting after taste oddly, I wasn't a fan of it. The latte was good! I enjoyed it, it was on the smaller side but if I came back here I would order it again. Not the best, but it would do. Hopefully next time I'll be back for the toast. 

Don't be like me, don't skip the toast. The toast looked delicious. 

My experience here was funny they closed the shop for 10 minutes and told everyone to get out in a funny humorous manner. The vibe was great and so was everyone their.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Best breakfast in the city. 

The toast is thick and perfectly laden with rich butter and sumptuously sweet cinnamon sugar. Instead of being fussy with you lattes and espressos, just grab a regular old cup of joe to accompany this little slice of heaven. 

Right after your toast is up, devour it on any one of the many perches just outside the shop or while you walk down to the water. 

It's literally the perfect breakfast.
author: Katie B.

description: I've been going here since they opened. I'm really only writing this review because I wanted to their to be a little more balance to the 2-star reviews because of bad parking. Look, it's not complicated. If you go there when the line's out the door that's on you. I've had years of solid coffee, toast, and cookies from Giulietta and the crew. It's not a typical spot. It's not hipster. It's just coastal. You either like it or you don't. I like it when something is polarizing. Trouble rules.
author: Jacob G.

description: Hipster toast: the most overrated thing I've ever had the misfortune of enjoying.
author: Andrew R.

description:
I read the reviews about the high risk of the staff being less than pleasant here.  There are quite a few of them.  But...

Hmmm.  I'm a big girl.  I don't really need my baristas to kiss up to me or anything.  I'm there for my caffeine fix, that's all.  

But, admittedly, I also don't really need my baristas to dole out an attitude either.  We all have our days after all.  

So I went to Trouble, prepared for surliness.  But I didn't care.  I had been craving cinnamon toast for days (strangely enough); only to learn these guys do supposedly THE BEST cinnamon toast EVER.  Go figure.

I went in.  There were 2 people standing ahead of me to order, so I sat down @ the counter in the interim.  No, not to be lazy.  I had been laid up all week nursing a really bad sprained ankle (it was now Saturday).  Yes, it was obviously a premature move, but I needed to get out of the apartment!  Anyway, I regretted my decision to venture out (especially without the ankle brace) as soon as I took a few steps after getting out of my car.  #lessonlearned

So, there I was.  After a few minutes, the barista guy notices me sitting there & says "...you haven't been helped yet, have you?"

He was actually...wait for it...
Pleasant.

I said no, & that I only sat down without ordering because of my ankle, & he stopped me right there with a big smile & said "no, no.  You're totally fine.  What would you like?"

Hmmm.  NOT very surly.  At all.

I ordered The Girlfriend & the cinnamon toast.
The Girlfriend is an earl grey tea based, lavender, honey, milk concoction.  Named such because, allegedly, like having a girlfriend, "it's kinda expensive, a little complicated, but well worth it."  I'd like to personally reiterate the "WELL" in "well worth it" for all the ladies out there.  Indeed.

Now, it's what happened next that really raised an eyebrow & left a lasting impression on me, for the best...

Somehow I forgot to request soy milk.  That never happens.  I've been doing soy lattes (or almond) for well over a decade now.  But, remember, I am under duress with a sprained ankle.  So as another barista is literally making orders at the espresso machine, & since he had his back turned to me, I...

I tapped him on the shoulder.  

No joke.  This is a no-no boys & girls.  Never tap a person on the shoulder, but instead say excuse me, right?  Only with all the froth noise I was afraid he wouldn't hear me in time...

The barista turned around.

I said "don't be mad at me!"

He kinda laughed, smiled, & to my surprise did not look even the least bit perturbed.  At all.

I explained that I had just ordered The Girlfriend, but I'd like soy or almond milk please.  He said they have soy, but not almond.  And he said so in a way that was polite & most certainly NOT surly.

He was actually totally pleasant, too.  

Huh.

I mean, really.  The tapping on the shoulder woulda kinda irked me.  I've done the barista thing before.

I limped back to my car.

The cinnamon toast was OFF THE HOOK.  I scarfed down the entire thing right there, in my car, dripping butter & all.  Loved The Girlfriend.  The bergamot in the earl grey mixed with the lavender...it's wonderful.
And the guys were actually princes.
Go figure.
5 stars Trouble.
author: Veronica M.

description: Coffee is ok. Cinnamon Toast is pretty good. Service is ok but nothing was really amazing about this place. Just average. The location is cool.
author: De M.

description:
I went across the city to try this place based on some high recommendations from friends. 

They serve Intelligentsia coffee here(Solid), their toast was good and the space was cute but the service was some of the worst I have ever received. 

We came in looking for a menu and after sometime the server finally told us there wasn't one but he knew it all by heart..., he then continued to wait for us to order. (I appreciate the fact you know it by heart but this is our first time here, would you mind sharing). Since we weren't getting anywhere with that we just ordered our go to drinks a latte and an americano and  I had heard about the toast so I ordered some of those.  The server continued to make us feel like we were imposing on his time and simply not welcome. 

While waiting for our drinks my sister tried to snap a picture of the whole place for yelp when the other Batista got mad at her and told her NO PHOTOS. she apologized but it was still super awkward. 

The quality of the food was diminished by the service that we received. I get the whole "we make good food so we don't have to be nice" thing, but there are so many great coffee shops in SF that provide great coffee AND great service that I would rather take my money there.  

Go down the street to Beachside.
author: Sara P.

description: I really loved the atmosphere and the interior of the shop, but my partner and i only came in to order a fanny pack (which was recommended that i order if i want a gibralter to go) and an ice coffee, and it took them 20 minuets to get the ice coffee AFTER my partner had to ask. my drink was not even made. i had to leave fast for work but i waited patiently until i couldn't wait anymore. i'm just disappointed that they got all the "locals" their drinks before us even after they ordered later. i'm definitely turned off by the personality of the baristas and will not be returning.
author: Andrea M.

description:
Location: convenient and not crowded on a weekday morning. Nice to enjoy a hot cup of coffee with the morning fog and most along with a nice breeze - One of the most unique parts of waking up in San Francisco. 

Good drip coffee: dark roast drip - which I enjoyed.

Cinnamon toast: agree it's worth trying, but it pretty much came as expected. Tasty. Will leave it up to you to decide if it's worth the price. 
 
I will be back.
author: D S.

description: Decent coffee, terrible bratty service. If you like to be demeaned for looking at your phone and getting sass about your order then by all means, frequent this place. I however don't like self depreciating coffee in the morning, or anytime for that matter. Management please teach your baristas, especially the woman with the short brown hair, some manners or general congeniality. Though the coffee was fine, the service left a terrible lingering taste in my mouth. Yuck.
author: Koko G.

description:
Walked in with my friends and I had no idea what to get. There were no menus (or at least I didn't see any) and I felt rushed to make my order. My friend saw my mini panic attack and he ended up ordering for me lol. 

A few minutes later, I had a cup of coffee and a piece of extremely dark looking toast handed to me. I was wondering, "wtf, this is my breakfast?!" I was hoping for something savory when my friend made the order.

Fear not! After my first bite into the toast, I was amazed how delicious it was. The bread was thick, chewy on the inside with a nice little crispy crunch on the outer layer. The cinnamon on top of the toast was sweet but not overbearing. Yum yum. 

Great place to grab a quick breakfast or afternoon snack! Will be return for their other toast/pastries! :3 



Hipster rating: 11/10
author: Anna H.

description:
The three stars is honestly for the coffee. I wasn't blown away. I expected to be blown away, but I wasn't.

And usually even if the coffee was ok, but the spot was great, I'd still bump it up. However, like many have said, this is a hipster hang out. They frown upon any kind of electronics and won't let you take photos inside. Not that its actually stopped anyone clearly looking at this Yelp entry ... but they're sort of the "hey, you wait your turn and we serve you whenever we like serving you" kind of crowd.

I guess the news flash might be that this is not Paris, and in the US it's hard to get away with this kind of customer service.

Regardless, their cash only, ok-coffee spot also serves up fresh coconuts and toast. You can get their thick toast covered in something or other, perhaps cinnamon? Most people were going for the coconut and the coffee so that's what I ended up with. 

A fresh coconut is just a coconut, hard to review nature since that's how it was intended. The coffee was a little bit on the weak side fro me, and their soy was a tad too sweet for the espresso roast they were using. I might give this place a try again if I am around the area ... but I am rare in this area.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
The wait for Outerlands brought us to Trouble. I felt the pressure ordering and almost had a little anxiety attack haha. Very hipster-y joint and it gets crowded! The two guys working the register seemed a little puzzled I didn't know what I wanted right on the spot. In my defense it was my first time there and they had a couple menus scattered around the room. There's no way anyone could see this from the outside before entering the shop.

The $4 Cinnamon Toast- I cannot believe I didn't order the cinnamon toast. Kinda wish they suggested it but it's okay, next time. It smelled wonderful and looked amazing. Everyone seemed to be ordering this in the morning. It gets really stuffy in front of the cashier to the point we were asked to wait outside for our lattes. The raw sugar and cream is placed outside the storefront to prevent extra crowding. I liked my latte but nothing to rave about in comparison to other great coffee shops. If we weren't going to Outerlands I would have definitely ordered a piece of that cinnamon toast though. CINNAMON TOAST.

Oh, I wouldn't even ask if there's a bathroom here. You might get bit :)
author: Daria B.

description: Delicious almond Gibraltar made by Taylor. Appreciate the sit-down bar that makes conversation easy! Cool spot.
author: S Tziporah M.

description: Weak, weak coffee and terrible staff. Came here over the holidays for a cup of coffee and was met with weak coffee and an extremely rude barista. I did not come back home to the great city of San Francisco for the holidays to get subpar coffee and baristas with bad attitudes - this is not what this city is about
author: Angel A.

description:
Small establishment, toast, small coffee, tea, and CASH ONLY!!!

So bizarre.  Loud.  Hipster.  Apparently popular.  People lined up for it.  

Also no bathroom.  I was told to go the 'Outerlimits' restaurant up the street on the corner.

And no parking.  Street only and good luck.
author: Crystal M.

description: Fast service and good iced coffee. As far as the toast goes, I prefer the Mill's because they have more options, but I suppose there is beauty in the simplicity of two options (cinnamon sugar, or nut butter). I just prefer the Mill's bread a little more!
author: Hayley H.

description:
The reviews for Trouble Coffee on Yelp make me laugh myself to tears.

Sure, the service "sucks", and they really only do the bare minimum to get you your caffeine & pastry fix, but to be honest, I've been coming here for a while now and they've ALWAYS been like this, so I at least know what to expect each time I come for a cup of their strong coffee. Also, I'm pretty sure they KNOW they're being asshats, but, living up to their name (a la Dick's Resort or something), they just don't give a damn.

No bullshit.
No frills.
Take your coffee and get the f*ck outta here!

So, some tips:
* Don't take pictures. Cuz y'know. Privacy, invasive-ness, yadda yadda. And the "guy with the hole-y ears" (as one Yelper described him) will lay down the law if he catches you.
* I would describe this place as pretty anti-tech in that they certainly don't want the great little local surfer community in outer sunset to get swarmed with business suits dropping dolla-dolla-billz-y'all on every restaurant and cafe in the area, therefore jacking up rent prices for everyone who calls this place home. So leave the fancy shmancy stuff back in the FIDI where you came from.
* God forbid you come in with Google Glass.

Things to try:
* Cup of coffee. Seriously. It's good. Not too acidic -- just mild, good, and strong.
* Any of their specialty toasts. They do NOT skimp on that sugar and butter. Mmm.
* Their various pastries. All good stuff.

Stuff you shouldn't expect:
* Those little cardboard things to wrap around your cup. What, it's too hot? Boo hoo.
* Over the counter conversation. These baristas don't want to talk to you. Pfft.
* A sense of welcome and warmth.

Mostly, what people do here is grab coffee or coconuts together and chill on the benches outside to gab as loudly as you want. But this is definitely not the coffee place to come and buddy up with the baristas.

Trouble Coffee lives up to its name.
It's a weird-ass coffee spot that makes you feel uncomfortable and at home all at the same time.

Yup.
author: Sherilynn M.

description: I don't want to support rude customer service. I was asked to leave for waiting for my drink (after waiting outside for 20 minutes), saw 2 other people get the wrong drinks & saw the woman at the cash register reprimand a man in front of us for the way he spoke when he ordered. Weird & not worth it!
author: Lily R.

description:
I'm not sure about this place....

I've been here twice, (also Outerlands twice... there is clearly a reason for my visits to this godforsaken area of SF), and I'm impressed/pleased with ASPECTS of this shop, but as a whole I guess I just get a "meh" vibe?

I think it just really comes down to service. Or specifically, lack thereof. It's like this kind of smug (hey, South Park! you're on the money here!) slash elitist slash hipster attitude that permeates throughout. 

The bits and pieces I love? That would be the design and layout of the cramped space - cute boots tucked into shoe stands serving doubletime as a door-stop, long wooden bar, very San Franciscan clientele, fun pictures and designs on the walls and along the upper shelves. 

The stuff I hate is the complete indifference with which the staff treat the customers. I mean they're not MEAN, exactly, but there's certainly no extra mile, or heck, even extra inch, being taken to welcome patrons. My friend and I each got a latte and their famed toast (which btw, is not listed? am I just blind here?) of the peanut butter honey variety. As soon as we ordered and were about to sit on the barstools facing the outer window, a gentleman came over and told us they were closing up for a few minutes for cleaning. Good thing my friend warned me this could happen or else I would have been seriously confused/annoyed... although I was STILL annoyed, because they kicked everyone out, but we hadn't even gotten our food yet! 

When we got our toast it came on a thin sheet of parchment paper... Um, what? What am I supposed to do with this? It was completely slathered so I didn't want to touch it with my bare hands lest I be sticky-fingered forever. I looked all around the counter areas but of course there are no napkins or forks or knives or anything USEFUL. Heaven forbid we help the customers enjoy their orders with any smidgen of convenience. The girl ended up cutting it in half for me, but we still had to grip the slices gingerly with our fingers and gulp it down quickly - not exactly the most savoring experience, IMO.

Coffee is coffee, I can't remark on how phenomenal it is because it wasn't particularly mind-blowing. The toast was good, but again... just toast, albeit a monstrosity of toast (think of Asian brick toast... that's the variety).
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Just got a small latte today and it was full of flavor while having a soft finish. I will come back to enjoy more of this coffee. However, $4 gets you a small size cup and while every dollar you spend equals delicious espresso and frothed milk with a cool leaf design on it, the price is a little steep. 

Very small shop with limited seating and no posted menu that I could see. There is product in cases and the famous toast (haven't tried it yet.) I suggest going when it is not busy in order to fully enjoy your caffeinated beverage. Labeled as a "hipster" coffee shop there is plenty of that here but who cares when the coffee (at least the cup I had) is this good!
author: Nick C.

description:
I'm leaving one star for the girl with darker hair that works the register at the front. She totally disrespected my girl friend and i today flipping out on us for leaning against the wall inside while we waited a very long time for our order, then she proceeded to treat us like shit even after we moved for her. It's like she wanted to start an argument with us for no reason. All I wanted was a cup of coffee, that's it, and she made it a pretty dramatic ordeal in front of an entire shop full of customers, so kind of humiliating and embarrassing yea. I definitely will not be going back, the coffee was okay and everyone else working there seemed just fine but she was outrageous and the idea of her makes my coffee just taste like shit.

 If she reads this I want her to know by treating customers like shit she is loosing money for her boss, and I would like her to know she is just simply bad at her job. It's not cute or hip to act like that people just don't like you.
author: Hunter H.

description:
This place is super simple which is what I think makes it perfect. Avoid this place if you are a tourist please? We are thrilled you are enjoying our beautiful city but the guys that work here don't want you to ask for a menu and they sure as hell don't want to make you a non-fat vanilla frappe with extra caramel. Go to Starbucks on fisherman's wharf. 
Get a coffee or Capp and some toast. It's literally crack.
author: Sam A.

description:
To be honest, I am a follower. I heard about this place, I heard the NPR story, and follow 7x7 and wanted to try the toast. So I went to the outer sunset to try it for myself.

Even though I am a poser, I am an honest yelper. And....honestly, I think its overrated. Sure, the story is interesting but I think good customer service is 75% of an establishment.The people that work here might think they work at a place that is the s***. Which might make them on the unfriendly side. Because the cafe is so small, they are very quick and firm in asking you to wait outside. 
So I marked it off my list of places to go and I can now contribute to conversations about this place, but I probably won't be going again.  And the cinnamon toast was unique but I'm not paying that much for toast, I don't really care what story goes along with it.
author: Julianna I.

description: I came here because the locals seem to love this place, but there wasn't anything special to brag home about. The service was good but the food was a little overpriced. The cinnamon sugar toast that everyone raves about was kind of boring. I felt like it's something I could make at home and be just as satisfied about. Overall worth a try for the sake of curiosity, but probably wouldn't recommend
author: Betty T.

description:
I don't care how much history this coffee shop has... its glory days are definitely in the past. Which is a real shame. I have been trying to grab coffee here for quite some time and after years I finally made it over. Unfortunately, as others have already stated in multiple reviews, there is no menu and its cash only.... which is fine however the extremely rude (please insert your favorite curse word here) cashier is just sad. Dear over entitled self absorbed giving anyone with a mustache, thick rimmed glasses and faded t-shirts a bad name, part time coffee shop worker..... customer service jobs are optional... you clearly hate helping anyone that isn't your personal friend and feel that putting the people who pay your bills down when they step through your door is the only way to get through the day... just leave already and find a job where you don't have to meet or help people. 

No one cares if you refuse to smile, join small talk or make 20oz sugar concoctions but don't be a complete d-bag to your customers... not even necessary...

I was a barista for many years and am extremely courteous when ordering coffee or asking for alterations but when I am the only customer in your shop and my only request was to make the latte a bit less hot (because it hurts my teeth when its like lava) if its not already and your response is to chuckle at me, look back at your coworker while rudely stating "we only make things one way here....soo......" its a bit off putting. I really don't think anyone should pay that much to be bullied & belittled.... especially when the coffee isn't nearly up to par with a majority of other independent coffee shops around the city.

Moral = mediocre coffee is not enough to the poor treatment. I hope no one goes to this shop... unless the clean out the current employees for normal human beings.

Also, I have been to hundreds of coffee shops across the US and this was bar far the worst treatment I have ever been given... and clearly I was not the only person....
author: Brandi B.

description:
My goto place for a relaxed weekend evening. 

Don't come out without a cinnamon toast. They absolutely kill it. Chai's decent too. They have a no-electronics-indoor policy which is actually weird this age, but it's actually nice. They have plenty of outdoor seating. 

Used to be cash only, but they accept cards now. This place has a character to it!!
author: Vikram A.

description:
CINNAMON TOAST!! Omg so good. So tasty and sugary..! Compared to other places I've been for this awesomeness of a toast, this is probably the best one.

The atmosphere in this small cafe is so cute, they have a lot of different decorations and it looks like a real beach cafe. You should definitely grab a toast here after a nice day at Ocean Beach.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
I don't get it. Call me a yuppie. Boring. Uncultured? This place overtly hyped up by the ever growing hipster movements that has started taking over the streets of San Francisco like a scene out of the walking dead. All trying to hard to be not like the rest. While everyone just is as pretentious as the guy with awful beard next to him. End rant.
