On to this place. Small, cramped, blaring punk rock music. No menu. One toaster. 20-40 people waiting to get or order their toast. I need and want coffee I asked for a suggestion and ended up what tasted like milk with lavender. Don't get the girlfriend drink. 

The toast. Well it's just that. A slice of toast. A bananas amount of butter. Enough cinnamon sugar on top that will get you straight on the way to type 2 diabetes. In all due respect. Really nothing special at all. I have wonder bread at home.
author: Michelle I.

description:
Ok, look. I love toast. I always have.  Since I was a little kid. Just loved it. 

Used to love trouble, until the last two visits. Last time, I ordered pb toast and they gave me a regular .   I walked over, ordered a peanut butter toast and coffee.  They burned the toast. The toaster was obviously smoking and they just used the burnt piece anyways. When he handed it to me, I inspected the bottom, which was black, and said as much. He tried to laugh it off and said he would make another. 

As I waited, more people ordered toasts and coffees and such. Maybe 5 minutes later, they called out two toasts, one with pb. I pulled mine off the top of someone else's, which is weird enough. I looked at the toast and it was THE SAME ONE. I know toast and I know it was the same. He told me it was different.   It was very clearly the same one.  He tried to tell me that's just how it's toasted, which is not how I've had it every other time and the standard conventions of toast do not include carbonization. 

Also, I watched the whole time and they never made a different one. He offered a third time to make it again, which seemed pointless, so I left. 

The whole point of toast and coffee is that they get eaten together at their maximum deliciousness. I'm so sick of this. Learn how to make toast. It's not that hard. It's your job!
author: Alex T.

description: I had such a negative experience here! I've been three times and it's a great location, so really want to like a small local business. The barista who helped me on two of the locations was quite unkind and passive aggressive. The first visit was during Bay to Breakers, so I totally understood because there were a ton of people, the second time, it was a very small line and relaxed group and same barista was hostile towards my friend and me. The coffee is okay. My suggestion/tip to management is to be really clear about the menu because the baristas don't enjoy answering questions. I'll gladly update the review when this is resolved.
author: Chelsea K.

description:
If you're looking for a place to feel like you're offending someone for giving them money or want to spend a morning dealing with people who feel too pretentious to take your order but otherwise don't have the skills to make anything other than liquid variants of caffeine, you've found your place!

Your run-of-the-mill beach-bum-turned-barista coffee place. The coffee is mediocre; the staff is racist (which is ironic considering the founder is from Baltimore and is proud of all the connections made through the coffee shop); there is no menu in the shop and assumes the customer /should/ know them by magic. 

Trouble coffee might be interesting for about five minutes, and then it devolves into self-absorbed jokes that humiliate clientele. 

If the trouble that Trouble Coffee is attempting to brew is racial tensions, it's doing a great job - with a slice of pretty good cinnamon toast.

They also hate techies.
author: Mary L.

description:
Cool spot, pretty unique.

Worth it for a once-in-a-lifetime experience. Too expensive to be a regular stop. The toast would always be worth it, but the coffee is very average. $15 for 2 pieces of toast and 2 coffees. Neat experience overall. Parking is rough. Good luck finding any on the street. Best bet is to park across the street at the 7/11, buy a water (and keep the receipt) to keep from getting towed, and then to walk it.

Neat spot and great toast! We'll continue to bring family and friends when they visit!
author: Jarrod F.

description:
There's seriously no menu. I asked the barista if I could see what drinks they offered, and I thought he was kidding when he said he'd make me anything I could think of. He ended up making me 'the girlfriend,' which was a lavender earl grey latte. So good! The flowery flavors were very dominant, which I loved. The bf got a regular drip coffee - pretty standard and appropriately strong.

We couldn't leave without trying the toast. We shared the buttered cinnamon and the peanut butter & honey. I loved the cinnamon and how the brown sugar crystalized on the top of the toast to provide a delicate crunch. The bf preferred the pb/honey one. It was really sticky and rich, but there was a nice balance of sweet and salty. The toast was the perfect compliment to our coffee.

This place is very small and it can only seat about 6-7 people inside at a time. There are a couple of benches outside though. It's also quite pricy and cash only, but there's an ATM nearby.
author: Nicole P.

description:
"they may have a no Nora Jones policy"

There's coffee. There's toast. There's no menu. But - thats not really why one goes to TCC.

Its a concept. I think its explained on the blackboard that hangs on the door.

The yelp stars this place gets are for the unique spin it puts on something as boring as a coffee shop.  Coffee and toast are OK too.

Like anything with lots of character - TCC wont appeal to mass taste. If you just want coffee - starbucks or peets may be a better call. Most will either love it or hate it. Thats what makes it so good.


PS:  You will not hear Norah Jones at a reasonable volume level at trouble. If you do - you're not in Trouble
author: Oleg H.

description: Crowded. Full of hipsters. Not really any room to sit. Ordered a latte and one of their buttered cinnamon toasts. The latte didn't do it for me but the toast was pretty good. If I was just looking for a spot to pick up a cup of coffee id prob go elsewhere.
author: Linz C.

description: I needed my caffeine fix and decided to come here since their coffee is strong.  I got the dirty chai and it was good.  It was spicy and exactly what I needed, but with that being said, I HATE this place.  The staff is rude, unfriendly and pretentious as hell.  I don't know what it is with their snobby attitude... Sorry I don't have a million tattoos or piercings... or wear a beanie with huge, lensless glasses.  I can't ignore their TERRIBLE TERRIBLE service. BYE FELICIA! I won't be back.
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
Great coffee.  Damn delicious toasts (I love the Cinnamon and peanut butter honey) and a good dose of attitude.  Whoever designed the place, does the staffing & runs it has spunk.  He/she/they must have a damn good dose of self worth.  Kudos man. 
I see so many Yelpers bemoan the nasty attitude and poor service.  Quit complaining.  This is a coffee joint, not a spa salon.  You come, you order, you leave.  You don't need the baristas to validate you, smile at you, or coo to your feelings. That's what friends & pets are for...
I had the "Build your own damn house" and I loved it.  Will be coming back often.
author: Michael L.

description:
One of the more quintessential up-to-the-minute San Francisco coffee shops became more than a good Instagram opportunity yesterday when I tried my very first Trouble toast.

What I like most about the place is the simplicity. Rather than cater to a variety of taste pallets, they just please everyone with toast. Classic and easy.

But of course I had to go beyond their standard toast and splurge for honey and peanut butter. If you like honey, this is your jam. If not, just ask for PB. 

If you've been living under a rock and haven't been in Trouble yet, get out of the Mission and head over to the sunset.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This place is awesome.  I recently moved to the area and have heard of Trouble.  Everyone says it's a must if you're a coffee fanatic..which I am.  

For starters...this is a really small coffee shop.  However that's perfect, given where it's located.  It's just a few blocks from the beach.  You can grab a quick caffeine fix then head down to the sand on a hot day (which is rare in SF).  But that's not the best part, out front they have a really cool seating area where locals commune and catch up.  I've already met a few locals and their dogs.  Really great people.  

The pastries they have are awesome.  A lot of people say they are known for their toast...it's great and I get it often but it's just one type of toast and it's not the best thick slice toast I've had.   The cups they use are the traditional 8oz cups.  So don't be alarmed when you ask for a latte and don't get that giant size cup you would get from Starbucks..that's just not normal. 

The reason I give this place 4 out of 5 is because everything adds up except one.  Occasionally the vibe the staff/baristas give off is often rude.  They yell, seem standoffish or just like they want you to get in, order, and get out.  This is not all the time and I know everyone has their days...but this has happened a few times.  Other than that the staff there is great and don't let that stop you from checking out this great little coffee shop.  I will definitely be back here.
author: Josh F.

description:
I was really excited to try Trouble from all the things I'd heard about it. But overall, for me it was just ok. The pastries were good (didn't adequately stalk on yelp and there was no menu to know we should have ordered toast) and the coffee was fine. 
It kind of struck me as a place where regulars feel at home, but for a first-timer it was hard to figure out. A menu would have been helpful.
author: Marilyn M.

description:
I try to leave my lost/confused look at home but when I stepped inside, I didn't see a menu! Dun dun duNnnNnnn.... Confused look on full blast!  

Good thing the barista was super friendly and patient with me.  I asked him what they offer and he listed their items.  

Coconut juice!?  You serve coconut juice at a coffee shop?!  

Toast-  thick slice of lightly toasted bread topped with cinnamon and sugar.  

Them coconuts though.... that just baffles me.
author: Linda N.

description: This is the worst I've ever been treated by a staff in any business... How do you forget an order, and then tell me "You must have finished it without realizing it"? I demanded my money back, and they refused. They literally stole from me.
author: Nathan S.

description:
soooo we walked in here after brunch at the corner at outer lands (highly recommended) to pick up some caffeine before hitting the road.
Guy at the counter was fine, able to help my friend and I order a drink sans menu. All fine. 

So then I get my drink In a glass and asked the barista if I could have it in a to go cup. he gives me a dirty look, says no, and turns back to his next drink... thought he was kidding but he wasn't so I asked the counter guy for a cup as we were leaving which he gave me without question.cool,thanks. the drink was decent. BUT a rude barista makes for a bad taste!

womp womp
author: Caitlin G.

description:
Hip, small, with tasty toast.  Went on a Sunday morning and there was a long line as expected. Waited quite a bit but wasn't mad about it, seemed pretty typical for the day and time I went. Don't expect too much, it's a small place and the baristas are working through a large volume of orders. 
You aren't going to sip and savor your latte on a comfy chair inside-you're more likely to be chilling outside waiting for your name to be called. If that's not your vibe, this is not your place. Had a cappuccino and a pice of cinnamon toast before heading to the beach. Judah St is a cute street with shops and restaurants, worth the stroll. Yummy, would go back.
author: Monica O.

description:
TOASTTTTTT! =D

While I'm aware that it is ludicrous to pay $3.50 for a piece of toast, I still couldn't stay away. The pictures made the bread look so delicious and I heard positive things about Trouble from my co-worker so I knew it was time I checked the place out. 

Trouble is definitely a hole in the wall hipster's paradise. I arrived around 12:30 on a Sunday and there was a pretty long line outside the door, but it moved quickly and soon I was at the register. I didn't see a menu, but thanks to Yelp I knew I wanted the cinnamon sugar toast which I promptly ordered. The guy at the register was a little surly and distracted, but the guy to the right who was making the toast was really nice and asked me for my name so they could call me when my order was ready. 

After 5 minutes I had my toast!! It was delicious and definitely worth the $3.50 price tag. Thick cut, drowning in butter and doused with a heavy helping of cinnamon, this was some of the yummiest sugary toast I have ever eaten. Be careful of getting the cinnamon everywhere! I had to spread the cinnamon around a bit because it hadn't soaked into the butter all the way and I didn't want to inhale pure cinnamon ;) 

It was really chill to have a piece of toast and relax on the big tree they have outside the shop. A very cool atmosphere to come with some friends, relax, eat toast and drink coffee. Definitely a treat and I look forward to coming back, but maybe in a month or two since I can buy a whole loaf of bread for the price of a slice here =)
author: Sam F.

description:
Can't say much about this place since I didn't get to try anything. Went in to order and was ignored by the people who work there. They were too busy talking to their friends to ask me what I wanted to order even when I was standing right at the cashiers spot and the only one in line. After standing there waiting for a while I realized they were just being rude and I left. It's too bad, I heard good things about their coffee.

I would suggest walking a couple blocks over to Andytown or one of the other cafes. There is plenty of good coffee in this area served with nicer attitudes.
author: Kathleen D.

description: I lived in the outer sunset for 4 years but I just had a chance to try their toast. OMG the cinnamon toast is so yummy!
author: Geetha M.

description:
I came here on a cloudy day with a family friend on a short visit to San Francisco. We had toast and black coffee from Trouble while we went for a walk on the beach and watched her dog play in the waves. I loved the story behind this little cafe and found the people working inside, or visiting, just as delightfully quirky. 

I'll be back for another cinnamon toast and strong black coffee -- it reminded me of my favorite series of scenes from Patti Smith's M Train.
author: Diana E.

description:
To the extent that toast can cost this much and be worth it, this toast was worth it. It seems insane but you really wouldn't be able to eat a second slice so it's pretty effective as a whole breakfast.

Black coffee is kinda meh.
author: Misha T.

description: The coffee is great. Got just a regular coffee and a latte two separate times and both were amazing. Their cinnamon sugar toast is so good. We also loved their peanut butter honey toast. It's a gem of a place in the sunset of San Fran. Loved it.
author: Cristin H.

description: So, so, so slow (25 minutes AFTER ordering). Staff is borderline rude when I attempted to check on my order.
author: Justin R.

description: My favorite place in the whole wide world **Happy Heart**
author: Sha L.

description:
Toast is fantastic but I wouldn't make a special trip...because it's just toast.

Came in here on a weekend morning and ordered a latte, a coffee and the cinnamon toast. This place is tiny with no menu and cash only. It was quite busy, with a line out the door but it moved relatively quickly. After we ordered, however, I think we waited almost 20 minutes for our coffees. 

The latte and coffee were fine. The toast was simple but delicious. Thick bread, slathered with butter and dusted with cinnamon for a nice salty-sweet combination. There's a nice set of wooden log benches outside to enjoy your coffee and toast on.

However, the service (as mentioned by others) really is terrible. It's one thing to be short or brusque when things are busy, it's another to be outright rude. As I waited (and waited) for my coffee I watched the baristas mock, scold and generally be rude to customers for minor infractions (ordering in a way that the barista did not like, looking at phones, making requests to modify coffee drinks, etc.) I'm sure this is all part of the vibe they are trying to convey but it wasn't for me. 

Overall, if you live in the neighborhood or are waiting for your Outerlands reservation it's a good place to stop in and grab something delicious.
author: Ana D.

description: Great spot and a really cool scene. They do nice cups of coffee and espresso drinks as well as great baked goods and toast. Come here grab a cup and sit on their amazing "fallen tree" parklet. Good for people/pupper watching.
author: Anthony S.

description:
I like the small-near-the-beach feel. I heard about this place from NPR, and I am amazed and encouraged by the owner's story. 

I do agree that this place is overpriced, the "Build your own damn house" (coffee, toast, coconut) is $11.50, when I think it should be priced at $9. I probably won't come here again, as I usually don't walk up Judah. However, I enjoyed the casual atmosphere and wooden benches. 

I also happen to love young coconut.
author: Amadeia R.

description: I don't understand how it is so annoying when people order what you have for sale. With so many choices out there for coffee you'd think there would be a little less eye rolling. It's not they are magical beans. Whatever though. I'm just writing all this so my one star will be registered. I'll go get my coffee with the friendly 7-11 guy across the street.
author: anthony m.

description:
3.5 stars for coffee. Nice finish, low acidity but nothing super special and 4 bucks for a small cup.
1 star for service. Forgot my order. I waited forever for them to remake it. Guy at front has smug attitude and no remorse
author: Jennifer L.

description:
based on what i saw on yelp, i was fully prepared to get verbally slaughtered when ordering the earl grey and lavender latte (i couldn't remember that it was called the girlfriend), but the guy was fine. and he told me that the pb/honey/cinnamon sugar toast was called the holy shit toast, but not in a condescending or mean way at all. and my friends and i all whipped out our cameras/phones (despite the "no electronics" sign); none of the employees said anything or sneered. they just ignored us, how a normal employee would. so i'm not sure what everyone's talking about when they said the employees were pompous and hipster and rude.

the holy shit toast is pb, honey, cinnamon sugar on thick josey baker toast. the bread was kind of like bread you get for honey toast, but with a thicker crumb and a sturdier crust. it wasn't omg bread, but it was smothered under some heavy stuff, so it makes sense that the bread wasn't the main star. and wow, that's a good combo. it's very sweet, but i like my sugar. i've made it at home since, and it's so satisfying.

the girlfriend is their earl grey lavender latte. i took it to go for the ride home. i let it steep for 30 minutes before tasting it (it was too hot before) and it got very lavendery and gross. i added a lot more milk and a tiny bit of maple syrup when i got home and it was a lot more pleasant and mild and lightly earl grey ish.

would i go back? probably not. but did i enjoy it while i was there? definitely.
author: Heather F.

description:
We came because we heard that Trouble was the origin of the "artisan toast" trend in SF, and because of the interesting piece we heard on This American Life.  

The reason for the low rating is that all of us in our group (3 adults, 1 kid) had enormous headaches after eating the cinnamon toast.  Sugar overload!!!!  I know many customers come for exactly this, but it was way over the top for us.  1" thick white bread lathered with butter, then peanut butter, then honey.  We seriously all had headaches.  

If you're a person with normal sugar intake, this place will overwhelm you.  If you must try it, it may help to hydrate in advance, and exercise right afterwards (and/or eat something heavy in fiber).

But I am personally not coming back.
author: Krishna N.

description:
It's hard to hate on Trouble Coffee. Yes, it's a hole in the wall. Yes, it's run by hipsters. Yes, there's always a crowd. But I've never had to wait that long and never had surly service. I love the parklet they've created outside (it's better to come on a day where you'll be comfortable outside as inside there's only seating for 5 people). It's got a great community vibe.

I finally tried their cinnamon toast. $3.50 for toast you might ask? It's pretty awesome. A thick slice of white bread toasted nicely then slathered with butter and sprinkled with sugar and cinnamon. Not great value I will admit but still a great idea and best execution. Those too lazy should just get it because it's that good. But now that I've had it once I can recreate it myself - thanks Trouble!
author: Jean K.

description: I find myself craving Trouble more than I should.  Everything about this café is perfect from the simple menu to the outdoor seating and cozy neighborhood feel.  The original $4 toast, trouble is the spot to come to and throwback to the childhood staple of PB&J.  The perfectly thick cut toast with a generous portion of peanut butter, honey, cinnamon, jam, or/and butter literally just melts in your mouth.  Anyone who mentions 'poor' or 'rude' service from the staff here is out of their mind.  Do yourself a favor and listen to NPRs "This American Life" episode featuring the owner/operator of Trouble Coffee Co. and you will be completely blown away by the badass businesswoman behind Trouble.  Her story literally makes this place that much better and coming here is an experience you can only find in SF. Quirky, simple, delicious, and perfect start to your day.  Grab your toast, an espresso and grab a seat on the parklet outside, people watch, get some rays, enjoy.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
This place is fantastic. It's small, straight-to-the-point, and only does a few things; and the things they do, they do REALLY well. We came in to grab some iced coffee, and it was so good we came back 2 hours later for more. On the second visit we picked up some cinnamon toast, which was also excellent. 

Staff was fantastic, and some cute kids made faces through the glass at us from the pre-school next door. 

It's way out in the Outer Sunset, but if I'm ever in that neighborhood again, I'll be back without a doubt. Infact, its the first place I'll go.
author: Laura J.

description: Excellent coffee and tasty toasts but handling food with bare hands after touching money and wiping the counter, not that appetizing...
author: Jasmine M.

description:
Discovered Trouble Coffee when I was apartment hunting in the Outer Sunset area. It's a tiny place with seating maybe for 7 people. I like coming here when you want real coffee. Not your Starbuck's flavored sweet coffee which to me isn't real coffee. You enter to the intoxicating aroma of sweet and bold smells that gets me all giddy.

I have tried the:

Gibraltar ~ a double-shot of espresso and a bit of milk. It's like a latte but stronger. Smooth and delicate with a bit of a punch.

"Build Your Own Damn House" ~ comes with a coffee, young coconut, and a piece of cinnamon toast.  Perfect  hangover cure and really hits the spot after a "late night" with the caffeine to wake you up, the bread to soak up whatever is left in your stomach and the coconut juice to hydrate.  What a simple yet genius combo!!! Must try!

Cinnamon Toast ~ made on thick, chewy slices of bread from Just For You Bakery in Potrero Hill. It's perfectly proportioned, rich with cinnamon, and made using top notch butter, to boot. That bread, though, really puts this toast over the edge. You can't come to Trouble without trying this.

CASH ONLY.  I keep getting into "Trouble" because simply put it is straightforward uncomplicated coffee which is just plain good. Five stars!!!
author: Maria M.

description: Trouble Coffee is a very eclectic coffee shop with a minimal menu. If you are looking for an independent Starbucks-style coffee shop, this is not the place for you. Their coffee itself is of very good quality and you can tell when you taste it, however, if you are not a big fan of drinking coffee with no sugar or cream, again, this is not your place. Both times I have been here, the condiment bar was completely out of everything except Sugar in the Raw, which is not a great sugar choice because it is so large, it does not mix well. In addition, I am not sure the employees working were in the business of restocking it because I made it pretty obvious it was ill-equipped both times and no one jumped at the opportunity to help out. However, their employees were very friendly and patient with us and their peanut butter toast is pretty darn good! I will be back if the chance arises, just for the toast. I totally would give 5 stars, but not until they can manage their space a little better and keep things well stocked. There is really no excuse for that. I have worked service jobs for many years and it is not that hard to walk outside their 300sqft to go refill the condiment station. Overall, the place has a nice vibe and a cool guy sits outside and plays music for the patrons. Worth a try, but show up with the right expectations. :)
author: Jade F.

description: Really not sure if my "girlfriend" was poorly made but my coffee had too much early grey to milk ratio ruining my drink altogether. Had already left the city for a few errands so just had to throw it out.
author: Vanessa O.

description: My absolute favourite coffee shop. Flavorful lattes prepared by your hipster crew. The cinnamon toast is delicious! We always get a bag of their trouble beans home, they taste amazing
author: Andreea C.

description: Before stopping at Outerlands, I wanted some coffee. First thing I thought was "this reminds me of Abraco in NYC". Limited seating and blasting underground hip hop but the comparison stops there. I got a cappuccino and the last coffee cake. Both were decent and I would come back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Kien M.

description:
I heard about the place through the NPR thing and was inspired to come here. The place is cute and the toast is a nice treat. Love the coconut water and the twisted tree bench outside. Coffee is okay. I wouldn't come back unless their service improves though.  

  It was my first time going there with some friends and we noticed that there was no menu (which is fine, lots of places do this) so we asked what kinds of toast they had.  Yet for some reason the guy at the cash register decided to give us useless, obscure answers and had a "too cool to tell you" attitude.  We asked him a couple times but he kept avoiding the question and even seemed impatient that we were asking him.

So what we ended up doing was point out the toast that other people were having (Cinnamon).  When we finally saw someone else with a different option (Peanut butter honey), we added that too but he seriously looked unhappy that we weren't done with our order.  Is it an SF thing? to keep everything a secret from new customers? I don't know but it's not that hard to say  "cinnamon and peanut butter toast"... c'mon now
author: Doto H.

description:
It's a simple menu, but it works! We aren't coffee drinkers, so we ordered toast and coconuts. The toast took a long time to arrive, but they warned us it would. It was worth the wait! The coconuts were very good, but the hole cut in the top of one of them was barely big enough to stick a spoon in. No big deal - it was cool to eat a coconut with a straw and a spoon.

I'm glad we went. I'd been curious about this place ever since I learned about it on This American Life. I'm very impressed by the courage and fortitude of the owner. It's a cool concept, a neighborhood gem and an inspiration. The opposite of Trouble, actually.  :)
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Great coffee, a great environment, and cool people.

I originally heard about trouble because of their toast, which really is great. The combination of their coffee and toast is perfect, but really I would probably only get the toast every now and then just so I don't get sick of it from eating it too often.

The vibe of the place is very homegrown, punk, get shit done, but also welcoming. Try this place out, and don't be scared by the fact that they don't have menus in the open. Just ask the cashier about their stuff, or look at pictures of the menu posted to yelp.

Go! You won't regret it!
author: Jake C.

description:
I've been here twice and the toast this place serves is good, but nothing I can't make at home. However, the coffee here is delicious, it has the perfect intensity to drink it black, because the roast isn't too dark.

Prices here are excellent considering the portion size and the location it's in. Cash only, by the way. 

Service is subpar, the two cashiers I've had weren't very friendly, although I've had worse service. At least they were helpful in explaining their menu items.
author: John A.

description: The guy working the cash register immediately was mean and made derogatory comments. Just because we may not look hipster or from San Fransisco (which we are) doesn't mean we can't come to your spot. Other than pretty bad customer service, their coconut chocolate bar was good.
author: Leslie A.

description:
Tea I had was excellent, but experienced one of the most passive aggressive customer service experiences in a long time. 

"That soliloquy in the corner was me talking about how much I want to go home. But you still didn't notice."

That was at 7:05, when yelp says they close at 8:00pm. 

They may actually close at 7pm. And I'm happy to leave when they close. 

But that is a really unnecessary way of letting us know that you want us to leave. I am not listening to you talk in the corner. 

Just be direct and ask me to leave.
author: alexis l.

description: Coffee is great but the wait is so long... And the will yell at u to wait outside lol
author: Bulgaa G.

description:
Fabulous coffee!!! Think straight forward, no bells and whistles. But solid amazingly flavorful coffee. We ordered a cold brew, a mocha and an espresso. The cold brew had intense chocolate flavors which somehow resembled chocolate pudding in a good way. The mocha had a perfect balance of chocolate and espresso. The espresso was flavorful, strong and not bitter.

For food, we ordered the much talked about cinnamon toast. They mastered this way before the mill. Good, but still hard to accept paying three plus dollars for a piece of toast.

And for the piece de resistance? A whole fresh coconut served with a straw and a spoon. I will never look at coconut water he same way. So darn good.

The only bummer is there is no menu. Before I've consumed coffee, it is hard for me to think on the fly.  It is great that they can offer the standards, but I'd like options it choose from. 

Stick with the items we ordered, and you can't go wrong!!!
author: Victoria O.

description: Awesome location with one of the best parklets in the city.  Great toast, good coffee.  Servers seemed pretty smug and weren't that friendly.  That parklet though, A+.
author: John S.

description:
Trouble coffee did not meet my expectations, with at least 5 other coffee shops down the street I was disappointed I chose this one. Here's why:
Menu- 1- doesn't exist. I understand this is on purpose, but as others have mentioned in previous reviews it causes the customer a little anxiety. 
Employees/service- 3- service was alright and they were kind
Payment- 1- cash only, I just don't understand this when most people don't carry around cash anymore. A square credit card reader is an inexpensive investment for a company
Size- 2 - the coffee was served in a tiny cup
Coffee- 4- I had a latte and it did taste great! Nothing special though
Price- 2 - it was still $4 for a latte, but when the portions are so small it is even more difficult to justify keeping pricing the same as surrounding coffee shops

Over all I give it a 2. Get a menu, except credit cards, get some bigger cups & I would give this place a 4
author: Alex E.

description:
There's really no trouble trouble. The coffee is delicious the staff is mostly nice. They just stick to their Rules. Which are not posted anywhere. I can respect that.  I like to make up my own rules too.

In this digital age it's hard to avoid people tweeting Facebook and yelping or taking photos of your place but they are pretty adamant they do not like photos of the inside of their facility. 

So I guess the moral is if you're supposed to get in trouble at trouble coffee then Take photos inside. 

Mission accomplished.
author: Joseph M.

description:
I had barely gotten in the door of this place and started to take a picture of my husband when one of the hipster baristas so kindly told me "You know, we don't really like our pictures taken." Excuse me? I quickly responded that I had no interest in taking a picture of him (narcissistic, just a little?), that I was taking a picture of my husband. He then proceeded to glare at me (I'm surprised a small, blonde woman in a bright pink North Face Jacket intimidated a grown man so much he felt the need to have a stare down with me, but, okay...). 

Apparently this coffee shop is SO good that they can be total you know whats to their customers and people will just keep coming back for more - we actually walked out. I hope all of the snobby hipsters who like abuse with their coffee keep you in business forever. At least until you become too "mainstream" for them and they drop you like they secretly drop $200 on designer jeans they're trying to pass off as "worn-in."

 PS - Rude, hipster barista jerk - I posted your picture here for everyone to see. Check it out.
author: Ashlee C.

description:
Yeah so maybe you should have the right hours posted on this yelp page, and you may wanna correct your employees attitude when people come from far to make it on time before you close then get additional attitude from mentioning the hours on your yelp page are wrong!!! "Colin" didn't even wanna give me his name let alone answer to me when I asked who maintains this page. It's pretty bad you sell 8oz of espresso for $5 then you have the wrong hours listed and bad costumer service. 

I would put a zero but I can't!!!

thanks
Colin :(
author: THE F.

description:
Great vibe in this well known coffee shop. I'm one street over so this has been the go-to stop and shop coffeehouse for me before hoping on the the transit.

Multiple types of beans, coffee blends and roasts with a nice food menu that includes the ever so sought after toast! Have not tried that yet but maybe if they see this post they will give us a good a reason to walk a street over for a cup of coffee and toast! 

Staff is educated and eager to help, looking to help any new customers, and we greatly appreciate it! Get the Americano
author: John R.

description:
If I could give it a negative rating I would!They say 'we can make what you want' but are unable to make a single espresso shot Cappuccino--apparently doubles only. 
Then I tried to post a pic of the pretty espresso cup but was told "electronics are not allowed inside, but I can go take a pic outside". I thought he was joking. Nope! 2 min later HE PLUGS IN HIS IPOD n cranks the music. 
Rude. Ridiculous. No menu. And paying for attitude to boot--No thanks! Lost 2 customers that day. I've lived in outer sunset 12yrs, drink coffee regularly and never been treated sooo poorly.
author: Christina V.

description:
I've been there three times and that will be it.  Hummm that's about a year ago.  This review is about my last experience. 
I normally take my coffee black but I wanted to explore this place, so I asked for a menu.  The guy said they didn't have a menu.  So I asked him what they had.  His answer - "Coffee".  The f%&k?  Don't I know that already? 
I had credit cards only so I couldn't order anything. I do have problems with business that takes cash only.  Shady business....
Yes, baristas have attitude that tells you "we are too cool to be here" like the other yelper said. 
Not going back again.
author: C MH L.

description:
I heart this place because it's so neighborhood-y. I've been here a couple of times, but the best time to go is when it's not busy. Then you can have a good chat with the barista. He gave me the low down on how the "community green area" was put together. They have a lovely driftwood log and a small bench area built out on the street, with obvious city permits and a collaboration of neighborhood donations. It's perfect to sit there on a warm sunny day (although it's not that common in  the outer sunset.)
Can't believe they've been there for nearly 5 years and really put outer sunset on the map- being featured in magazines (with the adjacent Outerlands cafe and the General Store.
Nothing can beat the smell of Hammerhead fresh coffee beans- had to pick up a bag to bring home a little of this goodness!
yes- and bring some cash and make sure you don't need the restroom (they don't have one)
author: Naomi K.

description:
Exactly what I expected: good coffee, fresh young coconut, and the best cinnamon toast imaginable. Thickly cut, smothered in butter and cinnamon sugar -- better than your average cinnamon bun by a mile. 

Extra pluses: cute and informal sidewalk seating with felled wood and a succulent garden and a variety of baked goods.

Wish I could come here every morning!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I'm a little bashful to admit that I sought this place out after hearing the story of the founder on This American Life. I read a few reviews mentioning some rudeness on the part of the staff and can't say I blame them, if others were doing what I did. However I popped in on a quiet afternoon and struck up a conversation with the two gentlemen in the shop. They were very pleasant to me, and very interesting to talk to. Not to mention the coffee was top notch. As was the toast. And the grapefruit juice. 

I told them I was a little nervous, as a lifelong east coaster, to be moving to the west coast, but that if Giulietta (founder of Trouble) could do what she did and find people who could help her and make a living for herself and do pretty well, I had nothing to fear. In short, I went looking for Trouble to find more than just coffee, and I found it. Thanks guys.
author: Lauren E.

description:
If you're looking for a great cup of coffee and have all the time in the world, this place is great! If you have somewhere to be, they will pour free drinks for their surfer friends who came in after you and THEN they'll make your drink. 

There were 3 cups in front of mine, but they poured 8 drinks before mine, and it took 17 minutes.
author: George S.

description:
I've heard so much hype about their cinnamon toast and Idk but I was expecting something magical.. But sad to say it wasn't. It was literally just a thick piece of toast with butter and cinnamon sugar. I feel like I could've made that at home myself. 

Maybe the peanut butter and honey would be better? Or maybe the guy messed up my toast or something? I'm not sure, but I'd give it another shot and maybe try their coffee too.
author: Krystelle D.

description: Best latte I have had in awhile. The espresso and milk are the right ratio so you can taste the espresso without being overwhelmed by the milk. The espresso is delicious.
author: Erika L.

description:
The coffee and toast is okay, nothing special.  

It took them 30 minutes to make 2 cups of coffee and one slice of toast for us.  Yes, the place was busy but a cup of drip coffee should never take that long.  People who ordered after us got their coffee and toast before we did which really sucks.  The hipster baristas seem to be more interested in looking cool and talking to their friends about how hungover they are after last night's drinking session than running and efficient coffee shop.  

This place is all style and very little substance, just like every other hipster-run cafe in SF these days.  Let's hope the owner's parents don't find out what they are doing with their trust fund...
author: D D.

description: Let me start by saying this place has killer cinnamon toast. I came here in the pouring rain, with that toast in mind, and it didn't disappoint, which is why this place still gets a couple stars. The bread was actually a little whiter than I remembered, but it's still a solid comfort food. I sat down at a counter seat where a young female employee had been sitting moments earlier, flirting with some guy. I was about 3 bites in, when she unceremoniously kicked me out, into the rain, so she could "mop the floor."  No humor and zero good will. They weren't closing and no one mentioned when I ordered that they would be briefly shutting down.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Horrible.  No organic coffee.  $4.00 for a cup of watered-down 3.00 per pound coffee feom costco. Extra charge for a splash of almond milk. Girl at the register informed me he's  living in the most expensive city. thing about that is that when you charge, like idk TWICE AS MUCH for a coffee, you should recieve more for your money... Like if it was organic, fair trade, locally roasted, or at least not tasting like crap and wateredbdown to save 0.00002% of their expenses.

this place rips off a bunch of kids who don't know any better than to go somewhere else. I will gladly support other shops which even give half a care about what they're doing.
author: Lifay L.

description: The coffee is great the baristas are very rude. I stumbled upon this coffee shop and it has interesting decorations. As I was taking a picture the barista were rude as can be. Do not recommend. Great coffee but not worth it.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
I appreciate that Trouble isn't trying to be all things to all people; it's unapologetically odd (fresh coconut on a cafe menu, wassup with that anomaly?!), simple, & tyrannical in their cash only/no decaf coffee policies. 

Ain't gonna lie, the friendly hipster toast maker guy was an unexpected delight, thank you for puttin' a bit of sunshine in my foggy, overcast morning, Sir. Like a well-oiled machine, he kept up with customers' demands for toast. The extra thick slice of white gets warm & toasty, is slathered with buttah, stabbed to death, then is blanketed in an obscene amount of cinnamon & sugar which seeps into its stab wounds. First bite takes you to a sweet, familiar place, even if you didn't eat this in your childhood.

Trouble doesn't just do toast well (trying their peanut butter/lavender honey toast next), their baked goods are also a hit -- PB cookie topped with a peanut butter cup & this chewy chocolate granola bar creation -- just a few more reasons to get your ass out to the Sunset.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Love their lattes!

Haven't tried their amazing toast yet.... but I've seen the cashier guy using his hands holding toast with one hand and spread butter with a knife without gloves or antyhing. Makes me kinda cringe. Even IF (key word IF) he washes his hands, it's still not good enough. 

Don't like how they don't even have a menu. I know they like being different, but I still want to see what options I have. I saw menus on Yelp but when I went in with a friend, we were told that they don't have any.
author: Erica L.

description:
This is my go-to ocean beach coffee shop. This last time I went for the girlfriend -- a lavender earl grey latte. The way the guy explained it, it's kinda expensive, a little high maintenance, but totally worth it. And it was. A little sweet with honey and a hint of vanilla but totally perfect (I don't like my drinks very sweet, I want it to taste like tea!)

Also tried their cinnamon toast, just some thick white bread and butter and more butter and cinnamon... Soooo good.

They also custom make whatever you want, for the non-caffeine drinker, they make a mean rooibos latte, with soy milk perhaps?

I just love the atmosphere -- neighborhood people, surfers, dogs, kids, everyone just chilling and taking a moment to enjoy life. Also the baristas crack me UP!

PS menu on the wall to right of cashier.
author: Vivian H.

description: Great coffee, great vibe.  Waited 30 minutes for our toast, and had to leave so unfortunately did not get to try it.
author: Kate B.

description:
I don't care what anyone else says - this is THE place for toast in SF. Delicious, butter thick-cut toast that's seriously addicting.

Don't count on a seat inside. Coffee, toast, perhaps a coconut, and go. Want a bit of history? Listen to Trouble's This American Life Segment on your trek there:
http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/520/no-place-like-home?act=3
author: Jessica O.

description:
Trouble Coffee epitomizes the stereotype of overrated hipster coffeeshop: the staff is plain unfriendly and pretentious.

Meanwhile everything on the menu from the coffee drinks to the baked goods is solidly average.

Therefore any other hip coffeeshop in the city will have at least as good food and drink, and with humane service: you have nearby options Java Beach, very close to the ocean a couple blocks down the street, and Andytown, a couple blocks south and away from the ocean, that fit the bill.

The only cool thing about this place is the tree-trunk seating area in the parklet - this is pretty awesome! But fortunately since it's a public parklet, you don't need to be a customer to enjoy it.
author: G K.

description: This place is TINY!  Still, nice coffee shop.  No menus so a little hard to figure out what they serve.  But the barista helped me find a decaf latte-alternative (herba mate latte) that was actually really good.  Love the local color too.
author: Seth E.

description:
Trouble Coffee lives up to it's billing. Trouble is an hole in the wall with a couple seats selling just coconuts, expresso, and cookies(2.5).

brew: (sm 2) la paz coffee
-smooth semibold coffee, well worth it.

drips:
-friendly service
-cookies not labeled, probably homemade for 2.5
author: Victor G.

description: Everything that everyone else has said is true except I got two of the most coolest baristas and the cinnamon toast was delicious! It's not just toast. It's just damn good cinnamon toast that someone else made.
author: Sharise H.

description:
This place is cash only, and doesn't have a menu due to it's simplicity.

Yay! I'm a fan of their cinnamon butter toast. The toast has the perfect balance between soft and crispy/crunchy. You can feel the butter melt in your mouth - yum!! I would definitely come back for their toast. 

Got their version of a green tea latte (genmaicha with jasmine?) with soymilk (they only have soy as an alternative) and thought it was decent. Warning: You have to walk outside to sweeten it yourself, so the first sip might taste watered down. Felt a little bit disappointed with this.

Loved the decor of the place, especially the giant tree trunk bench outside.
author: Annie L.

description: Bookmarked this place a while back for their peanut butter honey toast and "girlfriend" (earl grey with honey and lavender), and they did not disappoint when I finally made it out one gloomy Saturday morning. The toast was thick but even the crusts were still pretty soft (this coming from a no-crust-ever girl) and the gorgeous swirls of honey on peanut butter were ooey and gooey with each bite. So good. And the earl grey was just the right amount of sweetness to go with it. I wish I lived closer so I could have the combo every weekend!
author: Kathy L.

description:
It's worth the trek on the N Judah for the popular cinnamon toast but I can finally admit after over a dozen visits that the coffee is terrible - always burnt and bitter (except for that one time) and I've had it via several baristas now, so I'm not sure what's going on here. Every time I take a risk trying their coffee again, I'm left disappointed. Get hot chocolate or a tea latte instead - the non-coffee portion of the menu is pretty decent!

On weekends you'll notice that most of the patrons are overflow from Outerlands unacceptably long brunch wait, and I'm sure Trouble Coffee appreciates this extra business. 

Walk a few extra blocks west and you're at the Pacific Ocean.
author: Kat F.

description:
If your thing is average-tasting coffee and rude hipster service, this is your place. 

I've lived in SF for over a decade and I'm pretty used to getting treated badly by baristas but these folks surprised me. Seriously, mean people work here.
author: LeBaron B.

description:
Fresh coconuts.

Adorable charming staff.

Rustic warm vibe.

Thick slabs of fresh hot cinnamon toast.

Gooey just made brownies.

And some of the most superb handmade coffee and latte drinks around.

Trouble is tremendously what's up.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Iced coffee is spectacular! definitely a fan! But pricey though ~$3.50 for a small.

Staff is super friendly and helpful and the location is great.
author: N S.

description: I think they like giving off the vibe that their shop could care less: inconvenient space, inconsiderate employees. Sure. But the product has never really seemed worth it. There is better toast (almost everywhere else) in SF. I understand that a proper espresso drink does not have a quick turnaround. But watching their (single) barista work (for the 25+ minutes it took for him to even get to my cup) so slowly was excruciating. Their one good signature move is the extremely frothy cappuccinos. Nice parklet outside. Seating inside is limited, cramped, stuffy, and interrupted by orders being called out in your ear over the blaring music.
author: Taylor R.

description: Best cinnamon toast in SF. Really good vibes. The staff is kind of rude, but it's the kind of place you would want the staff to be rude at, if you're picking up what I'm putting down.
author: Parker W.

description:
The BEST Cappuccino you will EVER try. Okay, maybe not ever, but I always end up running back  to Trouble for their Cappuccino. You will be spoiled. The micro foam is perfect, rich, & simply different from any other Cappuccino I've had in the city. The Coffee is smooth & enjoyable. 

I also like the "girlfriend," which is basically a tea latte. 

This isn't really a place to take your laptop/MacBook for work. There are bar stools and seating (tree trunk) outside. It's a place for people to get together to socialize, share ideas, & relax. Baristas are super nice and friendly. 

Get the toast. Get the cappuccino. You won't regret it.
author: Danny Y.

description:
Interesting place--very small--only seating inside is a couple of narrow counters with bar stools--not really enough room to like spread out--this isn't a get comfy and stay awhile kind of cafe--at least for me. Most people were eating out front...front didn't really have proper seating complete with tables, either...but, that didn't seem to stop most people from hanging out front.  If I did come back--I would get it to go and head over to the beach which isn't too far from there.  
The cinnamon toast was a-ight--not write home about, really--but, just comforting in a simplistic way...butter, cinnamon and sugar--who can go wrong?! I was expecting something a little more artisanal, maybe...but, this struck me as more rustic, comfort food--if I had to classify it. The coffee was good--I drank it black, which I never do!

http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/520/transcript
author: C Z.

description:
CASH ONLY!  We went to Trouble Coffee Company on a rainy weekday.  It's a tiny place with seating maybe for 7 people.

You can get a Young Coconut, Regular coffee, & their Famous Cinnamon Toast for $8 called "Build Your Own Damn House".  $1 more if you want an Espresso drink.  They use De La Paz Coffee.

Found out they get the bread for the toast at Just For You Cafe in the Dogpatch. They also use Goody Goodie for cookies & Batter Bakery for some stuff like the Pumpkin Bread.

We got:

Regular coffee $2 - B. liked it.
1" Cinnamon Toast $2.5 - Yummy.  It's cut thick, toasted, then butter, brown sugar & cinnamon.  We shared it so he cut it in half:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ziENGkelh-BBEEbdAE6k2g?select=FOHxwFMnbEZoeldOYEOBUg
I got the Cappuccino $3.5 - liked it fine.  Kept me up the rest of the day.

CASH ONLY.  My total $8.33.  No Public bathrooms.  FREE Trouble Coffee stickers if you want.
author: Ann L.

description: This place is super hipster, to the point where it's a little intimidating. Know what you want to order in advance, since there isn't a menu. I recommend the peanut butter honey toast and a cappuccino! Delicious and filling breakfast!
author: Sophie N.

description:
Best cinnamon toast ever. It's really sugary and sweet, which makes it awesome but deadly. I haven't tried the coffee yet but I hear good things. Skip "the girlfriend" drink - earl grey tea + lavender + honey, it's not good at all. That's coming from a huge tea (latte) fan.

Just as everyone says here-the workers are rude and  the service sucks. 

Get your coffee and toast and bolt out of there.
author: Laura T.

description: Okay, I do not understand the hype on this place, but then again, I'm far from being a "hipster." Parking is so hard to find, we had to have someone drive around the block 10 times while we went inside. There's hardly any room for their customers, which wasn't very fun. I got an almond milk chai and it was so heavily spiced that I couldn't even drink it! I took 3 sips and had to just get rid of it because it was starting to taste soapy. The cinnamon toast is just bleh, nothing special at all. The peanut butter toast with honey was much better, but still I think the bread could be better. The three of us just didn't think it was anything worth visiting ever again. Such a disappointment, especially because the people working there could care less about their customers.
author: Jillian O.

description:
I've been a loyal Trouble Coffee customer for about a year. I love their coffee and toast, and the benches outside are a perfect spot for a relaxing Sunday morning.

Today I went in for my usual coffee and toast, and after watching about four people who ordered after me get their toast before me, I asked the cashier if he had put in my toast order. He brushed me off without checking the list and just told me that the line for toast is always long. I sat back down at the bar and watched another 8 people that I watched order after me get their toasts, so I asked the cashier again. This time he asked what my name was, and then continued to take people's orders. After taking 3 more orders, he finally asks the toast guy, who says my name isn't on the list. The next batch of toast came out, and STILL none for me. Really?? When I finally got my toast, they tossed it on the bar, yelled out my name, and didn't at all acknowledge their mistake.

Like another reviewer said, if you like your coffee with a side of douche, then please go to Trouble. I'm taking my business elsewhere.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Was a bit disappointed in this place. Had a latte and cinnamon sugar toast. Coffee quality was great, but the taste wasn't quite right. Also, the barista made about three other latte orders before mine even though they ordered after. Toast was excellent. I suppose I wasn't too surprised about certain employees attitudes given some of the reviews on here. Didn't bother me until one of the servers made a little kid (maybe 6 years old) feel bad. The boy's mom commented that he (the son) was so excited to see the cashier have a "man bun" too (his hair style); the cashier got irate and said it wasn't a man bun and went on a tirade about how it shouldn't be called that. Cool move dude.
author: Will H.

description: The staff is incredibly kind. The environment promotes the idea that people should converse and live off of electronic devices. It's a refreshing setting accompanied by a great cup of coffe and a thick slice of cinnamon toast.
author: Aaron R.

description: Yummy cap here! We ordered some hot drinks while waiting for Outerlands. The shop is very small and it was crowded.  While they do have a very simple menu, they could make just about anything if you ask.  I kind of wish they would expand their menu to just more than coffee, espresso, coconut, and toast because most of the time I never know what kind of caffeinated drink to order and love suggestions. The toast looked delish!
author: J P.

description: A tiny coffee place (with a handful of seats) seeing coffee, pies and toast. The staff is lively and possibly insane, the music was loud jazz. The coffee was excellent.
author: Will D.

description: I'm really disappointed with this place, it has good potential but the service was bad, both employees were rude and trying to just kick me out because they were closing in 15mins. I ordered a chai tea and I got a chai latte because apparently they not that good explaining and when I asked them why they gave me a latte the guy just said it was the way they did it. Then after like 10mins after they re-opened a really nice tattooed lady helped me out and made a real TEA without hesitating. She was absolutely great, I have a feeling she is the owner and if she's not, she should be. She made me a delicious orange spice tea and my whole experience changed. Thank you awsome tattoo girl, you rock.
author: Francisco Javier B.

description: We got two kinds of toast and coffee. The two guys working there were approachable and mentally present (rare for a coffee shop). If I could I'd come here for breakfast everyday.
author: David P.

description:
Love the coffee; love the toast (even though overpriced).

The coffee and food here are on point.

Here is the kicker. The service here was beyond rude.

First observation, the place is cash only, but there are no listings of what they have. People working have no interest in helping you order, but rather just getting you out of there. If you've never been here before and don't have someone with you that knows what they are doing, good luck to you.

Secondly, rude. When we did place our order, we were sitting inside waiting. There was a picture of a map on the wall so we were taking a look at it and pointing etc (typical interactions that a normal person would have when seeing a map). The guy at the counter says "Don't touch the map, it's very old." I immediately apologized as I did not know (and there were no signs saying so either). I was met with the retort "Keep your hands to yourself." Also, he called out an order to somebody saying "Here's the cookie you ordered and walked away" when he didn't tell them to wait while he got the cookie.

Unless you like coffee with a side of douchey ass, don't come here. I NEVER will again.
author: Eric C.

description: We really liked this cafe, and have been coming here for 5 years, since we moved to the neighborhood. Folks working the counter have always been friendly. But whoever is hired now needs a lesson in customer service and basic manners. I hope an owner reads the reviews. She worked so hard to build up this place, just to have a couple of smart arses taint the reputation.
author: Katya L.

description: The rudest baristas I have ever experienced. Not to mention that the music is loud and offensive to the ears. "Trouble" is an understatement!
author: Dana G.

description:
5 Star for the great toast and coffee, but 0 for the rude female cashier with tattoos. 

Went on a Saturday evening, very excited for the toast. My dog marks his territory on the stand in the 1.5 seconds I look away, leaving about 3 drops. The cashier walks by and says "You can't have your dog do that". Of course feeling very apologetic about the situation, I continued to apologize and cleaned the stand. As I'm waiting for my toast outside, I decide to walk inside to check on it. The woman stands about 2 inches from me and says "You can't come in here, wait outside". *Rude, but still reasonable*. As I am waiting, I hear her saying very clear and loud " This B**** let her dog pee on the stand and is trying to come in" and shouts about the situation for a full 5 minutes in front of the 4 customers waiting for their order. 

The point is, this was a terribly embarrassing and in appropriate situation. I will not be going back.
author: Christin J.

description:
Pros: The coffee is good, the mochas are amazing. I like the outdoor parklette just outside, so you can sip on your coffee outside.

Cons: The service is not so friendly. Cash only. And $5.50 for cinnamon toast?!!
author: Jess C.

description: The coffee was not very good, had a burnt/old flavor. Probably from being overheated. The toast was ok, a bit dry. Tiny space, has a few stools inside and big log in front. Ok as a neighborhood spot, wouldn't make a trip to it, as I did. It's just ok.
author: Rebekka T.

description:
Hipper-than-thou coffee joint... and they make you feel it.

Had, you know, an hour to kill while waiting for our table at Outerlands. Thought I might try out a new coffee place. I will just be getting my coffee at Outerlands from now on so I don't have to deal with the attitude. I asked for milk (only soy and cream were out) and it was like a total inconvenience for them. 

It's unfortunate that the guys behind the counter give off such a prick vibe (ok, the toast guy seems relatively jolly). While awaiting my beverage, I overheard conversations like so:

Q: "Do you guys have, like, a menu?"
A: "I know everything we serve." (uhm ok, but maybe your patron doesn't?)

Q: "What kinds of toast do you have?"
A: "If you have to ask you should probably just get the cinnamon one."

WHY DO YOU HAVE TO MAKE PEOPLE FEEL SO UNCOOL? It's the worst to see people so uncomfortable and clearly embarrassed on a Sunday morning just trying to grab a cup of coffee. 

It was a good, but small, latte. There is a sweet outdoor seating space though.
author: Subie C.

description:
By far my favorite place to get coffee in SF! And that's saying something since it's all the way in the sunset and I live in the mission. 

I regularly get a latte and "holy shit toast" 
The latte is very strong, foamy, creamy, and full of flavor. holy shit toast is a thick slice of bread, butter, peanut butter, honey, cinnamon and sugar. (If I'm correct) 

There's nothing like getting those two things on a weekend morning. 

Love. Love. Love trouble
author: Jariah B.

description:
Not a fan of the jerk baristas and the espresso is less than pleasant. 

A friend and I came here because we were trying to look for a quick place to have a 5 minute meeting. We thought that because it was a coffee shop there would be wifi. Just as we whip out a tiny laptop the barista turned into a pretentious pinky up coffee sipping hipster. As I can recall his exact words were "We like that we don't Wifi here so people can actually enjoy their coffee." First off your coffee sucks and second of all I can go to Starbucks and enjoy my burnt beans there without the attitude. 

I looked through some of the other reviews and saw that people had complaints about the staff as well. Clearly this whole "Im above it because I can make roastey bean water" attitude is not doing this business any favors.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Here is the Background story to the founding of Trouble Coffee Shop. Very inspiring story.
 
You can start the transcript at about 44:26 minutes. 
http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/520/no-place-like-home?act=3
author: Alex T.

description:
As a lifelong San Franciscan and Sunset local, I have been a supporter of Trouble Coffee for years. 

I will start this review by saying usually I just get a brewed coffee, which means I just walk in, pay my couple of bucks, get a delicious cup of coffee, and head on my merry way. Their coffee is a cut above everything else in the neighborhood and is also among my favorite in the city as a whole, so it fills that need to a T. 

I made the mistake of ordering toast a while ago, and I only refer to it as a mistake because now every time I walk by, I want a slice. It's incredible, it's delicious, and you get every cent worth of the cost. I haven't yet tried the peanut butter & honey toast, but the cinnamon sugar & butter one is one of my favorite treats in the world. 

My friends who order espresso drinks there occasionally gripe about the wait or the cost, but once their drink is ready and they take a sip they always forget what they were so worked up about. 

With regards to the service, people need to remember, this is in a stretch of the Outer Sunset where everyone knows everyone and it is a true neighborhood. Respect that the employees here are part of that community and sometimes talk to people they know, some of whom sometimes just come in to hang out. If your coffee takes an extra minute or so, so be it, it's worth the wait. If you can't spare an extra minute out of your morning, you probably shouldn't have stopped for coffee there anyways, just go across the street to 7-11 and get coffee there, because you clearly don't understand what Trouble is all about. They do things there better than other places, and it's because they take the time to do them right. 

I for one hope they never change a thing, because they have been doing everything right as far as I'm concerned, and I'll continue to support as often as I can.
author: Bill B.

description:
One coffee.
One coconut.
Two pieces of cinnamon toast.
One asshole at the register.
$ 17.

So this is what is so great about San Francisco?  No thanks.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I ALWAYS GET INTO TROUBLE, then come out with solid coffee and cinnamon toast. That's how I roll. I'm a badass.

___
So, how this works:

1. You go in.  Tight space.  Funky, typed up menu that is absolutely useless.

2. You order.  They brew good coffee. The Toast is a thick slice, generously buttered and cinnamon sugar-ed.  They also have fresh young coconut.  If you want all three: it's called "Build Your Own Damn House", which is the more affordable option but makes a poorly constructed building.

3. You pay with CASH.  Not because I said so; it's the only way they let you.

4. Fancy up your joe.  Sugar, cream, and all the other shenanigans are tabled outside. 

5. Snag one of the few limited seats; there's also a parklet and the street is quiet.
author: Diane N.

description: The coffee here is delicious, but the staff are absolute jerks. Customer service is not a term they are familiar with. I recommend paying for the coffee but skipping the tip.
author: Elisa R.

description: The three stars is because on wends the menu is more limited and not many choices sorry!
author: Nancie M.

description:
Was moved and inspired by the beautiful "This American Life" profile of owner Giulietta Carrelli, and couldn't wait to visit Trouble. So I was surprised when, after (happily) waiting in line for about ten or fifteen minutes, it was my turn and the guy behind the register barked (really, he kind of yelled at me), "You! What do you want?!" (And the customers in front of me hadn't even stepped aside yet.) I didn't see a menu and because it was my first time, I really didn't know what all was offered. He was impatient and curt with my questions - sort of a human bummer. The old "soup nazi" schtick is not only tired and lame, but runs counter to the spirit with which this cafe was built (at least from how I understand the story, but maybe I'm wrong). 

As for the cinnamon toast and coffee - both very good. There was an easy vibe among the many patrons and a cool little public parklet out front. 

Wish I could recommend this place to others but I can't - with a whole heart - tell people to go somewhere I was treated badly and where they will likely be treated badly too.
author: Jess A.

description:
The coffee was good, but not the best I've ever had. The toast, however, was delicious -- although, I could probably make it at home.

I have a few issues with this place though:

1) extremely rude baristas. My bad for asking for non-fat milk. For all future customers, they only have whole milk and soy milk. Nothing in between. I don't need a barista to sweet talk me or anything, but asking for a pleasant attitude is not asking for much. 

2) the drinks are tiny. Like, SUPER tiny. What is this? Coffee for ants? But in all seriousness, expensive for what you get in return.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Good for toast and regular coffee. Don't even bother ordering anything else!  Unless you want to waste more than half an hour of your time waiting for an Americano like we did!  Espresso drinks take FOREVER even when they're not that busy. Longest wait I've ever experienced at any coffee shop anywhere, period. Also this place is cash only. 

Cool atmosphere though with a nice parklet outside. I would definitely go back for toast and coffee, plain and simple. I don't know why they even offer anything else as they can't deliver. They stay pretty busy so expect a line and a short wait even for the basics. But the coffee is good and the toast is delicious, plus it has a great overall feel and is a San Francisco staple. There's a great story behind the owner and how this spot came to fruition as well.
author: Natalie W.

description: It's been said before but I'll say it again-- the cinnamon toast is bombaf. My friend got coffee and really enjoyed. I wish there was a menu because I didn't really know there were other options besides cinnamon toast but I guess a menu wouldn't differentiate between a yelper and a true hipster.
author: Amelia D.

description:
Killer coffee. Killer munch-ables. The toast is awesome and, yes, it's worth the sticker shock. 

There's no menu, so if you don't know what a coffee shop usually serves, you're out of luck. I would go with the coffee, personally. 

Don't be annoying, don't try to take stupid pictures when there's a ton of people trying to order and don't tell everyone you are here because NPR told you to come. There's plenty of good coffee downtown where that behavior is acceptable. 

This really a community hang out spot. If it feels like a locals only vibe, it kind of is. Who would come this far out for coffee and toast? You I guess.
author: Chris C.

description: Pretty sketchy neighborhood and the place reminded me of a rundown tattoo parlor, but it was worth stopping here. Got the cinnamon toast and a cup of coffee, since they didn't have a menu on display and they were the only things I knew they had. Toast was tasty. They also have a cool outdoor seating area.
author: Dirk N.

description: It is a cool place and i like the place's whole decoration. However, the staff is NOT nice. The guy keeps me waiting my ice coffee for 30 mins and all the costumers ordering after me get their coffee. At the beginning, I thought the guy who supposed to make my coffee didn't hear the order but later on I realize that the guy at cashier didn't even tell him my ice coffee order. I reminded them... And they keep telling you it is coming but even they order my coffee for 3 times , I saw the guy doing other stuff like cleaning the sink, washing the cups but just not pick up a paper cup and dump the coffee in it. What really bothers me is ... They didn't even apology for the delay ..They have this " we r so cool and I don't care to serve u" hummm.... For the first time, I wish I was  at Starbuck...cause at least, they pretend they care
author: Zoe C.

description:
I'd love to tell you how delicious the coffee is here. How good the brown sugar, cinnamon toast is when it's warm and melty. BUT I can't because I didn't get to eat or drink anything. We went in (screamo death metal in the background making our ears bleed) and asked if there was a menu. The cashier with stretched out, holey ear lobes and an angry face said, "No. You're going to have to talk to me."
We ordered, tried to pay with card, got rudely told we need cash. Left to go to the 7/11 to get some, came back, and they were closed. Like door shut, benches up on the bar closed. Even though they're still supposed to be open for 2 more hours.
To top it off, I got told I can't take pictures inside, with one of the servers literally putting an arm on me to deter me. Are you serious? Your over priced toast is not worth it. Sorry Trouble, you're just too much trouble. Fix your attitude.
author: Laura T.

description:
5 stars for the Cinnamon Toast, everything else... ehhh. (2 stars is being very generous, it hurts my heart when I give a low rate review).

Cons:
- NO MENU!
- Cash only
- Very rude barista (despite what other yelpers said, I went anyways and they are RIGHT)
- No electronics can be used in the store. Got called out for it. Sorry for using mine to check your business on yelp, I didn't see a sign. 
- Place is cramped but who wants to stay anyways?

Pros:
- Cinnamon Toast
- Quick Service

I asked what's good because I was overwhelmed on what to get without a menu in front of me; was told everything is great but how can I know if there's no menu?! 

My sister told me to just get a latte. The barista said, "that's too simple." So i told him to make me whatever taste good/best. I got my drink, it looked and tasted like a latte, whaaaa?? Despite that, it tasted pretty good, it had a few nice notes in the coffee but I had better. I'd only come back if I'm in the area and I'm in need of coffee but it's not some place I'd go out of my way to get. $8.50 for my drink and the Cinnamon Toast.
author: Hue V.

description:
Been here a couple of times. The baristas are pretty douchey but the coffee is fantastic and I'm pretty sure the cinnamon toast is part causation for the soaring obesity rates of our country (it's THAT good. it's THAT addicting. it's THAT bad for you).

First time I came here I immediately thought of all my hip friends back in Berkeley. you know the ones who go to class barefoot and drink their coffee in mason jars (before it became a thing). this place is HIP. It's cute, woodsy, no tables/chairs (just a small bar on the side), no menu. Seating is outside on the sidewalk where a huge tree trunk has somehow been hauled to rest right in the middle and cute little succulents act as decoration. 

I ordered a mocha & cinnamon toast - mocha was great. Not too sweet but was chocolatey albeit not in a syrupy kind away similar to the ones from Starbucks or Peets that make you feel like you are drinking the entire day's worth of calories. Cinnamon toast was buttery... cinnamony... so good.

A little pricey, forgot what it came out to be but probably around 7 bucks or so from what I can recall. Now I just get a large coffee & a toast if I'm feeling hungry but the coffee itself is enough to wake me up for the entire day - strongly brewed and goes down smooth. 

Great little place to sit and chat with friends. Looks great on instagram, lol. Be prepared, though, to be met with curtness from the baristas and incredibly long waits for espresso drinks when they start to get busy (it took me 20 minutes for my latte once!) You can always check out general store right next door during the wait though! Cute little shop equally as hip :)

CA$H ONLY
author: Shirley N.

description: Best damn toast I've ever had. Solid latte too. I got no attitude from the people working there but I would not be surprised. Got to love the punk rock steelo of this place!
author: Noah S.

description:
I've lived in the Sunset for over ten years and love that this specific area of the Sunset is growing. Today I wanted to treat myself to Trouble Coffee for the first time.

The coffee was absolutely delicious but the experience sucked. The staff wasn't friendly and god forbid I pull out a credit card to pay! The guy looked at me, threw his hands back like my credit card had herpes, and explained that they were cash only. Fine. I gave him cash and he rudely smacked my change into my hand.

I've worked in the service industry my entire life and I'm also a small business owner. I would never treat a paying customer like that.  I'm sad to see this business in our neighborhood and won't be back. These guys need a serious attitude adjustment.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I made a special trip out to the coast for this place. 

It was good. I would recommend it. 

IF you're in the area. I wouldn't go out of my way for this cinnamon toast. 

It was good, though. 

The bread was light and fluffy. But it was a really thick slice. Thick in a good way. 

Basically, try it if you're in the area. There isn't a menu. You just ask for cinnamon toast. I saw pictures for peanut butter, but the cinnamon is where it's at.
author: Janelle O.

description:
So much hipsterness going on in one little coffee shop to handle... Trying to get in and out with your coffee and toast fast probably won't happen here since there's usually a line (and wait for your order).  The coffee here is good, definitely not your sweet Starbucks coffee.  The soy chai latte is pretty delicious.  As for their famous toast, you definitely taste and see how much butter is slathered on it.  Butter everywhere... I'm only able to take two or three bites total because its so rich.  It's not bad just a too much butter IMO.

Like other reviewers mentioned, there is no menu and they accept cash only.
author: Stephanie T.

description: After driving into the sunset I knew I had to try this coffee place that people have told me about. Small little place with a wooden bar. TIP- Cash Only!!  The atmosphere was inviting and the people were friendly. I ordered a small coffee and a cinnamon toast.  I will say what a great combo!  Super tasty snack to go with a small cup of joe.
author: Sean B.

description:
First of all, build your own damn house.
Second of all, the pastry options..mmmm
Soy latte, americano, drip coffee...just do it.
 This place is literally the bees knees, whatever that even means..

TOOOAST!
author: Bree G.

description:
Best toast ever. I actually went to Just for You in the dogpatch, where they get their bread from, and trouble makes the toast WAY better. Best macchiato's of my life, thank you Trouble for not being swallowed by the medium roast fanaticism that's overtaking san francisco. 

way to have the best morning in san francisco: Toast, Macchiato, coconut. Enough said.
author: Ashley M.

description: Super small joint. Got the fresh coconut water and it was delicious! The guy taking orders refused to help someone behind us who was on her phone...LOVED that. They take the no electronic devices rule seriously!
author: Jenni B.

description: I don't know what everyone is complaining about I loved the service and items I received from Trouble. I came here to grab coffee and toast before I got a tattoo next door at Tuesday Tattoo and my cinnamon sugar toast was AWESOME!! Although I ended up getting "The Girlfriend" (Lavender tea Au Lait with honey) instead of coffee, i really enjoyed it!! I will be back!!
author: Moet M.

description:
I decided to give this place a try once more since I kept hearing about their delicious toast! 

I decided to go with the original Cinnamon Toast. Don't get me wrong, the toast was delicious! But I was a little disappointed because I was expecting to be BLOWN AWAY by something unique. I could easily make this toast at home with butter and cinnamon...
