I also ordered the "Girlfriend" which was an Earl Grey Black Tea Latte with Honey Lavender (I believe) -- this drink was alright. I ended up going home and adding more honey in it because it sort of just tasted like straight up milk. 

Their customer service isn't the great (but also not the worst). I just didn't really feel welcomed -- I felt like they just wanted to get the orders in-and-out. Which I totally understand, but they weren't very busy at all! Maybe like 5 drinks waiting to be made - I would say typical for a coffee shop.

I would come back ONLY to try their Peanut Butter Toast and Fresh Coconut (I'll give you a 3rd chance Trouble Coffee!), but other than that I don't plan on coming back at all. I rather go to a place that has welcoming, and efficient employees.
author: Vanessa P.

description: The kid who closes on Thursdays (idk his name) is an angel. I've been in coffee for a long time and his service is extremely good n welcoming. If you've had a bad experience here, you probably aren't meant to be here. Sure, their rules can be annoying for some, but most of them are based off of fair service interactions. If ya need to work on tech stuff, don't go there. That's what Starbucks or phils is 4. Trouble is clearly not to serve everyone (techies, general rude ppl on their phone) , and that is okay!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Finally got to cross Trouble Coffee off of my Bucket List! 

It was my first time here and I was a little confused because they didn't have a menu anywhere that clearly stated what they served and how much each item is.

We ordered:
1. Build Your Own Damn House: Coconut and cinnamon/sugar/buttery toast
2. Large coffee
3. Small coffee

Which all came out to $15.00, I was a little shocked when I heard how much it was because it is clearly overpriced. 

We sat inside along the window and we were asked to step outside as they would clean the floors for 10 minutes. The closed up shop for more than 10 minutes so we left. 

I'm happy to have tried Trouble Coffee but I wouldn't return again because the prices are ridiculous.
author: Juliette R.

description: One of the greatest coffee spots in SF and also the absolute worst customer experience I've ever received. It's almost like the baristas go a little out of there way to be assholes. I downloaded this app just to write this place a review after having had a few surprisingly poor interactions ... To the people at Trouble, let us enjoy your amazing coffee without feeling like we're ruining your day with our company  Smile a little, I promise it won't kill you, may even help you live a little longer
author: Kristina G.

description:
I have a hard time paying $4 for what appears to be a 3-4 ounce drink. I typically just drink my boyfriend's coffee and don't actually get anything when I come here. I also don't like waiting in lines, so often times I walk over here wanting to get coffee and see a line and just keep going. However, yesterday I woke up wanting Trouble Coffee and there was nothing I could do but get some. 

The mocha is really good. Bitter chocolate and not very sweet, but very rich and satisfying. After drinking the baby size cup you will at least feel satisfied. The outside decoration is cool - wood and succulent plants. Very hipster. All in all a good coffee.
author: Catherine H.

description:
Trouble!! I'm convinced you employ the cutest men to work behind your register, slinging the best espresso with their buff tattooed arms, wide-eyed smiles, and witty banter. Sometimes it's fun to go in just to see how cute they all are. No, seriously. 

The espresso is amazing, their coffee is great. I'm a huge fan of the soy Gibraltar. It's espresso with perfectly steamed soy in a small glass cup for-here. Their soy lattes are also some of the best I've had, ever, anywhere. It's a pleasure to have this place right down the street. 

Oh, and the toast. It's just stupid. In a really good way!
author: Julie W.

description:
One of my favorite coffee spots in the city all in.  The drinks are good, the cinnamon toast is divine, but the vibes of the area do it for me more than anything.  Sure, the guys behind the counter might not be the most friendly people you'll ever meet, but at the same time over-paid SF "foodies" (a label that could be sarcastically thrown at me) can be pretty obnoxious so let's let that slide.

While waiting two hours for Outerlands I love to slip inside this odd little treasure trove, grab some kickass free stickers and a latte and sip it outside or on my way down to Ocean Beach.  I'll keep coming back here perhaps because it's off the beaten path, brunch at Outerlands or not.
author: Chloe B.

description:
I came in after morning walk on the beach.  Coffee is very good..small
sizes like Paris.
My caveat here is no public bathrooms for customers. Not good at all.
If you are serving food and liquid drinks, any civilized place that cares
about the comfort of their customers will have bathrooms.
This is a stupid move on behalf of the owners. Went to the Beach Chalet
to use the restrooms. I won't be back.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I visited Trouble this past Saturday in the afternoon.  Some friends visiting from out of town were psyched to try 'this four-dollar toast place' on our way to hike Land's End.

After ordering two coffees and a slice of the notorious toast, I leaned on the counter to make way for the rest of the folks lining up to order.  Hardcore blasting over the speaker, two hardcore dudes running the place, people packed in tight (like the pit at a hardcore show) -- all expected and cool with me.

The hardcore dude operating the cappuccino machine was steaming milk for other peoples' orders, inspiring latte lust: 'Hey, did you start on the two coffees I'd just ordered?  I'd like to change one of them to a latte if it's not too late.'  To which the dude responds -- drum roll, please -- 'Why the f*ck are you talking to me?  Don't talk to me.'

The other dude, who worked the register, looked at me and politely smiled, 'You can ask me if you need anything'.

Uhhhhh?

The toast and the latte were pretty decent, but not worth the price or the attitude.  I'm pretty thick-skinned when it comes to condescending barristas venting discontent while working their understandably hated day-job, but you crossed the line, bro.  

If you do come here, go sip your drink in General Store, one door down.  They have lots of cute succulents and South-Western style trinkets to browse through.
author: Russell A.

description:
The only thing I really come here for are the drinks and only when I'm in the area. I supported Andytown Coffee Roasters on Kickstarter and so happy they finally opened. Now I can go to Andytown without the attitude of Trouble.

Pros: 
-Good cup of whatever you order

Cons:
1) THE PERSON WHO TAKES YOUR MONEY AT THE CASH REGISTER IS ALSO MAKING YOUR TOAST AT THE SAME TIME. DISGUSTING! Toast = toasted cinnamon bread, butter, and cinnamon sugar

2) Cash only

3) The music is always too loud. Reminds me of how Abercrombie & Fitch blasts their music. Different music but way too loud.

4) Crowded

5) The small table outside where the lids, sugar, etc are is a joke. Two people can barely use it at the same time. There has got to be a better way.

6) No picture taking inside. I've never heard a food place tell anyone this in my life. I couldn't believe it when I heard a worker yell that to a few people. Pictures help businesses, especially on popular sites like yelp. 

7) VERY hipster. Rude service. Too-cool-to-smile attitudes. Appreciate your customers. They deserve respect. The owner obviously doesn't care what we think or feel. Otherwise, how could he/she let his or her employees continue to treat customers in this manner?


Service = FAIL
Ambiance = FAIL
Product = Decent to good
author: Jen Y.

description:
Holy crap. 
I am so happy that AndyTown coffee just opened up in my neighborhood, because my only other option was Trouble for a long time. I liked the location, I liked the coffee, but jesus christ, the people who work there are the biggest dickheads. If you want a cup of coffee that tastes like somebody who is imagining you choking to death made it, then totally go to Trouble Coffee.
author: Lou D.

description:
No menu.  No bathroom.  No wifi.  No credit cards.  No decaf.  

Nice barista tho.  I didn't know they didn't accept cc before I ordered and I didn't have cash in me but he still offered it to me for free since he already poured it. That was gracious of him.  One star for having a heart.
author: Isaac L.

description:
No self-respecting person should come to this place.

I still like the coffee and baked stuff. But I was badly treated. I had my laptop on so I could charge my phone. A guy working there stopped me in such a rude manner. It's okay if you have a no laptop house rule, even when I couldn't see any sign about it. But not being scolded by a jerk like I was about to set the place on fire.

Paying or not, no one deserves to be treated in such a manner. No more business from me.
author: Roy C.

description: I'm sorry but any coffee place that will only do a double shot thinks too highly of themselves. Was there a few weekends ago and they refused to do a single shot latte. Sure, your machine only does double pours but how about just putting half of the espresso it produces into my drink? Won't be heading back to Trouble anytime soon...
author: Erin W.

description:
Watch out Blue Bottle coffee there is Trouble coming. Okay that was terribly lame but basically conveys the message. This little coffee shop located in outer Sunset is a hidden coffee gem. I went today for a midday pick-me-up and got their latte and it was the BEST latte I had. 

Yes, I have read the rave review and tried Blue Bottle Coffee Co. but I like Trouble more. Perhaps it's the name that really drives it home, like something out of an old western. Now, I will go looking for Trouble everyday. Okay, enough of my lameness. I will definitely go back to try every drink on their menu, which shouldn't take too long. 

What I recommend:

Latte

UPDATE: So, it is too early on yelp to write an actual update and that is why I am just adding to my recent review. Got another latte today from Trouble and it wasn't as good as yesterday. I think it's a hit or miss depending upon who makes your drink. Still a really good cup of coffee but not as great as yesterday. And therefore I must drop my five star rating to four stars.
author: Andrew W.

description: Went in Sunday morning and wasn't greeted by any of the 6 staff. All too busy chatting behind the bar probably talking about their newest tattoo or which drug they want to try next. When I finally got the attention of the cashier I asked if they do breakfast sandwiches, harmless question in my opinion. Boy must have had a rough morning (or night) because he says "you can have a chicken pot pie or apple pie, dontcha see what we have in the case. Does it look like I have any eggs or bacon?" I guess I should have known he lives off of coffee and cigarettes. My bad trouble coffee, I really wasn't looking for trouble. Figured I haven't had my coffee yet so I ordered an iced latte. For $4.00 I got a scoop of ice a burnt ass shot of espresso and maybe 2 ounces of milk and not a single smile. NEVER returning here AGAIN!
author: Mike L.

description:
I get it, I get it. They're in a great location by the beach, the coffee is tasty but why all the attitude?!? 
Everyone that works there is a hipster asshole that even if you walk in with a smile, you can't seem to win with these people. I've tried Trouble multiple times and after the guy threw my change on the counter in a rush ( there was no one behind me) I've decided I'm done with this place. 
Next time I'm taking a walk to the beach, I'd rather stop by 7-11 across the street. Maybe they'll be a little nicer.
author: Jenny D.

description: Great drip coffee and cinnamon toast here! It's kind of cramped and hard to tell who's ordering or who's waiting for their order. Service was fast and friendly. Good spot for a quick pick me up though!
author: Anne N.

description:
i was treated rudely this morning. I work in the service industry and have dealt with large SF egos (which I understand Will wear you down) and rude service all over San Francisco. This kinda seemed like a joke. What's really funny is these people who work here and I have mutual friends so I dunno if I need one of my homies to go with me who's also homies with them to get better treatment. This is small city we're all friends of friends so why be so rude cause you know...one of your friends is also one of my friends, we could actually be friends too! Have a sense of humor like Meg at bayview shop

I come from tough skin too and coffee is the first thing I do with my day, makes me a happier person! however leaving here today put a little damper on my daily coffee routine 

Cute boys be nice or funny either way you'll be way cuter!!

Mad Love, the girl from the city of Brotherly Love
author: Colleen H.

description: Cool small shop, awesome staff, amazing coffee, and that cinnamon toast is to kill for.
author: Kirill P.

description:
Great coffee.

Baked goods are always fantastic.  

Employees are very nice once they've seen your face a couple times.  Even before that they weren't mean. 

Yes, they are no nonsense, don't take cash and don't have Wifi.  But I like that.  It makes my experience as a relaxed coffee drinker more pleasant.

Always an interesting scene of people hanging around as well.
author: Cheese G.

description: How the fuck do you order from here when there is no visible menu? The guy working saw us looking around for one and didn't offer any help. Thanks guy.
author: Christina X.

description: Rude service and wait was extremely long. I understand you guys were busy after all, a lot of folks stopped by after bay to breakers yesterday. I gave a nice $5 top because of it. But my order of a cappuccino and latte must have been too hard for the bald tattoo gentleman to deal with as he kept skipping mine and others. I sat there for 25 mins. Finally the nice guy who I saw dump the trash, clean the sugar and cup area, and clean dishes did my order. I really like you guy with the long hair and the only one who smiled at anyone in the cafe. You even apologized for the wait I had to endure. Thank you! Seems like you lack the disgruntled attitude like the rest. Not sure why your not helping customers. Out of the total of 4 people who were working at the time you long haired dude were awesome! Everyone else sucked! Last time I will ever visit this crap hole.
author: Teresa L.

description:
This hidden gem is located on the opposite side of a 7-11, you can tell where it is because of the tree trunk bench and the hipstery looking customers hanging out in front. 

There is no official menu, but if you ask the staff they will let you know. The cinnamon toast is on the 7x7 and is really popular, what can go wrong with bread, butter, sugar, and cinnamon? I would definitely go back and try their other goodies!
author: Tina F.

description:
I was around the area and saw a group of people hovering around the coffee shop, so my friend and I decided to check it out. It wasn't open yet, but with a sea of people patiently waiting outside, we thought it must be amazing. 

We got a soy latte and their black coffee. Eh. Their toast was good but I wouldn't go back.
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Long wait, rude staff, angry loud music. 
These guys come recommended as a good place to get coffee while waiting for brunch nearby, but honestly this doesn't make a lot of sense since its a longer wait here than at the restaurant. 
If you want to wait 30 or 40 minutes for a cappuccino, and have the staff tell you "if you're unsatisfied then you shouldn't have ordered a cappuccino," then this is your place. 
My friends who ordered regular coffees finished theirs well ahead of my coffee getting anywhere close to the front. 
The fact that loud, aggressive, angry music was playing the whole time doesn't help. 
But seriously--long waits and very rude staff. Not recommended.
author: Charles E.

description:
I hardly ever judge a place by its service (because my stomach tends to gloss over how delicious food & drink end up in it) but the service at Trouble Coffee Company is impossible to disregard. I shouldn't have to wear my hip factor on my sleeve to be acknowledged, nor should I be the recipient of laborious sighs 'cuz it's my first time here (sorry for not knocking *sarcasm*) and I don't know what a "Girlfriend" or a "Build Your Own Damn House" is. Or whether either come with soymilk (Also sorry for being lactose intolerant *more sarcasm*).

I get it. I'm not a local. You're an artist, and you work as a barista on the side. Or even better- coffee *is* your art. Cool story, bruh. Now make me a sandwich.
author: Tianyi S.

description:
I have recently discovered Trouble Coffee. On my first visit, I was so excited about the cinnamon toast that I overlooked that the cashier appeared a little irritated when my boyfriend and I took a few extra seconds to decide what we wanted. Well, there is no menu, so we had to ask about the items they offer. Ok, maybe he had a busy or bad day. I let that slide. 

Here is where I my rating comes from, super rude service. Went their yesterday and asked for a macchiato. Same guy took our order. After paying, I kindly asked him, "can you please make sure it's dry?" His response was, "we make it the way we make it." In other words, take or leave it. Well, how do you make it? I'm just asking for an espresso with foam, no added milk. Am I stressing them out by asking them to spoon foam on my espresso? In scanning through other reviews, it appears that good customer service is not their thing. Shame on the owner for hiring these type of people and also for not responding to Yelp reviewers.
author: Sandra B.

description:
Pros:
Super friendly and welcoming staff which always helps any coffee shop experience even more worth it. 

Food: Toast was delicious! My friends and I tried the brown sugar/cinnamon and peanut butter with honey. Unfortunately they were out of nutella that night so we couldn't try it. 

Coffee/tea: cute art work on their lattes! Delicious chai tea and early grey tea (called girlfriend something). 

Cons:  

No menus which make it harder for you to order if you're anything like me and need to see your options in front of you. 

CASH ONLY!!! 


Overall, amazing gem in Sunset! Def worth a check out!
author: Roshni P.

description: Gibraltar and toast on point always, a must.  Super rad atmosphere inside the shop and outside on the urban patio.
author: Lucas R.

description: I'm so happy this place is here while I'm waiting for Outerlands for brunch, their peanut butter/butter/honey toast- Omg, definitely makes me happy during my wait for brunch. The coffee is great, service is friendly and they have a nice sustainable seatings outside.
author: Ennie L.

description:
I got cinnamon toast and a latte. Like everyone says, the coffee is tiny, but it's really about the roast and drip time for me. It was strong and aromatic coffee. Cinnamon toast was only okay -- perhaps because I like slightly toasted toast, not crunchy. Personal preference. I'd go again to try the PB toast.

The baristas can manage a sizable crowd without breaking a sweat. Well run; quick to get what you ordered!
author: Ann L.

description:
Great coffee, good toast. Other baked goods are decent too.

I've always had friendly service, but then again I don't stroll in with a Louis Vuitton, giggle and ask for a "vanilla latte and that toast you make". Please stay away. There's nothing for you in the Outer Sunset.

This is a small, simple coffee shop with good people. Period.
author: J. M.

description:
So wow, I have finally been moved to start a Yelp account and actually post a review. 

For my birthday I wanted a trip to the city with an overnight stay at a hotel so we could explore properly and I could play with my new camera (birthday present) I take artsy shots for my own personal use, I am not a reporter or photo journalist or even a blogger. I'm an artist and I just like to take pretty photos. 

We ended up staying in this very charming area, apparently it's a surfer/hipster favorite, but we were just there for an affordable hotel. In the morning we went out foraging for coffee, and I love to support the small local places when I'm in an area. 

We see this place, and it's just cool looking. Driftwood counters, found art, scribbled-on etch-a-sketch. Just overall a neat vibe, and just begging for some pics. I was happily taking a few abstract shots of some of the cooler aspects, not even aiming remotely near any of the people in the place, when they kinda went nuts, waving their arms and telling me not to take pictures inside. 

I was pretty taken aback, for a place to have such an interesting look and then forbid pictures? Of course there was nothing posted anywhere about not taking pictures, so it felt like a trap to me. "look, here's a really great photo op, loook at all the pretty thiiiings... come closer... cloooooserrrrr... NO! NO PICTURES FOR YOU!" 

I give two stars rather than just one because the cappuccino was decent, if overpriced, and the barista tried to be friendly about it afterwards, and I asked why the policy existed because it didn't make sense to me. He said they didn't want pictures of their place and their faces plastered over the internet. Because... publicity is bad? I get not wanting your personal face up, but I wasn't anywhere near taking pictures of anyone's faces, really I wanted some abstract shots of the wood grain on the bar and this interesting painted stain up on the ceiling, He kept saying "it's not personal" but really, they embarrassed me pretty badly. I have social anxiety issues and I'm an extremely polite person and if there had been signs posted I wouldn't have been taking photos in the first place.  

The kicker is that when we got home I did a google search and the internet is ALREADY slathered with pictures of the inside of the place, from inside the place, including many shots of baristas in action, and my photos were all abstract and you wouldn't have even known where they were taken. 

I know my little review won't mean much to them, they seem to have quite a following with the locals and I'm sure they will continue to do fine, but I feel like maybe any photogs checking yelp reviews on the place before going should be forewarned about this policy so they can avoid the embarrassment that I was subjected to.
author: Binary G.

description: Batista was rude as hell. Refused to give me a to go cup. And the honey that I asked him to add to my shots of espresso before he added ice? He said "I'll hand it to you" which, if you're trying to put in an ICED drink is counter productive...and on top of disregarding my order, he never handed it to me, instead, he ignored me when I asked for it again. I guess since I had already paid AND tipped, I was now nonexistent. Coffee wasn't anything special, I've had better from many a shop, and WAS excited to try a new one. But I think I'll just stick to the familiar. The name describes my entire experience at that coffee shop, nothing but trouble. And that's the last thing you want when you're just trying to jumpstart your day with a nice cup o' joe...
author: Makena O.

description:
It was a cold, rainy day so when a friend called asking to grab a coffee, we jumped @ the chance.  We had tried coming here on 2 previous occasions but once they were closed & the other time their espresso machine was broken.  But we got lucky this time!

I got a Deep charge which I think is like a red eye.  If it is the same, then this one was much, much stronger but without being too acidic.  The boyfriend got a Matador which we couldn't figure out what it was.  I tried a sip & found it really milky, even more so than a latte.  Anyone knows what this drink is?

We sat down @ the long counter & watched the barista work & to admire all the quirky decor like the toy horse on the ceiling & the shark fin soup in the pastry case.

I have since read that the cinnamon toast here is really delicious so I guess another trip is going to be coming up soon.
author: Karen S.

description: Went for the first time to grab some coffee with some friends. The person behind the counter was very rude and insistent that we could take a photo of the interior, which looked cool... It was very off putting. She also gave my friend a coffee that had a leaking cup and did not seem to care about that fact. Walk a few more blocks to Andy Town for a friendlier experience. I might return to try the toast though.
author: Tyler S.

description:
YES.

Coffee should be strong.
Coffee should not be decaf.
Coffee should not be Starbucks.

Sunset has been lacking for a long time but Trouble puts it on the map. 

Good job.

I'm coming back to build my own damn house


Oh, CA$H ONLY folks.
author: Susy C.

description: Mediocre coffee and terrible service from a rude serving staff.  The place is tiny and can't accommodate any amount of people waiting.  The baristas have horrible attitude toward customers.  It wouldn't be acceptable if the product were great,  but with a mediocre product it's just a joke.  Never coming back.
author: Davin A.

description: Coffee is mediocre and service is TERRIBLE! Don't even think about asking for any extras. Something as simple as a glass of ice water had the guy at the register acting like I was asking him to perform neurosurgery. Oh, sorry man, that I had to "inconvenience" you or your coworker to try to get me some ice. Did I get the extra ice? No. He replied with the water is cold anyway. I also noticed that their mentality is, we serve what we service, if we're not up to going the extra step, forget it or get lost. Trouble Coffee your customer service is crap. There are other places to get coffee along with some professional service.
author: Jack M.

description:
The trouble with Trouble Coffee is that they're selective with their service. There is no menu -- they have variable pricing. Staff is rude if you're not already friends with them.

After paying, was unnecessarily told "muchas gracias" based on my appearance. Stood around long enough to see that sort of banter is not regular for their other clientele.
author: John C.

description:
I admit I was suckered into finally trying this place because of the long lines that I see every time I pass by. 

If you've ever watched the TV show Portlandia and thought it was hilarious, then you need to come to this place at least once. That is all I could think about as I was laughing at the absurdity and irony of the scene unfolding before my eyes while sipping on my latte. At least from that respect, the trip was worth it. 

After being greeted with a "wassup" by a squinty-eyed fella, I ordered a macchiato and a latte. Unlike some of the other reviewers, I didn't think the staff was rude, but I can also see why they would come across as pretentious. As for the coffee itself, my latte was OK but I didn't think it was worth waiting for in a line with a TINY space occupied by a bunch of hipsters and their brass instruments. As for the macchiato, I thought it was pretty bad. My boyfriend drank the whole thing, but he didn't seem to enjoy it that much. Both drinks gave us an enormous caffeine buzz. 

The outdoor tree seating is awesome though - that's something!
author: Gloria B.

description:
My roommate: Hi, may I have a latte with an extra shot.
Cashier: No. You don't want an extra shot our coffee is really strong.

My boyfriend: Hey I think you might have forgotten our toast. 
Cashier: Did you get toast? Well what kind did you get.
My boyfriend: Cinnamon sugar. Like the one you just gave her.
Cashier: But she was after you.

Guy ordering in front of me: Hi, can I have a coffee.
Cashier: Yeah sure man how are your kids? How's your wife, Kim? Did you guys enjoy your trip up North?
*conversation continues*
Cashier: Cool dude. See you next time. 
Me: Hi! How are you? Can I have an iced coffee?
Cashier: $4.
Me *pays, tips*
Cashier *silence*

Me: Hi, may I have a large iced coffee?
Cashier: ...suuuuuuure. You know. That's a lot of iced coffee. 
Thank god you're here! I'm just an unknowing non-hipster that knows nothing of the relation of small-large. 


So glad I'm moving out of this neighborhood. Because Java Beach's coffee is bitter. And the service I receive at Trouble Coffee is comical. 

For all the reviews that say that people who hate the service here just aren't friendly: You're probably wearing a beanie and lensless glasses. You probably suited up in your perfectly manicured outfit that says, "I don't listen to the radio because once things are mainstream they are too played out." You probably just got back from your trip to Amsterdam or maybe Thailand. I agree, YOU get great service here. 

I don't feel bad for giving this place 1 star. Because they act like I'm a 1-star customer every time I go in there.
author: Annie R.

description: This place is okay. It's not my first choice but it works for my coffee fix because it's close. The toast is decent when you don't feel like making breakfast. The guys at the front counter are grumbly and not in a good mood. I can't blame them since I'm not a morning person either.
author: Irene C.

description:
This is the land of $4 toast and outfits and attitudes way cooler than yours. 
I come here because my friends all live within a walk of the store. Not to mention two of my closest friends have been former employees. That being said, I still feel like there is way too much of a locals only vibe at Trouble. 
The coffee is awesome, the toast is incredible but your first visit can be a little intimidating but its all worth it when you're sinking your teeth into the sweet, buttery heavenly toast. 
It should be noted, my fellow yelpers and foodies, there is a pretty staunch rule against taking photos inside the store so hold your instraming until you're outside.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: Hip place for hipster coffee. Minus one star for: wish they had almond milk and the heavy metal was a bit cacaphonous. The coffee was good. This place works symbiotically with Outerlands.
author: Andrew K.

description: Try the cinnamon toast! (They don't have much else in the way of food). Really hits the spot with an iced coffee!
author: Ronnie S.

description:
Got off the bus and walked a few blocks to "trouble coffee". Heard about this place's owner/founder on NPR and heard they made a great toast to go with your coffee.

When me and my GF arrived it was busy and full of people (it's a small place so it doesn't take much). Got our coffees and a blueberry crumble cake and stood outside in the interesting setup they have outside.

After our coffee I saw people leaving with this toast we had heard about. So I went in again and ordered a cinnamon toast. When we got it was like a great French toast slice that was gooey and toasted at the same time. 

Can't say anyone is serving toast and claiming it's the best but trouble must be in the running. Buy the toast, it's pretty good. Coffee is great too. 

Only complaints I might offer is that the place is crowded with locals and seemed a little off-put by outsiders but it wasn't a problem and the staff was pleasant. Was an interesting coffee experience.
author: Chad M.

description: The chocolate banana bread is moist and delicious. The lattes are amazing. It was pretty busy and they forgot to put in my latte order. Not a big deal to me, I'm not rushing. When I reminded them they apologized and I got a complimentary cinnamon toast. Super nice. It's grunge and tattooed guys are making my coffee,  what's not to love?
author: Sawsan D.

description: Don't get me wrong - I mean, who doesn't like toast art?! The peanut butter and honey were great (hard to mess that up - especially when it looks so darn pretty). But a bite of the toast all by itself...blech. Josey Baker bread at The Mill has ruined me. Trouble started this whole toast craze, so I expected their toast to taste better as a standalone. Maybe that's not what they are after, but it's all part of the prize for me. First timers tip - the "menu" is on the wall behind you when you walk in.
author: Robin P.

description: Horrible customer service. A woman who works there said I couldn't be on my phone even though I was actually just checking the time but um ok. I asked for two mochas. She kind of scoffed at me, and didn't say any confirmation so I just stepped out. I guess she forgot to put my order in so we had to wait 20 minutes extra. No apology by the way. My Mom didn't want to go back there because she said the service workers were too pretentious. Sad to see, they must have been from a different town or state because people I know that we're BORN and RAISED in San Francisco don't act like that.
author: Mileti A.

description: The staff weren't at all rude to me so - having read the other reviews - I feel as though maybe I didn't get the full Trouble experience... Coffee was nice enough. I live around the corner so will probably be back.
author: Fi M.

description:
Yes, the cinnamon toast is amazing. Simply more decadent than what you would make on your own. 

But no decaf coffee options at all. Weak sauce :-(
author: Karla R.

description:
2 dollar 75 cents for 1 small cup of Americano.
I am not an Anti-American, but I am a God-less person who is not much into any Jesus things but this is the best Americano I ever had.

As myself, a God-less person, means I suppose to be a bad person, right? Hell No! Bad means good! Am I in trouble? Hell yes I'm in trouble! Getting bad. No, Shit!

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kNbZcT8RXgE

Great whole in the wall coffee joint.
Loved it!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Hands down my favorite coffee shop!!

I always order the cappuccino whenever I'm visiting. The coffee here is great! 
A must try in my book if you're nearby and in need of some coffee. Because the coffee is so great here in my opinion, that I don't mind waiting in line. 

Warning: No cell phone usage while in the coffee shop. I witnessed how the barista will call out ppl on their phones in the store.
author: Kathy N.

description:
This place is pretty much a no-frills coffee place; simple and basic, that's why it's great. The cinnamon toast is INCREDIBLE and totally addicting, and their coffee is on-point. 

I understand the frustration of them not having a menu, but I'm sure they're able to make you whatever you want if you ask. Just don't make it super-complicated. If you want something really complex, hit up a Starbucks. 

Oh, and this place is cash only. There's a 7-11 across the street if you need an ATM.

Every time I visit SF, I'll make it a priority to make a trip here because it's THAT good.
author: Ace U.

description:
This place is super cute!  There are three window bar seats in the tiny place but there are places to sit out front.  There's this huge winding tree trunk in front so you can't miss the place.  It's a very trendy, hipster coffee shop.
The coffee is good and the toasts are delicious!  I've tried the Nutella toast and the peanut butter & honey toast.  The lattes are quite small and the only choices for milk were whole or soy milk.  While I do like the place, I probably won't be coming here often.  The service was iffy and it was a bit pricey for what it is.
author: Nikki L.

description:
Sometimes there's no menu so you're expected to know what you want when you get to the counter.  Or just be brave enough to ask the man at the counter.  The coffee is fine, it's good, it's great.  I just don't like the unwelcoming vibe this place gives off.  Makes me want to get in, get out, forget about lingering.  I guess that might be what they want though.

As for the toast, folks please just go home and make it yourselves.  It'll be just as good and cost you less. I've tried it and it's just ... well, toast.
author: Renee L.

description:
I liked it. The coconut was fun. For an asian guy like me, it wasn't the most unique drink in the world, but it was very refreshing. The toast was good. Not expensive either. Cash-only policy kind of surprised me, but what the heck, it only costs a few bucks.

I live in the Outer Sunset, so I'll definitely be back. But I don't think it's worth a trip across the city just to find the epicenter of fancy toast, which is frankly just thick sliced toast. 

Service was good too, but is it really too much to ask to have a menu with like a short list of available toast toppings?
author: Mark C.

description:
Bitter coffee, too many slumming hipsters, counter Attitude with a capital "A." 
Two stars is generous.
author: Tough C.

description:
What? No menu? Then how are you going to order if you're not already a coffee connoisseur?

No worries! The baristas here got you no problem. I tried my friend's coffee and it just goes down smooth and delicious. I myself ordered their cinnamon toast and a cold, refreshing coconut. I know toast is good, but who knew toast could be amazing. Just chill on the parklet outside with these treats and your day will be made. Just remember to bring cash.
author: Celia G.

description: This was by far the worst service I have had from a cafe. A cashier named TAYLOR refused to service me. I ordered a Chai Latte and he refused to give me half the amount of chai they normally give and more milk, because I have a weak stomach for spices. Common question I ask everywhere. No one has ever once questioned this. This guy not only told me he only makes it one way and that it tastes much better with more chai, but after I insisted I couldn't handle a lot of spice in the chai, that I just like a little, he told me 1) "well you shouldn't be ordering a chai then," 2) "I'm not going to make it." So, me and my friend who drove all the way over there for some toast and a drink, left empty handed and pissed off. DO NOT COME HERE IF YOU WANT TO HAVE A NICE DAY!!! READ THE BAD REVIEWS (someone uses the word Nazi to describe the service). It's not worth ruining your day for some toast or coffee. If the owner wants to keep her busy going, she needs to hire people who know how to communicate with human beings.
author: Clevergirl G.

description: Coffee is okay, comparable to blue bottle. People working there are rude. No menu thing is annoying and they don't offer any help when you ask what you can get there and how you should know what to order without a menu.
author: Emily M.

description:
$4 toast. and worth every cent.  Great coffee and the people who work there actually care, about coffee.  

Go for the trifecta: Coconut - Toast - Coffee. CTC.
author: Masato W.

description:
EXCELLENT great quality coffee! pastries are fresh & tasty too! hey have a cute nicely decorated spot right in front to sit & enjoy your cafesito! + such sweet friendly people work here! 

PD: they do not have almond milk (alternative for vegans that wish to stay away from soy)
author: Giselle C.

description:
It's not your grandmother's coffee shop. Cash only, no wi fi and they will let you know it! I've seen customers walk in who are used to being pampered at places at Starbucks, which is all good if you're into that, but Trouble won't do that. So don't expect anyone to suck up to you. It's very much a "locals" coffee shop.

If you're not a jerk, the staff are a group of cool, surfer/skater/insert label here, human beings, and once you start venturing there enough, you create a unique bond between the staff. It helps that I live down the street. If you're a jerk, they won't be afraid to let you know. "This is Trouble Coffee!!" an employee once yelled to a Beamer driver, stay at home Starbucks soccer mom. That didn't go over well.

The coffee gets you wired. I recommend the Gateway; a large ice coffee that holds you over for an hour. Very unique pastries; apple and pumpkin pie scones! The cinnamon toast is awesome. Some of the prices are a little high, but it's no different then if someone wants a blended drink (which they don't do!) 

Some things to know- bring cash, stay off your phone when ordering, and don't be a kook. Cheers!
author: Brad W.

description:
Well thank god for Yelp because now at least I know they have a menu somewhere.

The coffee and espresso taste good! That's why people keep coming back.

They're not very friendly, of course... and the toast is just a stick of butter with sugar piled on top. not the healthiest, but it's fun.
author: Carleen W.

description: It was one of those crisp mornings, a respite after a few days of rain. A friend suggested coffee, and I asked him, "Have you ever tried that Trouble place?" I'd read about the toast in an article and been wanting to try it, but don't find myself in the Outer Sunset very often. And now, having been there, my thoughts are restless. That cozy cup of delicious americano is haunting me, taunting me to try to find a better one somewhere else. The crunch of the cinnamon toast with its the buttery afterbite keeps appearing in my mind. "Come back." it beckons. "Come back for more." Even the tree branch bench out front with its heart-shaped hollow calls "Come back, friend. We've only just begun." Oh yes, we have. I knew you were trouble.
author: Pickles P.

description:
This place is located on the N Judah line.  The guys running the show are very nice down to earth bunch.  Small place but good when you just want coffee and a snack.  
The coffee called elbow grease has a good kick to it.  The bold and earthy flavor makes it stand-out.  Good for drip or espresso!!!
author: Philip W.

description:
I'm fairly certain this is my favorite coffee in the city. Espresso is good, Americano is good, Cappuccino... oh that perfect milk foam. It's hard for me to deviate from my addiction but I really want to try their dirty chai.

Not to mention that TOAST. Cinnamon sugar toast is ridiculous.

I have had nothing but positive experiences from the staff.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Get the toast! I've tried a couple of different kinds, but I'd say their staple cinnamon and butter is reliably amazing every time. Their coffee is strong and they have their own in-house roast, so definitely give it a try. 

Per foodie fashion, I was going to take a picture of my  toast and coffee when the barista informed me that they don't allow photos or electronic device use inside because they want to keep Trouble Coffee an experience destination. Respect. It was also refreshing that when I asked for a menu, they didn't have one. Instead, the person at the front replied, "You can just talk to me, what do you feel like having?" Double respect. 

This is a neat little place with unique decor and a cute little seating area inside (like 5 people). They also have a nice outdoor seating area. Everyone is very friendly.
author: Julie G.

description:
Unbelievably unpleasant experience... After a lovely brunch at Outerlands, we decided to check out the hipster coffee spot a couple doors down on Judah.   Ultimately, I wish we hadn't.  My wife walked out shortly after being refused an espresso macchiato in a to go cup - (Blue Bottle does this as well but doesn't spit in your face about it).   

I was outside with our dog so didn't quite hear what happened, but got the gist... I then went in and ordered a cappuccino to go and was immediately berated by the entire staff for taking a picture of the space with my phone.   Almost in unison, I was literally screamed at by no fewer than four people behind the counter and told how annoying I was for doing this.   I don't care how good their coffee is- which actually was pretty good, (although a typically overly milky cappuccino), there's no way I would ever go there again.    One of them even yelled at me in a total bullying fashion "I better not see that up on Instagram!"...   Less than an hour later I erased the picture, not wanting to ever be reminded of the experience. 

Hope they enjoy their little hobby as I doubt this business will survive....
author: chas k.

description:
-No photos allowed inside. Not sure why they dont allow it. This is probably the first coffee shop ive been to that doesnt. 
-They also dont have a menu so youll just have to ask the barista what you'd like. 
-limited seating. Seems more of a grab and go type of shop but theres a few stools inside and a bench right outside. 
-CASH ONLY. 

I didnt have the chance to try their so called famous toast but i did have a taste of their drip coffee and gibraltar. Definitely a lot darker roast than what i would like. Both cost $5.75 total so the price is not too bad. Aside from stopping us from taking photos INSIDE the shop, service was ok. i didnt really experience the 'bad service' previous yelpers mentioned below. 

Perhaps next time i am in the area i will ask for one of their specialty drinks and the toast.
author: Michelle H.

description:
toast is good,
the coffee is average,
the space outside is decent,
the staff friendly is below average
author: Paul P.

description:
Large outdoor parklette, with folks drinking their coffee with their dogs and lounging around. Small space inside, a little dark, combined with the fog and cold of the Outer Sunset makes for a darker space. Add the blaring metal music and I got out of there as fast as I could, despite the barista's serious focus on the coffee he was making. 

This article puts it in perspective though:
http://www.psmag.com/navigation/health-and-behavior/toast-story-latest-artisanal-food-craze-72676

Makes me want to go back for a coconut, sit outside away from the music, and strike up a a conversation with a stranger.
author: Shirley Y.

description: I have only had the coffee here. People really seem to dig that brick sugary toast. Working on my Coachella diet right now, so not trying anytime soon. The guys are pretty friendly. Rock/metal music always blasting and the employees seem to have a fun time. Don't ask for stupid alternatives like soy milk or anything sugar-free - guy at the register will laugh at you. I overheard him once say, "all of our coffee has caffeine and all of our milk has fat."
author: David D.

description: Good coffee. Good toast. Rudest staff on earth. No thanks.
author: Aeon G.

description:
I built my own damn house here, and I have to say, it was a pretty good house. The TOAST was so good and so was the coconut. I loved it and I would visit Trouble more often if I could. 

However, the atmosphere is a little intimidating... Maybe it's just because they know I'm only a wanna-be hipster.
author: Kathryn Y.

description: Almost worth going... Just so you can laugh at how absolutely rude the baristas are. Just make sure to try to pay with a card, and ask for a menu! They love that! Oh!!! And ask if the hipster fuck with the beard can take a picture of you!!!!!  He'll help you choose a filter and everything!
author: Natalie D.

description:
Stopped by here for a quick espresso last night after a meal. I hadn't been here before but it looked cool with a great parklet. As I walked in I was greeted by the barista who greeted me with, "We're closing so I can only do something fast to go". There was a customer in front of me so I thought, oh, it must be like 10 min past closing. Nope, 7pm on the dot. So I say, no worries, I'll take an espresso to go. Barista said, sorry, we don't do espresso to go. I can pull you a short americano. Uh....okay?! My two friends were so taken aback they walked out and said they'd rather not get coffee there. 

The coffee was good. But the lack of customer service angered me. You're a tiny little shop in the outer sunset. You're really going to pull that crap? Good coffee does not mean you can be an arsehole. At least at Starbucks I can count on friendly people that WILL stay open an extra minute to serve a customer.
author: Melanie N.

description:
After listening to the owner's story on This American Life, I had to come here. It is a beautiful story of community and pushing through life's struggles. I support a story like that. However, the staff is rather unpleasant so I will never return. I'm all for trying things at least once, so if you truly want to take a trip out to Trouble, here are a couple things to make your trip as pleasant as possible:

-Bring cash
-Know a basic coffee drink you want beforehand because they don't have a menu. If you want something non-traditional, ask the barista about their special drinks
-Do not ask them where their bread is from 
-Do not take photos inside
author: Lisa H.

description:
Cashier ripped us off. 

We ordered 2 black coffees (nothing special) and 2 pieces of toast...paid $13. We were only given one piece of toast, and when we asked for the second he said we had only paid for one. We told him how much we paid, and he said "yeah, that's right" and just went back to buttering bread. Of course there's no menu board, so we couldn't disputed it. And $9 for 2 mediocre cups of coffee is ridiculous. 

We went outside and asked someone how much is a cup of coffee at Trouble. Without hesitation she said, "$2.50," which would make our math correct. 

Bottom line: the staff are jerks; toast is tasty; don't bother with coffee. 

Worst part is that we tipped generously prior to receiving our order.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Small place.
The cashier is your menu! But I saw photos of the menu in the Yelp pictures too.
Had a cinnamon toast. Gets messy. And that's all I've been thinking about whenever I see bread.
author: C. C.

description:
Love this coffee sport. I went for brunch to Outerlands, which had an hour wait and this place was such a nice spot to wait for it. One of the best coffees in town, out of control chocolate chip cookies and fresh coconuts!

Definitely check if you are in the area.
author: Nadia A.

description: Another hip cafe that serves mediocre coffee. They are cool. I want to give them 5 stars, but...
author: Earl G.

description:
Ok, I am giving one star for the nice girl behind the counter. Another star for the cute inventive design. One more star for having banana bread that my bf wanted. I would have given four stars, if the owner didn't sour my latte and ruin my banana bread with her attitude.

The 6oz. or was it 8oz. latte you gave me, your only size for lattes, was a bit of a let down. 

I was about to drive to LA on the 1 the entire trip. I needed more espresso than that, and more liquid to sip really, for the drive before my next stop. 

While I was admiring the shop's quirky decor, I decided to take some pictures of it on my iPhone. My friend lives nearby and I wanted to show him a new place to try. I like to take photos and text. So sue me. Which is close to how the hipster cyclist short haired lady owner made me feel. 

I get you are proud of your store. You likely worked hard and long to come up with a concept and carry it thru production to the stage. I get it. It looks cute and quirky, with a touch that must be yours, also a poet/writer.

But don't chastise me for wanting to share your store (and increase your profits) by advertising it via MMS to my friends in the Sunset. 

I will NEVER go here again, and have shared my story with those friends. It's a shame. 

Learn your lesson. Also..if someone WAS to identically copy, or somewhat all of your never seen before ever on this planet ideas...consider it the most sincere form of flattery. If you live in fear of people seeing it, I mean...geesh.

Anyways, you made me feel like a child being scolded for reaching their hand in the cookie jar, and it ruined that latte, and the banana bread I purchased with it. Thanks.
author: Alia R.

description:
I heard about this place through some friends that suggested I try the cinnamon toast, since I am crazy about cinnamon and sugar and butter. I mean, who doesnt like any of those things, or all of them mixed together. 
So first, No Use of Electronic Devices - a little sign hung inside the door. Okay, no problem, I see not using your phone in a small cramped place when you are trying to order, its just rude. Ordering was fine, except the fact they had Wu-Tang playing, with all the "f" this and "f" that, and the staff were singing along. Okay, I live in the Mission, I get being edgy and not giving an "f" but you are working, trying to run a business, not everyone wants to hear foul mouth coming from employees. Overlooked that for the time being. Realized that the place had a Valencia street vibe, but a strange arrogance of Santa Cruz, like, "We are too cool to be here, this is our rules, and "f" you" Like they are doing us a service for being in business. Again, overlooked this, cause this is San Francisco after all. A man was asked not to take photos in the store, and to "enjoy being here" - again, as if being there, you set the rules. But, I digress, its too small to take photos, and no one wants to enjoy their food and drink with a camera in their face. 
I went back inside to ask about the coconuts and was told they sold them, and I asked "It's just coconut, nothing in it?" And the reply was "Nope, nothing in it just a coconut" Okay, cool, no problem, I saw spoons and rarely eat coconut, but I love the water in them, so call me a newb, but I just wondered what the deal with them was. What happened next is the reason you are getting two stars and why I likely wont return. As I was leaving, the cashier joked, with coworkers, "What? There is drugs in the coconut?" Which was not only snide, but rather uncalled for. I asked a simple, honest question, I did not need to be mocked or made fun of or have attitude thrown openly about it. I too work in a restaurant, customer service and was once a barista, so I know the silly questions asked from people, and it's totally okay to laugh and joke, just not where people can here it. You aren't working for that. You are working to serve, and to push a great product, with that comes a great attitude and loyalty. To which the employees of Trouble have trouble understanding, dealing with, and are gaining no loyalty other than one and done customers who arent going to return. 
Aside from this, feeling humiliated and embarrassed, the toast is decent. Worth the price, not even close, I can make it at home with Texas Toast and my own toaster - am I glad I tried it, absolutely, cause it was good, not mind blowing, but mostly cause I got the service that I did, and now know just one more place to avoid and not recommend. Thanks.
author: William D.

description:
CASH ONLY! And they don't have a menu so you gotta ask the cashier what they have!

Pretty good cinnamon toast which you can taste the butteriness too. They have fresh coconut which made it refreshing too. I need to go back and try out their coffee!
author: Hey Y.

description:
Oh, Trouble, you gave me some trouble.

I was so excited to venture out to this lovely abode and into the ensuring embrace of Karl the fog in the outer sunset, but my hopes and dreams were crushed.
 
It takes forgetting my toast (that deliciously thick, sugar and cinnamon detailed stuff dreams are made of) and remembering my company's, and being rude to me when I inquire about its whereabouts, and having me wait more than a reasonable amount of hangry moments without any sort of recognition or hunger apology or pep talk of "it's on it's way!" or even a simple smile, or even a lazy, slight half smile,  that makes me not want to return. 

I know I'm just another girl in San Francisco with bangs, but this sort of treatment to a girl who really only needs a piece of toast or an acknowledgement of a mishap was peeved by this incident. 

I'm not one to insult the product because of less then pleasant customer service, the toast was beautifully done and I can't say there is anywhere else in San Francisco who does it quite that way. And the coffee too. There is a reason there is a line out of the door and a collection of people and their dogs lounging outside on wood with blissful smiles on their faces.  

 But, Trouble, even though you're popular, you should be sensitive to the fact that hungry girls with bangs Yelp too.
author: Allyson D.

description: This is a great spot. If you don't like toast now, you will after you try this place. Coffee is great and the toast...big fluffy pieces toasted, slathered in butter, topped with cinnamon and sugar. So delicious. I've also had it with Nutella. Don't go for the customer service ...this place is hipster-ish and plays loud music so if those things bother you, you might not enjoy it. There are a few bar seats inside but most seats are out. Super dog friendly and they are CASH only!
author: Neal B.

description: Super busy during Bay to Breakers, but the line kept moving and the coffee kept pouring. The toast is not to be missed, crispy and thick slices, topped with lots of butter and cinnamon sugar. Yum! Their Chai is spicy, the Lattes are perfect! Be aware: there is only one size of latte (8oz) and one size of chai (12oz), and they are CASH ONLY!!!
author: Ashley W.

description: I was walking around the sunset today with my girl and stopped in here for a quick cup of joe. The service terrible and they were kinda dicks. The coffee was kinda cold too.
author: Mike B.

description: I live four blocks away and had heard a lot of hype about this place so I decided to check it out! I read online about owner, Giuletta, and her amazing story. I too, was curious about the "overpriced" toast. I was hesitant to stop in after reading some reviews about the lack of customer service but I will try anything once. I walked in and was given a friendly greeting- which is always the best indication of how my service is going to be. I ordered a latte- only size they have is 8oz and it was $3.50. I also ordered a piece of cinnamon sugar toast, also $3.50. The barista was super pleasant and accommodating- great since I had an impatient seven year old boy with me. He was more than happy to cut the toast in half for us. Great experience! Little pricey for my everyday latte but this is a great San Francisco treat!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Haha wow. I've been wanting to try this place for a year (don't live near) and I've got mixed feelings now that I have. The coffee was pretty good and the cinnamon toast was delicious, but the workers were surprisingly snobby!  I don't expect workers to fake a smile or conversation, but is it to much to ask for more than a chin nod of exasperated acknowledgement and mix between a sigh and a greeting 'what do you want?'. They didn't say anything rude in particular, but, as another review perfectly described them, they acted like they were too cool to serve the customers. Very douchy hipster vibe.
4 stars for the coffee and toast
2 stars for the angsty hipsters serving it without a glimmer of interest or joy in their vacant eyes.
author: Chelsea D.

description: AmazIng granola bar, the best one I've ever had. Chocolate and caramel after taste, pecans and oats. Delicious! Recipe please! And a pretty spicy chai latte.
author: Antoine A.

description: I have dreams about the cinnamon toast and I love coming out to this location as often as I can, but am glad there is a new location in Oakland so I don't have to drive across the bridge for my fix!  I also love the earl grey lavender latte (the girlfriend?)  Try it.
author: Andrea F.

description:
I think this place flies pretty under the radar as I believe it is the best coffee shop in San Francisco. The first time I came to Trouble the owner was doing an interview for some television special. I felt a little hesitant when arriving to see TV crews around, but she paused the interviewed and nicely welcomed me to Trouble. The staff has always been helpful with recommendations and quick service. I also love how close this is to the beach, because sometimes happiness can be as simple as a cup of Trouble coffee and an ocean view.  

Only downside about Trouble is you cannot take pictures of the unique decor inside. However, I also respect that as it keeps their stylings a secret and not to be easily duplicated.
author: Sara D.

description:
There's no place like home. 

Only downside to Trouble - they serve cold brews in paper cups.
author: L Stephanie L.

description: Great coffee, toast, music (some awesome, obscure, loud Alice Coltrane album), staff, service, vibe -- all the best SF that has to offer.
author: Adam Z.

description: This used to be my favorite spot, it always felt like part of the neighborhood and my favorite spot to stop on my way back from the beach. But I will not return. But I was treated terribly by a misogynistic cashier today.  While ordering my toast, my 85 year old aunt called.  I of course took the call (not in the habit of ignoring old women).  The cashier told me no calls inside.  I nodded and waited for him to hand me my change so I could finish my conversation outside.  Instead, he held my money and refused to give me my change.  As I couldn't leave without my money and couldn't hang up on my Aunt, I was perplexed.  He rudely said, "No calls inside. Now you're not getting your toast." as if attempting to discipline me.  I am a paying customer.  He would not have taken this approach had I been an older man rather than a young woman.  I was astounded by my treatment.  I asked him to return my money and I left.  Neither myself nor my family will return to Trouble coffee, which is a shame because we will walk by every day.
author: Jessica M.

description:
No joke, this is a hipster hang out joint. They're here almost all hours of the day when there is daylight. I've come here for coffee and espresso a few times and its become MEH to me. 

Earl Grey Latte is pretty good, but I've had better. 

The rustic ambiance in the shop is nice, however, I could do without the clickish hipster crowds.
author: Jason C. J.

description: Stopped by again to grab coffee for a friend and I, as we would be traveling out of the city and needed the caffeine. The coffee here is alright, and the toast is absolutely delicious, but I will not be returning due to the atmosphere here. The staff only seem to be nice to their regulars and are not friendly at all to new customers. While waiting for my order, I received a call from my friend asking if I was ready and had barely said two words when the cashier yelled at me to go outside. I had not known that phones were not allowed inside and had I known, I would never have picked up that phone call. However, I had barely said anything on the phone and I was talking very quietly, so there was no reason for the staff to yell at me in such a rude matter. I wish he had told me politely that phones were not allowed in the establishment and then ask me nicely to go outside instead of straight out commanding me to leave. I did in fact go outside to finish telling my friend that our order was not ready yet but when I returned back inside to continue waiting, I felt uncomfortable the entire time. I understand that I broke the rules but I really wish that the staff had been more nice about it. I just don't find this place to be be very welcoming to newcomers and will not be returning.
author: Christine K.

description:
This is pretty much as hipster as it gets...they don't even have a menu! The baristas were super friendly and helpful though. Just tell them what you want and they'll probably be open to making it as long as they have what you're looking for. 

My bf and I went to check this place out on a rainy day and luckily, there was no line and there were a couple available seats inside to enjoy our toast and drinks. It's a pretty small place, but there is also a bench outside to hang out at. I decided to order the regular cinnamon sugar toast (recommended by the guy working) and my bf ordered the peanut butter honey toast because he is obsessed with peanut butter. If you're a first timer, definitely order the cinnamon sugar! Its sooo good, but then again, it is kind of hard to go wrong with toast covered in butter and sugar... I love their bread though. It's so soft on the inside and crunchy on the edges, and it's loaded with butter and cinnamon sugar. The pb toast was just okay - it was too rich and sweet for me. Also, be careful when eating the pb honey toast! It can get messy - I somehow got some honey all over my jacket when I tried it.

For my drink, I ordered "The Girlfriend" which is basically an earl grey lavender latte. So yummy. All lavender lovers should order this. My bf wasn't in the mood for caffeine so he ordered a coconut drink. It's really interesting how they have coconuts here. I regretted not ordering one for myself because I was slightly hungover on this morning. These four items came out to around $17...pretty pricey so I probably won't be going all the time, but I'll be back one day!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I was super happy with my experience, both food and service were top quality. Sure I had to be corrected that the coconut I ordered is actually called a "build your own damn house," but they were nice a welcoming about the clarification. The barista was also very kind when they had to inform the three people behind me that, no. they do not take credit or debit, but pointed them in the direction of an ATM. 

I ordered an americano (excellent), toast (better than The Mill in Alamo Square), and the "build your own damn house" (refreshing). 

Sure I totally fangirled out on this place but I am so glad I did.
author: Lexi M.

description:
Come for the toast, stay for the authentic hipster vibe. I have never been to a coffee shop before where they play death metal in the background. It's not for everyone. 

Be warned: there is no menu so you will either need to (1) know what you want ahead of time or (2) quickly be able to scan and choose from the available items on display.
author: Sam R.

description:
GIBRALTAR! 
CINNAMON TOAST!

Who knew there would be a cool coffee shop this far out!?! Every time I'm here I feel like I'm intruding on surfer territory. But it's okay, all of them are friendly and engaging. 

The gibraltar is a good and quick way to get my coffee fix. They never hesitate to offer a swisher shot to send you off on your way too. The toast may seem intimidating but its a must, at least once. If you're all the way out here already, you might as well drop by.
author: Dennis L.

description: Decent coffee and delicious toast, but service is not the best. They're very disorganized with taking orders and putting them out. Someone could easily take drinks they didn't order by accident. I waited for my drink for 20 minutes until we realized someone took my drink. They were not super nice about making it for me when I told them.
author: Sabrina B.

description:
A cute little obscure hipster coffee shop flowing from people coming in and out of Outerlands. Got a latte here along with my friend as we were waiting on eating at Outerlands. Great place. Great latte. What can I say.
You know what? Latte art always wins my heart over. I feel like Im holding a little cup of art and Im probably gonna wish I didnt say that after this review.
Nothing spectacular, just a nice cozy place to grab a drink and sit down for a little bit in the abstract seating outside.
Would definitely recommend. Plus, I definitely need to come back to try some of their toast I see raving reviews on.
author: Veronica L.

description: Went looking for some quick, decent coffee, so I came into Trouble Coffee. Unfortunately I waited over 20 minutes for an Iced coffee. Didn't help that they decided to kick everyone out of the store to take a five minute break. Must have been really straining pouring that iced coffee... Bad customer service, but okay coffee. Just okay. Next time I'm just going to Starbucks where I know I'll get quick and friendly service.
author: Ryan J.

description:
We finally made it over to Trouble after wanting to try it for ages.  I read Yelp reviews extensively before heading over and was expecting some good toast and coffee and some terrible service.  Was quite worried about it spoiling the good eats, actually.  We got the good toast and coffee, but NOT the terrible service.  They were completely friendly, no problems with the service whatsoever.  Dare I say even friendlier than most coffee places?!?!  They were definitely friendly to their regulars which is great to see, but they were also friendly to us newbies.

Not sure what the negative fuss is about, but maybe because we knew what we wanted to order from reading about the place first, we did not take pictures or take out our phones at all, did not ask for special coffee requests, etc.  They have their shtick and we try to respect that.  If you are going to complain about $4 toast, then don't buy it.  If you must take pictures of everything you eat, go somewhere else.  If you need a menu, this is not the place for you.

My latte was delicious.   I got the peanut butter and honey toast and loved that.  The one piece was definitely hearty enough to be a meal.  My husband enjoyed the cinnamon toast, but said he prefered Andytown coffee.  We ate inside as it was raining and enjoyed the quirky decor and friendly atmosphere.

They take credit cards (I swear, I used my cc and they had Square) and I saw things like almond milk in their fridge so maybe things are a changin'?
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Went in here for the first time really because I needed to use the bathroom, but figured I'd order something just to be decent. After I had ordered, I walked toward the back, only to be told that there were no restrooms, by the overly tattoo'd chick employee who JUST came out of it. Ok.......

Then I sat down and started to call my buddy. "Can you take your phone outside?" they say. I was so startled that i spilled some of my drink on my hand and on the floor. "Napkins are outside," the dude says in a boring tone of voice.  Ok...........

So first they deny paying customers a bathroom, and then they also kick them out for using a phone indoors? Stop trying to be cool, and focus on providing good customer service.  

So I wasted 2.75 for a shotglass of grapefruit juice.  Why, oh why, did I go against my better judgment and visit the Outer Sunset?
author: David L.

description: The woman with the tats is incredibly rude! I was buying coffee for a friend who has trouble hearing and does not understand English well and she was rude and disrespectful to both is us. I wouldn't go back there if it was the last place to get coffee in the city!
author: Wave A.

description:
Trouble serves a wonderful cup of coffee, is always full of great free spirited energy, and is arguably the birthplace of artisanal toast.

If you've ever met Trouble's owner, Giulietta, or just want to read a great story about a remarkable woman, sit down with this one: http://www.psmag.com/navigation/health-and-behavior/toast-story-latest-artisanal-food-craze-72676/
author: Melanie W.

description:
If you're by the beach, you must stop by to Trouble. This coffee shop has a great story, great toast, and great coconuts.

Apparently, this is the shop that made artisanal toast "cool". So all of those bougie $4 toast places, the "tip of the hipster spear", can thank trouble for its origin.

The items that you can order are seemingly random: coffee (what the owner Carelli calls "guts"), espresso ("honor"), coconut, toast (cinnamon, peanut butter & honey), fresh squeezed grapefruit juice called "yoko".

The toast is great--thick, at least a stick of butter melted on each, and smothered with spread. When you bite into it, it is so unexpectedly light and crispy.
author: Andy J.

description: Tiny, cash only. But oh their cinnamon toast! Great parklet in the front to enjoy your coffee. Little hipsterness out in the Outer Sunset.
author: Dirk d.

description: Neat punk rock / metal vibe. Service is poor. Coffee is meh and overpriced. Would not return.
author: Robert W.

description:
Good coffee. Mediocre service, like they'd rather not be bothered with their customers. Morons behind the counter.

Lack of seating space and a poorly designed parklet add to the problems.

Unfortunately, there's little choice for decent coffee in this part of the Sunset.

Added 6/23/14: The recently-opened nearby Andytown is *vastly* better than this place. The coffee is better and the service has received better training. I say give this place the finger and take a stroll to Andytown. It gets everything right that this place finds itself fucking up.
author: Chuck G.

description:
This place is a vortex of bad energy. Horrible customer service. Avoid at all costs. My friend was screamed at for trying to use the bathroom. 

Here's and idea- start carrying decaf. You need it. You are way too charged up. Who screams in a cafe? At customers?!
author: Bons S.

description: Overhyped. Had a sip of husband's latte which was decent, but I ordered a soy chai which was terrible - the worst chai I've ever had. Made from powder and watered down, bland. Also annoying that there is no visible menu especially when there is a line out the door and you are needing to decide what to order without one - turns out they only have one size latte (smaller than a Starbucks tall) and no decaf coffee. Later saw that from Yelp reviews that they have a honey lavender earl grey latte, but again, how would I have known that without a menu. Some staff are nice, others outright rude. One commented about my lack of tipping right after I ordered - suggestion: make those comments after the customers have left, not when they are still within ear shot.
author: Christine C.

description: The staff should really get a few lessons on customer service . Not friendly and always very rude . Won't be going back . Also a few my friends won't either . Sad
author: Danielle L.

description: They may have great cookies and overly priced coffee. But the guy at the register is a rude dick. I hate when these new hipster businesses come into neighborhoods and offer a decent product but do not have the common decency to be kind to patrons. What business model teaches you that?! I'm over it I can make my own damn cookies and toast. With service like that, they won't have enough business to continue to pay the rent. Maybe that's why the coffee cost so damn much.
author: Janelle M.

description:
I really wish I could write a review on the coffee or toast here, but I wouldn't know what they taste like, and honestly I don't think I ever will. 

I'm new to the city and heard great things about this place so when I realized it's a block away from where I live, I excitedly walked over to try it out. Well this place has no menus. How the hell am I supposed to order anything? If I don't know what you offer, am I literally supposed to go up to the register and just say, "I want one coffee please." Do you have food? Do you have tea? Do you have different sizes? The blonde girl ringing up drinks seemed friendly and was chatting up guests with a smile. She looked busy, so before getting in line, I walked up to a dude behind the counter, smiled, and asked if they had any menus. He looked at me like I was the stupidest person in the world and shook his head and turned around to walk away. No explanation. No suggestions on what to order. Nothing. 

I was so turned off by his attitude that I immediately walked out pissed off. Maybe he was having a bad morning, but judging by other yelp reviews, Trouble's customer service just plain sucks. Too bad =/
author: Cat M.

description: The guy working the cash register had so much attitude. made the experience not as pleasant.
author: Liv P.

description: Came after hearing about Trouble on This American life. The owner wasn't around but the place had all the character/culture I expected it to and was a great time. The cinnamon toast is to die for, peanut butter was just okay in my opinion. Coffee is average, grapefruit shot is good but pricy for the size. The employees took a group double shot of jaeger at 11 am. Overall the entertaining visit I was expecting. Go here.
author: Brett L.

description: Everything about this place is awesome. Nice baristas, fantastic toast, delicious grapefruit juice, great decor.
author: Sara K.

description:
I've been coming to Trouble for 7 years now because the cinnamon toast just can't be beat. Yes, they're cash only so don't try and pay with a credit card. It's close to the beach, so it's always fun to take your coffee/toast down there. 

I love this place!
author: Ramsey M.

description: I'm sad I didn't try the toast because I feel that my rating MIGHT have been higher. I didn't even know about the toast because I didn't even see a menu? Where was that? The service was alright. The guys at the register were friendly because they have too not because they really want too (it seemed). So many coffee shops on the street and I just don't think this one compares (small cup, doesn't taste good- even when you ask for flavoring, and expensive).
author: Jordan W.

description:
I have a love/hate relationship with this place. Sunday is a good day to come as the staff ups their friendly customer service game and the customers are more varied with families and regular joes mixed in with the hipsters. Weekdays are to be avoided lest you fit in with burnt out or snarky hipsters balking at endless orders of toast arguing for almond as opposed to soy milk in their coffee while shouting over blaring punk rock.
Yet... there I am, hating myself for tolerating the attitude to get my fix of freaking amazing toast and latte.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Ordered the PEANUT BUTTER TOAST...it was good. not rockin' good, but OK. 

hummm, not sure it was YELP-review good.  My pal goes there often JUST for the toast, and she'd 5-star the TOAST. I wouldn't. 

The great thing about the server is that she went out of her way to cut it into 3 -pieces so  my posse could each enjoy a taste. (They did NOT say everyone needs their own which the reviews seem to postulate! But hey, their name IS 'trouble' after all ! )

So, after reading all the 'lack of customer service' comments, I'd have to say, they were really nice to us. And, yes, we do not give off the 'hipster'-vibe. Now, the clerk's attention did go to the 'hipster' who walked in and broke away the attention from us, but hey, it was like watching zoo animals...fun to enjoy for awhile, but i wouldn't want one at home.   

TROUBLE, Observe 'hipsterness' in all its glory.
author: Addadada A.

description:
And people forget
Forget they're hiding.
Behind an eminence front
Eminence front - It's a put on.

Come and get some pretentious coffee from our condescending workers.
author: Xany K.

description:
I'd build my own damn house errday if I lived closer.  This spot is legit - staff, parklet, and the rest.

Cash only.
author: Jenn C.

description: This was on my foodie bucket list and it lived up to my expectations!   The cinnamon toast was divine and we also tried the peanut butter and honey toast - also wonderful.  Great Chia Tea and coffee - and the coconut drink is not to be missed - so fun!
author: Jamaize S.

description: Alright coffee, and horrible service. I'd rather have one or the other. Not both. Unfriendly staff and none helpful
author: Amber S.

description:
I have never met a man, a woman or The Queen who could pop my cufflinks off my french cuffs and turn me on to tea. Until, Trouble. Until Trouble's "Girlfriend" tea. The "a little delicate, annoying complicated, but worth it" tea of lavender earl grey, an odd other herb taste, honey and steamed, frothed milk.
