The Toast. Everyone talks about it, and there's a reason. Order any drink, order toast, and post up in the best parklet in all of San Francisco. If you're looking for a reason to hop on the N Judah out to the ocean, here it is.
author: Jon A.

description:
So the staff gets a bad rep. Yeah, they have tattoos and earrings. There's weird dolls on the wall, and an animal skull or two. Who gives?

They did bark at me when I came in, and seemed to be having the time of their lives giggling away together behind the counter. I scanned the walls for a menu, couldn't find one, but was pretty set on ordering a cappuccino anyway. Glad I went with my gut -- it was seriously one of the best cappuccinos I've had in this city. Strong, with a smooth lingering aftertaste. My friend ordered a soy chai, which sadly was a bit on the spicy, watery side to me. 

By the time I'd finished up my drink at the counter (salvaged wood, very nice), the line was out the door. My general take on Trouble Coffee: While the atmosphere is not the most inviting (the baristas certainly do not go out of their way to make you feel comfortable, but they aren't exactly rude either), the coffee is delicious. Just depends on what your priorities are.

Tip: When the weather's nice, take your coffee outside to their public seating overlooking Outerlands. Pleasant spot to soak up some sun and take in the fresh ocean air.
author: Tiffany W.

description: My feelings are torn on Trouble coffee. The inside was very small and had some relaxed distressed decor, but the doorway is super close to that of a preschool which with a long line got very crowded as people were going in and out each door. The latte was great and I really enjoyed my lemon currant scone. One complaint was that there was no menu so we didn't know about all the different toast options which we later saw people with and they looked delicious. Over all it was a very pleasant experience but I'm not in a rush to return.
author: Kylie B.

description: I sat at the counter, where I enjoyed a coconut, cinnamon toast, peach crumb cake and coffee. The staff behind the counter made me want to be a regular. No laptops here, just neighborhood folks enjoying a beverage and conversation.
author: Ro M.

description:
Toast. Get the toast. Don't settle for anything else. Coffee is good too. Service was good and friendly. Outside seating is so communal and hip that I felt cooler just being in the area. 

Love it.
author: Mystical G.

description: The peanut butter honey toast is to die for. I grew up on peanut butter toast and at first thought WhAts the BiG deal it's just Toast n peanut bUtter??! But ya, no. It's just that good.
author: Sara Z.

description: We read about trouble and her story so we decide to give this place a visit. We ordered holy shit toast and it was just too much toppings and carbs. Felt a little strange in the stomach afterwards. They don't really take credit card so make sure you have some cash. The coffee was good but not really memorable. I think coming from Taiwan where this kind of fancy thick toast is abundant and cheap, paying 5 dollar for this doesn't sit well with most of our group. I would have to say that this place is uniquely San Francisco and I would take out of town friends here just to experience this new trend.
author: George L.

description: Perfect stop for a sunny day. Only because there is hardly any indoor seating and the outside seating area is pretty nice. I ordered a regular coffee and it was aiight. I wouldn't drive out of my way for a visit but it wasn't disappointing either.
author: Kristy F.

description:
That was the best cinnamon toast, coconut, and iced coffee* I've ever had. That's 3 out of 3. The girl behind the counter did seem a tad put out by having to deal with customers, but fake-chipper is worse than condescending, so I'm ok with it. 

*tie with Coffee Shop, on Mission at Precita
author: Scott C.

description: Lavender shortbread and sturdy coffee made my afternoon. Great staff and decent music.
author: Rachel F.

description: Best Coffee in San Francisco! Maybe anywhere honestly!
author: Morgan B.

description: Stopped in for a pick me up on a weekday afternoon. First time in the neighborhood, sun was out, nice laid back area. Had a delicious latte, cinnamon toast and grapefruit shot. Bare bones, a few stools on the window. Bench sitting outside. Enjoyed the place.
author: John B.

description: Coffee was good. Friendly people who knows every customer.  Good pastries.  Toast was ok.  Definitely generous on butter for cinnamon toast...too much for me.  Nice parklet to enjoy coffee n sf sun.
author: Linda T.

description: Strictly reviewing the taste of "the girlfriend," the toast, and their iced latte, I would give them a 4. I'm giving them 3 stars because 1) the size of their iced latte was laughable, 2) their reply to my request to have the girlfriend iced was, "We only make hot girlfriends," 3) you have to figure out what they have on your own, since there is no menu in sight, and 4) they're cash only. They do have a nice little outdoor area though where you can sip your drinks and wait for your name to be called for Outerlands.
author: Janet M.

description:
Dropped in on a whim yesterday for some toast and hot beverages.  I ordered a chamomile, which was lovely in a large solid mug that said "Trouble" on the side.  And the little knotted bag had real chamomile flowers in it, not that dusty stuff.  

Now: the toast.  I watched him make it.  The bread is insanely thick (like more than an inch thick) and he slathered the crap out of it with butter, then sprinkled an extremely generous coating of cinnamon sugar on top.  Yikes.  I was expecting it to be a major sugar overload.  But I have to say, even though the toast "trend" seems pretty dumb on the surface, that was one perfectly executed slice of cinnamon toast.  All elements were perfectly balanced.  Crispy warm and chewy bread, salted butter, and cinnamon sugar, all join hands in the most beautiful toast harmony one can imagine.  Pardon me for waxing poetic about some damn cinnamon toast, but dude, it was good.  Like stupidly good.

I could have done without the blasting screaming metal, but you can't be all things to all people.

If I ever make it back to the Sunset, perhaps I'll drop in again for some warm crispy comfort.
author: Rachel S.

description: The coffee is outstanding-- I love the latte. Also, the Lavender Sea Salt shortbread cookie is my new absolute favorite. I don't quite understand the hours they are open. It says 7 am to 7 pm but the past two times I've gone there at around 12 noon they were closed, only to open about 30 minutes later. Do they just pick random times to close and open? I dunno, but the coffee is good so I'm not complaining... really.
author: Rob W.

description:
The best cinnamon toast EVER!  Forget about trying the toast at other places, this is the spot to get the best toast that you will ever have!  The slice of toast is thick, buttery, with just the right amount of cinnamon.  

It's pretty quick too and you can grab a cup of coffee or tea with it!  The ginger tea was pretty good considering that I was nursing a cold.  

The place itself is small but there is a nice outdoor seating area right in front of the store.  Still dreaming about the toast!  Yummy ...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I have to confess, I was a little intimidated to try this place out. I just imagined me walking up to the counter with some snooty casher sneering at my lack of coffee knowledge. I was dead wrong!

These guys are great! Very welcoming and witty. I was tested with a request for extra dirt, and I declined. Passed that test!

The dirty chai blew me away! I could taste the spiciness of the chai and earthiness of the coffee. Not scalding hot, just Goldilocks right. There is no need to add sugar if you want to enjoy the simplest pleasure and/or have a delectable slice of their Cinnamon Toast!

The Cinnamon toast was out of this world! Light and fluffy, with a crispness, toast and a perfect balance of cinnamon, sugar and butter. You can actually taste the butter!
author: Kristyn W.

description:
I had high hopes for this place as I wandered down the street to get a coffee while waiting for a table at Outerlands. I love how neighborhood-y and visually interesting that little block of Judah has become, despite the oppressive hipster vibe. I kind of like the hipster vibe in fact, even though that is not how I "read," certainly.

So, my friend and I go into Trouble and speak to the lovely, adorable guy at the cash register who recommends their cappuccino ("the foam is like marshmallow"); I admire the atmosphere, and the cute wooden counter and am tempted by the cinnamon French toast and am already planning a trip back with my 2 kids who would love that place. My friend and I decide to go with the recommended cappuccino. The order gets forgotten - but no, that's not so troubling to me - that kind of thing happens and it is easily and politely rectified. However, I AM troubled by the fact that one of the guys behind the register (not the adorable one who helped us originally) leans over to my friend who is benignly leaning over the counter waiting for her cap (which, remember, the order of which had been forgotten) and says in a very rude and somewhat aggressive tone, "This is our register. Can you move?!"

Dude?! WTF? Seriously? It seemed not only very poor judgement and awful customer service, but also very hard to imagine him being so rude to either 1) a man; 2) a hipster of any gender; or 3) a young, beautiful woman. Now my friend IS a beautiful woman, but she is not 25. It was just unnecessary, rude, and made me think that the guys who run that place think they don't need the business.

Coffee was pretty tasty though; foam especially. Still not sure I will go back much as my kids would love to sit at that counter....
author: Judith S.

description:
I am giving 5 stars now because after a year of coming here this place is SO much better in terms of their attitude and welcoming vibe. Coffee is STILL the best in the city and the cinnamon toast is BY FAR the best - even better than my Nana's!

The outdoor seating is super unique and very comfy - bring a big sweater or hoody to enjoy the outside area.
author: Michelle J.

description: Had a latte and a friend had a mocha. Tasted mostly like milk even though he said they don't add much milk. Staff is very abrupt and rude. I get that it's a popular place but I don't see the need to yell at people that are not sure what they want (since there is no menu) or don't know where to stand (not much room inside). Pricey for the quality. Had the toast. Good, but not worth a separate trip.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
earl grey girlfriend - it was beautiful, sweet, and aromatic :) 

the fanny pack  - lol it's an americano topped with foamed milk
author: Jacquee P.

description: Love the simplicity and honesty!  The owner's story inspires me.  I can't wait to come back.
author: Joni W.

description: I heard the Radiolab (or was it This American Life?) episode and had to stop by just to check it out.  Sure, it's overpriced toast, but at least it's a unique experience.
author: Bob L.

description:
There are 12 oz and 8 oz sizes. There are espresso and non-espresso drinks. They make teabags with loose leaf tea. They also make tea lattes and the depth charge. Get the elbow grease. Get the cinnamon toast. Now get inspired and make the toast yourself at home, but come back for the coffee. The toast is good for sure, thick and soft like texas toast. The coffee is pretty amazing. 2 cups of coffee and 1 toast will put you under 6$.

There is also the fresh young coconut, but it's so not worth it. While I certainly can't replicate the way the coffee is prepared here, even if I bought a bag of trouble beans, I can most definitely chop off the top of a young coconut that I bought from the supermarket for a dollar.

The place is small, but plenty of counter and some benches. Our barista was friendly and helpful.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I met someone here and I have to say it's one of the best coffee I've had. Well, I had a latte, it was so good, I had two which I rarely do in one sitting.

I notice they also served young whole coconut and watch a guy easily eating one. I'll have to go back for that treat.
author: Brandon M.

description:
I think 3 times now I've paid $2 for a coffee and all 3 times I've thought to myself "self, this is only marginally better than the coffee at Uncle Benny's Bagels & Donuts at 22nd & Irving. It is in no way worth the .50 more and the Persian Aub Zam Zam game of hipster attitude roulette"

And so to Trouble I will no longer go.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Very cute and small coffee shop

Love the outside seating area

House coffee good!

Pastries are good too

Come and try their coconut drink, straight out of a coconut!
author: Carol Y.

description:
They have nice quality coffee and delicious toast with funny names. I had a holyshit(peanut butter+honey+cinnamon) 
It's very good, a bit of too sweet though.
author: Chester C.

description:
The cinnamon toast was fantastic. The coffee was good too. Seemed like a very friendly place and the reception we got at the front was positive and welcoming. The only negative is that there isn't a menu so you just have to ask about what's offered, but I suppose facilitating actual human interaction is their overall goal. Just don't come here when you're in a rush and you'll be set. 
It is a mom and pop business so it's a bit pricier but we really enjoyed our experience there.
author: Chase R.

description: This place is alright. The cinnamon toast is actually pretty good but it's very greasy! You're going to need lots of napkins! Just got the usual latte and it was alright. I gave them 3 stars just because the customer service was ok.Pretty chill area in the outer sunset right next to the beach. Overall it's decent.
author: Janice B.

description: Coffee is brilliant. Workers are super nice. Vibe rules and it's a super chill place. Highly recommend stopping in.
author: Lucy O.

description:
All I ever drink is espresso. Straight up. All I care about is espresso. If this doesn't sound like you, you probs should disregard my coffee reviews.

Still with me? Good. Trouble is small. No, I lied, it's tiny. There's enough room inside for like 4 people to sit at the bar, the another maybe 4 at the window, but who wants to sit inside when you've got a sick parklet right outside the door? Yeah. 

Service is great and lively. The dudes in there are friendly and quick... and kinda loud. So maybe that's a good thing or a bad thing, depending on how hung over you are. 

Prices are decent, $2.50 for an espresso.

So yeah, the espresso. I forgot who's beans they use, it was someone I wasn't familiar with, but they're good. Above average, actually. They've got decent machines, so they pull nice shots. Thick and creamy. Personally, I feel their shots are a TINY bit too hot. I think if they tuned it down ever so slightly they would get a better tasting shot. The presentation I'm a big fan of. They serve their espresso on these cool ceramic cups on rectangular plates and the presentation just works, especially with the vibe of the area.

That being said, it's the best in the Outer Sunset area. I live in Outer Noriega and walk up for their coffee when I had (key word: had) 2 shops within 2 blocks of me. Those shops are both now closed, and Trouble is poppin' off like Devil's Teeth, so apparently others were walking north for good coffee too.

It's not the best espresso in the city, but it's the best for miles.
author: Johnson M.

description: I read an article about the owner of Trouble and the toast craze and was excited to check it out. I was not disappointed. The coffee shop itself has a wonderful atmosphere with an artistic living room vibe (although seating is outside). I waited in line for 10 minutes. The guys working the counter were super friendly. The cinnamon toast was delicious. It was huge and I was sad when it was gone. Their coffee is yummy, too. I'm dying to go back. I cannot wait. Such a treat.
author: Kat R.

description:
Awesome little discovery; really tasty cakes, 
Amazing coffee and toast well you just got to try it !!!!
No matter what the weather sit chilling outside on the driftwood is relaxing and a great way to take a moment.
author: Jaime I.

description:
Love it!

My boyfriend and I have tried this place three times already. I've found that the male cashiers are way nicer than the female ones (at least in our experience). 

I even got my coffee free today for placing the menu back on the rack. :)

Thanks guys!
author: Angela R.

description: I loved the idea. I loved the stickers. I even loved the coconut/coffee/toast combo...but nothing makes up for that rude attitude from the staff. I don't need to feel belittled and insulted while trying to give my money to a small (somewhat dirty) coffeeshop. The place has been hit and miss but this last abrasive encounter sealed the deal. I won't be returning.
author: Carmella L.

description:
What's with all the hipster haters? Do you live in San Francisco? Have you been to a coffee shop before? What do you expect? I know it's silly, but if I wanted a smile and a red carpet rolled out for me, I'd go to Starbucks. Instead I want delicious coffee, tea, and toast, and I'm willing to accept that a hipster will be taking my money (God knows it will be in cash and cash only) in order for that to happen. 

Honestly, I've never received the bad treatment some people talk about here. The first time I went in, I was nervous because I was wearing Lululemon and looked out of place. To make it worse, my friend and I were indecisive about what we wanted and unsure if we had cash on us... 

Were we shunned or scoffed at? Did they tell us we didn't have enough tattoos to be served there? Did they summon a fixed-gear pedicab to take us away? Not even close. Our server was so sweet and adorable and walked me through all of their tea options. He waited while we decided on toast or a muffin, and he gave us everything with a smile (SHOCKER).

Another thing that's great is that they really look out for the community. Fun anecdote: my brother is a lifeguard at Ocean Beach, and they give him free coffee all the time. 

This place may seem like any other pretentious hipster coffee shop, and maybe it is, but at least they have a sense of humor about themselves (look at their website) and deliver a good product. This isn't a corporate coffee machine staffed by bubbly high schoolers, and you should be able to see that before you walk in the door. If you get a little attitude, brush it off and enjoy the darn toast.
author: Jenny M.

description: The strangest thing about this place is the absence of a drink menu.  Only after asking was I told about the Girlfriend, a tea latte with honey and lavender which almost is worth the drive to the Outer Sunset.  The cinnamon toast is bomb, of course. $4 is a bit much, of course, but when living in SF, why skimp on toast when you're already paying the world's most expensive rent?  Heard there's a place on Divisadero doing the same thing, slightly closer to civilization and presumably without the anti-technology spite that cost them a star (seriously, one of the employees snapped at a patron taking a group pic).  Go if you are in the area but don't brave the Outer Sunset blah just for this spot.
author: Annmarie L.

description:
I don't really like coffee in general, but the coffee here is so good that I can not only enjoy drinking it, but take it black. It' s smooth and not bitter at all.  Their pastries are always on point. The cookies are chewy and soft, and their scones are buttery and moist, and I'm a scone snob. They also have a great banana bread. 
The public outdoor seating right outside is on pretty driftwood logs among cleverly planted plants. 
The staff tends to be friendly, but can get preoccupied talking to their friends. I've also observed more attentive service for young, attractive women, which may or may not be a plus for you.
The only other drawback is that there are no print menus. No chalk menu. No menu to speak of. But...I think they can pretty much make anything. 
Overall, whenever I go to Trouble Coffee, I'm pretty confident that I'm at one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco. It's really good coffee.
author: Allxie C.

description: Great local place to stop in for coffee. Has great community vibes, and the cinnamon toast and the stickers are not to be missed.
author: Kira M.

description:
If you get an espresso, ask for a "swisher" after you finish. They will take your empty demitasse cup and put in some brewed coffee to soak up the leftover oils so you can get every last drop. It's free and a great service that everyone else should provide. 

Some of the workers here have a little attitude and they might look intimidating, but appearances are deceiving. They all know their stuff and they make each drink very carefully. They make seriously good coffee here. I've never had the teas or coconuts so I can't speak for those.
author: Anthony H.

description: I don't drink coffee because I'm not a goat though everyone I bring here doesn't say its terrible. I go for the coconuts on a nice "hot" SF beach day.  They're rightfully tasty and a spoon is included to eat the pulp.  The coconuts are from the philippines which is really far away.  A more responsible source would be Mexico or dare I say Florida, though those coconuts suck so lets just get bigger flip flops for our carbon footprint.  $4 toast is really $5 toast as you should leave a tip for the belaboring job of schmearing butter, sugar and cinnamon on bread.  Tastes like a giant piece of cinnamon toast crunch®. Yum. There's a sign that says "no electronic devices" yet they use one of those pad doohickeys for payments. Ironic since tax evasion is much easier with cash unless they know something I don't.  There's a book displayed called "Growing Up Absurd" they won't let you look at. It's a great book everyone should read. The last time I went was on a day I was thinking about our reptilian overlords and some dude started talking to me about the ninja turtles so I had to get the hell out of there.  This place might secretly be run by the CIA.  The women who work here are cute.  The gentleman quip funny.  I dream of the day I walk in and the album "Trouble" by Ray LaMontagne is playing. We don't deserve this place.
author: Chris K.

description: You gotta get a coconut when you come here. Amazing! Nothing like it. Good espresso here too. Had an americano and it was great. Didn't even need cream and sugar. Very bohemian/beachy feel. Small space but feels cozy. Nice wood bars. Great customer service.
author: Lisa V.

description:
The cinnamon toast is so yummy!   My friend and I tried to recreate the cinnamon toast at home and then we ended up getting burnt cardboard polka-dot crackers.  And then we still ate them and got stomaches and reminisced of the good times and toast that we had when we went to Trouble Coffee.

I love how you can have random conversations with the staff. They are just too cool for school.
author: Lee G.

description:
I actually am not a HUGE fan of this place, but some reason I always stop by when I'm in the area, just because I can't get enough of their toast, and the coffee is pretty good, too. Latte is small, but freshly roasted and has a nice nutty note. I've had both the peanut butter and cinnamon toasts and both are amazing.. I don't understand the review that complained about too much butter on the toasts. There is literally no such thing as too much butter, ever. 
I can't really say anything that the other reviewers haven't said already--the baristas are pretty rude, it's an uncomfortable ordering experience because there's no menu (that I can see), it's cash only so that's inconvenient (my bf and I had to share one toast and one latte today and felt like bougie paupers), and there's not really a place to sit, except for outside in the parklet. But I don't really want to sit on a giant branch, because I'm a princess. 
Despite the downsides, I'll begrudgingly admit that this place is pretty delicious, so I'd recommend giving it a try. I honestly never really have a craving for Trouble's toast to go out of my way to come here, but I usually end up here every few months when I'm taking a walk around Ocean Beach and I always have to stop by. So lukewarm 4 stars, I guess.
author: Jacqueline K.

description: Cinnamon toast was delicious. Coffee was expensive and small, but still good. Would return!
author: Haylee L.

description:
Wake up, walk down to Trouble, get a coffee (that's all you need) and small cookie, and take it down to the beach. Your life is good. 

Separately, the toast is insane so be prepared. Other folks have had issues with the staff's friendliness and I understand, but it's never bothered me none.
author: Axel F.

description:
I feel like everyone in the Outer Sunset has been lying to me for years. 
"No, don't move here," they said. "It's so cold and foggy. Really, stay in the Mission."
Now I realize they were just saying that to keep this amazing place their wonderful neighborhood secret. 
I had the Girlfriend (Earl Grey tea, steamed milk, honey, lavender) and a slice of the cinnamon toast, and I was instantly in love. Even under low fog, sitting in Trouble's parklet and feasting on these goodies was a warming, wonderful way to spend a morning. I'll be back for sure!
author: Tricia K.

description:
Stopped by here while waiting for a table at Outerlands. Heard about this coffee shop from a friend and decided to try. It's a tiny, rustic, and hip coffee shop. The place from outside to inside was covered with hipsters and wannabe hipsters with ugly dogs dressed in cute clothes. 

I got the latte and I must say one of the best coffees I've ever drank. I debated if Trouble trumps my past favorite, Blue Bottle, and I think it did. Yey to new favorites.

But, why you gotta be so rude for, barista?! No star for you!
author: Cindy W.

description: Love this hole in the wall located way out in the fog at the end of Judah...  Excellent coffee.   No one was an ass- not sure what these other reviewers are talking about.  Nothing hipster here.   We saw Giuleta too.   Quirky girl - listened to her story on This American Life after our visit.  Made us love it even more.
author: J M.

description: Really excited to finally get here. You cant miss it on the block, packed with ppl out front.  Ordered a coffee, mocha, cinnamon toast, and pb honey toast totalling about $15.50. There's no menu posted at the shop so you should look on yelp to see what they have. The toast was really good, nice and chewy (5 stars). The coffee and mocha not so good (2 stars). The cup of mocha was really small and can't taste any sweetness at all and had to wait about 30 mins for just the mocha. Would come back again for the toast. Gonna try the lavender honey pb toast next time.
author: J C.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for long time now and finally got the chance to this morning.  I now know the meaning of a hipster coffee shop.  I have nothing against hipsters, but the guy who took my order wasn't the most polite and the other staff members were using profanity loudly.  I had asked the guy taking my order if the toast would still taste okay if I took it to go.  His response in a sarcastic way was "you can take your toast wherever you want."  Also I had requested bags for my toast and instead of helping me bag it up he handed me 2 bags.   I get the chill vibe of this place, but it still is a business.  

The latte was decent, and the toast was delicious.  Wish the services was up to par.
author: Kristin C.

description: Super food! Amazing coffee! Staff? Probably the rudest I've encountered. However I love the place so I keep on going back and I'm starting to warm up to the staff so I guess they aren't that bad. The place doesn't have a menu though. They have a lot of options but again no menu.
author: Elena P.

description:
So I recently moved across the street from Trouble and I'm trying to become a regular. The only problem is, their staff makes it kind of hard. It seems more of a 'Locals Only' kind of place, and they aren't the friendliest people. However, their coffee is AMAZING and their toast is perfection. I'm still trying to figure out prices, because the last time I went I only got toast and coffee and my total come out to $7.50, like what?!
However, I'm still gonna come back! I can't go a week without toast!
author: Alexa A.

description:
Extremely rude employees. My coffee cup was so hot, I could barely hold it. When I asked the cashier for a coffee cup sleeve because it was scorching my hand, he replied condescendingly, "oh no. It's scorching your hand? Well there are napkins outside that you can use that will work just fine for that." 
Oh...and their coffee was "meh." I didn't try any of their pastries or toast.
author: D T.

description:
CASH ONLY

Great espresso. Ask for a swisher - nice to have along with our cinnamon toast. Always busy bit somehow room at the bar. Friendly service if you just calm down and relax
author: T T.

description: Not that great of a spot for me despite all the hype. While I love coffee, I don't do caffeine ... when I asked if they served decaf, the amount of attitude I got made me realize I'm not hip enough have coffee here, caffeine or not.
author: Kristine Kris C.

description: My fave cafe in SF. Great service and professionally made, original tasty coffee!
author: Belinda W.

description: Damm good coffee in this tiny whole in the wall place.
author: David G.

description:
Membership has privileges. When I go to Trouble, they make my drink before I even order. Their cappuccino is the best I know of and must be consumed in a "for here" cup. Their espresso is fantastic and they are a true Sunset institution, all grunge and swagger. The customers belly up to the bar.
One caveat: I go in the morning. The afternoon crew boots you out without warning and can be testy. Or not.
author: jessica d.

description: 6 dollar bag of dark roast coffee beans by the ocean,... Can't beat that,
author: Louise L.

description:
We recently started coming here on a search for some REALLY GOOD coffee/espresso in our new hood.  (unfortunately the sunset is pretty dry in terms of great coffee...)

Anyhow, we have really been enjoying a delicious latte here.  I also ordered a MATADOR, which is a cafe au lait with a shot of espresso in it... the only way to get a latte-ish drink in a size bigger than 8oz.  (I think it's 12 oz?)  very good, but i think I still prefer my latte!

Nice sense of community and nice chats with people sitting next to us... we are making this a regular spot!
author: Toby B.

description: Worst I've ever been treated, at a place of business, in my life. Congratulations you were written up about in NPR, people talk about your toast, and your staff are mediocre barista hipster, fixie bike riders - the basics of a good business is being positive, thankful and warm to your community, who supports you and hands over our money to keep you in business. I wouldn't be surprised if business starts to lag when word spreads on how terrible your baristas and staff are (looks like it's already kicking up on Yelp quite a bit). I certainly won't be spreading word of mouth suggestions to go here.
author: Jeanna B.

description: I wanted to like this place, but the service was so rude and music so loud.  I would say not just rude, but mean and a really negative vibe. I live in the Sunset and was spending more time than normal at the beach and wanted some coffee so I stumbled in. I was ignored for so long and there was hardly anyone in the tiny tiny place. I ended up finding Andytown where I had the most MAGNIFICENT mocha of my life and greeted warmly. I have been  back to Andytown many times to try other coffee drinks  and even took my husband!!
author: karen h.

description:
don't miss this while you are waiting in line for outer lands.  remember, cash only. 

super chill spot.  not much seating inside so bring a jacket.
author: Casey L.

description:
This place has grown on me a lot. I still wish they would take credit cards though.

Otherwise, I've fallen in love with the coffee and cinnamon toast!
author: vicki c.

description: Local spot, don't come into the place while on your phone or they'll tell you to put it away.  I love that.  Great people behind the bar and toast is spot on.  Coffee and tea are awesome.  I'm partial to the depth charge.
author: Koa K.

description: Trouble indeed! I ordered a coconut which took forever to prepare, mostly because the barista couldn't keep up with the orders. Upon asking the cashier (whom was friendly) if they had forgotten about my order, he asked the barista if it was on the way. To which I hear a reply of, "I have a lot of shit to do!" Don't know if this guy can't perform under pressure but it was very off-putting, and paying $5 for a coconut is pretty ridiculous to be given this type of service. I was expecting this type of service anyway upon seeing the hipster vibe of the shop, thus I didn't cause a scene.
author: Chris M.

description: Just love this place. Coffee is delicious and cinnamon toast reminds me of being a kid again. Very cool space and cool people work and hang here. Don't even think I'm hip enough to be here! But seriously, great place.
author: Ashley J.

description: one of my favorite places to get coffee beside Blue bottle. The customer service was good to me. it is a very hipster spot. The toast was really good but they aren't very consistent with it. some days are better then other days. other than that i love trouble
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Like a few others have said, the coffee here is good but expensive, and the baristas are effective, but really rude. We came to get a pre-brunch snack and coffee while waiting for a table at Outerlands and wish that we walked a few more blocks to Andytown. Trouble Coffee is a tiny hole in the wall with cramped space inside but ample outside seating. It's pretty much the epitome of what one might deem as a 'hipster coffee shop' in the city. Being completely honest, the coffee wasn't bad and the toast, while simple to make, was phenomenal. That said, I wish the barista wasn't incredibly rude to my girlfriend when she asked if they had nonfat milk (I'd say a typical request, rather than something more rare and picky like almond milk). I also wish that  it wasn't cash only and so popular such that we had to wait 15 minutes analyzing why the barista was so pissy before we got our coffee and toast. 

In short, the coffee here isn't worth the inconvenience of keeping ample cash (who knows the repercussions we would've gotten if we asked if they took credit card), dealing with an angry barista, and waiting long. Head over to nearby Andytown and get a better experience.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Came to this coffee shop because 7x7 said that the cinnamon toast here is one of the top 100 things to eat in SF this year. We decided to come and get the toast and some coffee. You walk into the small coffee shop and it's funky and there is a sign that says no electronics. I think that is odd until I see one of the employees yell at someone for having a phone out. That seemed a little unreasonable and a little totalitarian. 

So eventually we walk up to the counter and they don't have any menus to let you know what drinks they make. So we ordered a latte and an iced mocha. My girlfriend said "can I get an iced mocha?" The employee responded "NO!" We thought he was joking but he was dead serious. He also seemed a bit annoyed that we would ask for such a ridiculous drink. How do you expect people to avoid ordering it if you don't have a menu? We also ordered the toast and asked for it to be cut in half because we saw the pieces were pretty big. Once again, "NO!" was the response we got. We just paid and waited outside for our stuff. 

I went up to the counter to grab the coffee and all we needed was the toast and we sat outside on the hipster driftwood seats. Eventually the toast came and I went to pick it up and the guy said pretentiously "Uhh, you didn't order any toast." I'm pretty sure I remember ordering toast and also paying for it. Eventually he realized his mistake and apologized but the sheer arrogance and attitude of the people who work there is unsettling. These aren't the nice, inviting hipsters of Andytown, these are the "we are better than you and we know it" hipsters. I've seen other reviews and many people have complained about the treatment and service they have received but people still show up! We control your life with coffee and hipsterness so you have no choice but to deal with our shit and you will like it! The coffee was good but not amazing and the toast was also tasty, however I wouldn't go out of my way to get it again just because of the hassle I would have to go through just to get it. If you live in the sunset and are used to being treated poorly I can see why you don't' mind coming here but I'm not going all the way out there to be treated that way just for a cup of coffee, there are plenty of other good shops in the city. You aren't the only game in town. If I'm in the area maybe I will come back but that's it.
author: Jeromy G.

description: After a nice bike ride to the beach I have usually ended up at Trouble Coffee Co. It's got decent coffee, desserts, young coconuts, and these great petrified logs out front for taking in the peace of the Pacific. The trouble is the staff. I have been here on so many occasions and they insist on blaring vulgar, grating music (who cares about kids hearing the F-bomb?) and/or sporting a non-welcoming attitude. The café doesn't have a lot of space, but they do manage to make your coffee-drinking as unpleasant as they can with what space they have. And it's cash only in an area without many bank ATMs. The name of the café suits it perfectly - I won't be back.
author: Kevin B.

description:
One of the best cups of coffee I've ever had. Do yourself a favor - get your butt out to sunset and try it!!

The cinnamon toast is also a tasty treat to get to-go as you wait to be seated for brunch at Outerlands.

Beware, some of the guys behind the counter can be extremely rude and pretentious. It was my first time and I felt like I was being chastised for not knowing what was on the menu or where I should stand after I order, etc. I understand you are a busy man, but don't f-ing take it out on your customers.
author: May I.

description: Heard about this place from This American Life - such an inspiring story and a cute place. We got the cinnamon toast (so good), coconuts (very fresh), and lattes (also pretty good). Wish I lived closer to here but next time I'm near I'll definitely revisit!
author: Amanda L.

description: Horrible, horrible customer service. Once we arrived the door was shut with the sign that said "be back in 5". A few other people seated near the door who had already got their coffee told us that sign has been there for a while.  So we wait, and wait.. and wait standing in front of their door, in the rain.  One of the workers came out to get something and told us they were cleaning up the floor and having change of shifts. Okay, So we stand and wait some more because we wanted to try this place for the first time.  We waited a total of 20+ minutes, and they finally opened the door, there is no menu. There is also no signs on the walls or at counter regarding their menu.  The cashier rushes us to order even after we told them it was our first time, they were completely unhelpful and rushed us though the order even though they had just made us wait over 20mins standing outside in the rain.  They are nothing but rude assh*oles with nonexistent customer service or common manners.  There was absolutely no acknowledgment regarding the wait, no "thank you for waiting" or "sorry about the wait".  I also heard them yelling, "tip your baristas!!" To other customers after us.  HAH!, how about better customer service and not be so terribly rude and maybe you will get some tips naturally from your customers.  Honestly the coffee and toast was fine, but their rudeness completely ruined everything. Any capable business should be able to mop the floor and switch shifts without shutting down the whole business for half an hour, please acknowledge your customers staying outside in the rain for no reason.
author: Ree'Ay I.

description: Really small place but doesn't stop the hustle and bustle. Came here for a last minute gift for my dad for Xmas. Asked the guy behind the counter about the coffee to purchase and which one was a medium blend. $13 bucks for a moderate size bag of beans and comes with a complimentary cup of coffee. I told him that was ok and that I couldn't drink coffee because I am pregnant at the moment. He offered me a herbal tea instead which was delicious and thoughtful. In and out, fast, knowable staff and happy customer!
author: Marissa J.

description: All I will say is... cuppiepies with a cup of elbow grease coffee. Get there around 10a.m. everyday, but Monday. 'Nuff said. You're welcome.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: I live nearby and every time I have gone there they have been incredibly rude. Maybe their coffee is good but not good enough to deal with their awful staff.
author: Catherine K.

description:
This weekendI spent a beautiful morning in the Outer Sunset with my best friend, some sunshine, and toast.

I must say I've never had such good toast.  At 4$ a pop I suppose it better be good.  It's huge, fluffy and loaded with cinnamon and sugar.  It's everyone's comfort food--my friend and I were both raving about how it reminded us of being taken care of on sick days as a child.

BUT it's so apathetic and hipster that it almost ruins the good taste of the toast (and delicious coffee).  No one smiles, no one is psyched you are there.  I actually liked that it was super crowded and bustling but I didn't like that no one has any patience or earnest joy for interacting with their fellow humans.  Bad vibes overall.  I came, I saw, I felt unwelcome to return.
author: Meg M.

description: Cute location in the chill outer sunset. I though it would be a good place to grab a coffee after brunch at Outerlands. Unfortunately it was an unpleasant experience. The soy cappuccino was fine, nothing special, especially in a city full of pretty awesome coffee. There is no menu so I actually opened Yelp to find out what to order. The barista was then completely snarky to me about using Yelp and then refused to tell me what was on the menu.  Overall, very odd. Would not go back.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Great coffee, great people, great treats, great shop.  it's a bit hipster (ok, a lot hipster), but I warned you in advance! 

highly recommend the sweet jesus. you have to be a customer to understand.

OH. and the toast. order the toast. DO IT.
author: Saba N.

description: Last time I came here the guys working here were arrogant rude hipsters. We were just being normal and ordering and he alway felt like he had to say something to one-up us or belittle us. Keep your hipster attitude outside of work and provide some decent customer service.
author: Nahal S.

description: I love this espresso bar so bad, "Trouble Coffee Co."! Sitting aside the street with the installation art work, viewing the beach scene only two blocks away, you can either to start or end a day in this fancy shop. I'd prefer to wake my day up here by its bitter featured taste. The decor is greatly stylish, I can picture bikers stopping by for drinks. It's pretty close to beach but not difficult to reach, google it you'll see how to get here.
author: Wei-Hsiang H.

description: Good toast and coffee, but it's not worth dealing with the rude service and the staff throwing around the 'n' word.
author: Amin S.

description:
1 star only because the toast, coconut, and grapefruit juice were decent, otherwise the service was the worst thing I have ever experienced and not even the food can help that. I will never come here again. If my review can keep you from having to experience the unbelievably bad service, then I have done my job. I don't care if there was a touching story about them on NPR's This American Life, it's not worth it. 
You can get toast, coconut, grapefruit juice, and coffee that is more affordable, tastes better, and with much less attitude all over the city, so do yourself a favor and go anywhere else.
author: John R.

description:
I've lived in the neighborhood for 4+ years and love the little park that Trouble has contributed out front.  

However, the coffee is overrated and every time I walk in I feel like im several shades of not-cool-enough to be there. Or maybe they don't want me there? It could be true but then again....

Hand held pies are awesome
author: Eva E.

description:
BUILD
YOUR 
OWN
DAMN
HOUSE..
..FOR SEVEN BUCKS. 

Sitting at the bar, coffee in my right hand, big coconut filled with clear coconut juice and a red straw in my left hand, and a huge thick slice of buttery cinnamony toast stuffed in my mouth. 

Coffee was yummy, coconut was a big coconut and not much more, and the thick slice of texas toast on roids was lathered with a butt load of butter to feed my badonkadonk. 

Where else can you get this stimulus package in the sunset, just a couple minutes from Ocean Beach, and let alone in all of SF? In this time of economic crisis, if you can't afford your own real house, or even your monthly rent, come here and build yourself a house to feed your spirit, soul, and belly. 

They only have one menu hanging on the wall. Make sure you return it after looking and don't pick up the lids for the pastries (they're very expensive) or else the barista might get mad.
author: Angela W.

description:
Food- Consistently good.  Nothing mind blowing but each dish is done well.

Service- Slow and unfriendly...
author: Tatiana T.

description:
Oh wow - the toast. First time in the neighborhood to visit Adapt (ok, for my son), we decided to look for some coffee while we waited. I got my usually Americano which was great, wife got a vanilla latte but was a bit too bitter for her so she got a tea. While sitting there, everyone coming in got the toast and on a whim, I decided to try before we left. Wow - what a taste bud surprise: hot. toasty. cinnamon.

I've been raving about to friends and family and we'll be back for another morning breakfast run - even if it takes 50 minutes to drive up from the South Bay.
author: Jerry F.

description: I'm sorry, did I really just pay $5 for some iced coffee? Was the guy at the counter punking me because I'm not trendy enough to spend money here? Sorry "bro" as charming as you are, I'm unimpressed with your overpriced, bland coffee.
author: Christopher D.

description: Bomb food, shitty attitudes.   I held up my phone to send a text and four employees swarmed me screaming "No Pictures no pictures please!!!"..... as if I was trying to take a picture of you, don't flatter yourself.   Great cinnamon toast, but the people here kind of suck to put it bluntly.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Trouble Coffee. I'm confused. I want to like it but I feel snubbed the few times I've come here. The cappuccino's are really great. It is odd they only have whole milk or soy milk options. Sometimes I just want a 2%er. The cinnamon toast is fantastic. I absolutely adore chillin' on the new parklet.

I have had a few experiences with the register employees being less than friendly. I'm not asking for cartwheels, just some reasonable customer service. I kind of want to know, are you trying really hard to be super hipster dipster and way too cool for life, or do you have a big ol' pine cone up your butt that is making you really unhappy? Having worked in the service industry for years I try my best to be unobjectionable to occasional bad days.  I also have to say suck it up and fake a smile for the customer or call in sick if you feel too sad to fake smile. Most customers don't want to pay money to be treated as a nuisance. And just another reminder that good service = good tips. Don't you want good tips? 

For some reason the people who make my coffees have been the stronghold that pick up the slack for some particular unhappy register employees. My 2 stars for my recent visit was turned into 4 stars because of one really polite and friendly barista. He was the super cute young guy with the big big big brown eyes if that helps. He's a keeper. Thanks to him for turning my thumbs down into a thumbs up.

I guess Trouble Coffee has it's good days and it's bad days. I will try you out again Trouble Coffee. But there are only so many more of your bad days that I can reasonably handle.
author: Kristen E.

description: They're really bad ass here. They told these tourists not to take photos inside the cafe. And said phones were not allowed in the cafe. This is because they can joke around like this if they want to. Or make up their own rules. They are their own boss and built their own damn house so when they have a sign that says they'll be back in 5, you're going to wait longer than that. And you need cash and the closest ATM is in a corner liquor store. Save yourself the trouble and go to the other location. That is unless the baristas rotate around.
author: Xteethx B.

description: Good coffee, cool little shop, good music.
author: Sarah S.

description: Very rude employees! It's unfortunate that a few bad apples negate the years of good will the owner has created.
author: Susan L.

description:
The vibe of this place is really cool, and the coffee was delicious! I got a latte, and it was foamy and rich. 
I'm almost never in the neighborhood, but next time I am, I'll grab a coffee and a slice of toast, and wander over to the beach to enjoy them!
author: Cami J.

description:
Strikingly excellent latte. I'm one of those unfashionable people who likes skim milk and fake sugar as an option, but I'm willing to forgo that for the nicely bold espresso they use here (and I'm perfectly aware that the milkfat tips the scales in Trouble's favor, so to speak). 

Also a nice assortment of baked goods. Although I would prefer labels that conveyed information about the baked goods, such as what flavors/ingredients they have, to "humorous" labels (see above re: unfashionable me).
author: Lisa K.

description:
Coffee purists! Whole milk only, no decaf, no artificial sweeteners. And instead of the usual array of coffee shop sweets and pastries, Trouble only serves a few homemade bread options and perfect, thick cut ,white toast.

Fine and simple. 

Love it.
author: Sabrina F.

description:
Wow, how wonderful it is!!!
I am not  a caffeine addict. I only have coffee once a week as a pleasure enjoyment.  I used to go blue bottle which is far from my place.  I finally realize there's a awesome coffee shop in my neighborhood (sunset district).  From now on, I can enjoy a nice quality coffee at Trouble Coffee each week. :)
author: JustinE Y.

description:
I've been here twice in the last week. My first time was last Saturday  when I was waiting to get brunch with my family at outerlands up the street. It was a long wait so I decided to go to trouble and grab a drink to temporarily satisfy my hunger. There was a long line and a crowd of people outside which are both good signs that the place must be good. When it was finally my turn to order, I couldn't find a drink menu anywhere! I ask the guy at the register what's good and he recommended the "girlfriend" which was an earl grey tea latte with lavender honey. It sounded good and I didn't know what else to order and I also didn't want to just try a regular coffee it being my first time. So after a long wait, I sip my drink and it was...okay. Just okay nothing special bout it. It tasted like earl grey tea with milk that I make at home. It wasn't terrible but there wasn't anything spectacular about it and I sure wouldn't be paying $6 for a damn tea drink that I could make myself. I wanted to save my appetite for outerlands so I skip the cinnamon toast. 

My second visit was on a Friday morning. No crowd and not too busy. I order a regular coffee this time and their signature cinnamon toast. Coffee was alright. Toast was good! It wasn't overly sweet and it had a nice fluffiness to it in the middle! Pretty good, I'd come back if I'm ever craving it. I wish this place had a large visible drink menu and what ever pastries and toast they have available. I relied on people's pictures and comments on yelp to help me order. They only accept cash which sucks because I normally don't carry cash with me. Luckily the first time I went, I just had enough on me to get me my very expensive drink. You aight, trouble.
author: Marie N.

description:
YUM! Seriously, if you lived closer to me trouble, I would be a regular at your door...how about you consider opening a second location?  I'd help you! We could do it this weekend.  

The coffee is amazing, I had the latte but this is the kind of coffee I would drink just black and dirty (its actually not dirty, I don't know why I said that, except I just mean non-fancy or foo foo)...

Naked and Zico have nothing on the straight up fresh giant coconut they give you...

and the cinnamonny buttered giant toast held me over for five hours! If I wasn't with someone whose opinion kind of mattered, I would have licked the cinnamon goodness off the parchment paper that bread came in...

Sitting on the tree outside the door makes for a perfect lazy weekend morning.  This may sound dramatic, but I was hungover...and that combination changed my day...there was such a before and after change in my mood that in the moment I would have gone so far to say it saved my life.

So seriously trouble, I am thinking somewhere near alamo square...
author: Kierstan G.

description: I really believe in supporting independent coffee shops like this one but every time I come here I sense a certain air of pretension coming from the staff. I like the music they play, like the parklet, but the attitude has got to go. It makes the not so special $3 cup of coffee I bought seem even less special. (The two stars are for the music and parklet.)
author: Esta L.

description:
Their coffee is like their music, strong and delicious. The toast is this thick mass of mesmerizing bread slathered in butter and drowned in cinnamon and sugar. I swear galaxies are made in that melting crust....

Expert baristas and a great wait staff. 

The matador and "build your own damn house" are fantastic after a crazy night especially with a shot of yoko... Inquire at the shop.
author: Andrew K.

description: So I stopped here before my tattoo appointment cause I wanted something small to munch on and it was pretty much right next door. Best decision ever! I like the chill atmosphere and there's a seating area right outside. I got their strawberry lemon coffee cake. It had a balance between the strawberry and lemon flavors and it was extremely moist (something I don't typically find in coffee cake). The top had a crumble as well and it added a nice crunch. I'll be going back after my appointment to try out their coffee!
author: Marissa E.

description:
We were waiting around for Outlanders nearby and decided to come in because of the cool name. Mistake #1. The chai latte was actually really good but the lady seemed really annoyed that we

a. took time to read the menu
b. checked our wallets to pay them
c. asked for a receipt.

This was with no other customers.... you'd think they want our business. Don't go through the trouble for the Trouble.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Coffee is nasty , the toast everyone raves about is just that ... It's toast . You can make toast just as good for a fraction of the cost . Anyone who pays more that 50 cents for a piece of toast more than one time is a moron. Places like this are indicative of what has ruined San Francisco. Out of towners move in and start the dumbest trends for crazy prices. Overall ,it's a lame place with filled with a bunch of losers with attitudes. Makes you wanna say dude you make toast for a living ...
author: John H.

description: $4 for a piece of toast!!! YES! But it's totally worth it. Buttered and covered in cinnamon sugar, it's just to die for. Their coffee is good too!
author: Jamie W.

description: The trouble with trouble coffee is that it's so far out from where I normally hang out in San Francisco. The coffee is good. I love the little parklet that they have out front to hang (since it's pretty tiny inside.) The only thing is the menu is hard to find, so I just ordered a regular latte. Other than that, if i'm ever out in the Sunset district, Trouble Coffee calls my name!
author: Peonie S.

description:
omg their cinnamon toast and their dripped coffee together is an absolute must!

enough said, now go and get those combinations now!
author: Michelle L.

description: I will start by saying that yes the coffee and toast were good, however this place is a joke. The staff is a bunch of whiny hipsters that cant handle the volume of business they do. They are slow, rude and disorganized.  It took me 30 minutes to receive a piece of toast. Will not return.
author: Derek F.

description:
Fresh coconut juice?  Good coffee? Bomb ass cinnamon toast?  and an awesome attitude and style to go with it?   I'm ready for Trouble.  

It's all awesome to me: Bad, Terrible, Trouble.....we love our guilty pleasures, so why not have some Trouble Coffee, especially when its a pain to wait for a seat at Outerlands during brunch too.  

And the outside sidewalk area that makes use of a nicely fallen tree is absolutely genius and adds so much character to the storefront.  I can imagine even on a non outerlands trip, to just soak up the sun and enjoy a nice coffee while chompin on that delicious crispity toast.  

On my last visit, I had the drip coffee which was a nice but strong flavor, perfect for waking up to.  And the toast...o my lord, the toast.  that perfect combination of cinnamon and sugar sprinkled over a perfect lather of butter upon its grill makes for a nice morning snack and good starter to the endless wait for outerlands.  

And while I thought it was bread taken from Outerlands, its actually not.  They get it delivered each morning fresh from another artisan bakery.  Awesome!
author: Vincent K.

description:
Hell no. Everything's just a NO with this place. 
I went there on a Rainy Saturday morning, yeah, it was crazy busy. After 15 minutes Im finally the next person in line. I order a medium coffee and a non fat latte. Oh wait, what you mean you 'don't have' non fat milk? Like right now or you never have non fat? Nope. They don't. Come on dude, there's some people out there trying to save some calories you know? Whatever... BF is hungry, so he grabs a pastrie from the counter.... Im sorry what? 12 bucks? Give me a break!
So if the guy behind the counter didn't lie to me they don't carry non fat milk but they do have old Russian whatever pastries for 4 dollars a pice. That's trouble!
author: Maria C.

description: Giulietta, Trouble's owner, is profiled in a touching story on Pacific Standard magazine. Take a read: http://www.psmag.com/navigation/health-and-behavior/toast-story-latest-artisanal-food-craze-72676/
author: Stephanie G.

description: Considering the owner's story (schizoaffective disorder, episodes of disillusion) of opening the place so she stays out of "trouble" and cultivates an environment of familiarity, help, kindness, consistency and safety, I feel like taking advantage of someone's "weakness" is really fucked up and disgusting and ironic, which is what they tend to do. They overcharge people here based on who they think are regulars and who aren't, or maybe just who they decide to take a disliking to. My boyfriend and I got one coffee and one toast, which according to reviews, should be $2.50 + $4. But the barista said $9 and I was hungover and hungry and didn't think much about it until now. He probably gets that order 50 times a day, so I doubt he accidentally did the math wrong. He said it without hesitation. Bad vibes. It's mostly just a bunch of rich white people who thrive in the pretentiousness, standing around, digging into shitty coconuts and talking about their next trip abroad. Toast is good though.
author: Elle B.

description:
I was happy to give this place another try after a non-pleasant experience the first time. We took a close family friend who rarely gets to stop into the city. He wasn't hungry but I wanted for him to try something special since he rarely visits. I had heard so much from friends and read a few positive write ups about the cinnamon toast. I came in and ordered coffee and tried to convince our friend to try the toast with us since none of us had ever had it. 

In my mid-convincing/conversation with our close friend, the blonde guy at the counter rudely interrupts us with his lame snarky attitude.....the convo goes somewhat like this:

me to our friend "hey i know you aren't hungry but i heard the toast is really great and is well known. there has been great reviews/write ups about it and we should try it."

rude coffee server rudely interjects: "well don't get it because there were articles about it, get it because it is good."

we all kind of looked at him confused, because NONE of us were talking to him or asking for his input and also.... how would WE know it is good if none of us had tried it but only had heard about it.

we all kind of looked at each other, like what is wrong with this pretentious coffee douche.

at that point the coffee douche realized we were so turned off by his rudeness, he tried to play it off like he wasn't rude as hell and asked us about our day....we awkwardly answered and waited to get our coffees/toast. 

sooo so many amazing establishments in the city....i don't need to deal with coffee douche to get a decent coffee and breakfast.

toast is excellent.
coffee is decent.
service is awful.

go across the street to devils teeth!!! amazing coffee, pastries, excellent service, and kind humans. :)
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: Love the place, love the people and love the coffee even more. They may just make the best latte in the city. Also, their toast is amazing, brings me back to childhood. Butter and cinnamon OR if you're really feeling the sweet tooth ask for nutella on it.
author: Sierra M.

description: Always see this place busy and I've heard good things. I gave them two chances and the coffee is nothing special. The service at this place is horrible!! The female behind the counter is extremely rude both times!!  I prefer java beach down the street.
author: Diana s.

description: Came here for the first time. I was visiting from LA & in town for a lil. I'm not a coffee drinker, but I got a black tea and it was amazing. Along with the famous toast. So good even tho it was very sweet/ sugary. The shop is very small so there isn't really much seating inside the shop. But very nice and couple of seats outside. Love the environment of the shop. Ya this place is cash only.  This place isn't your to die coffee shop, but isn't bad at all.
author: Stacy H.

description: Perfect coffee - perfect cappuccino !  The cinnamon toast looked amazing...but sinful!   We took our drinks and found a lovely shop one or two doors down...(just next to the "immersion school" ) and wandered to to the back of the store to find the most enchanting backyard space where we sat with our coffee.  HEAVEN ON EARTH!
author: Lj F.

description: I like this place. Great friendly service and they make fine coffee. It's really small (like less than 8 seats) so you'll get served quick. Seems like a place with a perpetually solid soundtrack as well.
author: Danny H.

description:
this place was pretty cool! the lattes were good and so was their regular coffee. if ur not a regular here, be prepared to feel a little out if place. no menu available for u to check to see but there are definitely items they have that u wont kno about until someone tells you. 

i had the lavender and sea salt biscuit to the suggestion of one of the staff and i really enjoyed it! didnt expect that one coming! i hope to find something like that in NY!

the outdoor branch/bench seating area was pretty interesting and fun to hang out on but not something i could sit on all day. great spot if ur foreign to the area and looking for a place the locals frequent.
author: Katrina B.

description:
6 bucks for coffee and toast is far from good value but it's a delicious tandem.  the real roi kicks in 30 minutes later as you'll feel jacked as if ya just left the bathroom stall at the viper room

its definitely not midwestern, tell your life story in there but its not exactly f you i hate you cold either

sat counterside enjoying  texas sized cinnamon toast as a pair of euro girls walk in and ask for menu's, i open up my right ear for reply and sure enough like any other red blooded male, the cashier / barista was polite and patient as we know which head was lookin and which one was thinkin.  i believe he even said in a mannered tone 'what do you like miss' as he prepped two vanilla lattes

pretty sure ill be back as i just learned its intelligentsia coffee which i enjoyed and haven't had since my lakeview days on chicago's northside
author: Clark G.

description:
they weren't kidding when they (my fellow yelpers, of course) raved about the cinnamon toast. oh my yum! it's the best cinnamon toast you'll ever eat in your life!

and why is that? well...

1) because it's sans raisins. i mean, why do raisins exist anyway? not once was i ever jealous of kids who had those little red boxes of dried grapes in their lunch boxes. gah-ross!!!
2) the word slather is an understatement when describing the amount of melted butter on this toast. it's almost too much butter honestly. almost! but i love butter, so me and this toast get along great!
3) i'm not sure where they get their bread from but it's perfection. it's got a slight chew and the crust toasts up well.
4) paired with The Matador, it's a great accompaniment for a middle of the day break. what's The Matador, you ask? it's drip coffee with an espresso shot and steamed milk. such a good pair, those two.

i'm comin' back for more sometime in the very VERY near future. but i think i'll wait for all of that butter to clear out of my veins first.
author: Regina C.

description:
Trouble Coffee may have had more than a little to do with us packing up from Dolores St and moving to Outer Sunset. It reminds me of my hometown in ways that are hard to describe but I will try: the ceramic coffee mugs are made by a friend of the owner. The red neon sign on a foggy day. The ethos of "trouble" and "build your own damn house". The quirky-dark vintage map highlighting SF homicides in the 1950s. The beautiful and creative parklet made of driftwood, Bread and Puppet-style.

Although we have plentiful coffee-making devices at home I wind up at Trouble 2-3 times a week. My favorites are the lavender and sea-salt shortbread, the soy latte and the gibraltar. They are always fast, and at least as friendly as any other good coffee shop I've frequented.

Local tip: lately there have been long lines at 11am Saturday and 10 Sunday due to folks on the wait-list for brunch at Outerlands. So avoid those times unless you like to people watch or have romantic dreams of meeting someone while waiting in line for coffee.
author: Lex L.

description:
The toast ! The toast ! 

At first, I was thinking, how could toast cost that much?  But omg. Just get the toast.  It's delicious cinnamon buttery goodness!  The coffee is awesome. But it's better with toast.
author: Maxine C.

description:
A cute little hole in the wall with interesting coffee in the Outer Sunset.  

I first noticed this place when I got off the N line across the street, and was suffering due to lack of coffee.  I've tried their Iced coffee, which will knock you out (something I look for in coffee!), and their Dirty Chai (which leaves an interesting sensation in your throat).  They offer fresh coconut juice, too, which is really good to drink outside in their parklet.  I hear good things about their toast, and whenever I go, the guy behind the counter is forever yelling, "TOOOOOOAST!" Something to try the next time I go!  Do try their other pastries--my favorite is called the Sweet Jesus, which is basically a peanut butter cup baked into a peanut butter cookie.  It complements the coffee well!

At first, I got the impression that this was a hipster-only coffee shop, and I felt like I needed to apologize for having no holes in my clothing, or hair that was brushed.  But after several visits, that feeling lessens considerably.  The service is friendly enough, but sometimes they can take a while.  BRING CASH, or be prepared to either go next door to use the ATM machine or across the street to 7-Eleven and buy something with cash back.
author: Kai C.

description: Very typical, easily replicated, no intricacy. A new joint with a new atmosphere. The coffee is just coffee and the toast is just what you used to make as a kid but with proportionally more butter & sugar.
author: R W.

description: I rarely give 5 star reviews but now is the time.  After reading through some reviews I was a tad nervous about stopping by here.  The usual complaints about overly hip hipsters and overpriced toast are completely unjustified in this particular case.    The young men at the counter were helpful, friendly, chatty and just plain adorable.  My cappuccino was everything I've come to expect from Trouble (I frequent their Bayview location); flawless.  Don't fear the bad, apparently chip-on-the-shoulder reviews that say otherwise and drive on down to the Outer Sunset for a lovely cuppa.
author: tanuki c.

description: I tried this place again like I said I would and I still stand by my review of the toast. However, I got the mocha this time and it was pretty good - a nice balance of coffee and cocoa with a creamy finish. Overall, Trouble is just alright
author: Austin C.

description: The drip coffee is good, but nothing special, and I think it works way better as iced coffee. The toast is good. The service is surprisingly quick given the popularity! Our coffees took ~2 minutes during peak Sunday morning brunch hours. No attitude, would definitely stop here again :)
author: matt k.

description:
There are few things I will drive all the way out to the outer sunset for: 1. to enjoy the sun at ocean beach on one of the few super hot days in San Francisco 2. garlic roast crab at than long and 3.  a cup of coffee and cinnamon toast at Trouble Coffee..

The coffee here has a wonderfully silky texture, not bitter, and goes super well with a generous splash of cream. The last time I remember having such great coffee was from a local coffee shop in Brooklyn called Verb. Service is friendly with a smile. The only trouble you can get into here is if you spent your last $2 in quarters you dug out from your car on coffee and did not have enough cash for the toast. This place is cash-only.
author: Sue L.

description: Hot guys poring lushes lattes, Texas toast slathered with butter, cinnamon and sugar. What more could a girl wake up to?
author: Alison B.

description: Excellent coffee, and one of the few places you can still find the "California" beach vibe you might expect to find when you are near the beach in California, but don't hardly ever see any more in San Francisco. Hard-working, cool, punk-rock people who might hand you your ass if you ever called them a "hipster." Beware, they close the door for a ~15 minute "sanity break" around 1:00 every day to catch up, clean up, and chill out, so if it happens to you just do as they do and keep your zen-Your coffee can wait for 15 minutes!
author: Brian S.

description:
One of my neighborhood favorites, this place has some of the best drip coffee that you will find anywhere in San Francisco. Not only that, but they are famous for their cinnamon butter bread or is it butter cinnamon bread since they put enough butter on it to almost drip through to the bottom? I also love their small pies, if they have any left which is sometimes not the case, which comes in flavors such as pear, cherry, apple, etc. 

My favorite morning consists of going to Trouble, getting my coffee and toast or pie, hanging by the parklet outside and people watching and then taking a nice walk along the beach which is just a few blocks away. I love my neighborhood and Trouble is one of the many reasons.
author: Jared C.

description:
Delicious!! Cinnamon toast + coffee this time around, but I'll be back for more of the other menu items 
Would give a 5 if: 
- easier to order and service were a bit better.. .there was no menu and the barista/cashier did not seem to even really acknowledge us or act like he worked there
author: Victoria K.

description: You can't get decaf here and don't ask because the won't be nice about it. Always a line... Boggles the mind.
author: Kalie J.

description:
i would suggest than if you wearing  anything that is not  older than one month  , you should go to Starbuck's. .

 Trouble Coffee is worth the trouble!
author: Dirtzoo I.

description: OMG, the toast is literally 1.5 inches thick. Standard toast = butter, cinnamon, brown sugar. Yumz. Also, the bathroom is not public - that's why it says KEEP OUT all over it. I thought it was just them being ironic and quirky. B-)
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Completely like a skit out of Portlandia, this place has amazing coffee and often unfriendly, locals-only style of service.  Love the breads, pastries, etc and the coffee is really nice, but seems they are so precious and unwavering on their coffee purism that it can be a bit off-putting (dare you ask for an espresso to-go!).  The owner is never particularly happy to see us, yet we've come a few times now, however she is more than cordial with her surfer buddies from the neighborhood.  The baristas are great at what they do and as I said, so long as you speak *their language* they don't exhibit any weirdness.  The cashiers and not particularly nice nor friendly but having lived in other, similar communities, I suspect that if you had grown up alongside them, it'd be pretty different.  

Each time I stop I prep myself and while I wait there to pick up my coffee - eyes of judgment locked firmly on my outsider-ness - I ask myself, why am I here?  

The bakery nearby hasn't espresso drinks but is generally friendlier and their hand poured coffee is pretty acceptable.

I take solace in knowing that when they're old, and the remains if their piercings hang like so much meaty wobble, alone with runny, sun-faded tattoos; these hipsters-surfer snobs will have only the sound of their creaky rockers to keep them company.
author: Matt B.

description:
Whenever I question my choice to live on the edge of the world, an hour away from most places I need to be, and in an emotionally strange place, I just pop in here. 

They are exceptionally great to their regulars. It's the best way to start the day.
author: Maria D.

description:
Trouble Coffee was introduced to my wife and me over the weekend.  Our friend said, "TOAST".  I said, "HUH, SO WHAT..." 

After going there, now, I say "TOAST" too!  This place is quaint, tucked away between some really cute places like General Store and Outerlands, and still tasty plates by Celia's (but not better than Tommy's though for plates).  Digress...

Here, the quaint, neighborhood coffee shop has excellent coffee, (Elbow Grease for coffee beans)...but don't mistake The Hammer for your everyday roast.  This is their espresso bean...sounds good right?  I bought a bag of their beans, took that home and had some drip yesterday morning...excellent, smooth flavor.  Beans are a bit sticky, but probably due to the sweetness added.  

The Toast...yes, that's it.  Cinnamon toast but probably not the typical thing you're thinking.  It's big, probably two or three slices of nice artisan bread smacked together for a gigantic breakfast treat.  Get a cup of coffee and you're ready to ride up the undulating hills of Irving St.  

My wife and I got a Toast each, a bag of beans, and a cup of coffee for $13.  Good prices!   Next time Coconut...

Do it!  Try this place!
author: felix c.

description:
I'm not much of a coffee drinker, but I LOVE Trouble Coffee! 

The lattes are so rich and smooth, mochas are tasty, and the chai lattes are SO spicy! But even better than the drinks are of course the toast and coconuts. I could literally eat both of these every day. Something about that buttery sweet melt-in-your-mouth toast is like biting into a piece of heaven. My mouth is watering just thinking of it. And you can't go wrong with fresh coconut water and meat!
author: Megan K.

description: Rude!!!! I asked for a dry cap w non fat milk. Was told they only make it one way then was told to go outside and wait. Coffee was mediocre at best and my cappuccino was wet. I will never get used to being treated poorly when I am paying for a service.
author: Elisa Z.

description: I completely agree with the review by Esta. I don't normally write a review but feel like I should for this one since I gave the place a second chance after got treated badly by the staffs here the first time. The coffee is not bad but the attitude here makes even the best coffee tasted worst than coffee from seven eleven across the street.
author: apirada n.

description: Well this place is as hipster as a coffee shop can get. There's so menu... so just order whatever comes to mind. I got a mocha and it was really strong, but the coffee they used was really good and aromatic. I tried the famous toast but I thought it was too buttery and rather simple to be considered something so exciting. The place is tiny and has an interesting greet branch outside that you can sit on. It seemed like everyone who comes knows the works really well and is super hipster ... I didn't know my neighborhood became a hipster haven while I've been gone in college
author: Nikita K.

description: Laid back with amazing cinnamon toast and best cap I've had in a long time. Coffee guys like to dance...it was cute..this is a place you can roll out of bed with your hair destroyed and no one will judge you..sanctuary when you feel your in a bit of trouble...
author: Tam M.

description:
This is my first time writing a Yelp review and had to make an account because you all deserve to know what you are getting into. 

My sister and I were visiting San Francisco for the weekend staying in the Sunset area and decided to go for a walk to a local coffee house; seems pretty harmless. We love trying out new breakfast places and have gone to many in San Francisco loving all of them. As we approached "Trouble" the line was out the door and people were huddling along the side walk, precariously balancing food and coffee on their knees. We soon saw that was because the venue was about the size of a small bedroom and no one could fit inside. 

When we finally get to the front there is no menu to be found, apparently you are just supposed to know what they offer, and my sister asks for two large cafe au laits. The barista grabs two small. When she asked if we could actually have the larger size he responds "they only come in this size." Okay..
