When she asks if she could have carmel in hers (assuming they have it since there is no menu) he responds word for word "We actually don't believe in putting all that sugary shit in your coffee, its not very good for you" very matter of fact-ly (as right next to him another employee is slathering butter and sugar all over a piece of cinnamon toast the size of a loaf). He then proceeds to yell to people to take their coffee and food outside because they are exceeding fire code. As we pay he says "thank you for your cooperation" in a way as if he were stooping to do business with us.

We are given our barely lukewarm coffee without lids and instructed that sugar is outside, which turns out to be a jar of brown sugar with a communal spoon in it, sitting  on a kitchen stool. 

I was absolutely astounded at the experience. It seemed like we were in a living parody of snooty coffee houses. NEVER going back and will continue to pass on this story.
author: Haley C.

description: Oh how I miss this place. I would come here almost every weekend. The people who would work there were very friendly, the coffee and toast (cinnamon and butter) was great. Living here in Seattle, we have nothing at all comparable.
author: Albert S.

description: Great fun environment with top shelf coffee.  The guys are engaging and very knowledgeable of the craft of making an excellent brew.  The also know the neighborhood well.  Excellent location close to the ocean.
author: April M.

description:
Went out on a ride and stopped here in on a friend's recommendation. The cinnamon toast is really good. There's a nice parklet out front that members of the community pooled together to help build. The barrista and I had a good chat...not that that is a criteria for good coffee shops, but it was nice to learn a bit more about the neighborhood and why surfing at Ocean isn't as bad as I think it is. 

It was a windy Thursday afternoon so i missed the crush of people I assume show up here otherwise.  What I can say is that the stuff they're selling is great. I don't know why people are miffed when they show up to a shop like this at 8:30 am and can't get glowing and speedy service...are you there because the coffee's good or you want them to rub your butt and tell you you're special? Cut them a break or come in on a windy Thursday afternoon.
author: Konrad P.

description:
Trouble Coffee Company?

Is my coffee being made by a member of the mafia? Or maybe a Crip?
That is so bad ass.

TCC is a hidden gem located on Judah Street - right next to the beach - it serves delicious coffee [with coffee art - which Starbucks has yet to do..] to local surfers and beach-goers alike. The interior is so quaint, there isn't a lot of space but it's so efficient. The interior set up like a bar with some counter seating. You will not get bored here - plenty of decor eye-candy. There is a cute bench set up outside - great for people watching and just hanging out.

Don't let the name fool you. The baristas are not gang members nor will they give you any trouble. They're nice and make some really really good coffee. My latte ($3.50)  was creamy and strong. However, it was pretty small -- I finished it pretty quickly. The good thing about this place is that they use healthy ingredients - like brown, unprocessed sugar.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Four stars for their coffee, toast, and pastries. There are a lot of coffee shops in this area of the Sunset, but I like to come here for the Girlfriend and the peanut butter toast with honey. Mmm..
Minus one star for the service. I wouldn't say their employees are SO bad, but I didn't like how one of them acted the other day.. I ordered a blueberry pastry & he grabbed one with a tissue then placed it on the counter. I asked him if he had a bag so I could take it to go - he grabs a bag, hesitates, drops it on the counter next to the pastry & kinda throws his hands up like, "I'm not touching that thing". Umm, you did grab the pastry & now you don't wanna bag it? I mean that's fine, but don't act like what you JUST touched has a disease or something. Isn't that your job..?? Then you just place it right on the counter, where people put their hands & money & who knows what else. But what can you do, with a place this successful & well known, these employees probably don't care what customers think of them.
author: Marie C.

description: My favorite sunset based coffee shop. The  Intelligentsia sourced coffee was excellent and my cap was well prepared. This old guy was well treated despite its hipster reputation. However I founds the guys friendlier then the gals in limited visits.
author: R L.

description: Poorly crafted cappuccinos with a side of intensely boorish attitude.  I'd happily laugh along with the intentional abrasiveness, but the baristas pour a terrible cup. Sorry fellas.
author: Eric B.

description:
First thing you need to know about Trouble Coffee - CASH ONLY. Second thing you need know - NO DECAF.  If you were expecting to get  "a tall decaf latte" and pay with your debit card, you have come to the wrong place. Third thing -NO PHOTOS! Weird rule, but it's true. If they catch you they will tell you to stop. I found this out the hard way. 
This little nugget of a coffee shop is tucked away in the farthest corner of the Outer Sunset. I'm fairly new to the Trouble scene, but from what I gather, it's a nice place to hangout and drink straight up coffee. No frills included, I definitely recommend getting a slice of toast with your coffee. In fact, the cinnamon toast is probably the best thing I've eaten...EVER! Thick cut toast, sliced to order, slathered with butter and covered with a layer of cinnamon and sugar. I'm pretty sure it's simple enough to make it yourself, but let's be honest. It won't even come close! I like to wash down my toast with an Americano. The full-bodied flavor of the espresso is pure liquid gold.
author: Eileen V.

description: The toast is so yummy, oh cinnamon!  So glad to have stumbled upon this little cafe. Very friendly staff who know how to make serious espresso. I really like they're use for extended sidewalk of wood pieces and intwined  plants, great place to read a book.
author: Jeneal J.

description:
I can't not give Trouble five stars, and I've only been here once. 

First of all (because it's the first thing you'll see), their parklet out front is the essence of all that is good in the world. You can sit on the wall, you can sit on a tree trunk, you can sit in the sun or the shade, you can bring your dog, you can play with other people's dogs, you can people watch or be people-watched. 

The beach is just a couple blocks away, and the neighborhood is a good one to lazily walk about. There's a cute shop right next door, a super popular brunch place up the block, and you're only a short walk from Golden Gate Park. 

Oh, and the coffee! I ordered a latte 'for here' and it came in a great little mug with a whale on it. It tasted great, and I trusted Yelp's recommendation of the cinnamon toast and dear god, I was not disappointed. 

(Caution: I can't believe I'm saying this about the Outer Sunset, but good luck finding parking on a weekend morning!)
author: Alyssa G.

description: Waited for my mocha for much too long. Saw at least three or four customers (with orders placed after mine) served with other specialty coffees. Asked about my order and got a wordy lecture about the need to be patient because my mocha would be ready when it was ready. Said I had been patient. Then was asked if I was "insinuating" that the wait had been "unreasonably long." Said yes and was told once again that I would get my mocha when it was ready. The guys behind the counter high-fived each other over what they seemed to view as witty customer service. My order was ready a minute later. The mocha turned out to be subpar (lukewarm and bitter) so I brought it back saying it really wasn't worth the wait. Was told not to come back.
author: Robin I.

description:
This cool little Punk Rock Cafe is great! They pulled me a real good cappuccino and were friendly small talking too. Not to mention the Bob Mould and Vandals stickers on there Espresso machine. 
The Sunset used to be rough to find good coffee drink, but between this one and Hallow on Irving, I don't have to go downtown to get my hi-end espresso fix.
I'll be back!
author: dub g.

description: Super convenient location en route to the Judah line. Stop in for my morning cup ol' joe and the surfer's bar was amazingly good. Place is super cool with a wooden bench outside to chill out on a breezy morning
author: Angela L.

description: I went back for more toast, and the guy making it put a BUNCH of butter, underneath the peanut butter...and it hadn't melted at all by the time he put the peanut butter on. So when I bit into it it was pretty gross. First of all, I wouldn't have wanted the butter at all if I had known, but not even letting it melt? Ew. It was raining, and it was way too crowded for it to be worth it to ask them to remake it. Especially since they've all got a 'tude in there...
author: Elena T.

description: This place is stupid good, extremely good coffee, but the only thing is they close for a few minutes in the middle of the day all the time (weird. like, they just close, as people are wanting to order coffee, and lock the door for a few minutes). If it wasn't for that I'd give it five stars, but I've gone by a few times wanting coffee in the morning/afternoon and they're closed for "ten minutes" (why??).
author: Stefani O.

description:
THE SERVICE: The staff is really friendly and nice. They're always willing to make conversation, and they're super humble and fun to be around. This place gets pretty slammed on weekends, but the staff manages to keep up. 5/5

THE FOOD: Go buy a 'Build your own damn house' special and tell me you aren't happy with it. Their cinnamon toast is excellent. 5/5

THE AMBIANCE:It's a little hole-in-the-wall coffee shop with a hipster vibe. For what it is, it's great. 5/5
author: John M.

description: The little parklet out front is nice. I'm sure the baked goods and fancier drinks are great. But all I ever want is black coffee, and that's... okay. Definitely not worth 2 bucks for a small, which is even higher than shitty Starbucks, and definitely not worth dealing with the service. They're never outright hostile, but much more interested in chatting with their friends than even acknowledging my presence. From now on, I'll get the coffee at 7-11 and sit in the parklet. It's almost as good as Trouble's coffee, and I can get twice as much for the same price.
author: Joe G.

description:
Some of the best Coffee I've tasted in my life; highly recommend to those in search of a quality cup'o'joe. The crew is super hospitable and really make for an overall great experience. 
The 'rustic' real-estate is prime and just a few steps from MUNI N-Line!

Thanks Trouble makers
author: Collin C.

description:
mmmmmm trouble coffee. so good, so strong. 

come here for the coffee, toast or coconut. it's all incredible. the service is fine and even if they are a bit rude when it gets crowded, they are all very attractive (so that's good!)

Its the most hipster location that you can find in the city of San Francisco, the beach is right down the road and the coffee is incredible. What more could you want?
author: Abigail M.

description: went in for a latte and cinnamon toast and my order was rudely taken by a dude in glasses and a beard. then I got yelled at for taking a picture of my latte and toast which ironically I wanted to use for this review.  i paid too much for a semi-decent latte and a scolding.  there's plenty of great coffee in SF.  I'm taking my business to philz, sightglass, blue bottle, four barrel, and andytown. and oh, I also saw him impatiently serving a man who was speaking with limited English.  seriously what a jerk.
author: Donna V.

description: Good spot, close to the N-Judah. Staff is a little uptight, coffee a bit overrated. The cinnamon toast is as excellent as everyone says though. Overall, worth a stop if you are in the area.
author: Griffith P.

description: If I have to wait in a line out the door for like over a half hour only to get major attitude when I get to the front of the line, I can't support you. And I really wanted to because I think it's rad the owner is female and I always love to support women in business doing things they are passionate about, but what up with the vibes? Maybe I will try the Yosemite location and I'm hoping it's a different energy
author: Lauren V.

description: Burnt coffee, loud ass punk rock so you can't even hear your thoughts, and only serving triple shot mochas! I know the espresso machine makes singles guys.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Trouble happens to be in my neighborhood; their coffee is pretty good, probably the best around the Sunset. When I run out of Nespresso pods I come here for coffee. Cool little place. The staff is rather unwelcoming. Been many times and only once one of the guys (think his name was Peter) was friendly, shame he doesn't run that place all the time. So if you don't live in the area it's probably not worth driving here for the coffee. I you want good coffee go to Sightglass on 7th, unlike Trouble they roast the beans there and are real coffeee snobs they just don't act like it.                                      

P.S The fresh coconuts here are divine much better than the coffee.
author: Teresa B.

description:
It's cold. It's rainy. I'm on a bike + coming from the wind tunnel that is Ocean Beach. What could be better than a delicious, creamy, warm coffee beverage? Trouble to the rescue to ease my troubled soul.

Soy latte is amazing. Love that it's a smaller size so you actually can appreciate the delicious espresso in it + that the soy milk they use (wild wood) isn't crazy sweet like some places.

Americano was also spot on - not bitter at all and served at the perfect temp.

Not a ton of seating, maybe about 6 stools at the bar and another 4 facing the window, but plenty of people seem to just pop in + out so it wasn't an issue at all on the Saturday afternoon I was there.

Suuuuper chill vibe, friendly baristas, neato artwork, rad music, neighborhoody feel. I was kinda hesitant at first to hang out at such a small place where everyone (except me!) seemed to know each other, but it was super comfy + cozy once I got settled. 

Gotta go back and try the toast. It did look pretty friggin tasty. Oh yeah, and the coconuts.

Cash only, so bring your dollaz.
author: Monica C.

description:
Friendly staff and delicious drinks!

The young coconut with toast is definitely the highlight point for me.
author: Alice F.

description: They make good coffee, but be prepared for hostile attitude from the kids behind the counter. The service is beyond terrible, and I'm sure that's a point of pride. There aren't really any good alternatives in the Outer Sunset so if you want a good coffee out there this is your only real option, unfortunately.
author: Deacon B.

description:
I don't even drink coffee very much anymore because coffee and milk do not play nice with my bowels, but I would say Trouble coffee is worth it.

I've been here twice and the latte and drip coffees are both awesome quality. I dislike coffee in general because of the bitter aftertaste that lingers in your mouth, but it is practically nonexistent in their coffees. The latte has almost a caramel mid-tone. It is, like another reviewer said, a very complex tasting coffee and it's delicious! The first time I tasted their coffee, I literally said wow. This doesn't happen often (I think the only other time was for Philz).

Nothing horrible to say about service. I feel like people here are typical SF people haha. They are very casual, chill, but happy to answer questions or offer recommendations if asked. Both times I've been here there weren't any other customers, so no wait at all.
author: Jessica C.

description: Terrible coffee and definite bad service !!!! And so expensive !!!! Baristas are rude
author: Kenia F.

description:
Americano was good.  I've tasted my fair share due to partner having an acquired taste to such things.   

But good damn these people could get some lessons in not being rude snobs.  If you don't want to explain sh*it to people have it noted somewhere or display the effin menu, then maybe people wouldn't need to hear arsehole attitude.   

I'm not a coffee person at all but I wouldn't agree to go back here even if partner thought his cup was very good...
author: Yumi C.

description: I've only experienced not so great customer service and bad chai tea latte. Good cinnamon toast tho.
author: Raffy R.

description:
A tiny "hole in the wall" place, but their coffee is delicious and their little pastries are worth trying (I've had a very good surprise with the butternut squash-and-marshmallow tartlette!).

I'd stopped there while waiting for a table at Outerlands (a few feet away) and took my coffee cup and pastry on my way to the beach. A lovely little stop with friendly staff and a good atmosphere.
author: Regina P.

description:
i like the creative use of wood for benches & bar, the pastries are amazing but the staff/ownership are self-righteous & a bit snobby- specifically the female. every time i walk in & she's working, she looks at me like "why are you here?".... 

coffee is strong & good, i get mine to go. although, i have chosen to walk the extra 6 (?) blocks down to Java Beach just to avoid the attitude. 

(UPDATE: I AM NOT TALKING ABOUT THIS LOVELY GIULIETTA, there is another gal with daggers for eyes :-o 
https://psmag.com/a-toast-story-df3b8e99d07f#.tz9dj3yii
http://sprudge.com/this-american-life-toast-54486.html )
author: M.j. W.

description:
Wow-o.

My conversation with the owner continued, and we talked about when I had been there, and when the other bad reviews were. She mailed me back, saying she had identified the person who was behind the bad reviews. 

I stopped in a few days later - different parties behind the counter. Funny, fun, friendly. I forget what we kibitzed about - but the coffee was still fantastic, and the guy making it was still eerily fast. 

Haven't had the toast - but I will. 

Best espresso near the ocean I know of, and what a charming and responsive owner. Thanks, Giulietta! No trouble with Trouble now.
author: J M.

description: Coffee and toast , I dont get talked to death and my kid loves the the seating area in front.
author: Eric B.

description:
Get the cinnamon toast. Best. Cinnamon. Toast. Ever. I'd go here just for that. But I usually accompany it with a delicious dirty chai which always seems to have the perfect amount of spice. 

The place is small (with no public bathrooms fyi), but adorable. Eclectic art and clippings are pasted on the walls, and the nice but often quirky baristas working the counter will engage you with friendly banter.

Trouble is and will continue to be my coffee/snack spot whenever I find myself in the Outer Sunset.
author: Kori M.

description:
Got a cold brewed coffee, and it wasn't good -- way too bitter for my taste. Have had much better elsewhere (try Stumptown).

The toast was good though. I can see why they're known for it. Very delicious!

The service, however, was bad. Saw a few other reviews mentioning this same thing, and I'm not sure why folks come back when the people working here clearly couldn't give 2 craps about its customers. I saw the girl behind the register yell at a customer for trying to take a picture of the place. Really? Geez, are you guys doing so well that you can basically piss on paying customers who actually want to remember your establishment with a photo? Weak, guys. You need to thank your lucky stars Outerlands is next door to you, keeping your business afloat.
author: Patrick C.

description:
So as we were passing by this place to get to Outerlands for brunch, my boyfriend noticed someone holding a coconut. Since he's apparently never had one before even though he's from Hawaii, we decided to get one. 

We ordered a Build Your Own Damn House. It comes with coffee, the coconut, and toast. The coffee - well my bf makes it too bitter to my liking. They did have soy outside which is great for both of us since we're both a bit lactose intolerant. The coconut was...well a coconut. I've had it before, but my bf seems not to like it. Oh well, he doesn't like coconut juice. It was pretty cool though. They like freeze it or something so its cold when you get it. The toast with cinnamon sugar was really good. They lather a huge slice of homemade bread with butter and some cinnamon sugar. I love cinnamon so it was delicious. Totally will go back to get some of that.
author: Nina Y.

description: I really love the coffee and the toast here. The atmosphere is small but cute. The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is because the man at the cash register was quite rude. A little customer service can go a long way. This is our second time here and both times we left with a bad taste in our mouth because we thought the staff was rude.
author: Ashley K.

description: As mentioned in every review, the toast. It is the best. It is worth your time. SF has very many great coffee options but when it comes to a plain, black cup of coffee, Trouble's elbow grease has to be my favorite. The fact that they also serve coconuts is great. They are so refreshing and you can have the water and the flesh for $5 which is nothing compared to what the water can cost alone. Go, go, go!
author: Vanessa B.

description: The cinnamon toast here is perfection. A mocha is probably the most froufrou drink you can order, and the coffee is strong. The baristas aren't bubbly, but I think the service is efficient and pleasant. Bring cash and pocket your iPhone.
author: Jessie S.

description:
Want to see something random?

Click on the link to trouble Cafe'.

Burner Dive Cafe Bar extraordinaire... .

Oh HELLO! I'm in San Francisco? Where has san Francisco been hiding? Oh I'm here. I was here the whole time.

Get into Trouble!
author: Kimberley M.

description: Awesome coffee, and great outdoor seating to watch neighborhood cuties. But what's up with selling toast by the slice for $3? I get that it's good bread, lots of butter and cinnamon. But this is like a Portlandia skit. The coffee sizing and prices are a little effed too-- too small for the price, in my mind. But that's San Francisco in a nutshell these days, isn't it?
author: Andrew J.

description:
Cuuuuuute. I like.

One of my favorite things to do is to check out local coffee shops that carry locally roasted beans, teas, etc. As sort of a coffee nerd, I pride myself on being able to discern the good from the bad and the in-between.

Trouble carries awesome chai and great beans that are locally roasted. (I feel lame that I can't remember the name of the roaster, that said, whoever it was did a great job.)

Tiny, up on a hill (it is SF, after all... ), this little hole-in-the-wall couldn't be cuter or more representative of an independent coffee shop. Also, the guy behind the counter was terribly nice and really personable. 

Go. Get a cup, and go to the beach, and hang out. Breathe it all in... the local flavor.
author: Rachel F.

description: This is a cramped hallway of a coffee shop but its worth the struggle to make it to the front of the line--- why? B/c their goddamn coffee is great. You know you've found a keeper when you don't need the bells & whistles of mocha-spice-caramel-hazelnut-soy junk. I want my caffeine unadulterated, & that's what this is. Their cappuccino is perfect. I can still taste the bold flavor of espresso beneath the foamed milk, unlike the watery concoctions I'm used to. Besides their drinks, the thick slabs of cinnamon toast are a heavenly accompaniment to my morning buzz. I wish I could transplant this place into  my neighborhood in San Diego, but I'll settle for making it a permanent stop in my SF trips.
author: Julie K.

description:
Ate here this morning for the first time and really enjoyed the experience.  Loved the coffee and cinnamon toast.  The parklet outside is very unique with a dead tree branch to sit on.  The fresh coconut is very cool, but wasn't my personal favorite (but I am not a fan of coconut water).  The employees were friendly and helpful- I will be back! Check it out!

It is cash only, so come prepared.
author: Christy L.

description:
Tiny, pricey, and they don't carry a decaf roast.

Since I only drink decaf 99% of the time I can't sing the praises of Trouble as much as I'd like.  Normally if some snotty barista guy told me he didn't have any decaf for me I'd be giving them an automatic one star for their pretentious hipsterdom.  I know caffeine is rad, but you charge $3-4 for a cup of coffee and you can't serve me some water processed decaf?!  

But, for some reason I still really like Trouble.  It's cute that it's the size of my closet, they serve coconut milk in the coconut, and they have amazing pastries.  If caffeine is your drug of choice I've had both coffee & hot chocolate here and while my coffee kept me up all night it was delicious.  

Go here.  If caffeine doesn't make your heart have palpitations and jump out of your chest you will be a very happy camper.
author: Katie S.

description:
Sometimes the coffee is incredible, and other times it is out of this world. With personality alone this place gets 5 stars! I always see bright, cheery, funny people inside.  Everyone has a spark in their eye.

I love the bad yelp reviews too!  They are hilarious.  I used to think that some very creative employee or customer dreamt up some of the crazy things that people say happened to them because I get so much pleasure out of picturing how things went down for certain people.

Trouble is a local spot where everywhere is welcome.  Sorry if the staff has a sense of humor and you get your feelings hurt, but thank you so much for yelping it so I can have a laugh.  

All I know is that instead of waiting for the caffeine to course through my veins, my high starts when I round the corner, waive at the owners of the corner store, and see people enjoying the parklet outside Trouble.  

No disrespect to Java Beach, but if you don't want someone to hand you an empty cup and make you pump your coffee out of carafe like you are at a business luncheon in 1978, come hang out at Trouble.
author: Briggs B.

description: Pretty good little spot. Toast is yummy. Coffee isn't all too great and the customer service could use a little attention. Still a good local business!
author: Erin A.

description:
Hmm, I preempt this review with the following statement. I am usually not a big coffee drinker and with typical coffee I drink it for the caffeine mainly and I find myself adding a ton of sugar even with "nicer" coffees. 

This is the main reason why I was so impressed with the coffee at Troubled coffee. The flavor was complex, light with a subtle sweet/aromatic note and the texture was smooth and you could definitely taste that the coffee beans were lightly roasted. I was very impressed with their coffee and would highly recommend it to anyone. 

And as a bonus the coffee shop is very eclectic and the staff is pretty cool too, in a grungy kind of way. I'll definitely be back for a cup of joe or two. 


Enjoy!
author: Byron C.

description:
HOLE in the wall.

Chai tea latte. Meh.
Vanilla latte. Meh.

Wanted to like this place :(
Maybe next time I'll try the toast with the coconut juice since everyone keeps raving about it.
author: Lily Z.

description:
This place reminded me of the time I got a tattoo, and not just because my mom was the only person within a 1/2 mile radius without any ink.  It was because the guy who did my tattoo kindof ignored me and there were all these people around who were talking to each other and not to me.  Similarly, this place has a vibe that's more clique than friendly, enough to make me wonder, am I really here?  Yes, I am, and the coffee was good, and the toast was damn good, and the coconut... lemme back up a sec.

Okay my mom lost something like 50 pounds because she decided to stop eating bread.  That was ten-or-so years ago.  You would never know it if you'd only seen her at Trouble.  But what the hell is vacation for if you can't stuff your face with delicious sugary buttery brioche bread?  We had latte and toast every morning here for the whole trip and I honestly think the whole vacation was made with that decision.  Well, that and the place we sublet right down the street.  But I'm getting off the subject.

I checked Yelp before we came here just out of curiosity, and learned about this whole Build Your Own Damn House thing.  I wasn't sure I wanted to order it because it has a DIY vibe and I wasn't sure how I was supposed to Open My Own Damn Coconut.  I needn't have worried, as I saw a couple other customers consuming their coconut with all the machete work done for them.  So I gave it a try and I'm glad I did.

My point is, the food was all tasty, the coffee delicious, and the bikeshorts lady was hilarious when she screamed TOAST for order-up.  More stars will be awarded for some seating (I don't know how, I'm just saying, you need it) and a touch more friendliness.  

Oh and it's cash only, which was actually nice because I brought my vacation dollars in hundreds (like, two, I am such a big spender) and they changed me.  High five!
author: Emily C.

description:
I have been coming here for around two months now, as I needed some smooth coffee before work. I originally came because the reviews cracked me up (several people feel so neglected or put upon). On my first visit, the staff was professional but quiet, now they tend to be friendly and warm. I have yet to see them be rude to someone. The coffee takes longer to prepare than many places, but I have only received exemplary coffee there. The baked goods are great - pie for breakfast is a good thing (blueberry, cranberry, strawberry, rhubarb, apple, pear - in various combinations on different days). Scones are good. 

I keep waiting for them to make a bad cup of coffee - it would save me ten minutes on my commute to work - but they haven't. 

Quality over quick wins the day.
author: Kirk J.

description:
Ask for a gibraltar. It's one of the best caffeinated experiences you'll ever have. No, really. Add a surf granola bar, just to be decadent. Happiness ensues. And it lasts for a few hours. At that point, repeat the procedure to prolong the magic. 

Trouble is one one of the top five cafès in the City. 

Wait, scrap that: it's in the top three.
author: Matt B.

description: Really great latte and love the outdoor seating here. This is a 5 star coffee place anywhere else in the US but with Andytown close by I had to go 4 by comparison. Fast service one of the better lattes in SF a must stop by if you are in the Sunset.
author: John P.

description: Best little coffee shop venue in San Fran. Quite the SoCal feel which is a nice contrast to the surrounding city. There's wonderful outside relaxed seating area where you can find people lounging about drinking coffee or even sipping coconut water from whole coconuts. 100% recommend to anyone who wants to get out of the city and experience a little beachy atmosphere
author: Melissa D.

description:
OK so this place is a bit out of the way, I only found it when a friend of mine suggested we go there at the end of a bike ride.
But, its well worth the trip.. great coffee (can't quite remember the brand, think they roast their own?).. when i first went in I asked for a Flat White, to their credit they knew what one was (so many places do not) and introduced me to a Gibraltar instead (like a flat white but served in a glass).
Its now my fave type of coffee.
They also have some amazing cookies and a nutty, chocolate and toffee flapjack sort of thing which is delicious.
Great little terrace area outside to enjoy your coffee in the sun.
Cash only!
author: Alex P.

description:
Came here a while ago while waiting for Outerlands to get some nice hot black coffee. 

Ambiance: 
Love the parklet right outside! It totally fits the beach vibe. It's a small eclectic place, with only 3 stools for sitting at the window counter and 3-4 more at the cashier counter. Lots to look at - there's a riding pony above your head. LOL

Menu: 
Coffee was delish! and I love their menu. So original and interesting. Coconuts? Build Your Own Damn House? On binder paper?
I came here again yesterday so I could finally try their cinnamon toast. Again, coffee was very good, and I had it in a homemade mug! The toast took a while, but I didn't mind because that meant I got it fresh and warm! It had a great crunch, topped with cinnamon sugar and some syrup/butter that might have been a bit too sweet for me...but I love the thickness, texture, and taste of the toast! Their other pastries looked really good too. 
Both times I went, the friends that accompanied me both had the chai and said it was too spicy. Another friend really liked their mocha.

People: 
The first time I came, a lady was at the counter, and it seemed like she didn't want to be bothered. I couldn't elicit a smile from her. It might also be because it was Outerlands Sunday brunch hour so yeah...I'm trying to be understanding. 
But yesterday, there was a guy at the cashier and he was really friendly and chill. I greeted him with a smile and he reciprocated! He was super nice enough to cut the toast in half for me so I could split it with a friend. 

Nice place to chill on off days when it's not crowded...and when it's nice weather outside.
author: Hana K.

description: The chocolate chip scones are excellent and I just recently discovered their coffee cake. So yum. The cinnamon toast is good too, but I don't usually like to wait for it. Wish they had decaf, but the coffee is good.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Got "build you own damn house", which consists of a thick toast, small coffee and a coconut ($8).

The coffee is strong and goes really well with cream. The cinnamon toast is thick and very buttery. You can taste butter in every bite (feels like its oozing out of the toast). I couldn't quite tase the cinnamon, but it was good enough for what it is. I probably can go for less butter and more sugar, but that's just personal preference. The coconut was refreshing. It goes well with the toast, surprisingly. The only tricky part is to get all the coconut meat outta the coconut, but it's kinda fun if you've got the time. 

It has very little seating inside but everyone seem to just grab n go or sit out on the wooden benches or the huge log outside of the coffee shop. It's a cute and hip place to get coffee, but slightly pricy (~$3 per cup)

I tried their scones the other time I went. It was really good, buttery and soft...yum. Way better than expected. They have mini pies that I want to try too....next time.
author: Whitney W.

description:
I like this place because they make a good coffee. Definitely recommend the toast to add to your cup of joe. I had the Mocha, pretty good, rather small but definitely has the strong kick most "bigger" mochas have. 

Pure hipster place. Service are a bunch of d-bag hipsters who think they're super cool. Though I'd be cranky working in such a small cramped space. Despite that, I'll still definitely be coming here to get my coffee. Very few spots like this in the Sunset.
author: Robert C.

description: Great brew, cool spot. Not to be missed.
author: Noah W.

description: The coffee is darker than a lot of what is happening around the city but still excellent. My preferred cup. I've been here several times and true to the concept surrounding Trouble, always feel inspired walking away after a cup. The neighborhood frequents this place and are as welcoming as they are interesting. Love this place and the people involved.
author: Brett G.

description: Just a blob of foam on top the espresso for the cappuccino. Coffee is good, no Coava it Heart, but good.
author: Emily P.

description: If you want decaf, don't go here. If you want (and for those who are lactose-free and trying to avoid soy!) 2%, 1%, or fat-free milk, don't go here.  If you wanted to be treated like a human being instead of smelly crud that just walked in off the street, don't go here. Yes the toast is tasty, but the staff's attitude and air of pretension aren't worth making you feel like crap.
author: Bee H.

description:
Coffee is strong and complex. 

Staff is hippie-wonderful 

Only downside (well, a downside for those of us who aren't full-hippie) is the lack of splenda. Other than that, fantastic! 

Oh, and their banana chocolate bread was quite good (not as sweet as I generally like it, but still very good). Cookies looked amazing, too.
author: Heather W.

description: Cool little local spot that I'm happy to give my money to in exchange for a little cup of warmth on a cold SF night. Nowhere to sit Inside, but cool driftwoodish stuff to chill on outside. It's got character and nice local flavor.
author: Kris F.

description: If you want a simple breakfast bite this place is perfect. Best toast I have ever had. Thick cut, covered in cinnamon buttery sugary goodness. The coffee is delicious with a chocolatey under tone. I'll be back.
author: Maey P.

description:
1. the espresso
2. the attitude
3. the yummy munchies 
4. the sweet outside hangout area
5. the hot guy making toast that one Sunday I went 

Any questions?
author: Suzie B.

description: Really cool spot and a special place to visit after knowing the history of how the place got started. It is tiny but has a lot of character. After just a few minutes of being there, I could tell there was a community feel. When I looked around I I saw a crowded place with nobody on cell phones or any other technology. Obviously a rare sight in today's coffee shop world. The  cinnamon toast by the way was absolutely delicious, Best I've ever had. The outside patio is also very unique, complete with part of a tree trunk sprawled across the cement.
author: Brian H.

description: A good place to grab coffee, tea or hot chocolate when you're waiting for outerlands to open, but other than that, it's just "a-ok". Coffee is a little weak. I'm still a blue bottle fan.
author: Vanessa K.

description: I waited only 5 minutes to order my latte, but then I waited 20 minutes for them to make it, and it still wasn't ready. By that point my table was ready at the restaurant down the street (Outerlands, great place). So I left to sit down for breakfast. I came back 10 minutes later to see if my coffee was *now* ready. Indeed they finished making it, and they called my name and I wasn't there, so they threw it out. That's BS.
author: Shahaf A.

description: Cute small place. I picked up a Girlfriend here. I love how they called out the order: "Giiirlfriend! Make her sweet and hot!" Yes, please. Ok, it's actually an Earl Grey latte with honey and lavender. Strong on the milk and mild on the lavender. I'm currently obsessed with lavender so it wasn't potent enough for me. This is good for people such as my friend who doesn't enjoy lavender but still wanted to try a Girlfriend (because who doesn't).  Tiny place with no seating. You can drink it outside in their parklet which features a large tree trunk for seating, or walk a few blocks to the beach to take in the fresh, cold, cold ocean breeze. Enjoy.
author: Yan E.

description: I guess I'm not hipster enough to go here. Ordered an americano and they forgot about my order. 4 other americano's came up and i got attitude from the owner lady for trying to take them. Finally they made mine and just put it on the counter without telling me its ready.
author: Gray S.

description:
This place kind of impressed me.  I am a TRUE coffee snob.  I can taste the difference in roasts and treat a cup of coffee the way some people treat a bottle of wine.

I was on Judah for a completely different reason, but had an empty stomach and about 15 minutes to kill.  So I came here.  There was pretty cool punk music playing.  It was about 1pm on a foggy Monday.  There were several parents milling around the joint with their kids in tow.  Usually that will turn me off of a place.  I dislike the soccer mom crowd who chill at a coffee place and let their kids run amok.  But that was not the case here.  It seemed the parents were genuinely interested in paying attention to their kids and were making chatter with each other when there was a moment.  It was not rush hour or before noon so maybe that had something to do with it too.

Regardless, I got a small latte and a peanut butter cookie.  It is the best coffee I have had in a while.  The cookie was absolutely fantastic.  

The guy behind the counter was friendly and thoughtful.

I may have to come back here for a cup of joe before my next walk on the beach.  

Unexpected and pleasantly surprised by my experience here.  I think I will grab some beans next time too!
author: M M.

description: Coffee was good, but the cinnamon toast was a outta this world tasty treat. Perfect combo for a foggy day mid-ride caffeine and sugar jolt.
author: Bowen P.

description:
I didn't realize toast could be so good. Trouble's big slab of toasted bread, slathered in butter and topped with sugar and cinnamon is hands down the best. I can't imagine it getting any better. 

Sit on the wooden steps outside, take in the off-the-ocean air. Eat toast, be content.
author: N P.

description:
I think they are now my favorite coffee spot. 

No frills, get a cup, get a slice of coffee cake. Have a great freaking day.
author: Melissa T.

description: These days it's hard to have an experience at a cafe where the food/drink is a direct channel to the truth and vision from the owner. She started the toast craze just by offering to the public what has defined her. The cinnamon toast feels like a hug. The coconut starts a conversation. The coffee is perfect. I had a Gibraltar that was the perfect temperature and the espresso is pulled with heart. I wish there were more places like this.
author: Katherine J.

description:
Such a cool place.  So different.  Great coffee, oddball menu (yes, sometimes it's written in Russian), beautiful people both working there and enjoying the coffee, cinnamon toast and wonderful outdoor seating made from a carved out tree trunk (oak?).

Julianna is a cool owner, but don't piss her off!  Seriously, hers is a business I always want to patronize and I feel like an insider having it right in my 'hood...

I would say "go there" but everyone already seems to know about it!
author: Michael S.

description: Trouble is quite a lot of trouble! I love the atmosphere, it is almost like a room of a rebellious college student. Personally when I came here we ordered a gibraltor and it was INSANELY sour. I think it really has to do with the barista. Not a lot of sitting space and parking isn't all that convenient either. I really wanted to like this place, but so far I can't seem to go back again.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Juliet-
Your baristas are out of control. They are rude; not funny, not cute. They are demeaning and superior. It was downright offensive. 

I have been coming to trouble since the beginning. I am one of the people who you handed $20 to and asked to go get you half and half because you were out. I love you and this place. 
I recently went with my friends who were in from out of town and my two year old. 

I obviously said something wrong in their eyes. I think I used the word "need" instead of some other pre-approved one, but I'm still not sure? So, their lesson, if they were trying to impart one, is lost.  I'm not a rushed corporate person that demands things and "needs to be schooled". I'm just a mom who was excited to be out of the house for coffee for the first time in a while! 
I'm sad that I was so excited to show my friends (Including a 13 year old and her friend who would love to be adults and are thoughtful interesting people watching the world and learning. )Trouble and they got an experience for sure.  But not one worth ever repeating. Your baristas could've been cute or funny with whatever point they were trying to get across. They weren't. They made me repeat some "acceptable" phrase to order my coffee?! Now the only lesson I learned is that the two baristas working that day were jerks in that moment. From other reviews I am sad to hear that it isn't an isolated incident. 

You are awesome and interesting and friendly and always an experience to talk to. I started coming to your shop for friendly interaction with you and community.  
Please bring that back if you can.
author: Ranger V.

description: I tried the cappuccino.  It was good.  It is a simple two men shop which is cute.
author: Jackie J.

description:
I don't get it.  

This place sucks, straight up.  Expensive, not THAT good for the price and the girl behind the counter was beyond rude.  I generally hate it when people give bad reviews based largely on service, but I'll make an exception here because of her obnoxious, pretentious attitude.

Why the f would anyone pay their prices for slightly above average coffee and bad service?  Not me.
author: Erin B.

description:
Will be my neighborhood go-to coffee spot. Space is tight, but they do have a few seats inside and outside. 

The Gilbatar was amazing. Just the right amount of liquid for me (espresso and a tad bit of steamed milk). The dirty chai (chai, shot of espresso, and steamed milk) was really good, but developed a really strong chai after taste if you leave it sitting for awhile. We sat right by the counter near the cashier and chatted a bit with the fellows working there, who were super nice. The peanut butter toast on their thick slices of bread looked amazing...will have to come back to try it.
author: Lisa C.

description:
The vibe here is laid back, surfer at the beach with plenty of attitude.  For example, they offer "Build Your Own Damn House" on the menu ($8).  If you order this, you get coffee, a coconut, and their famous Toast.  I don't understand what one does with a coconut especially in the morning?  Do you stick a straw in it and drink it?  

The menu is limited to various coffee drinks, chai, tea, toast, coconuts and jars of pickled veggies.  On the side they have Etch-a-Sketches to play with and free Trouble Coffee stickers.  The place is filled with antique knick knacks like a huge tic-tac-toe game mounted on the wall, old boots as the doorstopper, and rusty tools.

I had the impression this place existed in someone's garage but it's a real storefront and although small, it's larger than I expected.  They have three indoor stools and a tiny bit of outdoor seating.  The feeling there is communal and everyone's friendlier than I'm used to at say, Peet's where people are focused on getting their coffee and getting out the door.

I highly recommend the Toast ($2).  The white bread is cut by hand into inch thick slices, lathered with butter, topped liberally with cinnamon sugar and toasted till hot and crispy on the outside (but still soft inside). The bread is really good. It's simple and divine.  

The Elbow Grease coffee ($2-2.25) was bold and smooth but I wish it were (much) stronger.  I should have gotten a latte but I was afraid it would be too small.  Will definitely be back for more Toast and a latte, though the friendliness did throw me for a loop.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: Delicious thick, crispy cinnamon toast with butter. Lavender black tea. Many regular customers stopping by on a Thursday morning. Definitely a hipster vibe inside. Bundle up and sit outside if that vibe is not for you!
author: Pearl L.

description: After hearing about the backstory on This American Life, I ventured over to the Outer Sunset to eat at Trouble. I wasn't expecting high quality toast or coffee (in fact, my first breakfast of the day was at The Mill, known for quality hipsterness), but was delighted to find myself nomming on a delicious thick piece of fresh toast, slathered in butter and cinnamon sugar. The iced coffee was quality, too. My sister got the grapefruit juice and a Gibraltar (espresso with a little steamed milk). Both delicious as well. Aside from the food, the spot itself is delightfully bizarre, complete with hipster espresso art making baristas, local artist made ceramic mugs, and a map of San Francisco calling out annual murders. Will go back. Perhaps tomorrow.
author: Emily K.

description: Maybe my favorite coffee in the city.   The toast is just really good toast, but a nice quick bite.
author: Courtney C.

description:
My boyfriend really likes this place, but he is weird. I, on the other hand, do not. Yes they serve huge slices of bread with cinnamon and sugar and 3 table spoons of butter, but it is not good. Their bread is too thick, the butter does not seep into it and the only way to get the bread crunchy through out the whole thing is to burn the outside. My chai is seriously lacking, i've had better at starbucks.

I'm sure my boyfriend will drag me back here eventually, i do not look forward to the dirty looks i will receive on that day, but i gotta make him happy, right?
author: A. H.

description: Great place on the way to Ocean Beach on the N train... However, when one of the employees told a customer no photos it made me very sad. (Let people take a photo, we're in San Francisco!) Also, they only serve 8 oz latte's. :(
author: Brock E.

description:
Great coffee and amazing cinnamon toast (an entire meal). Several guests ordered a coconut water inside a real coconut with pieces of coconut - which seemed to be a real specialty. 

A real social cafe where people talk to each other from the neighborhood, not a stone silent laptop cafe. A real pleasure. 

Since it is the outer sunset near the beach, combined with a beach excursion, it is on the N Judah line, making it the perfect beach trip stop.
author: Eliott R.

description: Trouble is a great place to grab a coffee and to just chill since they have outdoor seating. I usually get a latte, but every now and then I'll get an Americano and add some soy milk that is provided on their cream/sugars table outside. Don't forget to try the toast!
author: Kathy L.

description: Coffee is pretty good. The first time the cinnamon toast was awesome but the barista toaster guy told me not to take pictures of the toast which i was going to send to my daughter because we both love cinnamon toast. This is the second time I've been here . The toaster barista guy was very friendly when he greeted me and took my order. I work 10 hour graveyard shifts and commute 1 to 1.5 hours each way. I really had a craving for the toast and while I was waiting the toaster guy was giving me the eye while I was on the phone asking my room mate if any bills came in that I need to know about. I'm on contract and my home is in LA so the little time i do have not driving or sleeping is time to catch up on business. When my toast was ready he remarked that I'm not supposed to be on my phone in the cafe. Really? While I'm waiting for my toast i can't be on the phone? I feel like I'm at a job where i keep getting told what I'm doing wrong. I don't get much time off and both times I've been here i feel like i have to walk on eggshells. For sone reason the toast was not so awesome this time. It's their business and they can run it the way they like. I wasn't even taking loud and the music was pretty loud so I'm not sure what was so offensive about my call. This is the last time I'll be coming. I heard some place nearby had even better soda bread than the toast at Trouble. I'll spend my precious time somewhere i feel comfortable. 3 stars for the toast and minus for the service. A paying customer should never be made to feel badly about coming.
author: coco c.

description:
Freaky weird concept, tiny shack like place, killer Americano I'd seek out again. Big thick slabs of cinnamon toast. Coconuts are god here. Trouble will cure all your ills either by good toast, good coffee, or a fresh coconut.

Worth a trip to come here, or tie it in with a beach trip a block away. (Tip: if you're training for a charity marathon leave the path and come here instead.)

Coffee must have a mind control substance that I'm giving it 5 stars since I couldn't use my laptop and really wanted to. I liked it as much as  Blue Bottle.

And to those who got ignored here: I ended up at Trouble because I was ignored at Starbucks. Give it another chance.

[update: took 1 star off as I did not feel cool enough on my 2nd visit. And it wasn't just me being insecure about my coolness I swear.]
author: Susie W.

description: The girl at the counter was cute enough. The guy making the coffee was cool enough. Who knew that they are Coffee Nazi's there!?! :^O I order a double latte' and get it in a Dixie cup sized cup. I point at the large cup and say I want it in that cup and I will pay extra, the hot girl tells me no. That I can only get a large cup for Ice coffee and tea? Really, WTF are you thinking? I own small businesses and try to spend my money with other small businesses. But Trouble seems to think they know how I like my coffee better than I do. So I guess I'll go to starbucks or Pete's , as they let me order my coffee the same way I have for 15 years, not how they think I should drink it.
author: Keyser S.

description:
If you can fight through the sea of pretension, it's worth a visit. I love their coffee (although some days it's quite watery) . 

Today, though, I turned around while my boyfriend ordered to see where we might sit outside, and he yells (like, really yelled!) "Well, BYE THEN!" in a really snide way. I actually stopped and turned around and raised my eyebrows because I was so taken aback. Like, really? Who the hell is paying your bills? Oh yeah, me, the patron you just insulted. Stupid pansy b*tch. Won't be going back. I hope these brats and their bratty attitude run themselves right into the red and they close. I'd rather get crappy 7/11 coffee then go deal with this first thing in the morning.
author: Aisha B.

description:
It was mother's day and I wanted to take my mom for her fave drink...coffee and instead of going to (my usual) Java Beach...no I decided to take her to Trouble.  I love supporting small business and you know, buying local...we had a great time my mom loved it and I, being down the street and all, made this my new coffee "home".  

Hypothesis:  Is this coffee establishment the best in the city???

Observation #1:
However, the second time I went, was all together a much different story. This time I brought business for them.  We purchased coffee played with the Etcha-skectch and talked to folks.  I went there all jolly and expecting the best dirty chai, and I got some rude bastard who looked at me as if I didn't have any $$.  This tall drink of water left my coffee to sit and get cold, and didn't even tell me it was ready.  I had to look at my watch and then look at the counter and think to myself "Is that my coffee?!"  UGH.

New Hypothesis:  Are they rude, racists, bigots, lazy, elitist???

Observation #2: 
Okay, so call me a glutton for punishment, I went there again...just to see.  A good scientist always notes many observations before coming to a proper conclusion.   So it was again with the rude and condescending looks from the baristas.  NO ONE who makes under $10 an hour should give anyone condescending looks...

Conclusion:
Long story short...I will never, ever go to Trouble coffee again.  I'd rather go all the way to Hayes Valley and get some Blue Bottle Coffee, wait in a long ass line and get great coffee and service, while I stand in an alley with 20 other people enjoying their coffee.  Because it's actually coffee.  And you know when something is free it tastes sooo much better...this goes for coffee too.  Good service is free and when it's good, the coffee tastes good too.  

Oh yeah and to answer the new-hypothesis...all the above.
author: A. M.

description: Trouble is a great little place, I love how they make their cappuccinos, I love the decorations, big fan of the super attractive staff, it's generally pretty great. Expect to wait a while to get your coffee, but expect that anywhere honestly.
author: Ali D.

description:
I hesitated giving this place a 1 star because the coffee and cinnamon toast are so darn good. If that was only being considered in this review then I would give Trouble 4 stars at least.  I am just not down for uber contrived hipsters who are trying really hard to look like they are not trying hard.  I have been going to this place for about three years and hadn't been there for a while and dear lord,  "get over yourselves" to all the wannabes that show up there.  The woman next to me smelled and looked like she had not seen soap in weeks, sporting meth makeup.  Everyone came in and used  really sleepy bored voices to order their drinks.  One lady had a glass of pink liquid - I asked "what is that?" she said, "the Yoko - it's grapefruit juice" - a reference to the Yoko Ono photo book that was on a shelf - puh-leeze!  
My daughter wanted to send her friends a picture of the peanut butter toast and was told "no pictures inside, we are trying to move away from electronics"...

Great coffee, yes but please get over yourselves!!
author: Jane H.

description: seriously the coolest coffee shop in the city, hands down. awesome iced coffee, i know i don't even need to mention the cinnamon toast (which is so good it makes my brain explode), and of course, the coconuts. get all three, sit outside in their ramshackle parklet, and life is good. it's ok they don't have a menu because the cute boy with tattoos will patiently list every single thing they offer and answer all your questions and be really nice to you even when you steal someone else's drink accidentally.
author: Lala S.

description:
while waiting for a table at outerlands, i found myself at Trouble getting in trouble with an amazing piece of cinnamon toast, which was one of the best pieces of toast ever.  But afterwards i felt a bit sick. i know i i have an issue with dirty hands but i don't think it's too much to ask for food preparers to clean hands.

While i was enjoying my piece of toast, the toast preparer saw a friend enter the shop and stopped preparing the toast to give him a surfer style handshake and then went back to preparing toast without washing his hands. pretty gross.  To make sure i was not overreacting, i continued to watch to see if he would touch the toast with his dirty hand....he did.
author: Maria R.

description:
I love this place and I live on the other side of SF. The cinnamon toast is soooo badforyou amazing. I love their coffee and this is my go-to place for a cappuccino. Their espresso has a more rounded, full flavor that I like. 

A lot of people complain about the service, which I find interesting.  I used to be a barista before I finished school.  The premise that "NO ONE who makes under $10 an hour should give anyone condescending looks..." as said by one reviewer, is false.  That's just weird, projected elitist bullsh!t and you have to live with yourself for which I am sorry.  At least the baristas don't have to deal with you anymore.

For the people intimidated by the people at Trouble Coffee: No, these baristas are not going to handhold you through your coffee order.  If you are friendly, they are friendly--or at least not rude.  And no, they are not all hipsters.  Some are straight up punk rock, which is not hipster ;)  I always find it fascinating why people give a shit about some dude's George Michael cross earring in the first place, but whatever.  

On another note, don't by a coconut here.  There's a few hundred markets which sell them for cheaper around the corner.
author: Jolly G.

description: This place used to be great! Now it's overpriced and the staff has the most horrible attitude. Don't go there!
author: Carla D.

description:
As I walked aimlessly for twenty minutes on a cold summer morning in San Francisco, waiting for my cohorts to awaken from their slumbers before embarking on our journey to the opening day of Outside Lands, I came across Trouble Coffee Co..  Upon entering, I was initially taken aback by the interior of this tiny espresso cavern.  Confused by what surrounded me: a frail bearded man sipping from a coconut and a couple of timeworn gentlemen eating toast - I stood silent and frozen, not knowing what I had stepped in to.  When the barista with the crooked, yet pleasant toothy grin welcomed me, my anxiety soon began to dwindle.

Their coffee is delicious...
author: Colleen C.

description: One of the Sunset's best spots on one of the Sunsets most interesting streets.  I buy and drink Elbow Grease regularly, my heart usually starts palpitating after 2 cups.  The baked goods are outstanding, the parklet out front fits the neighborhood, and the staff have always been lovely.  Trouble is a gem.
author: Helmut S.

description: I love everything about this place. The people, location, music, the no technology rule, cash only, the look, the vibe, the stories I heard, the cookies, and the cinnamon toast. The cinnamon toast! I'm an atheist but this toast had me wondering for a fraction of a second. Kidding. But still, cinnamon toast! Thank you for enduring the crusty cinnamon and sugar caked on your clothes and hands and trapped under your fingernails as if it belongs there to make this amazing toast for us bar-sitters. Much love. Also the hot chocolate was killer. I would come here every day if I lived closer.
author: K D.

description:
Latte and cappuccino drinks are enjoyable. I do appreciate that they care about their coffee. Espresso very acidic, but not bad. 

Too much personality and input for a cafe. Style,design,music and hipster tatted servers is just too much.

Listen guys. It's about COFFEE not your fucking shitty pirate clothes...
author: Daniel H.

description:
There's something magical about this coffee that I just can't pin down. Their soy latte has a distinct note of "pretzel m&m." Don't worry about why, it just does. And it makes it perfect.  

The cinnamon toast is great... it's fat, which is the way good toast should be. The cookie was good. Not great, but it's certainly not going to make me deduct a star. After all, this is a coffee place, not a cookie place.

The service has always been wonderful. It's a small little coffee shop, which makes it hard to find a space to sit and linger, but the baristas have always been friendly. One of them even ran to get me a napkin when they saw me spilling the aforementioned pretzel m&m soy latte all over myself.
author: Kristen B.

description: Witch @ssness barista, with the worst attitude and customer service! I guess you can't expect much from homeless, weed smoking homies. However the interior is unique with old skool toys and the coffee is ok at best . Very close to Ritual but not Blue Bottle. $4 mocha is in a tiny cup. If you compare it to Starbucks it's smaller than a tall. Good to try but not good enough to be a consistent customer.
author: Cee B.

description:
Three years of bliss and counting. From the moment I tasted this coffee, it is all I want to drink. When I give it as a gift, which I often do, folks are ecstatic.
I'm so happy to be a regular and to be in trouble as much as possible.
author: Michele F.

description:
If you truly enjoy a good cup then a trip out to this side of town is worth it.  Do good for your future self and grab a bag of beans...Dark, rich and smooth.  The milk ( or cream?) they set out is extra rich, -hey, sometimes its fun to be a little bit bad which brings me to the orange-chocolate scone...so rich and buttery sooo freakin delicious- you'll feel pretty naughty eating it and you'll love every second of it. - Just DO IT. 

Get your butt out there, get a cup and head a few  more blocks west for a walk out on ocean beach!
author: Jodi R.

description: I wish all businesses were like this: small, authentic, gorgeously specific.  It's wonderful to walk into this shop and feel you've entered another person's world.  I adore every single thing on the quirkily short menu.  MOST DELICIOUS COFFEE OF ALL TIME.
author: Sophie R.

description: The best coffee in SF - hands down.  Folks can have that sour mash Blue Bottle, this is what real, dark, smoky Italian coffee is all about.  Thankfully I have self control and only get the delicious cinnamon toast once every 5-6 trips
author: Scott L.

description:
Hands down, best cup of coffee of my life. 

Yes, it's far away from the hustle and bustle of the main city. Yes, it is worth the trek out. Yes, it is tiny and no, it doesn't have the conveniences of a Starbucks. (Thank God.) If you're ready to stop whining about "service" and want to get a good cup of joe from someone who isn't dripping in saccharine corporate-America faux sincerity, come in. If not, limp back to The Coffee Bean.

Also: the baked goods are amazing.
author: Alexandra P.

description: Pretty much the saving grace on an ill-fated brunch expedition to the outer Sunset one Sunday morning. This fun little coffee shop made the 2 hour wait for a table at Outerlands more bearable by serving up a great cappuccino and a thick slice of cinnamon toast that was worth the N Judah ride on its own. Seriously, you have to get the cinnamon toast or you will look like a fool. There isn't much (if any) seating here and it's cash only.
author: Mark A.

description:
I LOVE me some good coffee, and I LOVE me some good service! So why on earth did I come here????? 

Rude service, wrong order, long wait, serious bad-attitude, skinny-jeans and the most overpriced mediocre coffee in sf!!! If that's what you come here for, then SCORE for you! 

If you wanna see mission hipsters taking over the last bastion of REAL-SF then this also may be your place. BOOOOOOO! 

I will NEVER return.. I'd rather drink 3 day old coffee out of the south-side of a north-facing dog!!!!!!!!!
author: Moocifer M.

description:
(Five stars for the cinnamon toast, one star for the below account.)

Self-importance reaches a new high at the Trouble Coffee Company in the Outer Sunset.

After ordering my (quite expensive) $2.50 cup of herbal tea, I made my way to the fixings station to prepare my beverage for consumption, according to my personal preferences. When I found only brown sugar and raw sugar on the table, I inquired about where I might find the artificial sweeteners.

The response I received from the female barista was, "We don't subscribe to that."

Huh?!

To what do you actually not subscribe?!

Diabetics experiencing the joy of sweetness without slipping into a coma?

How about better oral health? Is that on your watch list, too?

Is it the concept of enjoying a beverage while consuming fewer calories that keeps you awake at night?

Or is your issue with the general presence of facts - like the fact that decades of (independent) medical research have failed to yield a connection between artificial sweeteners and health problems?

Holy moly, people. My local coffee shop has become a campaign office. Their target? Big Sweetener.

This is the eleventh plague.

To be fair, I can appreciate that groundbreaking ideas are often initially met with disbelief, and that the proprietors of the Trouble Coffee Company are entitled to run their business however they damned well please.

However, there is one critical problem with the dogma being preached at the Trouble Coffee Company: it is not available to you until after you have paid, and only when you arrive at the fixings bar, just in time to hear the din of Satan's laughter. This means that a beverage that is purchased by a customer who uses artificial sweetener as their primary sweetening method is a beverage that is rendered useless.

It is arrogant to expect that customers would plan for the contingency of there not being artificial sweetener prior to their ordering. I don't care at which music festival your parents conceived you, there is a globally accepted standard that any hot beverage fixings bar will include artificial sweetener of some sort, and that deviations on the theme would include only the esoteric, not the canon. For instance, you might not expect to find Stevia, but you can always expect to come face to face with a packet of Splenda, Equal, or Sweet 'N Low.

To the proprietors of the Trouble Coffee Company:

If you want to take on the seemingly bulletproof artificial sweetener machine, replete with its backdoor-deal lobbyists and midnight baby-stealing, don't bankroll your coup on the backs of unsuspecting customers who would otherwise prefer to redirect their funds to higher-impact pursuits, like buying paint and watching it dry.

Won't you please do the right thing, and hang a simple sign that simply states that you are simply uncomfortable with artificial sweeteners?

Even in your utopia, where waterfalls of organic aardvark milk infused with old-vine hemp stalks unfold in the sky, as if to climb to Heaven, where every last naked pedestrian greets one another with a wink and a smile, and where people pay one another in smiles, consumers will still have preferences and the instinct to choose based on them.

As such, I'll be taking my business to a place that offers less trouble.

And more sucralose.
author: D B.

description:
Quicktip:  not-on-the menu Must Have item
Cinnamon Toast

made with brioche bread, thickly sliced, with the perfect balance of butter, sugar, and cinnamon.  undeniably tasty in a way that will tickle your childhood memories.
author: Liz S.

description: I love the name of the company, but this is not what I'm looking for in a coffee shop.  Very hipster, very tiny, and almost no indoor seating, which makes zero sense when it is located so close to the windy, foggy beach.  Yes, the benches outdoors are nice, but it's cold 10 months out of the year here!  I was also bummed at the lack of Splenda or Stevia; not very diabetic-friendly.  So, all in all, there are other cafes in town I can get a good cup of coffee - AND a place to drink it in.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Hot Hippy Girlfriend on a foggy Sunset morning and no b.s. Doesn't get better than that:)
author: Mary G.

description:
The only thing I know about coffee is that it costs too much. Seems like now a days if you go into any artisanal coffee shop you always get the coffee snob attitude because you had to bother the college dropout behind the counter with a question about what's offered at their establishment.

You don't get that here at trouble coffee. The people here are nice and most importantly, you get great coffee. Go there because going that far out in the city and you deserve a reward.
author: Vince and sabrina B.

description:
I wish I had more time to explore the other goodies they offer besides your standard coffee drinks, but we hastily ordered two lattes and that was that.   As we enjoyed our drinks in their parklet that features a giant tree trunk with several hipsters perched on top/next to it, I saw a lot of customers actually getting fresh coconuts and toasts (who sells toasts?  now I am very curious but I don't want to stare.)  

The whole vibe fits the Outer Sunset/Ocean Beach scene: laid back yet hustles and bustles.  We thought we saw the girl behind the counter going surfing later.  No wonder she seemed a bit in a rush.

The lattes were fine but they came in teeny cups.  $3.5 each.
author: Candice B.

description: This Outer Sunset nook serves up stiff, damn good java and toast that demands to be appreciated; and appreciate it you will. Cash only.
author: Anthony C.

description:
I learned of the TROUBLE story in pacific standard  magazine, was in town from NYC area and decided to try it for fun.  The thick chewy slab of cinnamon butter and sugar toast was delicious, three teas for about $10 was not crazy pricey . The service was fun, counter help being of good humor quite accepting of a tourist toast taster.

The neighborhood is fun too, and a walk to nearby beach and/or sutro park makes for a really neat tourist zone.  Now maybe the hipster vibe area doesn't want that, but c'mon people...it's a simple ,easy little TOAST and coffee shop...decent, yummy food and drink.

If I were a local id frequent the place. As a tourist ,it helped me discover a little corner of San Francisco I might have missed otherwise.

A local neighbor even kindly warned me not to leave my car parked too long ,to avoid sweeping day ticket.   My trouble experience was a positive from every angle, and the reviews that get highly critical like they were expecting a Michelin star  or Zagats review, well,   It is TOAST.....relax and enjoy!
author: Mike K.

description: The cinnamon toast is delicious!! (and better than the PB in my and my party's option).
author: Theresa C.

description: Best coffee in Outer Sunset. Trouble's baked goods are absolutely delectable! The handcrafted strawberry pie was the best I ever had! My only complaint was the pie was a mini pie and embarrassed myself when I looked like a fat kid and went back in and ordered 3 more (that's all they had left. I would have bought a dozen:)
author: Ashley E.

description: Small coffee shop with great coffee and amazing huge cinnamon toast. Didn't get to try the fresh coconut but will definitely be back for it. Good spot to ride your bike too as street parking can be limited.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Yummyyummyyummyyummyyummyyummyyummyyummy...

Nice guy working there, everyone loved their drink.  Smooth coffee.  Hot chocolate that wasn't overwhelmingly sweet.  And soy... oh, the soy.  And did you just make a heart in my friend's drink?  Yes, yes you did.  Us girls are suckers for latte art, aren't we? 

Only down a star cuz it's not a place you can sit and chill... we're not from the area, and we're used to a different kinda set up, but clearly you're doing well, and it's just a preference thing.
author: Ramy S.

description:
a small, simple repurposed arty stylish, and tasty coffeery out in the stix,  45th n Judah...

i dont do coffee, so pay attention as much as you must, or not...

the scones and mini chicken pot pie were tasty, the coffee caller is a nice creative, but for the trained pedestrian, there are no prices or menu...

such a wonderfully beachy parklet and rear yard...it has a wonderfully accentual friend next door in 'the general store...

guess, what, its for hipsters...
author: alex m.

description:
Pumpkin Chocolate Chip  Bread is killer!
Came home with a bag of The Hammer espresso & cant hardly drink anything else!!!!
author: HoneyBadger C.

description: Great little coffee shop just down the street from the beach!
author: Buck H.

description: Had a good enough cup of coffee and had a amazing slice of cinnamon toast.  Heavy on the hipster vibe but great for a quick coffee on the run or linger a moment in the mini park
author: Nick H.

description:
I noticed there were no menus to be seen so I asked the behind the counter where it was. He explained what they served. He was friendly about it and taking his time explaining what they served. I eventually ordered hot chocolate to which he mentioned that he forgot to say that was sold there too. I was afraid to take the first sip because I thought it would be very hot, but it was just warm enough and tasted like no other hot coco I've tasted. Best way to explain it is when someone who came from a European trip brings back some chocolate. That chocolate has a different, better taste than local chocolate.

I also explained why I didn't like coffee as much since I crashed hard on it after the caffeine effects start to go away from my system and he went into detail about how their coffee is a bit different than others. I might just try out there coffee the next time I go back.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
OLD SKOOL
Coffee and Community..
My community...
I saw someone yesterday and other times too... having a first time visit... she was dismayed... i mean a place offers espresso drinks... they tell you how they make them.....you don't like it?? too bad... when I came back from France the first time I wanted every espresso made restreto or pulled short... and when I didn't get?  I was like yeah adam get real they just work there it's not italy..... now If you want it short ask for it... but don't tell them put three shots in when they only pull doubles.... it's not an option... go to mcdonalds and have it your way.... I say this is what i Do and this is How I do it... the rest of the reviews explain themselves as most negatives come from people outside the community... not from the sunset, not moving here... not spending money in this neighborhood... who needs them then... the people working living breathing and earning livings raising familys and so forth... come here...i'm a little bit a cynic.  I patronize my local community coffee shop...and I'm better for it.  It's a great way I connect with my local comunity without the need for phone numbers business cards, or any of that stuff...as for those who think there stuff doesn't stink.. it does...and my favorite thing about them is that they are cash only... get with it people:
CASH:  DON'T LEAVE HOME WITHOUT IT! ...
author: Adam O.

description: ...back for another cup of coffee and conversation.  This time I had a currant and Meyer lemon scone (delicious) and one of their fantastic cappuccinos.  On the way out, I noticed a bag of coffee labeled "The Hammer".  I asked about it and was told, "That's the espresso".  You know me, I jumped at the chance to buy their espresso roast.  I have to admit, I love their "Elbow Grease", however, I ADORE "The Hammer".  Ground and run through my espresso machine, it is worth the 7.00 a half pound cost (yikes!).  OMG!  It was smooth, produced a creamy crema and has an anise or fig after taste.  MMmmmmmmn!
author: Kelly B.

description:
Trouble Coffee is  new in the Sunset. The coffee is good and freshly brewed ($2 for a small). Try one with a cinnamon toast. For $2, you will have huge slice of homemade bread toasted with butter, sugar and cinnamon. Yummy! I dreamed about it for days. A real comfort food!

A cheap thrill for less than $5, very cool ambiance.
author: Christine L.

description:
I really think this coffee is outstanding. Last time I was out here I brought back a pound of beans and went through them within days.

Cinnamon toast and a small cup of black Trouble is all I need to get the day started.

They have great stickers too!
author: Monica H.

description: Love this place! Coffee is good and seating outside is great. I live nearby so I try and go as often as I can. I'm not a pro with coffee so I can't tell ya the body or flavors or even the origin of it.... But it's good and better then most places I've been to in SF/Santa Cruz/Surrounding Portland area (you get it).  The N runs right in front of it so I can get my coffee and hop back on the train!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Awesome lattes, Tasty baked goods, Eclectic Decor and punk rock music. The cold brew coffee is real good.
author: Matt K.

description:
A classic San Francisco Mission-hipster style coffee shop, planted directly in the midst of the Outer Sunset. It's very similar to Subrosa in Oakland, except that they have the Holy Grail of cinnamon toast (which is not on the menu). 

The coffee is really, really good. It might even be better than Philz, IMO. I've tried their lattes iced and hot, as well as their mocha and a sip of the Gibraltar (really intense espresso). I took off a star because of one of the space cadet baristas is usually rude and prone to screwing up multiple orders at once without apologizing.
