It's also pretty overpriced for the portion size, but I suppose you're paying for the imported Mission ambience as well. Another slight downside is the lack of sugar substitutes and indoor seating.

Tip: GET THE TOAST. IT'S PERFECT.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Cool space, great vibe, funky interior w/ some darn good eats! 

Went on a Sunday morning around 9am...by 9:30am the place was packed! And it is small...4 bar-window seats & 5 counter-bar seats. I could almost touch the espresso machine from my bar seat so it's intimate but that's what quirky cafes should be like! 

Went for the Build Your Own Damn House. Coffee was smooth and silky- not sure what they're pouring but I should have found out. Toast is definitely thick, cut to the width of a bread knife, toasted using a regular toaster, slathered w/ butter & cinnamon sugar topping. It was good...I almost wanted maple syrup or pan-fried apple slices with it (just b/c that's what I do when I make French Toast) but this cafe's all about good for you...no unneeded sugars (only raw sugar offered for coffee, no Splenda/Equal/etc)...she has a following. The coconut was wonderful. How can you not like coconut juice, then spooning out the insides which they so thoughtfully slice up for you, w/ your spoon? Kept me full for a long time & cost $8.

Cash only.
author: Marissa H.

description:
Super cute little spot with friendly staff and AMAZING coffee! I wandered in after a long bike ride and sampled the cinnamon toast per a friend's suggestion. Thick, dense toast coated with slightly salty butter, sugar and cinnamon. Not too sweet and it went perfectly with my cup of coffee, which they don't roast, but I want whatever they're buying...all of it, all the time.

I hung out a bit chatting with the guy at the register and some of the people that wandered in...perfect way to end a long ride. Next time I'm in the neighborhood I'm totally trying one of their surf bars, which the guy described as being a bowl of oatmeal in a bar. Awesome.
author: Karena Q.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!! Just moved to the neighborhood and completely missed this place for almost a month. A month wasted. I walked in and ordered the "Build your own damn house" and was completely thrown. I expected the coffee and cinnamon sugar toast, both of which where FANTASTIC!!!! I was not expecting the young coconut with a spoon and straw. This was what blew me away. I had just gone for a bike ride, and the coconut water was AMAZING. So refreshing. Then the coffee and toast. It was just awesomeness followed by more awesomeness. I highly suggest this place. Great drip coffee and I hear the Espresso drinks are really good, too. I look forward to going for a latte. Check it out. It will blow you away.

Also, they sell their house blend beans, both drip and espresso. They only have the two kinds, but I think it is all they need.
author: Thomas E.

description:
Great cup of coffee and cool decor.  The only downsides:
no white granulated sugar, no restroom, and they didn't allow photos of the cool walkie-talkies on the shelf.  Cookies looked/sounded great, but didn't try one.
author: N P.

description: ok the coffee is ok,  but the crap service too cool for school, unsmiling, unfriendly cashier kills the vibe of the quaint setting. *sigh* had so much potential too.
author: Charlie C.

description:
$9 for 2 small lattes and one small coffee. Surprisingly good coffee for the location.

cute place squeezed in a unsuspecting neighborhood.
author: Kristina S.

description:
Awesome little boutique coffee shop in the outer sunset by the beach. The people who work here are fun, and I love the intimate space & bar stool setup--- it's like a bar where everyone socializes from caffeine instead of alcohol.    Trouble is a true tribute to caffeine-- I am humored by the sites I observe here:  A fully caffeinated, shaky handed hipster sitting at the bar philosophizing about politics... Eccentric artists, etc. 

As far as the product goes, Trouble has some of my favorite coffee in San Francisco. I love their standard cup of drip coffee-- "Elbow Grease", and their espresso drinks are great as well. I suggest the "Gibraltar", which is their specialty espresso drink.  I would NOT suggest drinking it after 6pm, however, if you value sleep before 4am!  =P
author: James M.

description: I love these neighborhood coffee shops. Very delicious Americano, unfortunately wasn't hot enough (possibly because I added too much milk?). Definitely need to try the cinnamon toast!
author: Derrick H.

description:
Loved me some trouble.
They have the thick, buttery, cinnamon toast. Big, chunky cookies with coconut and chunks of chocolate.  The coffee was super good..and the hot cocoa was yum! 
Sadly, I no longer live nearby.  I honestly emailed the owner when I moved away to see if they shipped their stuff.  She told me they ship their coffee, but being that I was pregnant at the time, I really, really wanted those damn cookies!
author: Sommer R.

description: Stopped in, great coffee and little peach pie w/ crumbled topping.  Excellent staff.  Every town should have a coffee shop like this.
author: T. E.

description: The most amazing coffee....cinnamon toast to die for and friendly helpful employees!  You will dream about this place......
author: Steve D.

description:
I give this place 4 stars for the coffee, and an extra just for not being Java Beach.

There's barely enough room to stand in line here, so don't plan on bringing a Sunday newspaper with you and perusing the comics for an hour or two.  The serving size is a bit on the tiny side, as someone else already pointed out.  However, I think this place has a certain vibe to it that transcends comfort or value.  Behind the counter, mounted to the wall, are two separate racks of LPs.  On my first visit here, the ones that were visible were Yoko Ono, the Butthole Surfers, and Throbbing Gristle.  

They made my mocha just barely sweeter than an unsweetened latte, which is how I like it.  

If they had more space to dwell in it would be perfect, but its close enough as is.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Simple Goodness

coffee+cinnamon toast+fresh young coconut

Their lattes and other espresso drinks feature 'extra-rich' clover milk. Coffee is ssssssmoooooth! (Bring home the beans-$6 and amazing in the Bodum)

Best friggin cinnamon toast: thick white bread slopped w salted butter. The taste of warm, sugary butter oozing is amazing

Fresh Young Coconut (Who would've thought it does so well with coffee? not only does it re-hydrate you from the drying effects of caffeine, but has an amazing super-nutty flavor when tasted after a sip of coffee. That's right...this is the kind of coconut that us Asians see at Sunset Super, except they save us the 'trouble' of busting out that cleaver!

They know what's up. 
I appreciate that they specialize in just a few things and make each one damn good.
author: Jessica h.

description:
My GF and I drove all the way from Oakland to try this coffee because we saw the reviews on Yelp. This future of this place will definitely be in big trouble if they don't change their freaking attitude. It was packed inside so we decided to wait a few minutes until it cleared up a bit before we got in line.  My GF stood in line for about 5 minutes when a neighborhood regular (dressed in gym shorts, a button down collared shirt and alaskan fur hat, mind you) totally cut in front of her...  He started chatting up the barista and got served right away.  She came back outside to wait because there were way too many people inside.... 

After a few more minutes I went in by myself to order and stood at the counter at least 2 minutes while the barista chatted to her friend who was sitting at the side bar, completely ignoring me, despite standing in front of her holding money.  Completely unprofessional... when she took my order she did not say hi but rather "what do you want"... and charged me $4.00 for hot chocolate.  I dropped $1 into her tip jar thinking she would be nicer but it only got worse, and she did not say thank you or smile once.  Just after I paid, another "regular" named Harry came in and she immediately lit up and started chatting with him, saying that she had his drink ready.  Instead of making my hot chocolate which I had just paid for, she then made Harry's drink first, and then continued talking to her friend about her unborn child and whether or not she would keep it.  ...REALLY?! ...at work? Seriously, freaking ridiculous. I finally got my drink.... no thank you, nothing... I walked out.  I am so pissed and disappointed about this whole experience not to mention it tasted like watered down carnation.
author: KL S.

description: I've bought many coffees here, cause its close, despite the long wait times, difficult lay out, few real options, and lack of places to sit.  Today was the last straw.  When they are busy they often short the frother time on a milk based drink leaving it a tepid temperature.  Today - Me: "Can I get an extra hot latte" obviously annoyed counter person "Don't worry it will come out perfect" - hey dbag, I'm not going to drink this for 20 minutes.  The discussion to straighten him out wasn't worth the $3.50 I paid.  Beachside, a block away, has a far greater variety, much friendlier service, room to stand, and actual place to sit, and very little attitude.  At least there is truth in advertising with their name.  Trouble is more trouble than its worth, no amount of $4 toast will overcome that.
author: Kelly R.

description:
CINNAMON TOAST. 

Go get that right now.

Yes, the people in there are kinda stinky... and it's hella cramped, and you kinda gotta be wearing TOMS and jean cutoffs to truly get a smile from the baristas...

BUT

They do coffee right... if you  enjoy a good strong cup of joe from a place that doesn't offer sizes that are larger than your stomach.
author: Nnekay F.

description:
Trouble Coffee is a wonderful place for great cup of coffee. It is a small shop filled with amazing people. My friend Lace and I went there together and had an amazing experience. The owner, Julia, makes her own tea and has created many exotic flavors like early grey lavender, gemmai, etc. I commute back to the city every weekend and I always have to stop there to have a cup of their tea latte, they are just amazing.

Here is what I recommend:

Regular Coffee

Tea Lattes (earl grey w/ lavendar)

The toast

Any pastries, but the best on is the chocolate chip banana bread

Your experience here will keep you coming back for more!
author: Allie B.

description: One of America's greatest breakfast items is toast. Toast is cheap, easy to make, and can be eaten in a variety of ways. With that said, Trouble Coffee's Cinnamon toast captures that morning crispy goodness. At $3.50 their toast is thick with a bountiful of flavor, crispy, and worth coming for.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
This was a pleasant surprise on a bike ride out to the ocean and back. Excellent cappuccino, very fresh beans with a slight molasses flavor. My wife had a chai latté, which was one of the spiciest I've ever had. Lots of black pepper and punch, which is a plus for me. The spices were recently ground; it wasn't some generic, overly sweet garbage from a tea bag. We kept trading back and forth because we both wanted to have both drinks.

The barristas were really friendly, made us feel welcome right away, definitely not the typical "I don't care, hurry up and order" attitude you get at most cafés.

The place is cramped and has no bathroom and they play loud punk music. If you like the more mainstream coffee with less flavor and nothing but bitterness, go to Starbucks instead. I can't say I'll become a regular b/c outer sunset is just too far out of the way, but definitely worth trying if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Aaron G.

description:
In my usual fashion, I read the reviews to prepare for my first trip to Trouble.  

I almost didn't go because I was nervous about how I would defend myself against the stare-down from all the hipsters.  I was wearing a pair of sweat pants and a navy blue thermal shirt.  I know, not cool enough.  

I finally made it into the car and headed over to Trouble after giving myself another pep-talk about how my inferiority complex prevents me from opportunities to try new things and mingle with people who are cooler and better than me.  

Seriously now, how ridiculous does that sound?  I could give a shit what people think of what I am wearing.  The so-called hipsters were no more than mere 30-something beach bums chillaxin' with their beverages.  They sure were staring alright!  But I think it was because a) they were hung over, b)  they had just finished smoking a bowl, or c) the coke was wearing off from the night before.  But even though I dress like a dork and the other customers looked like a bunch of dirty junkies, we all got along just fine.  It was a very chill atmosphere.

The staff was nice.  The latte was great albeit tiny.  But the size won't deter me from coming back.  I know--that's what she said.

I take issue with the cinnamon toast.  I tried it for the hell of it, and just as expected it tasted like what I make at home for free.  I will give away all of my top secret ingredients right here on this review.  Get ready for this.  Bread.  Butter.  Sugar.  Cinnamon.  If you can't figure out how to toast bread and dump all that shit on top, God help you.  Their bread tasted a bit on the salty side, and I am sensitive to salt (i.e. I don't like salt).  Their lattes and mochas rock though...I'll stick with those.
author: Kandi K.

description: Trendy spot, tasty toast warms frost.
author: Ruby M.

description:
Yes, yes and YES!

This place nails it. One of my all time favorite places to recommend to friends who are looking for something "a little different."

"I'd like to build my own damn house, please!' I say, cause that's what you really need to order when you get there. I don't really know where the name for that particular combo came from, but if you want people to talk about your shop at the foggy, other-worldly end of San Francisco, make 'em swear when they get to the counter! Marketing genius!

But what do you get for your profanity? A fresh coconut with the top lopped off, a nice warm cup of joe, and a slice of cinnamon toast so thick it'd make a porn star blush. While each of these are pretty good on their own, they create a synergy when combined. 

The coffee is bitter and the coconut milk is cold and sweet. When sipped in rapid succession they throw your mouth into blissful confusion as your warring taste buds compete for dominance. Take a break and sink your teeth into the cinnamon toast and you'll be lifted to heaven in a way that only this holy trinity can accomplish.

Don't even think twice about the trek - just go, swear at the counter, and enjoy.

What do you think? Did I fulfill my mixed-metaphor quota for the day?
author: Dan W.

description:
Ah.  Good coffee.  Really good coffee.  It is right down the block from us, and it is a curse and a blessing.  We go there often enough that they know our kids.  Coffee is better than anything at starbucks and is as good, if not better than Blue bottle that I have had.

If you are in the area, try it.  Oh ya, pick up the Cinnamon toast also.  You will be happy.

there is a park let outside, so you can use it.  

Enjoy.
author: Clifford S.

description:
I have not been served there but all I can say that the coffee is kick ass good.  I read all the bad service reviews.  Someone got a bag of elbow grease and made it for me.  Serious buzz like no other coffee I have ever have.  My pause  and heart rate increased like I have ran a mile and I feel so jittery.   IS it addictive?  since first cup, I have been thinking about it and am a die heart tea drinker not at all a coffee drinker.
Making the mistake of drinking it after dinner and can't sleep at all and usually coffee has no effects on me.  What the hack did they put into that grind?
About their bad service, what do you expect from a place called "trouble?"
Warning: do not  consume unless consult with your physician first.
author: Mar H.

description:
The three best things about Trouble, alphabetically:

the Americano, Chris, Ruben.
author: Megan O.

description: It still is pretty hip. But the coffee is good and the toast is super naughty. and plus plus plus for the coconut!
author: Chelsey G.

description: Great coffee and amazing cinnamon toast. It has very cute decor - nothing different from typical hipster cafes like Blue Bottle Coffee. It's a bit of a hole in the wall, but it's awesome. When you're done with your coffee, you can always stop by the General Store next door...Kinfolk-type decor.
author: Gina T.

description: Best mochas around! Delicious toast and a great place to chill in the neighborhood -especially during the week when it isn't overrun by weekend brunch hipsters...
author: C B.

description: These hipsters make some strong iced coffee, I approve. All the weird crap on the walls and the noise, I think it's music, coming from the speakers will keep you in a state of pondering as you wait in line, so that's nice, I guess. Their parklet is pretty rad though.
author: Tyler C.

description: I am so torn about this place. The espresso was good and the mini pies are worth the weight gain but the service was down right insulting. I asked, politely, for a 6 oz. latte to go. I was told "no. we don't make that here." I can totally wrap my head around a crazy mixed milk, 4 flavorings change but 2 oz. less milk at the same price as an 8 oz. drink? That I am struggling with. Sure, lots of people love this place AND true I won't be back until I'm much more hip so the line will be slightly shorter. I heard the owner is really nice. I wonder if this is her goal?
author: Clark C.

description:
It is not ok to serve great coffee and be a jerk about it. 

I've gone to Trouble three times as their cold brewed coffee and "surf bars" (some oak connoction with dried fruit) are heavenly. Their attitude towards their customers is somewhere between indifferent and a snarl. 

First Time: Proprietor scolds me for leaving the lid on the soy milk pot open after I brought it to her behind the counter when it needed refilling. 

Second: Same proprietor answers "sometime" when I ask when they'll be making another batch of cold brew. 

Third Time: Otherwise very nice barrista rings me up then waits a full five minutes before taking my money because she's talking to another customer. I missed my train home. 

The vibe here is east bay punk meets Santa Cruz surfer. I suppose that means that  it cool, neigh expected to be rude to someone who wants to give you money. 

Call me puritanical but being a jerk is being a jerk. In any subculture, in any language. It's not ok and I can find my cold brew jolt elsewhere.
author: Kevin S.

description:
try the Gibralter, it's fantastic.

This is the third wave role model with personality and less affect.
no one seems to want to be in a hair band like four barrell. 

they are cool 
they are surfers
they are artists
they are building a community of caring people in the outer sunset
and the coffee is bomb

If you simply don't have time to sleep ever again 
try the cold press
author: Enrico B.

description: Good coffee and cinnamon toast. Definitely recommended. Only downside are the people working there, but that's a minor point at best.
author: Justin G.

description:
Best coffee in the 'hood. 'Nuff said! 

Get the toast if you're feeling decadent!
author: Brandi S.

description: My co-workers were raving about the Toast so I had to try it, after a long line later it tasted like toast - not sure what I was expecting for bread but was still somewhat disapointed.
author: Roman I.

description:
Trouble Cafe Company is a breath of fresh San Franciscan air- especially from a tourists point of view. It's homey and welcoming, small, yet cozy. A place I'd want to have my cup of coffee every day (even though I'm not the biggest coffee drinker- that says a lot!). 

What did I do when I went to Trouble cafe? I built my own damn house- that's what I did- or ate... What does that mean you ask? Basically the serve you a coffee- coconut, and a delicious dense piece of toast lathered in butter and cinnamon sugar.  One of the lovely baristas also convinced me to get the yoko- which is basically fresh squeezed grapefruit juice. Apparently the antioxidants from the grapefruit somehow open up your blood stream and allow the coffee to flow through. And mixed with the coconut milk- you're set to build a damn house! Those three liquids combined was definitely an interesting variety- but somehow all complimented one another quite well. 

So whether you live in SF, or are visiting, make your way over to the Sunset and start your morning off at Trouble... you won't regret it.
author: Megan L.

description: If you like decent coffee, frowny baristas, lines and fun driftwood to sit on, you will love this place!
author: Aaron J.

description: Love this place. Good coffee. Good pastries. And freaking amazing coconut juice right out of the coconut!
author: Kristen C.

description:
I find I usually like places that have terrible yelp reviews on service because it frequently just means that the employees act like normal humans and not overly cheery robots terrified of being yelled at by their boss if their smile drops for a second.

That's pretty much the case with Trouble, the barista when I went today (a dude, I suspect that's some of their negative service review issue, people seem to have serious issues with boy baristas for some reason) greeted me, asked me how I was, took my order and gave me a drink in exchange for money. Bam, done, what more should I ask for?

The place is super cool looking, the coffee is only okay. The awesome part is that their cappuccinos have super thick foam (and the milk is steamed the right way to bring out the sweetness) and their espresso is overly bitter so when you start drinking the cappuccino it's like eating a burnt marshmallow, which is amazing. Sadly, once the foam is gone, the drink tastes slightly like cigarette ash, so be prepared for that in your espresso drinks.
author: Sandra D.

description:
When sitting on my deathbed many, many years from now, I will ask for a latte from Trouble to be the last thing I taste.

Say no more.

Best.
Latte.
of.
all.
time.

wow.
author: Pete J.

description: Personally "elbow grease" is a terrible house coffee. My cup tasted like hot brown water. AND when you drink your coffee black, there isn't much you can do when the coffee tastes bad. Disappointing.
author: Brooke F.

description:
I love this little shop.  I just recently discovered this place during my wait to eat next door at Outerlands, and I feel like they compliment each-other greatly.

The service is sweet, and friendly.  The younger guy went out of his way to give us the low down on the spot, and other info even when it was getting busy.

The coffee was DELICIOUS! I had a Mocha, and it had the right consistancy of sweet, but not too sweet.  

The food looked great, but I was eating next door so we split a little slice of the daily loaf.  I saw other people eating Cinnamon Toast (Exactly what it sounds like) and even Whole Coconuts to sip on to forget the pain you earned from the night before.

Well, enough typing, I am headed for the N-Judah! See you there!
author: David K.

description: Peanut butter toast with lavender honey is fantastic! Cinnamon sugar toast is definitely not worth the same. $5 for a coconut? Yeah, no. With that being said, it was an insanely fresh and fantastic coconut, as it should be for $5. The coffee is dope. I usually get espresso or soy lattes. Chai tea is phenomenal with soooo much spice! And their girlfriend drink is amazing. In love with the atmosphere and all the hot boys. Let's be real, that's why I actually go.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Disagree with most reviews of the guys and new gal at the front - I find them to very friendly and welcoming.  The owner, on the other hand......bossy, cranky and knows everything about everything.  She did educate me on why I didn't need a big ol' latte and that a really good small one, even with full fat milk, would be much more satisfying.  Thanks for that.

Coffee is really, really good ...banana bread is delish.
author: Linda C.

description: Skip it. The service is abysmal, and while the coffee is good, it's not anywhere good enough to merit the attitude. There's an amazing little Italian coffee shop at 18th and Irving. The Italian place has been there forever and, unlike Trouble (the coy, cutesy name isn't doing the place any favors), they roast their own beans. Across the park, of course, there's Simple Pleasures, which also roasts their own. If you can't be bothered to roast the beans, how serious about coffee can you really be?
author: Michelle P.

description:
I love Trouble Coffee. The coffees seem super caffeinated and has me wired all day, but I really love to just head down there and hang in the shop. It's super cool inside (although also super small) and the employees are fun to chat with. I do wish they had non fat milk- only whole and soy. 
Definitely recommend checking it out though!
author: Emily B.

description:
Ya. methinks Nyet!

$2.75 for a large coffee? cash only! I'm thinking, Oh it must be like Philz or Blue bottle because that's what they charge.. nope. Not even! Oh, ok ok.. it must be higher priced because of the luxurious environment.. hmmm. not really  The amazing view is  the 7/11 and Indian Pizza strip mall.. a few hard barstools and a bench outside with the milk and sugar.  oh.. I know i know.. its the wide variety of blends for your coffee. huh-uh.. you'll have half and half and sugar only.. no light milk or splenda here, you'z!..

ahhh .. it's got to be the lovely personality of the barristas.. HA! try again.

No man, with Java beach just down the street with lots of comfy seating inside and out.. free wifi, beach and garden across the street, great menu of food and beer as well. but most importantly nice people and prices (Cash or plastic)..  Save yourself the eh  .."Trouble" and relax at Java Beach.
author: Jacky J.

description:
Went in for a coffee.
Came back for a coconut and another coffee.
There was a busy looking woman who stuck her head in and asked, "DO YOU GUYS HAVE THE BREAD?!" when they told her they did, she sat down and said, "Yes. Toast, Toast, Toast." With a capital T. 
I reckon I must go back for that even though I live on the other side of town.
author: Addyline L.

description:
It feels fitting that Trouble should be my first ever Yelp review, seeing as how it was really my first home in this crazy Outer Sunset neighborhood.  

Trouble is it's own species.  Their coffee is some of the best in the city, which is saying quite a bit.  The eclectic decor and colorful clientele also make for a good time.  I love the fact that they don't have a menu and don't serve decaf-- I feel like I discover something new that they have to offer each morning.  The coconuts are a pretty genius way to balance hyper-caffination, and I'm pretty addicted to their surf bars.

My morning routine of grabbing a coffee at Trouble and walking the few blocks to the beach is pretty unbeatable.  Enjoy!
author: Sara R.

description:
Very good lattes!  They have a high quality grinder MAZZER E ROBUR (could be a MAJOR r ROYALE), this makes all the difference in the world when trying pull a good shot.   They use high quality milk n cream from STRUASS n CLOVER.  Their espresso cups are Sorrentos from Italy,  this is really the one of the better cups to serve it in and is easily available.  It is very thick and keeps your drink warmer longer. .Very good service and extremely friendly.

Only thing...  I got the beans to go, wasn't about to try their coffee from a BUNN "O MATIC" Coffee Machine.  Its very tight in there n tryng to do other brewing methods could be a pain... I understand.
author: Demanding T.

description:
Finally tried their toast! We were actually trying to go to Outerlands... but I fail at realizing they are closed on Mondays. Since we were already on the block, might as well get some coffee and a snack.

The toast was thick, very thick but I really liked the bread. It was toasted just right, and the bread itself just tasted good. It did have an insane amount of butter on it. A bit too much for me. But it did taste good, fatty things so often do. More cinnamon and less butter would have been better.
author: Angela T.

description: Friendly service, good coffee, awesome rustic parklet, and AMAZING cinnamon toast.
author: Alicia J.

description:
Ok, I've been going here pretty regularly for a few weeks now and the coffee's starting to grow on me, although I do wish they had a stronger brew available. Also, in a correction to my previous review, there *is* a menu available - it's on a clipboard, hanging on the wall just to the right of the bar. In my defense, it looks exactly like the rest of the wall art plastered all over the cafe.

Two more observations that have prompted me to bump up my review a notch: although the stiflingly clique-ish, hipster atmosphere in here would normally demand a terrible service experience, I've found the staff to be generally more friendly than the often-irritated group at Java Beach. And while I still feel most of the menu is overpriced, the $2 cinnamon toast is worth every cent.
author: Nick R.

description: Delicious cappuccino.  Yummy lavender shortbread.  Super chill.  Very friendly.  I'll be back.
author: Shauna L.

description: Great customer service, awesome cinnamon toast and really good coffee, plus it's in my neighborhood. Can't get much better than that!
author: Farah R.

description: I've been to Trouble a couple of times now and I think I have this place figured out. Trouble is a pretty hip, hole in the wall cafe that's always busy with tons of foot traffic (which I attribute the "meh" customer service to). First off, their toast is awesome! I definitely recommend trying it although it is a little pricey. Coffee wise, their cappuccinos are awesome! A+ micro-foam and the espresso isn't watered down by massive amounts of milk. I have also tried the Girlfriend which is Earl Grey, lavender, honey and steamed milk. The Girlfriend was alright but could have been stronger or made with less milk. (Side note: I prefer stronger drinks.) Overall Trouble is a cool place with good drinks and alright service. I will definitely be back to try some of their other drinks soon!
author: Lilly J.

description: Buttery, cinnamon-y, spongy toast sweetened to perfection. Super cheap & fast service. So go get it!
author: Camie K.

description:
Definitely worth the 30 minute ride from The Richmond over to this hip coffee shop with delicious latte's and YUMMY grub. The butter was drippin' off of my toast...who could ask for more. 

Then, on top of that...everyone that came in and out of this small place was just all smiles...a great neighborhood spot where families, bicyclists and friends can meet up for some amazing artisan coffee. 

For 2 latte's and 2 cinnamon toasts - you're asking for around $12 for breakfast...but it was well worth it.
I had a grin on my face all the way home.
author: Katy A.

description:
A little too kool for skool. hmm, trying a tad too hard one might think. Website is just pretentious as all hell. Turns me off, real off. Get over ones self troubled oh so troubled cafe coffee hole in my arse coffee room in the Sunset. I prefer Java beach at least i can read their menu and visit their website and say hello to a human being with a smile. Yeah smiling is a part of being human, really it is. check it. Attitude. Coffee is decent though, but not the best by far in SF or the Set. Did anyone tell you that you are in the Sunset?
yeah, trouble with trouble is they just too cool for school. check clickity check. And , uh nope i have no tangible skills. Lame.
author: SForiginal T.

description: Best toast I've ever sank my teeth into. Plus, they have a fantastic Gibraltar!
author: Austin F.

description: Hipster-ish kinda coffee shop but the coffee and the toast makes you worth the wait!
author: Khaloud D.

description:
Hands down, best latte I've ever had. Whole milk only, don't even think about asking for low fat. I've also had the chilled whole coconut. 

Simple is better. What they specialize in is coffee and they're damn good at it. Right up the street from java beach which is always packed anyways and there coffee sucks compared to Trouble
author: sarah f.

description:
I think anyone who walks out of Trouble after their first sip will admit that the coffee is hard to beat, but lets give the pastries a little love here shall we?!?! 

Incredible, creative little morsels of fat and happiness that I often have to resist as I do my laundry across the street at Judah Cleaners. Oh well, since I only do laundry every few weeks I guess my allowance is spaced out enough :-D 

Decor is funky and cozy and the reclaimed wooden tabletop bar upon which I groggily wait for my warm cup of splendor is something I would love to have in my future home.

A great new spot ONCE AGAIN adding to the FLAVA of the outer sunset...we pretty much rock out here folks!
author: Tina D.

description:
Magical enough that it was the centerpiece in an early romance date.  I always want to call it Toast instead of Trouble.  Maybe I'm too literal.  

Someday I hope to be highly evolved and live in clean and warm driftwood hut out by Ocean Beach.  In this fantasy, I wake early and surf every morning.  I enjoy the foggy calm of outer sunset and wear cable knit sweaters while reading multiple books a day and whittling otter figurines.  Always this dream involves drinking coffee with abnormally wise young people at Trouble, sipping coconut juice and smushing thick wonderful toast in my face.
author: Bobby S.

description:
The coffee here is above average, that's all. It is the sides that make this place unique. 

Forget crepes, real people eat toast and here you can get it with cinnamon sugar or nutella. They also have fresh coconuts. 
Where else can you get either of those? 

Service has been good. 

But some of the clientele need to check themselves.
author: forrest l.

description: !! Perfect for a rainy day. Favorite tea lattes w/ Earl Grey lavender. Cool hang out spot right in front to sit down and enjoy your cup. Blocks from Ocean beach and in one of the most undervalued neighborhoods in the city!
author: Yashad K.

description: The coffee is good and simple. No frills is exactly what I need in the morning. Not elitist hipster customers taking up both employees full attention with conversions starting with "I". Oh and the toast is awesome. Although our toast maker doubled as our cashier, with no hand washing while making the transition...
author: Christian Y.

description: I decided to give their coffee another try. Bad idea. Also, they just built a "parklet" in front of the shop. At least, that's what they call it. I call it an eyesore, house for rats, and it makes parking more difficult in an already difficult neighborhood. I hope someone burns the damn thing to the ground.
author: Bryan E.

description: Fantastic coffee. Good people behind the counter. Cash only.
author: S Y.

description:
Hands down best latte in the city.
In my humble opinion, the best coffee experience is in Australia. The Italian and Greek immigrant population there has created a coffee culture there that is amazing.It shows in the range, style and quality of espresso and coffee experiences there. In addition, more than one billion cups of coffee are consumed in cafés, restaurants and other outlets each year.  An increase of 65% over the last 10 years. 
My drink of choice while living there was a "Fat White"

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flat_white

I have not lived down unda in 4 years and everyday I'm drinking half assed lattes here in the city I'm miss my drink more and more.

Along comes Trouble Coffee. Being in my neighborhood, I wandered in there last week to grab a quick latte before work. 
After standing there watching them prepare my drink for a length of time that would make a high powered executive's head explode, I knew something good was coming. When your latte is ready is about 34 seconds, it is never going to be good. This took a while.  I was happy to wait. What came over the beautiful oak countertop was by far, hands down, THE BEST LATTE I've had in SF. I've lived here since 93 so...I've tried my fair share. 

This is almost spot on similar to the flat whites of OZ I enjoyed daily. 

This alone is enough to bring me  back there. But if that was not enough, the 3 different staff I've talked to there have all been consistently friendly, funny, quirky and positive. Its nice to leave a place feeling good and smiling. I beg you you to tell me that's what you get from the Starbucks at Safeway. 

The 3rd thing I like is that Trouble Coffee is really a completely different experience than Java Beach which is just a few blocks down. I also enjoy going to Java Beach for different reasons. I'm happy that I have 2 places in my hood that I can support and enjoy. I don't see how they compete.  In fact the two of them together only add to the area. 
Love these guys. Really, you should check them out.
You will be happy that you did.
author: Chris L.

description: Loved this place... We just happened to stumble across this place while waiting for Outerlands to open. The guy behind the counter was really nice and patient. I have to say it was the best cup of Earl Grey and Lavendar Tea I have had in a very long time... =)
author: Shannan J.

description: woooooow are these people serious? The place is cheesy as hell. The art of trying too hard while looking like you just skipped a shower. You want to be hip, start with good coffee, hire non-douchebags, and get some good pastries. I remember the owner from tartine, but your not in the mission hunnie, your in the outersunset, and while I do see a lot more skinny jeans out here lately, most of us dont think its hip to pay for overpriced coffee that is utter crap, served  with a "why are you here bothering me" attitude. Good luck keeping up with rent and payroll
author: johnny s.

description: Coffee, coconuts, and toast!  I love their coffee and this place.  The bike ride to the outer sunset for a fantastic cup of coffee is worth it.
author: Tia B.

description: Great coffee! Amazingly knowledgeable people work at the cafe and they have a fantastic attitude!
author: Teija F.

description:
Why are all the reviews so high?  I don't understand at all.  Honestly I checked the place out because of the yelp reviews and I'm left with this sense that the yelpers have misled me or that Trouble is manipulating the market by creating fake yelp user IDs and writing their own reviews.

I ordered a coffee, wasn't asked if I wanted a small or large or told how much it would cost.  I get a 12 oz cup with 8 oz of brown water and am told "TWO DOLLARS."

Then some old dude with long white hair and sandals takes me picture without my permission using a camera that is at least 30 years old and the guy who served me the brown water goes outside to smoke.  The smoke blows into the small "coffee" shop and my brown water now tastes like burnt tobacco.

I'm like, "WTF is up with this?" but for some reason the friend I've met up with says she really likes the place...  To each their own.

Somebody has to be the yelp avenger, and it might as well be me.  If you like coffee, go somewhere else.  If you like don't-give-a-damn attitude, shell out your donations.
author: Jin D.

description: I get the latte, my significant other gets the gibraltar, and we sit outside on the wonderful tree bench, marveling at what a gorgeous day it is, even if it's foggy, windy, and spitting rain. That's some darn good coffee they're making here. The guys are always nice, and the cookies will ruin anyone's dinner. Worth every bite and sip.
author: J. C.

description: Small and worth it. Can't imagine what I would do without their matador: coffee + espresso + steamed milk (soy for me). There may be limited seating outside, but the tree seating on the outside makes up for it in every way. Amazing spot on a nice day in the sunset, but just as great to stop by on the many foggy days over here in the outer sunset. Gotta try their dirty chai as well. Extremely delicious and spicy:] I definitely recommend this place!
author: Paige I.

description:
The test for a good coffee shop is a cup of their coffee. Drip coffee, which I take with cream & sugar (because I'm a wuss... but a good coffee will stand up to both cream and sugar).

The coffee is great. It's rich and flavorful and layered and since I live in the Outer Sunset I can walk here.

Staff are kind, genuine and friendly, and they pay attention to their store and the people in it. I've never had to wait more than a couple minutes with a short line, and I like that if the cashier is going to make eye contact and say hello with the few people in front of me, they're probably going to offer me the same courtesy. And they do.

The couple minutes are worth it.
author: Erin W.

description:
I'm still new to the 'hood, but I'll give it all five without hesitation.  An delicious cup of drip, and if you build your own damn house, you'll not be disappointed.  Even if, like me, you typically wouldn't go for a coconut.

Great baked goods, and I hear the latte is extra-special.
author: Jimmy C.

description: I came here enticed by their yelp pics of huge slices of cinnamon toast while in SF. I jumped the gun and headed over without reading the yelp reviews... gosh I wish I did. Walked in to see no menu, but it was cool I was there for some coffee and toast so that's easy enough. The cashier gave me a douchy look and said "what do you want?" okay... maybe he's just having a bad day. Put my order in and had him swip my card and had me sign the screen. I turn my back and he talks to the barista saying "people always click on Done so that we can't see that they don't tip, but I can still check." umm... I tipped you but boy i shouldn't have. I waited for a good 25 mins for my latte and not until they suddenly tried to kick me out to close mid-day did they acknowlegde they didn't make it. I usually have a lot of patience, but this is a place i would recommend NOT to stop by. I don't pay overpriced coffee and toast just to get horribly rude service. I still got my okay toast which is just heavily buttered Texas toast dosed with cinnamon. Nothing really to rave about.
author: Jessica T.

description:
pretty terrible. I paid like 3 bucks for an americano that was pretty damn small with only one shot in it. It tasted bitter and didn't have sleeves so I basically burned my hand off. 


And I don't know how I feel with the sugar and milk being on the outside of the store. 


overall- I rather go to the 7 Eleven across the street.


update:Oh! and they wrote me around a two page letter basically Yelling at me for my review. Which in case I blocked the owner and am updating to say, After their letter I feel like its not inviting and after reading their review they pushed me away and made excuses for their poor service. 

Overall I don't plan on going there and they are just rude.
author: Jen M.

description:
I love Trouble.  I had a rocky period, when I stopped going there after a series of bad experiences with one of the staff.  However, after a series of messages with the owner I'm back to my normal routine of coconuts and coffee while I do my laundry across the street.  I'm glad because I love that routine!

I have to say, I have a great respect for the owner.  Not only does she run a successful business, but I thoroughly appreciated her concern over the customer service I received.  A rare gem.
author: liz s.

description: yes. toast & a fresh coconut
author: Unkl- T.

description:
Well.. I didn't really purposely go to get coffee here but was in the neighborhood and wanted to buy my mom a cup of coffee.
and since there were people bustling around it i went to see,
and the price was sorta on the pricy side (considering that even starbucks is $1.95 for a regular venti .. right? and also the bad economy)
the medium was $2.00 and large at this store was $2.75 .. i believe
but then when i tasted some of it... i could tell it was worth the price,
not that i could afford to drink it everyday.

The only minor issue with the cream being outside was that little things could also fly in... like a fruit fly.
and so when i was pouring in the cream i noticed a little black thing also falling rapidly into the coffee with the cream, and later when i swished around the coffee a little a fruit fly rose up to the top.
and i don't know about you (maybe if the coffee is good enough a little fruit fly won't hurt?) but i didn't really like the fact that a fruit fly was swishing around in the coffee that i was going to give my mom so i went back to get a another cup of coffee.  The lady gave me another cup but since the fly happened to sink below right when i was showing it to her... i could tell she didn't believe me :(
so the second cup ended up having a lot more "room for cream"...

Anyways I won't rate them down because of a fruit fly and i understand why the creamer is outside... the store itself can't handle any more space consuming objects. But customer service can be better. The taste is most important.. right?
author: Jane J.

description: Coffee, cinnamon toast and coconut - ex-ceee-llent.  Love these guys - anyone who risks their index finger for some coconut water deserves a raise.  And all with a smile...also, a perfect place to hang out before trying to get in to Outerlands down the road...
author: Jill K.

description:
So as far as I'm concerned Trouble is the bomb! The Chai latte are my favorite along with the Chocolate chip cookies and Pumpkin chocolate chip cake. I'm not much of a coffee guy but I do like the mochas

As far as the location goes. For being such a small place I think they hold down damn good. It's creative and original. The hard work and care put into the place shows including the effort in making the block look better.

 Ok I've seen so many reviews about the service being piss ass poor and "SOL" or just plain out rude.  I think the staff is chill and laid back. My order has been wrong before. And they have always offered to change it. 

Anyways I'm down with Trouble.
author: M P.

description: The coffee is strangely mediocre, especially given the attitude it's served with.  Not all but most of the staff are so rude it's kind of hilarious.  I really try to like this place given that it's the only coffee shop around, but it's a tough sell between the quality and limited selection.
author: BW A.

description: Long line, but goes by really quickly.  There's a great parklet just outside, on a nice morning it's a good spot to have your coffee and toast, which is what we had.  There's no menu inside....so if it's your first time it's hard to figure out what they have to offer - I just see everyone walking away with coconuts and toast....so I figured that's their seller.  Their website, although unique and "hip", is not super intuitive to navigate....nor is the content really clear....but you can figure it out by going through some yelp reviews.  Had a Mocha with almond milk and and iced coffee.  I really liked the ice coffee, but wasn't super into the mocha - I just don't think mocha and almond milk works well....tried it in many coffee shops and didn't like the results. Coffee comes out in tiny cups (pricy for the amount of coffee served).  The toast is good - but only because they slather it with butter. Had the cinnamon toast - nice thick bread with butter, cinnamon and sugar.
author: Janelle H.

description: Tiny little place and has awesome latte ( they get offended if you ask for decaf!) and the toast is heavenly. A pleasant experience on weekend morning. would go back again for sure.
author: A S.

description: I learned of Trouble when I read an article about the owner (a fascinating and touching story of how Trouble came to be). That was about a year ago. I finally made it over to Trouble yesterday, on an especially exquisitely gorgeous SF day. I've worked as a barista at a funky old coffeehouse in northern California for eleven years. My standards when it comes to coffeehouses are high; I'm picky. Trouble is located just a couple of blocks from the ocean, a tiny and terrific hole-in-the-wall cafe with a magnificent wood sculpture that provides all sorts of interesting seating outside. The two baristas who were working, two young men, could not have been warmer and more friendly. I felt wonderfully welcomed into Trouble the moment I stepped inside. My daughter and I shared a coconut, a cinnamon toast, and I ordered a latte. Everything we ate & drank was just delicious - excellent espresso, btw. I am giving Trouble Coffee Company 5 sparkly stars. I'll definitely be returning to the cafe when I next visit the city.
author: RoadMy O.

description: If you are looking for the perfect espresso drinks, this is the place to go.  The drinks are made with a precision and attention to detail that is expressed in the flavor of every sip.  Just know, once you have experienced an espresso drink from trouble, you will find few others that compare.
author: Shyam B.

description:
I'm not going to editorialize - here's the straight up word-for-word transcript:

Me:
 "Hi (smile), can a grab a triple macchiato?"

Coffee Guy:
"We don't do triples."

Me:
"Uhh... really (still smiling)?"

Coffee Guy:
"Nope. Just doubles."

Me:
"Ok (smile starting to fade), can I get a double then? To go."

Coffee Guy:    
"We don't do doubles to go."

Me:
"Seriously (smile gone)?"

Coffee Guy:
"Yeah."

Me:
"Ok, have a good one."
author: Shane C.

description: I love strong coffee! The actual store front is interesting, almost like a walk-up window. Young coconut + coffee? It's as if this coffee house was made for me! I am obsessed with both! I have no complaints about the staff or service. It's typical, easy-going, figure it out yourself San Francisco type attitude.
author: Angie Q.

description:
BEST cup of coffee! (cafe de la paz, I highly recommend the elbow grease beans) This place is always a treat. Friendly people, amazing cookies, and the ocean is only a few blocks away.

"be flexible, I am"

the coconuts a great
author: nana r.

description: Coffee was good, nothing special. Coffee as good as any coffee shop. However the service is awful. The staff act as if they are too cool for their customers, and they forgot my order. I will not be going there again. It's a coffee shop for people who want to feel like they are in the know, but in reality we are all just at a coffee shop. The sitting log area outside is a nice touch.
author: Cecy G.

description:
Trouble coffee makes everyday better whether I am fighting a hangover at 3:30pm or going to work at 7 there is always some attractive person right down the street to make me coffee. I am entertained by the owner and have become very fond of watching her be a bit crazy. The shop is the epitome of SF/Ocean Beach mentality which sucks your first time there because you feel like an idiot trying to when you try to give them a card. Slowly but surely you will become accustomed to the attitude and grow to like it. A few weeks ago I had friends from out of town come in and the employees gave them lists of things to do in the neighborhood and city. They are all super helpful if you ask questions so don't be shy to ask them anything from what to do with your day to what is a Gibraltar. Trouble toast will save your life and you can eat it everyday! Mocha Mocha Mocha!!! 
-don't stand behind the bar stools
I LOVE TROUBLE!
author: Lauren M.

description: So so. I did come here because of the TAL episode. No decaf coffee, no nonfat milk. So didn't even try the coffee. Got the coconut. It was ok, but way overpriced. The toast was amazing. And the barista was friendly and helpful when I told him I'd never been there before. Cool outside vibe with logs/wood benches to sit on. It was alright.
author: Rachel F.

description:
really makes me laugh how butt hurt most yelpers get over the "customer service" at this place. they are brusk on purpose- call it their aesthetic. it's not a personal insult so please stop crying. that being said, i have never had an even remotely unpleasant interaction with ANY of the guys there, and i visit weekly. everything is delicious and well priced for what you get. try the toast and the chai latte. 

say hello, order your coffee, have your cash in hand, move out of the line. if jerry can handle the soup nazi, you can handle the trouble baristas.
author: Patricia J.

description:
trouble: cold press is crrrrack! thanks for the recommendation of a small cup. i drank that at 8am and was up the entire day and into the night. 

crrrrrack.
author: Maria B.

description:
Unsure of all the hype.

Cool space, and I do applaud any joint that confidently does one thing and does it well, but I wasn't impressed. Service was indifferent. Yelper Loren A. stated it perfectly as "don't give a damn". Lack of milk options other than whole was disappointing. Coffee tasted no better than at a thousand other spots in the city.

Blue Bottle remains my mecca of coffee.
author: Jason B.

description: Decor is cool. Staff was friendly overall. However, I got barked at pretty sharply for trying to take a photo of the moment. Relatives in Europe would have been interested, but alas... Over the vintage punk on the sound system (get the irony - surely intentional) a self important 20 year old full of gluten free wheaties went all command and control on me and asserted the house rules du jour. Next week they'll have a submit your favorite photo contest. Typical millenial self-contradictions.
author: hyvjhbgjuyhgjuhb i.

description:
in a nut shell: i am a self imposed coffee addict. 

we first saw the outdoor seating which is amazing.  the tree bark and surrounding seating gave the store a very rugged feel to it.  the interior is very small but they really utilized the space.  The interior reminds me of finds at the Alameda flea market....old books, vintage pieces, woodsy counter top.  i ordered a depth charge ( coffee with espresso shot ) and the boy ordered a mocha and we decided to split a cuppie pie ( mini pies are wayy better than cupcake balls on a stick) My coffee was smooth, full bodied and delicious.  pretty much up there with blue bottle and that is saying a lot.  the boy's mocha was full fat milk with mocha powder.  He loved that it was rich but not overly sweet and without the powder after taste.  the cuppie pie was like a mini apple pie.  The crust was like no other pie crust.  It wasn't too flaky or doughy and the apple filling had such a nostalgic taste to it.  I should have realized it was made from butter love bakeshop.  hands down best pies. ever. 

so amazing black coffee, delicious mocha, and freshly homemade cuppie pie to start off our morning...and we walked up the street to grab brunch at outerlands already satisfied with how great the morning started. this is exactly the kind of breakfast I'm talking about.
author: Justina F.

description:
A little bit of the Mission in Ocean Beach -- that is, decent coffee served up with a healthy dose of single-speed world-weary 'tude.

News flash -- I moved to Ocean Beach to get away from that bull shit. Why oh why did you follow me, o painfully hip-sters? Fuck off, please, and take your coconuts with you. 

I still like it more than Java Beach, but MAN they're making it tough.
author: Chris R.

description: Fresh coconut.  Strong coffee.  Good Sunday!
author: Christine N.

description:
Thumbs down. As in two unwashed, stanky, greasy, thumbs down in your toast.

Coffee = meh. While I am fixing my own damn house I'll send someone to not grab coffee from Trouble. (Definitely lives up to its name).
author: RC K.

description: This place rocks.  Great coffee great service.  A must try if your in the neighborhood!
author: Kevin R.

description:
Go there and build your own house.
Coffee. Butter-slathered toast with cinnamon. A coconut cut fresh for you!
I don't even like coconuts usually.  I've had some coconut milk before and tend to dislike severely anything with the shredded stuff (like a German chocolate cake for example...where the eff did ze Germans have palm trees?), but the above-mentioned combination of goods really hit the spot. 
Very nicely pulled espresso shots.  Coffee could be a little stronger.
The place oozes goodvibes.
Gotta love the local spots.
author: Edward F.

description: Nice neighbohood coffee shop with awesome decor considering the space that they're working with. I ilk it when a place has a simple menu and it doesn't get any simpler than "drink coffee" and "do not drink coffee." The coffee is good and the service is speedy. The oversized chocolate chip cookies are just the perfect size for me. The cost of a cup of coffee is a tad bit pricier than Starbucks but I'd rather support a local shop than a corporate conglomerate :)
author: Angelina G.

description: Love the way they make a teabag from fresh leaves even though the service is slow.  Will I ever be cool enough to feel at ease in this place?  Magic 8 ball says... Outlook not so good ;(
author: Vivek P.

description: My very first Gibraltar in such an intimate setting.  Loved this busy, quirky and handmade-with-love coffee joint.  It's going to be astop on my beach bike ride days.
author: Mac M.

description: Pricey but good mocha perfect for a rainy Sunday afternoon while waiting to get seated at Outerlands.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The menu board is simple:

Elbow Grease
Coffee and Tea
Coconuts and Toast

Aside from the elbow grease these are the only items available. 

There are a lot of coconuts, I saw them with my own two eyes. I saw homemade bread with lots of spreadable options - Nutella, peanut butter, plum jam, cinnamon and sugar to name a few. 

There is a good vinyl collection, a turntable and CD player. Tones on Tail was playing. Bad Brains was recently taken off the turntable. 

There is quite a random collection of stuff adorning the walls. Quite random indeed.

The sole employee/owner treats everyone who walks in like she has known them for longer than the four days she has been open. We had a conversation about janky kitchen timers and the insanity of counting in your head when your timer breaks. 

I had THE BEST latte I have ever had or ever hoped to have in the Sunset. It was even organic!  

I wish they had longer hours (8-2 daily) and they will as soon as the Mission living, bike riding owner finds a place close to her business. Please give her a place to live so she can open earlier and feed my addiction more often. A garage with a heater is fine with her. She said so. 

I was not on drugs when I visited this place. Everything I just wrote is true and accurate.
author: Drue C.

description:
I've updated Trouble from 4 to 5 stars because of sustained consistent awesomeness. Yay!

Oh, except for one thing. Please don't play any more Velvet Underground / Lou Reed guitar noise. Okay? It just doesn't go with a relaxing afternoon mocha on a foggy Sunset afternoon. Weird sounds from The Residents and Mike Patton, that's okay in a local-hip-pretentious kind of way. Guitar feedback? If you're not on acid, it just sounds bad.
author: Joseph H.

description:
FINALLY, A COFFEE SHOP WORTH GOING TO IN SF. 

When I moved back to the city by the bay from the rain-soaked streets of Seattle and was thrown into the depths of despair after being unable to find a single, decent shot of espresso in the entire city limits. On crisp Spring morning I stumbled into an alley by the Dogpatch and ordered an americano from Blue Bottle.  The espresso was fine, but nothing to rival the shots pulled at Seattle's Vivace, or even Portland's Stumptown. So I had to make a choice; either drink swill for the rest of eternity, or quit the demon bean all together. Until recently, the later option had been the only one for me, but no more.  I found you Trouble Coffee, and you and your seductive, dark-roasted, caffeinated goodness are a mistress worthy of my adoration. 

P.S. Cash only
author: Margaret W.

description:
pros
2 baristas were nice
latte was good
choc. chip banana bread good

cons
music too loud inside to enjoy sitting at bar
kids' hot chocolate not that great...kinda watery.
no menu (even just a chalkboard would be helpful)

wasn't blown away but maybe will try again.
author: nikki b.

description:
Best latte ever!
Bold flavor, felt very fresh.
Too bad they have their coffee lids, milk and sugar outside. To me, that seems kind of dirty since it's literally out in the open outside where there's open traffic but eh, whatever.
author: Theresa M.

description:
In case you have doubts about the existence of a counterculture scene at Ocean Beach (and I know I once did), look no further than Trouble Coffee: the punkest coffee shop in the city, for which it gets an automatic 5 stars.

There is no menu, no low or non-fat milk, and maybe 2 stools to sit down on.  There is exactly one very memorable staff member (I can only assume it was Giulietta) to take the orders, make the minuscule but perfect lattes, and butter up the thick slices of cinnamon toast (which only a fool would forgo).  The stereo was (very appropriately) playing The Fall, that most cultish of 80's British-Post-Punk-Meets-American-Underground bands.  

So be prepared.  You wouldn't want to look like a deer-in-headlights yuppie who got lost looking for Starbucks.  And I don't want them getting suspicious that they've been "discovered"...
author: Wes M.

description:
Trouble Coffee is just what the soul needs!  The whole package, the killer espresso, the decor and style, the people that work there and frequent the little cafe....its perfect!  

But dont let the other niceties of Trouble fool you...they make a dam good espresso, that rivals any other cafe in the city.   

Love the coffee, love the concept, keep it rockin TCC!
author: Dominic P.

description: 5 years later and they're still my favorite. xo Trouble!
author: M M.

description: Regular drip accompanied with their cinnamon toast. YUM! You should really get their toast! The thing is humongous and such a good snack to go with coffee. This place is tiny and unique. Okay it's the only coffee place that serves fresh baby coconut. Yes, they crack it open for you to drink out of its shell. You would only see something like that at an Asian restaurant. Has a very cool laid back chill vibe to it. However this is not a coffee joint where you occupy for hours by reading a book or camping out with your laptop. It is a place where you can enjoy a good cup of coffee, mocha, or a baby coconut then leave. Well they don't have much of a seating area. They only have a few seats by the counter.
author: Eileen B.

description:
"Guts & Heart" in the form of a double-shot 10oz latte.  
That's what they serve, and that's how they serve it.
Beans sourced direct trade from El Salvador, locally and independently roasted.
Bold, flavorful, in-your-face-in-a-hawt-way - just like the owner.
You'll like it.
author: CINDY K.

description:
I'm too old to be a hipster and I'm not a regular here, yet the staff has always been super friendly to me.  Go figure.  I think if you come in expecting attitude, that's what you'll perceive.

Trouble serves expertly-brewed coffee made from De La Paz beans to accompany thick toast and fresh coconuts.  They don't serve decaf or nonfat milk.  The setting is a tiny cafe with 80s garage punk references and McSweeney's-eqsue tendencies.  If all this sounds like it would annoy the crap out of you, then it probably will.  I give it four stars.
author: Ben R.

description:
Five months ago a woman I met in the park gave me a hint to try out Trouble Coffee, and I am so glad I did.

Let's start off with the toast. True, you can make your own cinnamon toast at home. But Trouble toasts are huge, thick, soft pieces of bread slathered with butter and dusted with cinnamon sugar. So yes, I could bake my own bread and cut thick slices. But do I feel like doing that every morning, or every couple of days for that matter? No. Trouble has won my $2.

Now let's get to the hot chocolate. I don't drink much coffee, which is a little strange for someone who works in a coffee shop, I know, but Trouble's hot chocolate is awesomely rich and deep without being too sweet (but still sweet enough to share with my daughter). I love it... It's so good that you don't need whipped cream. 

At the end of my visit, my order comes to $5. Totally worth it, to me at least. I also know the owner, and she is so vibrant and different from anyone I've ever met. Go have a conversation with her. Learn something new.  The staff is one-of-a-kind as well. Everyone is so sweet and pretty much know my order by heart now.
author: Catherine H.

description: Really miss their coffee and toast. Take them and sit on the street, or walk to the General store next door and sit in their washed-out garden.
author: Sans S.

description: just look at their website, it says it all: 'we don't give a fuck about being a decent human being or prioritizing customers, only about being cool.'
author: Susanne A.

description:
A friend recently brought Trouble to our attention so we made a trek to the end of the N Judah line to try it. I remember the old days of riding the line down to the beach and making a stop at Java Beach Cafe. Back then, it was the only place to get a bite and some joe before or after playing in the sand. 

Now there is a new community of young interesting businesses in the neighborhood. Trouble, like some of its coffee compatriots, is housed in a very small storefront and has a funky home grown feel. The walls are covered with interesting objects and found photos. My eyes stayed busy as I waited for my coffee to be served. 

The staff was friendly and humble. A few people came in as we waited and there was a healthy rapport and familiarity. It felt like a nice place to be. And if it were in my neighborhood I would find myself being a regular. Oh. I guess I should mention the coffee. It was nice smooth and satisfying. My husband really liked his Mocha as well. 

One thing about this neighborhood that I noticed, is all the boys had their jeans rolled up in a clumsy sort of way. I thought it was a little mini fashion trend, but now it dawns on me that when you are at the beach, you have to roll up your pants or you end up soggy. Boy, sometimes I think I spent too much time in the "big city" that I think everyone is trying to hard, when some are just simply being. And so too is Trouble.
author: Tina E.

description:
My review of Trouble Coffee Company got me a letter from the owner offering her apologies for comments that were said to me.  More importantly she addressed her decision as to why Trouble Coffee Company doesn't offer artificial sweetener and her coffee blend being a sweeter bean than others. That being said, I am at least a fan of the owner and her willingness to help a change my negative outcome to a positive.

I will give "Trouble" another chance.
author: Craig N.

description:
This place caught my eye on an amble toward the ocean. Walking in without a single expectation, I was enchanted by the dollhouse beach shack atmosphere.

The friendly barista served us up the house special in a flash (coffee, coconut, cinnamon toast: irresistible to my sweetie). The coffee was excellent, the coconut sweet and refreshing, and the thick slab of toast was nothing but a buttery cinnamon memory, we gobbled it so ravenously. They have Morning Glory Chai-- the only packaged chai I like.

Yeah, you could slice the hipsterness with a shark fin in there. But it's a nice treat near the beach, and I do prefer it to JB.
author: Jaina D.

description:
Unique experiences make the lasting impressions and when coffee houses tend to pop up every other corner, you have to be a little different.  Trouble Coffee is very different and I mean different.  As soon as you walk in, you'll know what I mean.  The interior space isn't large, so don't try come and bring your laptop, it is made to order your cup, gaze at all the weird, but cool things (all found abandoned on across the City) on the wall  then go on your merry way.  

The coffee beans used for their espresso is smooth with a dark taste, in fact, they load every latte, mocha, etc. with at least three shots and the cups aren't that big.  The one of a kind experience outside of the decor, is the fresh young coconut on the menu.  Yes, they hack a fresh one open for you.  The coconut is meant to have before or after your coffee/espresso to prolong and mellow out the caffeine buzz.  You'd think you could ask for a shot of espresso in the coconut, but they highly recommend against it. 

Albeit, Trouble Coffee is out of the way for most, it is one of those "not over-hyped" or "good, but super crowded" coffee shops that is worth checking out at least once. and I've been there 4 times!
author: Jason A.

description: The toast is good and this is one of the best coffee places in Outer Sunset, but I'm not a huge fan of the crowd or decor, I think the drinks are overpriced (~$3.50-4.50 for the one's that I've ordered), and I hate how they only take cash, took down the menu, and close the place at random times throughout the day.  Why post store hours if you're not going to be open during them?
author: M. N.

description: everything but the coffee was great. but since all the other reviews on the coffee were so high, maybe mine was an off batch. like someone accidentally put a cigarette in it or something.
author: S. K.

description: By I chance I wander into this place and got a cappucino. It is a really cute and homey store, but the coffee quality is just meh. I don't really like the strong sour aftertaste.
author: Erica B.

description:
The prices are a complete rip off. Yes the coffee is good, but you have to wait about 20 minutes for it because that girl who owns it never shuts up. All you hear when you go in there is how great she is. Well her concept for a new business is obviously a hit with the thirty something have kids crowd... but for people who need to catch the train before work... make your own coffee at home.  
The environment is pretentious and closed minded.  Luckily you wont need to worry about the wait for coffee because half of the time you drive by, the place is closed.
author: Young M.

description: Not 3rd wave coffee, served with an undeserved premise of illumination
author: andrew b.

description: Great place on a Sunday morning to stop in for some coffee.  The place is small, cozy and friendly.  It's really refreshing to see young and hip types smiling and providing good service while still enforcing their message.  Had a delicious, spicy chai and they have a nice seating area out in front.
author: Veronica B.

description: Blue bottle is slightly better, but I am no expert. Their pastries are pretty good, but limited selection. Pumpkin bread. mmmm.
author: William H.

description: Great americanos. Cute guy making my coffee. Life is good. Will return.
author: Judy L.

description:
You know what I consider 'Trouble', going to this place and finding out it's closed.  All day on Saturday the 21st.  Too bad yelp can't tell you when a place goes out of business (or the owner just decides not to show up, I don't know which).  If they redeem themselves I'm happy to update my review, but people should not go without confirming they are still in business.

Update: OK so I went back when they were open.  I had a cup of coffee and it was nothing special at all.  I really don't get it.  I will say the woman at the counter was nice.  It's not even in the same league at Ritual.  I don't know what all these people are excited about, but I'll upgrade from 1 to 2 stars as a courtesy.
author: Al K.

description:
I've said it before, and I'll say it again - the Outer outer Sunset is blowing up. Well... it's trying.

I heard about Trouble Coffee in the tablehopper and from a guy who didn't even live in the Sunset. It's two blocks from my house, so I was a little ashamed that someone who didn't live out here had tried it before me. I went down there on a gorgeous hot Sunday to get some coffee and their famed cinnamon toast. The girl that was making the coffee seemed standoffish at first, and I was scared that the reviews saying the service was too cool for school were right. When she finally got to us, though, she was friendly. I got a coffee and the cinnamon toast. The coffee? It was a-ight. Could have been Starbucks. Unlike Starbucks, they didn't have Splenda or Equal out, just brown sugar and raw sugar (much like any other place that serves coffee in the neighborhood... Judahlicious, I'm talking to you). 

The toast was pretty amazing, though. Thick Texas toast slathered in butter, then coated heavily with cinnamon and sugar, which melts all over the toast.

The place is adorable inside. A lot going on, and it struck the right chord between beachy (in keeping with the hippie/beachy atmosphere of the neighborhood) and Mission-style cool.

Even though the coffee wasn't great, I have to rate Trouble Coffee highly for taking a chance on bringing a cool, indie coffee spot to the Outer outer.
author: Aylin S.

description:
It was my first cup of the day the first time I tried Trouble Coffee.  My conversation with the owner went a little something like this:

Me:  Hmm, I can't decide between a small and a large.
Her: Go with a small, it will keep you going all day.
Me: 

Now imagine my mouth gaping, a puzzled look on my face.  I've been up-sized before, sure.  But downsized?  It was amazing.  She was right, I didn't need the large.  The small coffee I received was delicious and it did keep me going for hours, without the sweating, jaw clenching, and tummy ache that I often get with "strong" coffee. 

Now we all know that the owner roasts her own coffee, but I also heard through the grapevine that she also bakes that amazing bread that the cinnamon toast is made with.  

In other words, this woman is my hero, and this coffee shop is my new favorite.
author: Annie A.

description:
Your refuge from conceptual consistence. A textural wonderland, trimmed of selection adipose. The je ne sais quoi produces a comforting sense of reliance and trust. If only my family deserved such a distinction. *sniff* *loads cylinder* *realizes brilliance and cereal selfishness could rob world of imperative force*  *rejoices...humbly*

Crisp carbs, Sinewy flesh, molten caffeine. Be sure to take note of Giulietta's didactic spunk- you could open your own proprietorship with the secrets she unfastens for the taking.

TROUBLE!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Christopher J.

description:
why you gotta be so far away??
a bike ride away the best reason to get out to the sunset..I love good coffee..

thanks for letting get in trouble
author: Bici G.

description:
Come for the coffee toast & coconuts, stay for the people.

I go here every day. It makes me happy. Come in. Don't be in a hurry, just grab a stool and relax. Take it as it comes. Get the toast. Talk to the person next to you. Have fun. Learn something. Enjoy the coffee.
author: James R.

description: Delicious espresso... Quite sour but not TOO sour. Toast looked amazing but didn't try it. Very friendly staff to chat with. Cute cozy place... Seemed not very comfy during rushes tho.
author: Erik P.

description:
YOU ARE THE WORST COFFEE SHOP IN THE WORLD !!!

They most certainly are the most pretentious people who work in a coffee shop. Get over your self you guys. Come on really what makes you think you can be that way to other people? I have been there 3 times and each time the service has been bad but the worst was the owner. As soon as I found out who that was I couldn't believe it. It's no wonder why the staff thinks they can be just as horrible. I get the feeling that they only want to serve one kind of people (      ) are they bigots? I also don't even like to go by there anymore but when I do it's to go to 7/11 and as I drive by I give those nasties a dirty look from my car. Hoping they remember when: 
1.The day they didn't want to serve me
2. Made me 15 minutes late for work when all I wanted was a cup
3. The time I actually was sitting at the bar eating - they couldn't wait for me to get out.
4. The time I told my family to go there for mothers day and they were only kinda nice to a few of us even though clearly we were all together... (let's just say that we are a by racial family) you can just imagine what I am talking about.

I have more... 
but the point is don't go to that UGLY place I promise you can get better coffee close by or even across the street.
author: Xeni S.

description:
I like this place because of their beautiful simplicity.  The people working and hanging around have been real chill, and seem to be on the same wavelength.

Go there and drink a cold coconut.

If you like fancy shit, you might not get it.
author: L J.

description:
This place is super cute and groovy. Lots of quirky decor and funky  art.
It's teeny tiny but also very charming.
The menu offering is simple: Coffee, espresso and toast.
The latte I received was excellent and the toast was tasty.
BUT
Heres the thing. My latte was served in a cup that was tiny, smaller than a Starbucks Tall (and don't pretend you don't know what size that is, we have all been there at least once!).
So for a super extra, extra small latte and ONE slice of toast I paid $5.
Maybe it's just me but that seemed like a lot.
I'm all about supporting the local non-chain businesses but I also like a reasonable price. I will probably be back but maybe just for a latte.....if I'm feeling flush.
author: Catty C.

description:
I've had exactly one cup here (espresso, nothing in it) and never had the toast.  

So why does it get five stars?

Because they have the best beans I have ever bought.  I have to go to Trouble every two weeks for a bag of Elbow Grease.  This makes the best cup of espresso in my home machine I have ever been able to make.  And I've tried a lot of places.

Even though I spend less than five minutes here each time I come in, I do like the vibe and the funky signs and all of that.  Makes me happy to live in San Francisco.
author: Spike S.

description: Adorable place. Funny man made me a spectacular Americano- perfect water to espresso ratio:) He must be some sort of scientist.
author: Jill H.

description:
Without doubt the strangest little coffee shop I have ever seen. Its about the size of a bathroom - hence the lids, sugar and milk are outside on the pavement on a little table.
There's a sign on the wall inside that says "no masks allowed". Apparently this has been a problem in the past. 
On the right is a big map of SF with hundreds of red pins on it. I asked the barista if this is where her customers live and she said no - every time there's a murder they put a pin at the location.
The service was great + really friendly, but I found the place bizarre. Maybe its just me..
The girl who works early mornings wears a racoon skin cap too. I sh*t you not...check it out!
author: Richie S.

description: I dream about working at this place and loving my life. The cinnamon toast and coffee are possibly the best edible combination ever devised. Build your own damn house. Be Flexible, I Am.
author: Ryan K.
