description: The coffee ($3.50 for a latte) was solid, but nothing spectacular. The service was kind and friendly. The cinnamon toast ($2.50) that everyone raves about was very good, but when does something smothered in butter NOT taste good? As a super health-conscious person I probably wouldn't get it again unless my arteries wanted to die a little. Also, people are not exaggerating when they say this place has HIPSTER written all over it--which is fine, but it's just not my scene.
author: Diane G.

description:
Great vibe all around. Thanks Guilietta.  Discovering Trouble turned our weekly slog across town for our kids' lessons into a happy Sat. morning ritual.

Great coffee -  love the latte and the toast is perfect - thick, crispy and loaded with butter and cinnamon sugar. 

On our way out the door this week with some of the "elbow grease" coffee beans in hand, we decided to splurge on the pickled green beans sitting on the shelf ?? yes, green beans.  They were expensive, but, my oh my were they delicious. Briny, crunchy and spicy they are terrific and addictive. I only wish I knew how to make them.
author: S G.

description: The latte was pretty damn good. The cinnamon sugar toast was very nice (i think they get their bread from Outerlands). The coconut my friend and i got was bland. I guess that's not really something they can help though, right?
author: Phuong M.

description:
I really, really want to love this little coffee cafe.  I am a big believer in supporting small locally owned shops.  I love good coffee. But I give up. Trouble Coffee Company just doesn't get it!   A "third wave" cafe cafe should, at barest minimum, serve good coffee.  I'm not talking the fru-fru milk drinks, just basic coffee, espresso etc.  I can only assume that the highly favorable reviews were drinkers of  milk/coffee drinks. The brewed coffee is weak and flavorless. The espresso was weak and over extracted with the barest minimum crema.  I am not asking for high-end specialty coffee beans, just good preparation of the beans that they do serve.

A neighborhood coffee cafe should be relaxed and welcoming. Not with a snippy  "I could care less" attitude.  There are typically two staff. One order taker/cashier/attitude purveyor. Two, a clearly overworked barista trying to keep up with the orders, but consistently failing.

I really want to love this place. It is really close to one of my favorite brunch/breakfast joints.  But I need real coffee and this little place gives every impression that it serves such. It just fails to do so.

BTW, nice latte art was observed during this morning's visit, but  I can get that at Outlander, without the attitude. The breakfast breads always look delectable!!

I hope Trouble Coffee makes it.  Maybe there are enough milk/coffee drinkers to sustain the business. But it would be nice for them to serve a decent cup of coffee.
author: Geary L.

description: Gibraltar was delicious with properly textured milk. I liked the vibe. Nice little seating area outside too. Hot chocolate for the kids.
author: Saks T.

description:
It's more than 2 years later and Trouble is still here.  The proprietor still pours the best cappuccino, but other staff are pretty damned good.   Trouble's espresso drinks are really superb. The pastries are a limited selection, but similarly good.  The company can be great, depending on the day and some of the most interesting people in the Sunset (all kinds of people of all kinds of ages and backgrounds) show up if you hang around a little.

To address the critique: 

Whether you like Trouble depends on your priorities.  They're not cheap -- there's a 7-11 right across the street if you were looking for cheap, or you can go to Java Beach for the midpoint. They're not always fast, and sometimes the staff gets a little chatty with regulars -- it's not McDonald's.  If cheap and fast are important to you, you're not going to be rating Trouble highly, and that's okay.

Also, all you people fretting about how the hipsters are rude to you? I'm a 40-ish mom, and the staff are okay to me.  Most of the morning regulars are even more middle aged than I and not particularly hipstery.  Occasionally one does see the lone Ocean Beach hipster. Guess what? They're people too.  Whatever.  Check your high school insecurities at the door.
author: Eva R.

description: When I second walked in there, they were playing John Lennon's Double Fantasy Stripped Down (and the Yoko songs weren't on the playlist). They've also got a copy of Yoko Ono's "Grapefruit" on the shelf, available for public perusal by request. On top of that, the coffee's good. On top of that, they people are "cool". The location is stellar, two blocks from beautiful ocean beach. How can I not call this place my favorite coffee shop in the city? I just wish they served raw chocolate deserts.
author: Samuel C.

description:
so grateful that this place is in my neighborhood. love the owners and most people who have worked there in the past have been great in there own colorful ways. 

So hows the coffee? well, there is plenty of good coffee in SF.  four barrel, blue bottle, spy glass, ritual etc. etc.... Its a great city to be a coffee lover.  Trouble is up there with the best for sure.  Everyone has there favorites. But when I got home from a long journey and wanted to treat myself to the finest the City could offer in order to cleanse my palette of all the garbage coffee I had been ingesting... Trouble did me right and served up a mean little cappuccino that made me glad to be home.   thanks guys.
author: Art V.

description:
Really good coffee...I didnt get the famous toast with coconut etc, but my friend did- the coconut was SO SWEET!

I got the cherry and pecan scone. Really rich, heavy, buttery....amazing. 

The coffee was strong and dark (with soy milk option, of course). 

I liked the interior a lot but it was really crowded on a Saturday morning. So we sat by the bar for a bit, then moved to the window (it was too hot) and then eventually took our coffees to the beach for a walk. and air.

The waiters were a little harsh- one of them was screaming at the top of her lungs each time she made a coffee ('LATTE!!!!!! CAPPUCINO!!!!")..Like, Ok, calm down lady. I just want to enjoy my coffee in peace, not be yelled at.

And I didn't feel like tipping them that much because they seemed annoyed when I asked them what kinds of scones they had. And they ignored me completely when I asked them for a knife. Like they looked at me straight in the face and ignored me. Then they gave my friend a funny look when she asked for her toast to be buttered on both sides (what is wrong with that?!)

Anyway, overall, good....fun....tasty.....interesting. I like how its in the middle of nowhere- its worth the trip if you have a lot of time. But yes, the minus star is for the jerky staff. 

Having said that, I am sure some of the other staff who were not on shift that day are perfectly sweet.
author: Tara S.

description:
I moved into the neighborhood a few weeks back and have been to Trouble about a half dozen times.  I don't drink coffee, but they have a small but solid loose-leaf tea selection and source their baked goods from awesome local bakeries (scones, muffins and surf bars are all super good).  They've cobbled together a cute place and they play good music, which along with the good food and drink makes this place just peachy in my view.

A lot of reviews mention ill treatment from the staff.  I did notice a definite clique vibe when I first went.  Not too-cool-hipster lameness (I just moved from Brooklyn so I'm an expert on that bs), just neighborhood joint giving love to the regulars and friends style cliquishness.  The one barista is pretty cold, but most are friendly and attentive.  I notice that almost all the negative reviews are from neighborhood folks who seem to be angry at being excluded from the group, out-of-towners almost universally love the place.  Also, people complain a lot about the small espresso drinks.  A full shot or two is going in each one, so I think the smaller sizes reflect how Trouble thinks you should make a top notch coffee, not stinginess since adding a few ounces more of water costs them virtually nothing.

I like the place and will keep going back.  I don't need the people at the coffee shop to be my friends.  I've always gotten attentive service, if that changes I'll update my review.
author: F U.

description: Tried a texas toast with light butter and cinnamon along with a steamed chai latte (although a bit strong on the spices)- perfect for a drizzling Sunday Morning. A little pricy for the combo but the service was speedy and the decor interesting to read while waiting.
author: Liz L.

description: So I don't know how to write this review as we have been to this shop countless times and have loved the vibe, coffee, toast, and treats.  That said, this last experience soured me on trouble.  We walked in with our 2 kids.  Our 7 year old immediately gravitated to the army guy within reach and promptly showed it to me while my eight year old asked me to find out house on the map with pins.  I made the mistake of moving a pin back to where our house is and found that the guy at the register (maybe 5 ft away) was yelling at us like we were vandalizing the property.  Note, none of these items within easy reach had signs asking people not to touch.  I think he tried to soften the moment when we were checking out by saying the owner was very picky about these things.  Fair enough, being anal about details is likely what has made this shop great in so many other areas.  That said, I still found the experience very upsetting rather than relaxing.  It would have been easy enough for the guy to kindly notify us they don't like people touching any of the items.  I don't like my children nor myself being treated this way.
author: Mary K.

description: Good coffee place. They have some outdoor seating including horizontal branches of a super-cool tree. It actually works quite well. Nice folks.
author: Jack S.

description:
Who would've thought one of the best coffee shops in the city is located in Outer Sunset?  (Sorry Avenue residents...  I just don't go there much)

They know what they are doing with their coffee.  Only uses whole milk,  espresso shots and amount of milk are already set for you unless specially ordered.  I usually order large single low fat latte, and I ordered my usual except low fat milk part, but I should've gone with their judgment.  Small  cup, whole milk, and 1 shot of espresso makes the perfect latte.  My latte was still good, but it would've been better with their suggestion.

Just curious.  Do they have any food/sweets?
author: Yoko S.

description: If I could give 0 stars I would. WORST customer service EVER. Barista just stood there talking with one of her friends (for several minutes) while everyone was waiting to order. Coffee is not good, not fair, just bad. Doesn't live up to the hype, NOT worth the drive to the Sunset.
author: Oaktown S.

description:
This is the anti-Starbucks. 

Instead of being able to download the new Paul McCartney song via the ether you listen to a cassette mix tape. 

They serve coconuts and toast. I wonder if I contributed jello. 

An amazing place that seems apart from the grid.
author: Marcus R.

description: Simple and amazing!  Had coffee and cin. toast here for 9 days in a row during vacation.
author: Eric M.

description:
If you want to be a productive awesome human being and be a credit to the society as a whole. you should probably drink trouble once a day followed by there toast and coconut. this way you will get shit done and have a balanced meal in the morning to kick butt all day long.

And now they have cookies so you can kick butt later in the night with a coffee and cookie.
author: Anthony M.

description:
This is the freshest coffee I've bought in years. Perfectly roasted. Just plain old damn good coffee. It's also fairly kid friendly, and just friendly in general.

Sorry, but I have to take off a star for s.h.s. (stupid hippie shit). No offense. I do it for everyone.
author: Melinda B.

description: Americano wasn't bad.  i brought my own mug but they didn't fill it all the way up.  i suppose they didn't want to water down the Americano.  Their scones... they were pretty amazing.  Overall, pretty good.  I'd go back for their scones.
author: Joe A.

description: this place sucks. a friend and I were passing through San Francisco on our way south. we were referred to this place by another business a block away so we decided to give it a try. when we got there, their was a line out the door because the place is the size of a small tool shed. none of these things really bothered me. What bothered me was the cashier in the front doesn't say a word to me the whole transaction other than displaying an annoying look on his face. Granted I was only buying a drip coffee, but I would at least expect a "Thank You" at the bare minimum. But Just to add insult to injury, the coffee tasted like hot water. They may have better drinks to offer, but my experience with this place was awful and there are other better coffee shops in San Francisco
author: Max J.

description:
Who knew there is actually quality coffee in the Sunset? I didn't... until this place popped up on Yelp. Trouble Coffee... Trouble indeed! That is, if you're a coffee addict like I am. This place is going to eat through my wallet. Thanks Uncle Sam for the stimulus check! It's all going to be invest into this place!

After numerous attempts to find Trouble Coffee's location, I finally found it by foot. Lesson learned - sometimes it's MUCH BETTER to walk up and down the street to find a place if I'm unable to see it as I drive by. For those who are curious about this place, it is a tiny shop next to a graphic design office. There is also a sign posted on the sidewalk that can help you locate the entrance. I almost walked past it... so look out for it! 

Now onto the good stuff.... the COFFEE. Byron, the cool and incredibly friendly guy who worked here this afternoon, recommended the Americano and mmm mmm mmmmm.... great coffee. It was smooth and bold with a hint of sweetness at the end. He even made some coconut cinnamon toast for my friend and I to try. If I lived closer here, I'd probably come by here every morning for breakfast. 

Sure Java Beach is just down the street, but for really GOOD coffee (probably one of the best in the Outer Sunset), come here. You won't be disappointed.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
very well might be my fav coffee in the city.  i drink machiatos and granted i'm new to the coffee game, but trouble is great.  not a huge fan of ritual (too light) or four barrel, the other touted 3rd wavers.  and i admit, i do love me some philz (coffee snobs are rolling their eyes).  

i don't get the bad service i'm seeing on yelp.  ever since a couple weeks ago when i started going, these guys have been really cool to talk to when i ordered my mach.  found out yesterday that their beans are sourced by them, but roasted by intelligentsia.  pretty cool.
author: shar d.

description: I've been looking for a local coffee place for the longest time!! Living in the sunset I usually take the drive to Philz in the Castro but ever since the gas prices have went up I've been wanting to stay local. One Sunday my girlfriend and I were looking for a coffee place and stumbled upon Trouble Coffee on 45th and Judah. As I walked in I noticed spotted my neighbor Julietta who lives right across the street from me! She recommended the soy cappuccino and let me say it was DELICIOUS!! Very excited to try many of their other drinks!
author: nabil s.

description: This has to be one of the best coffee shops in the outer sunset. I've only tried the drip coffee, but they make it good and they have good fixings such as real brown sugar and cinnamon. Along with the coffee they serve up tasty baked goods that are a step above the standard coffee shop fare in creativity and flavor. The cinnamon toast is to die for made with a thick 1" slice of fresh bread smothered in butter and cinnamon. You can order it in combination with a fresh coconut and a coffee...My favorite way to start a foggy sunset morning.
author: Amybeth O.

description:
5 days later, I'm still fantasizing about that soy latte that I got here.  yumm.     
 
I was staring at their amazingly thick baked good that supposedly come with a shot of milk.  But, I held back...will definitely try next time!
author: stephanie c.

description: This place is a tiny hole in the wall with great coffee. I hear good things about their baked goods as well, but haven't tried them yet. The coffee is delicious (coming from an addict and a bit of a snob). I wouldn't mind if it were a bit stronger, but other than that it's great. Probably not a place to sit down unless it's nice out (they do have cool outdoor seating) or you don't mind it being very crowded. It really is tiny. Friendly atmosphere. It's nice to see a good coffee place in the Sunset, considering Starbucks is really not my thing. I'm considering getting my beans there for my French press at home.
author: Abi L.

description: Believe it or not, it is a lot more spacious than what it was before she renovated. I love her coffee and her spunk. The cinnamon toast makes regular appearances in my dreams. If you're craving for an excellent breakfast/brunch after her blissful cup of joe, just walk a block down and chow down at Outerlands.
author: Jacinta H.

description:
Not sure how I found myself here, but I did and I'm happy.  It's waaaaay out in the Sunset.  But I'll tell you what, if you cross 19th and you're looking for a good macchiato or late, you might as well go the distance and get the good stuff.  

I didn't try a coconut, but the two kids sitting next to me were raving about how good they were.  

Oh yah, and the scones are really tasty!
author: Marc H.

description:
Definitely a good cup of coffee.  Had an Americano for I think $2-2.50.  Friend and I went there at the end of a 6 mile run.  The baby coconut was AMAZING.  I'm sure being tired and thirsty had something to do with it, but the coconut water was super sweet.  Took one sip and said out loud "Oh man, where did they get this from?!"  Woman nearby, who looked to be the owner, said "Thailand."  Impressive.
The cinnamon toast was definitely tasty, but I felt bad about myself for eating it when I saw how much butter goes on that thing.  Oh well.
Inside space is minimal; expect to stand outside with your food or just take it to go.
Guy behind the counter wasn't rude but definitely did not fall in to the warm or friendly category either.  Woman who (I think) owns the place was very friendly.
Will definitely go back.
author: A K.

description:
Came here on a lazy Saturday afternoon while trolling around with a friend. The coffee is pretty good. Some of the best in the city, but then again, there's a lot of good coffee in this city. There's better coffee to be had, but you won't be disappointed.

What I really love about this place is the coastal vibe out here. I live in Hayes Valley, but will always have a special place in my heart for coastal cities.  This coffee fits in perfectly with the outer sunset. Fog rolling by, reggae on the speakers, relaxed service and a comfy little bar to sit and enjoy your coffee.
author: Kyle N.

description: I stopped in here this morning while I was doing laundry and treated myself to an Americano. Nicely made, although the portion was a bit smaller than I expected. I was lucky enough to get in there when it was quiet, so I was able to sit by the window counter and watch the N Judah roll by while I sipped my coffee. I'll be back again to try the cinnamon toast I've read so much about in the reviews here.
author: Rory O.

description:
I just stopped in here once and I'm personally not taken by their whole revolution by way of dressing punk and knowing your neighbors.  Although that's a good way to start.  And come to think of it, so is cinnamon toast.  

They do their three things here well, so power to 'em.  Not much of a space to speak of, but they've figured out how to work it.  Dig the mini chairs.  Wait, were those for small children only?
author: Jennifer B.

description: Very nice peeps. Cinnamon toast is prime time. Coffee is good, kinda expensive though. I'm sure you're paying for the super ingredients. No bathroom kinda sucks.
author: Jeanette V.

description:
excellent find in the off the track outer sunset...
get lunch at outerlands and walk down to trouble and consider it a SF secret find (unless your a OS resident).

I stumbled in here, thinking i had been to about every coffee shop SF could offer. Obviously i was wrong and humbled. 

Great coffee. NO DECAF....good story behind it though as to the why.

if you like coconuts they got coconuts too....lol and toast.
author: Mohammad G.

description: Best soy latte and chocolate chip banana bread I have tasted in a long time :).
author: lacou f.

description: awesome staff w/ awesome treats... can i get a refill on this pie? didnt read the fine print, but i believe the customer is always right!!
author: Stephan T.

description: I love this place.  They do everything so perfectly there.  Keeping it simple means taking time to make it special.  If I wander up the block while they make my delicious chai or coffee they remake it for me when I return because they care about quality (and temperature) like a business from another place in time.  These days I stay put when they make my drink because there are plenty of interesting things to gaze at and the staff and customers are friendly and surprisingly unpretentious.
author: Amy S.

description:
I read the reviews and agree with all them. The drinks I had were stellar. Really. The owner made them herself and they were damn impressive. I will go back.

However, I'm really sensitive to "the balance" when it comes to customers getting what they're willing to pay good money for. And being treated respectfully, every time, when they're spending hard earned money at your place. It's a balance. An exchange. There should be good will in that every single time. I loathe the odd slogan that the customer is always right. No. Sometimes customers have had their expectations set by others with backwards customer service models, sub-par products or services and/or frankly, they just might have no taste. This is where you can be polite, respectful and help by suggesting they remain open to something new, that they should trust you - that they'll likely love the results. That respect can help customers to overlook many small inconveniences, without issue. This is where Trouble can both hold their ground, to the integrity of what they're doing, and make customer happy. 

A customer should never, ever be made to feel bad while they're coming into a place to spend their money. Not by employees or the other customers. It's not that difficult to make people feel good.
author: S S.

description:
A log is a portion of a tree. At the end of a crosscut log, there are rings. Each ring represents one year in the life of the tree. How long it takes to a grow a tree. Even though it has stopped growing larger, my log is aware. 

My log has guided me to the finest coffee distributor in the Bay Area, where a warm, sprightly young woman in nothing but a Ushanka, leather jacket and ruffled underwear told me stories of her mother, aliens, and reflected upon death whilst brewing the most savory and balanced cup of cappuccino my log has ever consumed. So much so that my log refused to add a dash of sugar.

My log was once fooled into thinking that a finer brew could not be found outside of the Blue Bottle garage in Hayes Valley, but my log was wrong. 

I could write an epic poem about the thick, savory slices of cinnamon toast that this coffee distributor had made herself. My log has yet to try the pickled green beans and beef jerky that this java pusher also makes herself, but my log tells me I must return very soon in order to do so.

Also, she sells fresh coconuts.
author: amity b.

description: ooooooo. much love for trouble, esp. on a sunny day!
author: chloe w.

description: Eh. I want to like this place, and I've tried to. It's a couple blocks from my house, and my go-to place on freezing mornings when I have to wait longer than 5 minutes for the N-Judah. To be fair, I've only had their coffee, I have yet to try any of their espresso drinks. I was curious about this place after seeing swarms of hipsters hanging out outside (surprised how many of them have been popping up in the sunset lately, btw) but avoided it until I was able to spot it crowd-free (early weekday mornings before work). I've had better coffee, so I'm confused about the crowds. The first time, my coffee was just ok, did the trick, but not the best. I gave it the benefit of the doubt and came back, again a mediocre cup of coffee. After maybe 5 or 6 mediocre large cups of watered down coffee, I think I'm over it and have seriously contemplated walking across the street to 7-11 to grab a coffee instead (decided against it, thankfully). I'd still come back to try a latte, since it looks like people do like this place, but if that disappoints as well, I'm not coming back.
author: Irina S.

description:
I haven't been too wowed by the coffee available in the Sunset. Since moving back to the City from Santa Cruz (and bemoaning the loss of Lulu's at the Octagon), I've been looking for a great coffee place that I don't need to go to the Mission for. 

Enter: Trouble Coffee Company. A cute little coffee shop making some damn fine espresso right here in the Sunset. Sometimes the service can be a little cold if the baristas are busy chatting up customers who got there before you, but they do a great job of pulling shots and making sure your steamed milk is ready just ready to pour into the espresso when it comes out of the machine. 

I just wish this place had a little more seating. Maybe a few tables, but there just isn't enough room.

Edit: I'm going to say this place only deserves 3.5 stars instead of 4. And that's cause $3.50 for a small latte/cappucino is ridiculous. I'll still come for the coffee, but compared to places like Ritual which have wifi and more space/seating, it's not so amazing.
author: Crystal L.

description: Much better latte than my last visit! I'm glad I gave Trouble another try.
author: Loretta G.

description:
Do NOT ask for non-fat anything!!! and you will be BLESSED by Giulietta's amazing coffee. It's hard to find - as there's no sign up yet - but in the meantime - look for the seven eleven on 47th and Judah - directly across the street is java heaven.

She only has one size, but swears it'll be enough to keep you wired throughout the day. I'm on my first cup - but its so good, I may need to go back for more.
author: Jane H.

description:
Pros
- Nice location
- Cool looking shop
- De La Paz Coffee for Espresso Drinks

Cons
- Drop coffee is very average compared to Blue Bottle, Ritual, Sightglass, etc.
- Unfriendly baristas more interested in having a conversation with the one customer in the store than to tell me about their coffee
- No coffee sleeves to hold the scalding hot coffee cup
- Condiments (Sugar, Cream, Stirrers,etc.) placed outside of the shop on Judah Street. Don't think this is very clean with all the traffic on this street

Verdict
- If you have time, you can get a better cup of Chemex brewed coffee from Sighglass/Verve just a few stores up at Outerlands.
- If you just want to buy coffee beans, you can go up the block to the organic food coop and get De La Paz and Ritual Beans
author: Roger R.

description:
Pumpkin Chocolate Chip bread was pretty good.

But the coffee (gf's soy latte, and my cappuccino) were mediocre. And kinda expensive... :(

ambience was kinda cool though, glad they managed to seat 10 or so people in that closet-sized store...
author: Jeremy B.

description: Coffee *and* coconuts? Dang! I also love that it's small, and you can sit at the bar and chatter on with whoever's in there.
author: Lucy M.

description:
There is nothing like a big, fat piece of yummy cinnamon toast here.  I constantly crave it, and it's totally worth the $2.
The mocha is so smooth and goes down very easy, but a little pricey if you ask me.

Just don't order when the owner is playing with her phone.... :)
author: Jessica G.

description:
Simply the best and most satisfying cup of coffee I have ever had. 
I don't usually drink milk in my coffee but Trouble's latte is the most sinfully delicious java I have ever had on any continent. 

Support this little coffee house that does coffee right!
author: K S.

description:
Update 7/21: JOY!  New faces, new attitude--much more agreeable!!  I am back. 

Update 5/18:  with sadness in my heart decreasing stars as I've started avoiding going there (despite my caffeine cravings) for fear of getting a great helping of ATTITUDE and SNOOTINESS from the staff (I miss Giulietta). The girl there apparently hates me. Never smiles, always makes me wait forever for my orders w/o an apology. I know, it's not personal--I see her treat others that way, too. But I want reliably good coffee delivered in a reliably professional manner. After all, my $3.50 is always $3.50. Back to the chemex. 

---
CAN"T STOP EATING THEIR SCONES (Day 3). My waistline is in TROUBLE. 

Thick slices of cinnamon toast (who knew? so good!) , heavenly lattes,  and a really friendly owner. What more can you ask in my 'hood so far out by the seashore?  It's been a treat bumping into your friends and neighbors here---something in their coffee makes people more sociable and sweet (oh, I guess it's called caffeine).  Love it!
author: Ms. Q.

description:
Trouble Coffee Co. has the BEST CHAI! Made by Morning Glory in Seattle, WA.  There's only one other place in SF to get it, that I know of and that's at a Succulent shop behind a video store in Bernal Heights, and it's for take home and cook. :(  
I love my Chai, so the owner recommended a cup to me and it's the Bomb!  They also have delicious Buttery THICK Cinnamon Bread (another treasure), bagels, pastries, strong tasty coffee and the BEST CHAI!
The owner and staff are nice, helpful, and quick.
Even if they were mean, slow and grumpy I'd still go here to support a rad coffee shop like this.
I love the atmosphere! It's a real coffee bar, with salty dogs drinking a cup at the bar chatting, and decor on the walls that resonate from 80's skateboard, surf, punk culture and other cool kitch items that you would want to look at while drinking your morning cup, working off a hangover, waiting for change, or your food.
I used to live in SF but now I'm out in Oakland, so I don't make it into Trouble enough except when visiting Tuesday Tattoo shop, but if I was lived nearby I'd be there all the time!
author: dave em all z.

description:
This place is a rip off!  Plain large coffee $2.75??? Where do they get the nerve?  I should have gone right down the street to Java Beach and paid $2.15 for an even bigger coffee!

Note to Trouble: Charging a lot doesnt make it good.  

Place: extremely tiny.  Its so small that the sugar and cream is outside!
Coffee: Fair at best
author: Dan M.

description: I was really happy to find really good coffee in the Sunset.  Trouble's owner is very opinionated about her coffee.  She knows what she likes and what you should like, too.  I like that because I can be a bit indecisive at times.  The cinnamon toast is so yummy, they get fresh bread delivered, and they cut those slices THICK.  The coconuts hit the spot on an especially hung-over morning.  Yes, the hipsters have sort of taken over, but there are still the little surfer families that come in, and there was probably a time (a long time ago) I might have been considered a hipster (though, I doubt it).  I don't know, anyways, I'm not intimidated.  It's my hood.  Deal with my old, slightly more mainstream looking ass.
author: Cami B.

description:
Coffee was good.  Cinnamon toast was good, but not something I would go back for; at $2.50 a piece I could easily make it at home.   

I guess if you are a regular and the barista remembers your order it's kinda cool.

Yes, the barista did say something to the guy that used their bathroom.  Why don't they lock the door or put a sign on it if they don't want customers to go in there?
author: J. L.

description: Nice, quirky little shop. Not very big, but they have about 8 stools (4 by window, 4 at the bar). This is my first visit, so I haven't tried everything yet. But, the double macchiato wasn't very smooth. Have had better at my other favorite places in the Bay area. The drip coffee was quite good though. Friendly staff and pretty unique to get coconuts at a coffee bar!
author: Larry C.

description: Good coffee, yum! Pastries look good but I didn't eat any. They don't have a bathroom for customers though. That's okay, I went across the street instead. I want to try the fresh coconut, sounds amazing!
author: Gina R.

description: Trouble is great.  They are obsessive about pouring great coffee and the cinnamon toast is the best.  Depending on who's working the counter, they can be a little too hip for comfort.
author: David B.

description: Today was my first time visiting this place.  I bought a 12 oz. cup of regular coffee for $3.00.  To my great disappointment the coffee was not strong enough and such taste as was there was unpleasant.  Tasted like it was made in a large vat, reminding me of Greek Diner/Bodega coffee in Manhattan.  I am a coffee fanatic and for my money you won't find a stronger, more flavorful cup of coffee than at Starbucks in the Laurel Village part of the city.  I am not talking about the Starbucks regular drip, which is bad. I am talking about the "Clover" type brewed coffee, which I understand to only be available in four stores in the city.  Its possible I got to taste a "bad batch" and will try this place again.  Maybe next time it will be better.
author: Alex V.

description: Wow, one of the best lattes I've ever had. such a cool place!
author: Lauren D.

description: A spot of warmth in this chilly city. To start, these folks are committed to your buzz - the coffee is excellent. I am a latte fan - these are the best kind. Next, these guys have some specialties I haven't found anywhere else - such as the toast - thick slice - I mean, like an inch thick - of cinnamon toast - they have a peanut butter option, as well. Get the toast. Finally, and best of all - the company - no laptops here, well, maybe a few i phones here and there, but the main event is great conversation - kind and friendly people - an intimate setting where the barista takes the time to introduce you to the guy you are sitting next to - I am hooked. Come on down.
author: Will B.

description: A drip coffee and toast. Just great. Run off that butter on the beach. If it's foggy, and you're sapped of the urge to run and splash, all that butter just might leave you feeling heavy and sad. No problem. Just have another cup of Elbow Grease and get some other shit done.
author: heather d.

description: Perfect cappucino. Not burned. Not too hot. Creamy. Small. Delicious!
author: Hilde L.

description: Delicious coffee made by baristas that know what they are doing. I typically don't mind paying a little more or waiting a little longer for great coffee made with intention. The space is small, but well put together. The bar was a great addition. Don't live on this side of town, but a great spot to hit up before going to the beach.
author: Mel Z.

description: I don't live in the area but tried this cafe including their beans last week while we waitied to try a nearby restaurant.  Coffee was good, and more notably, we just made coffee at home from the beans and it is really good, and the cost of the beans was more affordable than our usual places.. Ritual, etc.  Great find!
author: R N.

description: I live in the neighborhood and it's my favorite out of everything I've tried. I'd give their coffee and espresso drinks a 7.5/10 (5 being average). The foods I've tried are excellent. the community and atmosphere is what sold me. The people who work there are really know how to keep a customer, and are some of the best baristas I've ordered with. I have a place down the street who's cappuccino and coffee is the best in the neighborhood but my dollar is better spent at trouble.
author: B K.

description:
the ride to trouble coffee was better than the coffee.  the coconuts kinda redeemed their burnt milk.

that being said, i've been there several times and will probably still go back-for the coconuts and toast.
author: Katie Sue A.

description: Had the fanny pack. The guys were super nice and helpful advising me on what to get, even though I probably broke the coffee rules and asked for low fat milk (They only have whole milk and soy milk).
author: Apple P.

description: Good lord in heaven this place makes some obscenely good coffee.  The whole milk makes an already exquisite cup of joe taste like an ice cream joyride through heaven, and that thick toast...hot and buttery and covered with cinnamon...I will spend my meager paycheck here any day, and be fat.  Thank you, lord, for Trouble Coffee Company.  Amen.
author: Alanna C.

description:
So, I've been trying to like this joint since day one.  I think I actually wrote the first negative review, and then deleted it because I felt bad about bashing a new place-- figured they might have to get their act together.  

The bad part about trouble is not the coffee or food, but the attitude.  I have to agree with the other haters here.  The hipsterella business is a bit much for the beach.  I mean really, who the fukk wears tight jeans in the sand anyway?

To the point now, first time i gave a bad review was for the slow service where I couldn't get served, then when I got served, i couldn't pay until the gal behind the corner finished the same story I;ve heard her tell a thousand times.

But that's old news.  This time I just ducked in for a quick double shot.  I wanted it togo because I sip on espresso-- as do a lot of people-- and was on my way to meet up with someone at the beach.   

After i had paid and asked for the coffee to go, they told me that they don't do espresso to go because the caffeine sticks to the side of the togo cup... what the fuck ever to that-- but after refusing me a togo, the gal says it should be ok-- because espresso is actually really small.... really?  No fucking shit?   What an asshole I am to want to walk down the street and sip my drink rather than pound it as i did.  

fukin a people-- get off it and just start pouring coffee already.
author: Jake R.

description: Love the coffee here. Even it is a little pricy, but I think it is worth it. Staff is friendly, and the space outside of the store is not bad also. Even though the space is not large, people can manage to find their own corner to hang out.
author: Martin N.

description: I was looking forward to trying a local coffee store. From where I'm from all around within a short distance is just a bunch of Starbucks stores. It's very cute- small, but efficient. You get the lids outside along with sugar so there's not a bunch of people crowding the inside of the shop. I usually don't buy coffee or tea at a shop because it's at a premium price. But I thought, eh, why not, just this once. I paid 3.50 for a chai tea. That's pretty pricey for me. Sipped it on my way out, tasted a zing of spiciness from what I think is the cardamom. I usually don't put anything in my chai, but after that first sip, it tasted kinda like it was missing a touch of sugar. I don't know, maybe I was supposed to put a tad in it. I put a little bit, less than a teaspoon, and that did it for me. If I do go back, I would maybe try it with milk not chai. It's a little bit thin for me. Friendly and fast service. And contrary to other reviews, it does not smell stuffy or stinky in here. I mean, when I went at least.
author: Ally W.

description: Some of the best coffee and lattes in town.  Great munchies, with a cool location when the weather is good, very little indoor seating.  Awesome Vibe Unless....Unfortunately, there is a female barista, who is a combination of obnoxious, forgetful, and not very talented.  Usually wears a headscarf.  If she is working, move along to another spot.  If not, this place is one of my favorites down by the beach. When she is not there the place is a 4+
author: Tod S.

description: After 10 miles of bike riding, an espresso and calorie-rich slab of cinnamon toast. As good as it gets.
author: Holly A.

description: I've only had a latte from Trouble once, because I usually drink decaf and unfortunately that's not an option there.  It was very good.  What I've had many times is a cookie and a shot - a shot of milk, that is.  Usually split both with the BF and it's the perfect treat.  The folks that work there - and the other customers - are usually friendly and mellow.  A great neighborhood place.  If I could get decaf here, I'd give them 5 stars.
author: Cindi L.

description: Good place to go for coffee and unusual conversation.  Leans heavily to the hippster-ness. which can be a little too much. But the cinnamon toast is fabulous and the setting good.
author: Jay H.

description: Can't say i've had the cocconut or toast, though I have been tempted....but the coffee is oh so smooth. Be warned though $2 for a cup of joe is just too much, I don't care how good it is.  If the servers paid a little more attention to the customer and Trouble lowered the price per cup, i'd be a regular. But 'nough said, they brew up a god damn good cup of coffee and that's the bottom line.
author: Forrest C.

description: The only place to get a delicious cup of brew in the Outer Sunset.
author: Elle M.

description:
i really, really want to like this place. i really do. their coffee is awesome, free trade and organic, and the place itself is absolutely lovely and artistic and analog. but man do i have a fricken beef with them. the exorbitant prices i get, good coffee is something i am absolutely willing to pay for, a heavy dose of holier than thou attitude, however, i am certainly NOT. 

I've lived in this neighborhood for five years and love it, i love the people, the chill attitude, the environmental commitment and the lack of snotty hepsters and too cool for school people that i find in much of san francisco. enter trouble coffee...

i go there yesterday and get a cup of coffee, the counter girl was fab and we talk about how much we dig our chill ass neighborhood. enter the owner, who, talking to some regulars who are there, doesn't bother to acknowledge me (no smile, no eye contact, no 'what's up') until i have the gall to ask for a lid. this is when she tells me i need to "prove that i need one'. when i tell her that i need to walk two blocks with a big bag of groceries and my clumsy ass, she says: uhhhh.... the nice counter girl gives me a lid and smiles at me as the owner doubts my necessity and i walk out the fricken door.  

so here's the funny part, my husband bought us coffee there earlier that very morning, and was served by the owner, who put the fricken lids on his two coffee cups without even asking if he needed them. 

this is a revised review.. i dont' need to assume why she was rude to me, she just was, when she hadn't had the same issue with someone else not two hours prior. 

I very begrudgingly will not  be going there again...should i need a heavy dose of attitude, there are plenty of places in san francisco to give it to me other than my own neighborhood.... this makes me sad.
author: Sarita K.

description: I agree with the "too cool for school" vibe that you get here. You can walk down to Java Beach and stand line for five minutes, or stand at Trouble and get ignored for five minutes. Wanted to like it. Bummer.
author: lee d.

description: The thing about Trouble Coffee is that they love their coffee...not in a football fan way, but with more of a political extremist fervor. The steps they take to make sure the handles are clean, the old grinds are gone, the coffee is perfectly tamped and pulled for just the right amount of time...the extra rich milk...it all creates the kind of espresso you just dont find very often...whether someone is using "blue bottle coffee" or not, so much comes down to the love & handling of the bean...and Trouble nails it. I'll take espresso like this over formica tables and formulaic "service" any day. You WAIT for coffee this good. For all you haters looking for service with a smile and comfy chairs...I think theres a Starbucks at 9th...
author: Tobi S.

description: What Trieste is to North Beach, Trouble is brewing at Ocean Beach. The real MF deal. Coffee with oomph. Yeah, they got personality. Love the self-sufficient, pioneering spirit that is the mission at Trouble. My whole fam-damily bikes down here every chance we get. We run into old friends from all over the city who are magnetically drawn here. Cinnamon toast!
author: Brandon R.

description: Trouble Coffee just gave me one more reason to love love LOVE my neighborhood.  My husband says the coffee rulez(with a Z).  Trouble coffee is located in a little strip just below the fog belt.  I swear...I just came from Dolores park where the fog was creeping in, to find that my little neighborhood was surprisingly breathtakingly sunny.
author: Joni S.

description: Seabiscuit is my girlfriend but Trouble is my thang on the side. Seabiscuit is reliable; we have a comfortable arrangement and I feel as though we understand each other. On the other hand, Trouble is mysterious and slightly out of reach; kind of artsy and aloof. I hope that Seabiscuit doesn't know about how I see Trouble from time to time, out of convenience mostly - sometimes just to switch things up. I will say that $2.00 is a painful amount to spend on a small cup of coffee, this is Trouble's one character flaw that keeps me from breaking things off with Seabiscuit. Trouble, I know you're a sexy, struggling artist and your drip tastes like divine-caffeine-nectar BUT you ask just a little too much from me. I would rather be settled in a steady relationship with Seabiscuit than pursuing something that I can never afford with a temptress like you.
author: Sylvia P.

description: Yikes!  Hipster cafe in the outer Sunset!  But I love it anyway!   Okay, that's three exclamation points in a row.  The Gibraltar is just my style- like a mini latte without so much milk.   And cinnamon toast...   how many great childhood memories does that bring back?!  A piece of bread shouldn't cost so much but it is tasty.  Great stop- off after a ride or run and less crowded than Java Beach.
author: laura a.

description: I can have free espresso when i get to work but i still like stopping here before jumping on the muni.  good coffee and good people
author: Tony V.

description: Get gurped with a man-cup sized coffee and some toast. The owner wears the illest blue bloomers I've ever seen. If you have a problem with the combination of these two things, move to Daly City.
author: Sidney L.

description:
Coconuts, toast and coffee? I totally don't get it. Maybe I'm not cool enough...
I had the latte and I will say that it was the smoothest I've had in a while, didn't even have to put sugar in it as I am a sugar whore. I savored every sip but to pay 3.50 for a 6oz latte, I'll save this place for special occasions.
author: Jen H.

description:
even if they didn't have excellent chai and scones, i would give em 5 stars b/c the place is stunning. every piece of furniture, the shelving, the cake stands -GOD - YOU MUST GO JUST TO CHECK THOSE OUT!, the typewriter font - every aesthetic flourish is unique, perfect & studied to the exact right degree.
i've found the people there to be really nice.  i was expecting attitude, so was pleasantly surprised.
author: Kim Y.

description: Wow. I'm just a five star machine...but what can I say, I like good stuff. Trouble is no different. I have gotten some...hhmmm...interesting service here. Yet I have also had the best mocha I've ever had (not too sweet, coffee forward flavor) and a young coconut with a straw here and there. Check it out.
author: Robert K.

description: Insane Coffee.. If i ever leave this place (OB) I'll need to bring a couple of pounds with me be cause the coffee rules!
author: Lindonesia S.

description:
i recently had an inspiration to give up coffee for tea. well, isn't drinking tea a trait of the more mature persona?  the more health conscious ? the more balanced individual ?  after all, them brits do have their tea time.  
so for the sake of personal evolution, i gave it a whirl - a disciplined and difficult two or three days without the java.  like crossing the sahara i tell ya. but then like a spurned and ignored girlfriend, she came back. strong. and in my face. i crossed paths with the trouble.  and the makeup was good.  coffee, you and i, we're meant to be.
simultaneously blending artsy and utilitarian, trouble is a unique coffee spot in a unique city.  coffee and coconuts speaks to that.
but who really cares, their coffee is efffin bueno.
author: Ed S.

description: Small business in a sleepy neighborhood. The coffee and tea are first class and no bullshit.  I often skip my stop on the N Judah and stop by here on the way home of a cup of their beautiful loose chamomile tea! Love it! Cool staff, cute decor and good prices.
author: Eryn S.

description: I literally joined yelp to write a review in praise of trouble. Having Trouble as my local coffee shop is very seriously one of the best parts of living in the sunset. The food choices are unique and coconuts plus toast is an amazing idea. Their coffee is strong and masterfully prepared staff are very good at what they do (masters of alchemy really) and having read the previous yelp reviews I felt inclined to stick up for them. Since when did it become a requirement for a barista to have to be extra nice to everyone? The staff at Trouble are GREAT at making espresso drinks, they are there for that reason and will have intelligent, sincere conversations with anyone willing to meet them half way. So don't go there if you need to be coddled, go there for good food and coffee with a strong sense of character.
author: dead b.

description: After drinking a latte at Touble Coffee my husband said, "This coffee is so good, it feels healthy!"  I had to agree and let other rooibos and mate drinkers in on the secret of what real coffee can do for you. There is no other coffee place like it. It's coffee magic!
author: Cynthia P.

description: Best coffee ever.  Not sure exactly what they do to their beans and brewing, but there is a notable difference between any coffee drink you get here and drinks at other places in the city.  Not to mention, it's near the beach, not crazy busy, and they do sell coconuts.
author: Linus L.

description: Places like this are WHY I live in San Francisco.  Both the drip and espresso are top notch.  Definitely on par with Blue Bottle, though it's definitely an apple orange thing to compare them.  Who knew a coconut, coffee and cinnamon toast went together so well?
author: Leon S.

description: So, I don't want t ruin the vibe of this place, because there seem to be some people that think that this is the best place ever, so i'll apologize up from. I'm sorry that this is not the best coffee ever. My wife and I both had latte's and thought the same thing. Very mild flavor. I actually think it's pretty cool that they only have one size of latte, lends to the "hip" attitude of the place, but that can't make up for the lack of flavor. If I had to judge Trouble on the latte alone, I'd give it 3 stars, but the Toast was great. It was big and flavorful. I don't know that I would return to this place, and if I was in the area, I would probably go to Java Beach instead. Sorry to all you die hard fans of Trouble.
author: Erik S.

description: I'm very happy to have this simple and delicious coffee spot in my neighborhood. Their breads are very tasty too.
author: Jeremiah A.

description: This is my morning spot. I get a large drip coffee and the cinnamon toast. A few people have mentioned it's not friendly/welcoming. I disagree, it's a very mellow place (with very mellow coffee, which I like cause I hate it when my coffee tastes like it's giving me an ulcer) and both the staff and customers have always been super friendly to me. Just walk in and sit down at the counter, you will thank yourself. Oh, and you should definitely get the toast.
author: Lindsey B.

description: What's the big deal? Maybe I'm missing something...I'm on this tour of all the various SF coffee houses and I'm using Yelp as a starting point to try places I haven't been.  I like the concept...cool, edgy, anti-establishment sorta vibe.  Unusual, interesting space - not for sitting with your lap top or meeting a friend to chat. Employees are pleasant.  I ordered a regular drip.  I found it somewhat watery and lacked flavor.  I didn't have the cinnamon toast, since I don't eat sugary carbs for breakfast, but maybe that would have done the trick.
author: Eric C.

description: Good coffee, hot chocolate and cakes. Friendly people. Prices are okay. A good place to wait your turn to have brunch at Outerlands.
author: R S.

description: Worth a trek to the Outer Sunset. Excellent coffee and lattes. The baked goodies are excellent too. Refreshing laid back vibe...yet the coffee was quickly prepared.
author: Mary P.

description: I just moved from downtown to the Sunset and this is definitely my new coffee shop! This place is hella rad, don't let the very small and intimate size of the shop scare you away. This is no few-blocks-from the-beach tourist ripoff factory. These guys take their coffee seriously. They don't have an ultraextensive list of traditional drinks, although you can get a latte, mocha, etc. Instead they have a bunch of original drinks that you really can't get elsewhere except perhaps by giving the baristas a lesson on what it is. My favorite is the dirty chai. I repeat, dirty chai. Dirty chai. Get one. Go now. By combining sweet and spicy chai, milk, espresso, and I think a tasted some cinnamon, it makes for a really bold drink. All their drinks are STRONG so if you aren't into that, you're going to have a hard time finding anything you like on the menu. Staff are great and extremely friendly. There are only a few of them so its easy to remember them and have them remember you. Customer base is equally friendly. This is really a hidden jewel in the Sunset. Starbucks out. Trouble Coffee company in.
author: Alexander W.

description: Tiny store caught my attention as I rode the N along Judah. Who wouldn't be intrigued by a coffee shop with such a name? Outside, early a.m., a trio of very not dangerous regulars chatted and drank their brew from mugs brought from home. Conveniently for them, the sugars and stirrers were on a stand beside the bench their tushes warmed. Inside, the beach shack-themed store consisted of a few stools at a narrow bar and a few window stools at a narrow piece of beach wood. The display case under the cash register contained, uhm, coconuts. The friendly coffee guy explained that coconuts, toast, and coffee were the shop's specialty breakfast and provided lots of nutrients, hydration, and a full feeling to take one through to lunch. Well, if I actually liked coconut, he would have sold me. Instead, I had a coffee and watched a number of characters (and their cutie dogs) wander in and then out with cappuccinos, lattes, and some sage surfer advice.
author: Poet D.

description: My wife says this is the best coffee in the city. The service is uppity - really the term Coffee Nazi comes up. They need to trade in their sense of entitlement for a sense of humor. Remember that scene in 5 easy pieces with Elliot Gould in the restaurant?... It was almost funny - but not.
author: jim m.

description: Hands down the best latte ever. The owner knows her stuff when it comes to brewing it right. She serves at the perfect drinking temp and in a perfect sized cup. Every time I go in there everyone is friendly, laughing and enjoying themselves. I always say going to trouble for coffee is an experience. It's so good you might not be able to stop at one....TROUBLE!
author: melissa a.

description: Great cafe in a great place.  The owners are very kind.  The coffee is remarkably good, and every time I experiment with other things on the menu it has been great (I recommend the chai latte).
author: Edith h.

description: Awesome cute unpretentious place to get delicious caffeine fix. I love their cappuccino! and fresh coconut juice on hot or cold days...
author: Quynh I.

description:
butthole surfers vinyl hanging off the wall.  hell yeah.  triple shots of caffeine perfection.  hell yeah!

latte.  excellent.  cinnamon toast sans crunch.  awesome.

byron was more than willing to answer to all my general coffee snobbery.  i have a new spot to drop by before work.  sweet.
author: Steven C.

description: what is not to love about a young coconut, cinnamon toast and coffee breakfast?
author: Angela K.

description: Damn, I'm lucky! Who knew a little coffee shop a block from my place would be so good?!?! If only it was open when I go to work in the morning. if only...
author: Dustin H.

description: Someone working an espresso machine in San Francisco who actually gives a shit about getting smooth, velvety foam.  Screw Java Beach, hello Trouble.
author: Kyle L.

description: Possibly the best espresso in America -- worth a special journey.
author: Armand G.

description:
Damn Sarita, you have a thin skin.

I've been meaning to write about this place for a while.  The *only* complaint i have is that it is like 3 miles from my place.  I've been there 3 times and absolutely love it.  If I were nearby, I'd be there almost everyday.  Not only is it friendly, the coffee is genuinely fantastic-- easily top tier, and that's saying something in SF.  Not to mention the yummy bread.
author: Troy B.

description: I loved the breakfast which is eassentially a toast, coconut water and coffee....
author: saroj y.

description: Looking for great coffee in the Sunset district? Then this is the place to visit. It's a very small cafe, with minimal seating, so it's not really a place to people watch or study. But the interior is pretty cool, with all kinds of items decorating the wall. I had the latte, which had a bold flavor, but smooth finish....excellent! It was somewhat pricey, at $3.50, and smaller than a "tall" that you could get at Starbucks, but delicious. Definitely 5 stars; give it a try!
author: Derrick S.

description: I went to the Trouble of getting an espresso there the other day. The staff was really nice and the espresso was excellent. My criticism is that it seemed a bit overpriced. Also, the surf bars are off the hook.
author: David S.

description: Awesome coffee served by awesome people at great prices.  Every experience I have ever had at Trouble has been great.  They're an asset to the neighborhood.
author: Kevin W.

description: Cappuccino .... the best in the city - if you think you can make a better one send me your address and I will try it, otherwise go to Trouble and taste the real thing!
author: Julie M.

description: i went to trouble for the last time the other day.  i decided that the $3.50 8oz. soy latte was hardly worth it anymore.  the employees think that they don't have to follow your normal food service establishment (*gasp* how dare i call it an establishment) regulations.  and they only like their friends that come in.  if it's empty, then they are nice to you.   each drink is made one at a time, that's fine, but it doesn't need that much attention.  when i order 2 of the same drink at once, you can make 2 espressos and steam milk enough for both drinks at the same time.  the thing that really irked me was that i heard the barista say that she hated soy milk and that it doesn't steam well.  i've been a barista for 5 years and know that it is the easiest steamable foamable milk ever.  maybe she didn't know how to work it.
author: Monk R.

description: Yes, the coffee is quite good, but this city is full of wonderful places to buy coffee, without the extra dose of distain, and $3.50 is just too much to pay for 6 oz of latte.  We live right around the corner, and have tried Trouble various times.  The coffee and hot cocoa are way overpriced, the staff is just TOO painfully, self-consciously "cool,"  and just plain attitudinally challenged.  The highly acclaimed cinnamon toast is a wide slab of white bread plastered with butter, sugar and cinnamon (try it at home, kids! ...and while you're at it, compare the cost).  Coconuts are pretty easy to come by and relatively inexpensive.  Check them out at Sunset Supermarket.  I wanted to like this place, I liked the manifesto posted in the window, even if it is a little pretentious, but they won't let me...to be fair, I'm  certain that they don't care one iota if I like them, to judge from their decided lack of enthusiasm for my patronage.  So, I'll leave them to it.
author: Angela M.

description: Great drinks, but be prepared to be told they make all espresso drinks with 3 shots and whole milk.  If you might, like, have your own tastes and preferences, you apparently don't know enough about coffee to deserve them.
author: Ted M.

description: I love this spot. This tiny coffee shop has great decor and a cozy surfer-y vibe. The coffee and chocolate chip cookie was the best thing. Looking forward to going back.
author: Missy D.

description:
I write this fueled solely by Trouble's Elbow Grease coffee (didn't have time for toast today, had to catch the N).

At Trouble, you can:
- drink a coffee, latte, cappuccino, espresso, americano, chai, or tea, with half-and-half, soy milk, brown sugar, or sugar cubes (no decaf, no low/non-fat, no artifical sweeteners, no syrups).  Try the latte, and (as Giulietta will recommend) try it without sugar.
- eat a coconut or the finest toast in the City
- buy a bag of Elbow Grease or espresso beans
- learn about the fascinating life of Giulietta
- listen to lo-fi, analog-recorded music on the tape player or the phonograph
- watch the congregation of Sunset hipsters and ne'er-do-wells (as well as a few that float in from other parts of the City)
- maybe sit down, inside if there's a free stool, or outside on one of the kindergarten-sized folding chairs (update - Trouble is undergoing renovations, including more seating inside and out)
- enjoy the warmth of one of the friendliest, most energetic, and still neighborhoody spots at the tail end of Judah.

If you want to sit at a table (or recline on a couch) with a low-fat decaf vanilla mocha, a croissandwich, and your laptop, go down the street to Java Beach.  They're nice too, but it's a totally different experience.

If you just want a really good cup of coffee (or latte!) and maybe some cinnamon-sugar toast or a hangover-curing coconut, and you're in the neighborhood, get yourself into Trouble.
author: Rob E.

description: love the coffee, love the a.m. granola surf bar, the cookies are Amazing (chocolate chip and the sweet jesus - which is basically a soft snickerdoodle with a peanut butter cup on top).  The place has a great vibe.
author: Fallon C.

description:
guilietta has created some of the best blends i've ever had. even more spectacular is trouble's pulling methods. oh yes, i want every shot to look like motor oil and taste like caramel. nothing more to ask for in a spectacular cup of coffee. 
trouble gets some great local handbaked pastries as well...check out the lavender sea salt shortbread if you get a chance. your psyche will thank you.
author: alexandra v.

description: I like it....had to wait a while for my order. Saw many slices of toast burn....if they work out a more efficient way to fulfill orders they would get the extra star. Good coffee, great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Jamie C.

description: I love my coffee. In fact I need coffee to function appropriately ie. put sentences together and walk in a straight line. Julietta  roasts her own beans. I think she may also throw a few of her marbles in there as well.  Besides a good strong cup of coffee she wakes you up with her kookieness. My fave is the latee. Just perfect and smooth. None of that Starbuckle bitterness here. Cinnamon toast and coconuts add a yum factor to the place. However if you're in a hurry don't come here because waiting and people watching is a part of the Trouble experience.
author: Lina L.

description: Every few months I bike across the city just to get espresso and cinnamon toast here.
author: Max D.

description: awesome peoples, radical teas, chilling coconuts, good vibes on the inside and outside, sweet knick nacks on the walls, close to the beach, hella steezy.
author: t k.

description: Eh. A lot could be forgiven for great coffee, but that's not part of this equation.  I've lived in the 'hood for years, and the businesses that fit well here don't need to work so hard at being cool.  Treating customers differently depending on what they're wearing or how old they are or other superficial criteria is just not the way we do it around here. Since they're small, they've been able to attract enough striving hipsters to keep them in business, but the rest of us have much better choices available.  Seabiscuit comes to mind...
author: Leslie M.

description: this place is rad - a driftwood meets beat happening meets ocean vibe. the drip coffee and espresso is good. i am a vegan so don't know about their baked goods but i'm sure they're good too, my fiancee and daughter love them. if you're in sunset, hit it up.
author: kenneth p.

description: i have a friend that lives literally around the corner from trouble coffee. what a gem this place is. the coffee is top notch, and the cinammon toast....goodness gracious. to die for. i have driven an hour from san jose to get coffee here. delish...
author: nicole p.

description: i'd give five, but all her friends did that already. excellent alternative to java beach. class act coffee and all those other pressure drinks if you're into them. i'm not quite cool enough to really hang there and there's no real sit-down seating, but i'm always happy to run in there and lay down two bucks for a hot cup.
author: makaha f.

description: if i went to coffee shops to hang out for half a day and make new friends i would probably like it a lot more.
author: why l.
